headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: G.M. AND UNION IN SETTLEMENT General Motors and the United Automobile Workers reached a new contract agreement, ending a two-day strike. The contract's main feature -- a health care trust called a voluntary employee benefit association -- will ease the cost to G.M. of providing benefits to its workers.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International LAW PROHIBITS STANDING

headline: Ripple Effect Of Smartphones
summary: The cellphone is beginning to have the kind of impact on industry that has been seen with only a few products, like the car or big kitchen appliances. The ripple effect showed up this week in a number of corporate earnings reports. Corning said on Tuesday that its quarterly profit surged 41 percent, in part because of rising sales of its unusually strong Gorilla Glass, which is used in smartphone displays. Gorilla Glass, which is used in roughly 200 million mobile devices, produced about $250 million in revenue for Corning in 2010. James B. Flaws, the company's chief financial officer, told analysts that Gorilla Glass could generate $1 billion in revenue this year.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WACHS, NANCY
summary: WACHS--Nancy, ground breaking green architect, humanitarian and beloved mother and grandmother, dies at 76. Ms. Wachs, a lifelong humanitarian, was an inspiration to all who knew her. She was a strong advocate for the arts, education, women's rights, Hospice and helping those in need. Ms. Wachs was utilizing green architecture practices in the 1950s long before it became popular. She inspired her children with a strong sense of social justice, environmentalism and a love of nature. A native of Rochester, NY, Ms. Wachs graduated from Cornell University's Architecture, Art and Planning School, one of a few women at that time with a major in architecture (Class of 1954). Her architectural career featured working for the City of Rochester and others designing contemporary commercial structures and residences. She served as a longtime editor and staff member for the American Institute of Architects (AIA) of Rochester newsletter. As an expression of respect, please consider making donations in Nancy M. Wachs name to: Lifetime Care Hospice 3111 Winton Road South, Rochester, NY 14623. A memorial ceremony will be held in the future. Please contact Molly.Lavik@verizon.net for details. Ms. Wachs was married to Arthur Wachs who predeceased her in 2003 and is remembered by her son Christopher Wachs, daughter Molly Wachs Lavik and granddaughter Lindsey Megan Trauty Wachs.

headline: LOOKING AHEAD
summary: ECONOMIC DATA Reports will include new-home sales for June (Monday); the Case-Shiller home price index for June and the Conference Board's consumer confidence index for July (Tuesday); durable goods for June and the Federal Reserve beige book (Wednesday); and gross domestic product for the second quarter (Friday). CORPORATE EARNINGS Reports will come from Amgen, Corning, Honeywell International, RadioShack and Verizon Communications (Monday); BP, Deutsche Bank, DreamWorks Animation, Electronic Arts, McGraw-Hill, Office Depot, United States Steel and Viacom (Tuesday); Aetna, Bayer, Coca-Cola Enterprises, ConocoPhillips, Daimler, General Dynamics, Hartford Financial Services, IAC/InterActiveCorp, Jones Apparel, KKR Financial, Lazard, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, Qwest Communications, Sanofi-Aventis, SAP, Sprint Nextel, Time Warner, Visa, WellPoint and Wyndham Worldwide (Wednesday); Alcatel-Lucent, AstraZeneca, Avon Products, BASF, Beazer Homes, Cablevision, Cigna, Colgate-Palmolive, Dow Chemical, Eastman Kodak, Exxon Mobil, Goodyear Tire and Rubber, International Paper, Kellogg, MasterCard, MetLife, Motorola, Newell Rubbermaid, NYSE Euronext, Royal Dutch Shell, Siemens, Travelers, Walt Disney and Waste Management (Thursday); and Chevron, The Washington Post Company and Weyerhaeuser (Friday).

headline: How to Jog Firefox's Memory
summary: Q.Ever since I upgraded to Firefox 4, the browser no longer remembers the tabs I had open just before I quit the program. Is there a way to restore this feature? A. Mozilla's default start page for Firefox 4 includes a Restore Previous Session button you can click to reopen all the tabs you were using before you closed the browser. But if you have changed your default home page to something different, the Restore Previous Session button does not appear.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: P.R. FOR BIG OIL -- A new public relations campaign by the oil industry, coupled with a huge lobbying network in Washington, is not only aimed at consumers but is an effort to blunt intensifying efforts by lawmakers who are calling for a windfall profits tax and repeal of some of the tax breaks and other incentives provided just last year by Congress in its energy legislation. [C1.] SHIFT IN SOUTH AMERICA -- Bolivia's nationalization of its energy industry indicates that the populist policies championed most prominently by Venezuela are spreading. [A8.] ESCHEWING S.U.V.'S -- Americans shied away from large sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks in April as gas prices approached $3 a gallon. With a battery of new S.U.V.'s waiting in the wings, domestic automakers are now facing the very situation they had hoped to avoid. [C3.] EMI IN TALKS FOR WARNER -- The EMI Group, the world's third-largest music company, is in early talks to acquire the Warner Music Group for more than $5 billion, people involved in the negotiations said. [C1.] VW CHIEF TO STAY -- Ending a protracted boardroom battle, Volkswagen announced that it would extend for five years the contract of its chief executive, Bernd Pischetsrieder, left, despite the qualms of employees and an earlier expression of no confidence by the company's chairman. A unanimous vote by Volkswagen's supervisory board gave Mr. Pischetsrieder another chance to revive Volkswagen, which has lost ground to more efficient rivals like Toyota. [C4.] WORKERS IN JORDAN -- Foreign workers in some Jordanian factories, which produce apparel for the likes of Target, Wal-Mart and other American retailers, say they must work 20-hour days, are not being paid, and are being hit by supervisors and jailed when they complain. [C1.] TAX CUTS IN CANADA -- The Canadian government of Prime Minister Stephen Harper announced nearly $20 billion in tax cuts for individuals and businesses over two years, at a time when the budget surplus is bulging along with the economy. [A14.] VERIZON RESULTS -- Verizon Communications said that its profits dipped 7.1 percent in the first quarter as it absorbed the costs of integrating MCI and building a fiber optic network designed to deliver television to homes. Sales, however, jumped because the company's mobile phone division, Verizon Wireless, continued to outperform its competitors, and because of strong demand for broadband lines. Market Place. [C3.] MICROSOFT AND HOLLYWOOD -- Microsoft is teaming up with some high-profile Hollywood talent to create original entertainment programming for the Web. [E1.] STOCKS RISE -- The Dow Jones industrial average rose 73.16 points, to end at 11,416.45. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed up 8.02 points, at 1,313.21. The Nasdaq finished up 5.05 points, at 2,309.84. [C11.] KENNETH LAY ON THE STAND -- To the surprise of many legal specialists, Kenneth L. Lay, the former Enron chief executive who is on trial, caught an affliction common to chief executives unaccustomed to being challenged or criticized: an inability to modify the very personality traits that got them to the top of the corporate ladder. News Analysis. [C1.] DELAY OF AIRLINE RULES -- The United States, facing opposition to rules that would let European airlines play a greater role in the management of American carriers they have invested in, has decided to delay the regulations, officials said. [C4.] MORE EYE INFECTIONS -- Reports of a rare fungal infection linked to contact lens cleaners have edged up slightly in the last week, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. [C4.] FOOD MARKETING -- As childhood obesity rates climb, the food industry needs to improve the way it markets its products to children, according to a government report. [C5.]

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: I.R.S. ASKS THE EXPERTS -- The Internal Revenue Service is asking tax lawyers and accountants who help create tax shelters and advise clients on how to exploit loopholes to take the lead in writing some of its new tax rules. [Page C1.] A NEW PRODUCER'S CHALLENGE -- Rick Kaplan, who was hired by CBS to turn around the ratings slide of its evening newscast with Katie Couric, has an opportunity in his new job to stage a comeback of his own. [C1.] OLD NAME, NEW MONEY -- The man in line to be the fifth Baron Rothschild is close to becoming a billionaire through a web of private equity investments. He has reinvigorated the prestige and wealth of Europe's most storied banking family. [C1.] A TROUBLED OIL COMPANY -- Pemex, Mexico's oil monopoly, is struggling with falling production and reserves, and no money to reverse the slide. [C1.] SOME SAW IT COMING -- The meltdown of the subprime mortgage market is producing a who's who of winners and losers among hedge funds. And some hedge funds have made a killing. [C1.] LENDER STOPS TAKING APPLICATIONS -- New Century Financial, the troubled mortgage company, stopped accepting new loan applications as it tried to negotiate the terms of financing arrangements with banks that had cut off its access to billions of dollars in funds. [C3.] VONAGE TOLD TO PAY $58 MILLION -- A federal court ordered Vonage, the Internet phone provider, to pay $58 million for infringing Verizon's patents, dealing a blow to a company already showing signs of stress. [C3.] THREE WINNERS' PROJECTS -- The annual TED conference, named for the confluence of technology, entertainment and design, presents $100,000 to each of three prize winners to help them realize a dream. This year's winners, including the photographer James Nachtwey, above, announced their projects this week. [C4.] FORD WORKERS TO GET BONUSES -- Ford Motor Company, which lost a record $12.7 billion last year, said that all of its employees would receive a ''modest'' bonus. Union leaders had criticized the company over the prospect of bonuses for management. [C3.] BIDDING ESCALATES FOR CAREMARK -- CVS delivered what it hoped would be its knockout punch in the fight to acquire Caremark Rx, raising its offer for the drug benefits manager to $26 billion less than a day after a rival suitor sweetened its own proposal. [C3.] THE S.E.C. VS. SPAM -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, taking a step toward combating stock spam, the unsolicited bulk e-mail that promotes cheap stocks for quick profits, has suspended trading in 35 company stocks that had been promoted in recent spam campaigns. [C4.] RISING MORTGAGE DEBT -- Americans continued to load up on mortgage debt last year, even though the housing market was stalling, according to data from the Federal Reserve. [C2.] WEATHER-BEATEN RETAILERS -- Retailers like Wal-Mart Stores and Federated Department Stores reported weak February sales, saying the month's cold temperatures and stormy weather hampered results. But Wal-Mart's rival, the Target Corporation, posted stronger-than-expected comparable-store sales figures, and some retailers said they expected the Easter holiday to help their March results.[C2.] A RATE INCREASE IN EUROPE -- The European Central Bank raised its benchmark interest rate by one-quarter of a percentage point, to 3.75 percent, and made clear that it was willing to tighten credit further in a humming European economy that could generate inflation. [C7.] PRIVATE PROPERTY IN CHINA -- China's national legislature began deliberating on a landmark law that would provide legal protections for private property as well as a law that would gradually equalize corporate taxes on foreign and domestic corporations. [C3.] ORGANIZING THE INTERNET -- A new company founded by a longtime technologist is setting out to create a vast public database, paving the way for a more automated Internet in which machines will routinely share information. [C7.] SHARE THE GLORY -- The automaker Saturn is inviting owners of its new Aura sedan to borrow for a day or two a replica of the five-pound trophy it won as the North American Car of the Year. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C8.] INVESTORS' CONFIDENCE RISES -- Wall Street extended its recovery from last week's big plunge, closing up after several stable sessions helped buttress investor sentiment and allay some concerns about the economy. [C11.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. Dell Inc. did not infringe a patent held by Alcatel-Lucent in its personal organizer products, a federal court ruled in a summary judgment. (REUTERS) Costco Wholesale, the warehouse retailer, said that its fiscal second-quarter profit dropped 16 percent, hurt in part by costs associated with revamping its consumer electronics return policy. (AP) A real estate promoter was charged in a federal indictment with stealing tens of millions of dollars from investors in a Ponzi scheme and using the money to pay for jewelry, luxury automobiles, and credit card and tax bills. (AP) Hovnanian Enterprises, the home builder, reported that it swung to a loss in the first quarter, continuing a trend of bad news in the housing market. (AP)

headline: Nokia Chief Looks For a Turnaround In Smartphones
summary: The challenge Nokia faces in the smartphone market was grimly detailed last week. In the third quarter, according to IDC, Nokia's worldwide smartphone sales fell 37 percent to 16.8 million phones from 26.5 million a year ago. Nokia's retreat comes in a booming market. Smartphone shipments grew 43 percent in the third quarter.

headline: Q&A
summary: Turning Down Free 'Help'

headline: VERIZON TO SHUT WI-FI ACCESS SPOTS IN NEW YORK CITY
summary: Verizon Communications plans to shut public sites that provide high-speed wireless Internet access in New York City because of a lack of use. Verizon, which is based in New York, has begun shutting 380 so-called Wi-Fi hot spots in Manhattan and Brooklyn and will phase out the service over the next two months, the company said on Wednesday. The move lets Verizon concentrate on an expansion of a fee-based service provided by its mobile phone division, Verizon Wireless.

headline: Campaign Finance Capers
summary: By day, lawmakers feud over the state budget with new-found intensity. But at dusk, Albany's legislative routines revert to normal. Sundown is fund-raising hour in the state capital, the time when every restaurant or club or hotel has a room or two with an open bar and a few tough canapés and a lawmaker shaking hands in exchange for campaign checks. To be fair, nobody much enjoys these evening routines -- not the politicians and not even the lobbyists. But they all know that New York's public servants have to party, party, party every night after work if they're going to milk their share of the available special-interest money.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SLOAN, HOWARD
summary: SLOAN--Howard, WWII bomber pilot, former Chairman of New York Blood Center, died at 91. From a base in East Anglia during World War II, 19 year old Howard Sloan flew 33 missions over Germany. His B-24 was named "The Stork Club." When praised for his bravery, he would invariably respond: "Was there a choice?" Cheers erupted from a crowd on the beach when, piloting his plane home to the states after the war, he dipped his wings over the Inwood Country Club. Mr. Sloan was born in New York City on March 20, 1924. He graduated from the Woodmere Academy and Pawling Preparatory School, and received a Bachelor of Arts degree from Yale University, Class of '45W. He and his late wife, Sonny, along with George and Barbara Bush, were the only two married couples on campus. Dreams of business school were dashed by financial necessity and he joined his father's insurance company, Harris, Sloan and Finn. Characteristically, he turned the experience into a colorful one, representing clients such as Restaurant Associates; Richard Burton, who dispatched him to Rome to deliver a diamond he'd bought at auction for Elizabeth Taylor, or Cartier to present a love bracelet to Valentino, who insisted Howard personally fasten it on his wrist. He became an art insurer, developing great interest and knowledge of art in the process, befriending numerous artists and inspiring a lifetime of collecting: Mayan and PreColumbian sculpture, works by artists as diverse as Giacometti and Bill King, Henry Moore and Lindner. He acquired an art gallery, Multiples, for his wife, Sonny, and Marian Goodman to run. In 1990, he was invited by his friend and mentor, Charles Wohlstetter, to become a partner in the latter's acquisitions of hundreds of independent telephone companies from Alaska to California. They formed Continental Telephone, later known as Contel, in 1962. The company then agreed to be acquired by GTE, a combination that created the nation's largest local telephone company. Sloan remained on the Board of GTE until it was restructured as Verizon. In 1968, an American syndicate acquired an 18th century chateau in Bordeaux with Wohlstetter and Sloan installed as new owners. Chateau Bouscaut was the second most beautiful vineyard in Bordeaux, Sloan proclaimed, second, he said, because he didn't want to boast. Among the many American guests who flocked to visit, his favorite was Mary Lindsay, whom he overheard saying to her husband, then mayor of NYC, "John, if I have to see one more vineyard, I'll kill myself." To Sloan's eternal regret, Bouscat was sold in 1980. Mayor Lindsay brought Sloan onto the board of the Vivian Beaumont Theatre in 1984. At that time, according to Andre Bishop, current artistic director, "Nobody would give you a nickel for the Beaumont." It is now one of the leading theatrical companies in New York, if not the world. Mr. Sloan served on the Board until his death on Thursday. In 1977, Sloan joined the Board of Trustees of the New York Blood Center, of which he was Chairman from 1993 to 2000, nominating his successor, Howard Milstein. In January 2013, a congressional extension prepared by Representative Carolyn Maloney in recognition of Mr. Sloan's 15 years of distinguished service and dedication to NYBC's mission, was entered into the congressional record. She cited his humanitarian status and commended his leadership and tireless advocacy. For several years, he presided as Chairman of Northside Center for Child Development, founded by Kenneth and Mamie Clarke, earning a colleague's recent comment, "There was a time this place wouldn't have existed without Howard Sloan." He and his wife are to be honored for their dedication to Northside at a gala in May 2017. Howard Sloan died of kidney failure in Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital on January 21, 2016. Handsome as a film star, he will be remembered for his elegance and extraordinary wit. He is survived by his wife, Barbara; two daughters, Kathryn Roth of Weston, Massachusetts, Gillis Cone of Woodbury, Connecticut; a son, Douglas Sloan, of Palm Beach; a stepdaughter, Paulette Bartlett Robinson, of Los Angeles, and four grandchildren. Interment will be private and a memorial service will take place at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on Wednesday, February 10th. 1/3

headline: If Disney Owns It, Comcast Will Soon Be Streaming It
summary: 1/5/12 | Updated In a deal that represents billions of dollars in revenue for the Walt Disney Company, the entertainment giant and Comcast said Wednesday that they had reached a decade-long distribution agreement covering all of Disney's television content, including streaming for iPads and other devices. The unusually long-term agreement provides a window into the future of television viewing and how its content will be consumed. Comcast, the nation's largest cable provider, will gain the rights to provide the Disney Channel, ESPN, Disney XD, ABC Family and the ABC broadcast network, among other Disney-owned services, to subscribers wherever they want to watch.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths HENNESSY, G
summary: HENNESSY--G. Michael, 80, passed away January 20, in Manhattan, of infectious complications from pneumonia that developed following knee replacement surgery. For many years a highly-regarded furrier whose G. Michael Hennessy Furs label is found inside hundreds of his beautiful furs. Proud of his service as a U.S. Marine Corps Officer in Korea. Beloved husband of Rubye Graham Hennessy. Also survived by three sons, Robert, Wally and Mike, all of whom followed him into the fur trade; daughter Andrea, grandsons Nick, Charles and Thomas Hennessy, sister Marion Taggart. Predeceased by daughter Alexandra. An avid opera lover, world-wide traveler and proud Irishman. Memorial service will be held Sunday, February 15, 3:30pm at Frank E. Campbells, 81st St. and Madison Ave. hennessylatona@verizon.net

headline: Already Third, Sprint Would Fall Farther Behind
summary: With AT&T agreeing to buy T-Mobile USA for $39 billion, the future of Sprint Nextel just got fuzzier. Over the past several months, Sprint had held its own talks with Deutsche Telekom, the owner of T-Mobile, over a potential deal, as part of an effort to gain sorely needed scale and wireless spectrum, according to people with knowledge of the talks, which were intended to be private. But Telekom's discussions with AT&T moved more quickly this month, and the two reached a preliminary agreement last week, one of these people said.

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A2-14 Effect of Truce Unclear After a Day Fierce Fighting Hours before a cease-fire was due to start in the conflict between Israel and Hezbollah, both sides in the Middle East conflict carried out fierce attacks. Israel bombed Beirut suburbs and raced to consolidate its positions in southern Lebanon, and Hezbollah fired more than 220 rockets into northern Israel. A1 Charity May Have Aided Plot British and Pakistani investigators are trying to determine whether the group of Britons suspected of plotting to blow up as many as 10 commercial airliners received money raised for earthquake relief by Jamaat ud Dawa, a Pakistani charity that is active in the mosques of Britain's largest cities and is a front for an Islamic militant group. A1 Britain's highestranking law enforcement official, Home Secretary John Reid, said that the threat of a terrorist attack remained very substantial,'' disclosing that some two dozen major terrorist conspiracies were under investigation. A8 Cuba Is Calm Without Castro The decline of Fidel Castro, who turned 80 and appeared in photographs for the first time since his unspecified intestinal surgery last month, was supposed to be a kind of second Cuban revolution. But in the last two weeks, with Mr. Castro turning over power to his brother Raúl, there appeared to be calm and normalcy, not chaos and hysteria. A1 5 Explosions in Iraq Kill 57 As American forces conducted a new security sweep in western Baghdad, five apparently coordinated bombings in a predominantly Shiite neighborhood on the city's south side killed at least 57 people and wounded 148, an Iraqi government official said. The toll could rise, he said, as emergency workers searched the rubble of an apartment building that collapsed as a result of the bombings. A10 NATIONAL A16-19 Three Sons Strike Back After Fathers' Defeats Three Democrats whose fathers were defeated in the 1980 election that began a generation of conservative dominance are now seeking political office. One, Senator Evan Bayh, above, son of former Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana, is testing the waters for a possible presidential bid in 2008. A1 New Screeners for Airports Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff said he intended to replace contractors who inspect passenger identification at airport checkpoints with staff members from the Transportation Security Administration. Mr. Chertoff's comments came as the agency slightly eased its restrictions on items taken on board airplanes. A18 Stem Cell Research Goals Shift Many scientists no longer see cell therapy as the first goal of human embryonic stem cell research. Instead, these researchers see a longer-term program in which the cells would be a tool to study the mechanisms of disease. A18 ARTS E1-10 Piano Competition Scandal The Villa-Lobos International Piano Competition in São Paulo, Brazil, will open with its luster tarnished by accusations from its former director that the process of selecting the contestants has been manipulated. E1 9/11 Film Opens at No. 3 Oliver Stone's ''World Trade Center,'' the 9/11 rescue drama from Paramount starring Nicolas Cage, placed No. 3 at the box office over the weekend, but its $19 million gross far exceeded the opening weekend of last spring's ''United 93,'' the first Hollywood movie to tackle the events of Sept. 11, 2001. E2 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 Limits on Tanning Salons Urged as Skin Cancer Rises Health officials, in response to an unexplained increase in skin cancer among young people, have fixed their sights on the indoor tanning industry, particularly the unregulated use of tanning beds by young people. B1 Nightclub Plan Draws Ire New York City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn, the city's most visible gay official, has proposed that nightclubs be required to install security cameras at their entrances and exits in the wake of the murders of two club patrons. But many gay people argue that cameras violate their privacy. B1 Lieberman's Closest Adviser Senator Joseph I. Lieberman's vow to fight on to the general election as an independent candidate was a decision that has roiled the national political landscape, one that political advisers say stemmed in part from a belief of his wife, Hadassah, that her husband had to fight for his political beliefs. B1 SPORTSMONDAY D1-7 Drug Worries Rise in Golf Professional golf is increasingly becoming identified with power, so much so that some players are questioning whether golf, in which cheating is seen as the worst possible sin, could one day fall prey to the performance-enhancing drugs that have plagued other sports. D1 BUSINESS DAY C1-8 Finding Media Balance American news organizations are struggling to determine how images of civilian dead and injured should be displayed in their coverage of war. C1 Verizon Rewires New York Verizon is building a new state-of-the-art network in New York City, in an effort to fend off rivals like Comcast and Vonage. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A20-21 Editorials: Rewriting the Geneva Conventions; still spinning; an unwelcome visitor center; shoot first -- no questions asked. Columns: Bob Herbert, Paul Krugman. Bridge E4 Crossword E2 Metro Diary B2 Obituaries B8 TV Listings E9 Weather D8

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Wireless To End a Monthly Fee
summary: Verizon Wireless, the nation's second-largest mobile phone carrier, will eliminate a 40-cent monthly fee it has been charging customers to cover costs associated with a rule that allows clients to keep their phone numbers when switching service providers. The company's 42.1 million customers will continue to pay 5 cents a phone number each month for regulatory fees in the United States, a company spokesman, Jeffrey Nelson, said. The reduction will begin with billing cycles next week, Verizon Wireless said. Sprint, the nation's third-largest cellphone carrier, lowered its monthly regulatory fee rate to 25 cents from 40 cents on Nov. 1. Verizon Wireless, which is owned by Verizon Communications and Vodafone, has been collecting about $15 million a month with its fee. Under a November 2003 rule by the Federal Communications Commission, mobile phone users can keep their numbers when they switch providers. Verizon Wireless, which is based in Bedminster, N.J., has said about three customers switch to its service and keep their phone numbers for every one who leaves for another provider.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WALDHUTER, JEFFREY
summary: WALDHUTER--Jeffrey, 58, died unexpectedly on April 1, 2011. Jeff was a retired electrical engineer, who had formerly worked in telecommunications at Verizon. Jeff was a very skilled craftsman who spent hours at hobbies such as carpentry in his free time. He was loved by his many good friends, and was a loyal friend. He was always there when a friend, or his community, needed help. His energy and his exuberance will be missed.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Nelly Furtado Is No. 1
summary: On the strength of a catchy new single, ''Promiscuous'' -- a hit on radio and ubiquitous on television thanks to its use in a Verizon Wireless commercial -- Nelly Furtado reached the top of the Billboard chart this week with her album ''Loose'' (Geffen). It sold 219,000 copies in its first week at stores, according to Nielsen SoundScan, giving Ms. Furtado her first No. 1 album. The No. 2 album in the country, ''Define the Great Line'' (Tooth & Nail) by the Christian hard rock band Underoath, sold 98,000 copies last week with very little commercial airplay; it is the highest-charting Christian album since LeAnn Rimes's ''You Light Up My Life -- Inspirational Songs'' reached No. 1 in 1997, Billboard said. The Dixie Chicks' ''Taking the Long Way'' (Columbia) slipped to No. 3; the British band Keane's new album, ''Under the Iron Sea'' (Interscope), opened at No. 4; and Busta Rhymes's ''Big Bang'' (Aftermath/Interscope), last week's chart topper, fell to No. 5. Music sales overall are down 4 percent from last year at this time, at 261 million units. BEN SISARIO

headline: The New York Times Newsroom Navigator
summary: For more than 10 years, the Newsroom Navigator has been used by New York Times reporters and editors as the starting point for their forays onto the Web.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International SOUTH AFRICA'S POOR DEMAND BASIC SERVICES

headline: Tracking Down Warranty Callers
summary: CONSUMERS across the country are flooding Web sites with complaints about car warranty telemarketing calls. Officials in 40 states are investigating the companies behind the calls, and the Better Business Bureau said it had received more than 140,000 complaints about the calls last year. Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, has asked the Federal Trade Commission to investigate and put an end to the calls.

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONALA3-18 Reports Assail Oversight

headline: Qwest Receives Break on Rules
summary: Qwest Communications International., the telecommunications company, can merge its local and long-distance operations with fewer federal restrictions than some rivals had sought, regulators said Tuesday. The Federal Communications Commission agreed not to subject Qwest's long-distance division to some so-called dominant-carrier rules, which impose price controls and other restrictions, if the company consolidates its long-distance and local-phone services under one unit.

headline: CITY ROOM
summary: A PHANTOM Of a Phone Booth

headline: INSIDE
summary: Call to End Penalty for Missing Medicare Deadline A powerful bipartisan group of senators announced that they would push legislation to eliminate the financial penalty for people who missed Monday's deadline for Medicare's prescription drug benefit. PAGE A18 Verizon Denies Giving Data Verizon said it had not provided local phone records to the National Security Agency for a database to help track terrorists. PAGE A15 Heat Ends Nets' Season For the second consecutive season, the Miami Heat ousted the Nets from the N.B.A. playoffs, this time in five games with a 106-105 victory. THE ARTS, PAGE E1 SPECIAL TODAY The Business of Green Businesses are going green for many reasons, not just to enhance their image. Some are seeking a competitive advantage. SECTION G

headline: CAMPAIGN SPOTLIGHT: Best Buy Calls for New Venture
summary: Look for In Advertising next week on Tues., Jan. 16, rather than Mon., Jan. 15, in honor of the Dr. King holiday. The phrase "Best Buy Mobile" now means more than just someplace in Alabama to buy flat-screen TV sets, digital cameras and refrigerators.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: FRAUD PROSECUTIONS DROP Federal officials are bringing far fewer prosecutions over fraudulent stock schemes, according to a Syracuse University research group using Justice Department figures. There were 133 prosecutions for securities fraud in the first 11 months of this fiscal year, down from a high of 513 cases in 2002. CENTER OF MORTGAGE CRISIS At World Savings Bank, Herbert and Marion Sandler pioneered an exotic but popular mortgage that helped generate billions of dollars of revenue. Known as an ''option ARM,'' it is now seen as the Typhoid Mary of the mortgage industry. [A1.]

headline: Vision 2020
summary: Discover why security budgets are growing, but the frequency of data breaches are growing faster.

headline: Fuming Over the Cost of Classics on Cable
summary: ARMAND D'AMOUR of Elmsford, a retired automobile body-shop owner with a name that might have lured Hedy Lamarr to the Casbah, loves the old movies. Bette Davis, Jimmy Stewart and John Wayne are the stars that twinkle for him on his favorite channel, Turner Classic Movies. So Mr. D'Amour was more than a little disturbed to learn recently that Cablevision, which had always provided the channel as part of its so-called expanded basic package, was requiring that he rent a digital box and remote for $5.80 a month per television to continue to receive TCM. Of all the channels in all the cable systems in all the world, Cablevision is taking away his favorite. Because Mr. D'Amour, like many people, has multiple TVs -- three, in his case -- he would pay an extra $18 a month.

headline: YouTube, I Read
summary: To the Editor: Re ''YouTube Coming Soon to Cellphones'' (Business Day, Nov. 28):

headline: N.F.L. Extends Deal With DirecTV
summary: DirecTV renewed its deal as the N.F.L.'s exclusive satellite carrier and will continue to offer the Sunday Ticket package of out-of-market afternoon games from 2011 to 2014. The deal will cost DirecTV $1 billion a year, a leap from $700 million. The new agreement will offer features that fans without DirecTV have long wanted. Fans living in areas where they cannot get DirecTV will be able to buy it on broadband directly from the satellite carrier, no later than 2012. Also, Sunday Ticket's Red Zone Channel will be made available, for a fee, also no later than 2012, to Dish; telephone companies like Verizon and AT&T; wireless; and Internet providers. The four-year-old Red Zone channel provides highlights and live look-ins to games when teams are inside their opponents' 20-yard line.

headline: Unlimited Data As Selling Point
summary: While Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive, and Andy Rubin, the vice president of engineering at Google, fire pot shots at one another over their rival cellphone platforms, the wireless carriers are engaging in their own snipefest behind the scenes. Several media outlets, including Engadget, a technology blog, are reporting that Verizon Wireless is preparing to introduce tiered data plans for its smartphone subscribers.

headline: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.
summary: AD FINALISTS FIND Muse on F Train

headline: Lighter on Laps and Wallets
summary: LAPTOPS on airplanes are hardly an unusual sight these days, but when Heather Poole pulled out her computer on a recent flight from New York to Los Angeles, she got a surprising reaction from the flight attendants serving drinks. ''They stopped service -- they wanted to hold it, look at it,'' said Ms. Poole, 38, a flight attendant herself, who also writes for the travel Web site Gadling.com.

headline: Back in Class, 3 Inches Taller And an Octave Lower
summary: Radcliffe Saddler bounded from the basement cafeteria up four flights of stairs with 100 of his new classmates -- some breathless, most nervous -- and emerged into the blue and white hallway of a different world. At 9:10 a.m., he entered his Algebra II classroom and began tackling a word problem, neatly printing familiar formulas into his notebook. After the tortuous route Radcliffe had taken just to get into high school, this first day as a freshman turned out to be reassuringly calm.

headline: In Letters to F.C.C., Big Names in Technology Back AT&T's Bid for T-Mobile
summary: In its quest to win approval of its $39 billion takeover of T-Mobile USA, AT&T just got a lot of help from its friends. Eight technology giants, including Facebook and Microsoft, and 10 venture capital firms, filed letters supporting the acquisition late on Monday. The letters, filed with the Federal Communications Commission, lent their support to AT&T's argument that the T-Mobile deal will help the company extend its next-generation data network across the country, helping to meet the growing need for wireless broadband services.

headline: MCI Backs Qwest Over Verizon
summary: MCI, the long-distance phone company at the heart of a pitched takeover battle, raised the ante yesterday by declaring a sweetened bid from Qwest Communications to be superior to an offer it had already accepted from Verizon. In so doing, MCI's board, for the first time during the two-month bidding war, sided with Qwest. The decision gives Qwest a chance to wrest control of the company from Verizon, but that outcome is by no means certain because Verizon still has the legal and financial upper hand. Earlier this month, MCI's board accepted a takeover offer from Verizon worth $23.10 a share, or 30 percent less than Qwest's new bid.

headline: TimesCast | January 11, 2011
summary: Doctors give the latest on Representative Gabrielle Giffords; lawmakers weigh new security measures after Saturday's shooting; and Verizon announces it will sell the iPhone.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Justice Department Plans Fraud Claims Against Money Manager in Wireless Auctions The Justice Department announced that it planned to pursue civil fraud claims against the famed money manager Mario Gabelli, contending that he orchestrated a scheme to deceive the Federal Communications Commission in its auctions of wireless spectrum several years ago. [Page C1.] Former Enron Finance Officer Continues Testimony Andrew S. Fastow, the onetime chief financial officer of Enron, provided some of the strongest evidence yet linking Kenneth L. Lay, the company's founder, to a conspiracy to defraud investors. But Mr. Fastow's statements, coming in the sixth week of the trial of Mr. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, another former chief executive, were almost lost under a searing cross-examination by Daniel Petrocelli, Mr. Skilling's lead lawyer. [C1.] Data Show Soda Losing Ground to Other Beverages As Americans look for greater variety in their drinks and strive for healthier diets, consumption of soda -- with its 250 calories and 67 grams of sugar in a 20-ounce bottle -- is slipping. [C1.] Sale Is Test for Knight Ridder and Newspaper Industry The fate of Knight Ridder newspapers, the nation's second-largest newspaper chain that is for sale, could be determined any day -- and with it, the future of what has come to be known as the mainstream media. [C1.] New York Stock Exchange Shares Close at $80 Shares of the New York Stock Exchange soared on their trading debut, capping a tumultuous year for the 214-year-old exchange. The mood was festive on the bustling floor of the exchange, now part of a publicly held company called the NYSE Group. At 9:29 a.m., hundreds of people started ringing small commemorative bells, a nod to the Big Board's trademark bell ringing that marks the start of trading every day. The stock rose to close at $80, giving the NYSE Group a market value of $12.6 billion. [C11.] Consultant Warned Guidant About Device, Papers Show A consultant to the Guidant Corporation told the company last year that he believed it had a clear ethical obligation to tell physicians about heart device defects, and urged the company to overhaul its practices, newly released court records show. [C3.] Bail Is Granted to Ex-KPMG Partner Facing Trial A judge granted bail to a former KPMG partner, David Greenberg, who is awaiting trial for selling questionable tax shelters, even as the judge blasted him over what he called secret partnerships full of ill-gotten gains. [C7.] OPEC to Continue Pumping Near Maximum OPEC said that it would keep pumping oil near its maximum levels in an effort that could cool down prices. [C3.] Radio Giant Accused of Extracting Payments for Play The New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, accused the radio giant Entercom Communications of soliciting money and gifts from record companies in exchange for playing songs on the air. [C4.] Music Industry Weighs Value of Delaying Downloads If the music industry determines that restricting digital sales pays off with bigger album sales -- as appears to have happened with Ne-Yo's No. 1 CD ''In My Own Words'' -- fans may soon find the instant gratification of snapping up new songs online becoming a little less instant. [E1.] Large Shareholders of VNU Oppose Takeover Plan Two large shareholders of the Dutch media company VNU said that they opposed a takeover bid that the company had approved just hours earlier. The two own enough stock to block the proposed takeover, increasing the likelihood that instead of being taken over, VNU will be sold in pieces. [C5.] After AT&T Deal to Buy BellSouth, Eyes Are on Verizon With AT&T proposing to buy BellSouth, Wall Street is looking to Verizon to make the next move. Verizon has already said it wants to buy out Vodafone, which owns 45 percent of Verizon Wireless. But while taking full control of the wireless division would allow Verizon to include all the profits from its mobile phone division on its income statements, some investors say that Verizon would be smarter to sit tight, at least for now. Market Place. [C5.] Dow and Standard & Poor's 500 Rise; Nasdaq Dips The Dow industrials gained 25.05 points, closing at 11,005.74. The Standard & Poor's 500 added 2.59 points, to 1,278.47. The Nasdaq composite index slipped 0.92 point, to 2,267.46. [C11.] Another North American Executive to Leave Nissan Nissan Motor said that its top North American sales executive was retiring, the highest-level employee to leave as the company prepares to move its American headquarters to Tennessee from Southern California. [C3.] Directory Assistance, Without the Fee As cellphones become more sophisticated, the options for avoiding paid directory assistance are multiplying. Circuits. [C9.]

summary: WALDHUTER--Jeffrey, 58, died unexpectedly on April 1, 2011. Jeff was a retired electrical engineer, who had formerly worked in telecommunications at Verizon. Jeff was a very skilled craftsman who spent hours at hobbies such as carpentry in his free time. He was loved by his many good friends, and was a loyal friend. He was always there when a friend, or his community, needed help. His energy and his exuberance will be missed.

headline: Invading Cablevision's Neighborhood
summary: FED up with Cablevision, John Kraft of Massapequa Park was about to switch to satellite television when he learned that Verizon Communications was preparing to start a cable service -- the first challenge to Cablevision's two-decade domination of the Long Island cable TV market. The Village of Massapequa Park signed a franchise agreement with Verizon on Sept. 26, becoming the first municipality in the state and one of a handful in the country to approve Verizon's entry into the cable television market. Verizon is rewiring other areas of Long Island so it can offer service there beginning next year.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International INDIA'S ECONOMIC REFORMS

headline: Two Independent Agencies Agree to Be Acquired
summary: Two independent agencies are being acquired for undisclosed terms by large holding companies. Rodgers/Townsend in St. Louis was acquired by the Omnicom Group in New York. Rodgers/Townsend, which has about 100 employees, works for AT&T, as does an Omnicom agency, GSD&M in Austin, Tex. Rodgers/Townsend will operate as an autonomous agency under current management.

headline: Popular Demand
summary: Some 17.5 million young people ages 13 to 17, like Kabrina Moton of Cincinnati, above, own cellphones. Most get connected along with their parents: of 230 million users in the United States, 114 million belong to a family plan. Verizon and Sprint have the largest group of young people, each with about 4.5 million users. Their phones, like the enV and the Rumor, offer a music player, video capabilities, a camera and, for fast text messaging, a full qwerty keyboard. SHELLY FREIERMAN

headline: Off the Electrical Grid: Using the Sun to Power A Cellphone Charger
summary: Pacing around his Brooklyn apartment, Tommy Mitchell paused to eye his machine with frustration. On top was an 85-watt solar panel that he realized he had just installed upside down. A solar-powered cellphone charger, it looks like an oversize white iPad on stilts, with eight charging wires sprouting like tentacles from the middle. Once charged, the machine, which sits on a huge battery, can run a whole week without sun, he said.

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Verizon Wireless Gets Approval Of Airwaves Purchase
summary: Verizon Wireless won approval from federal regulators to complete its $3 billion purchase of NextWave Telecom's airwaves for sending mobile telephone calls in New York and 22 other cities. The decision by the Federal Communications Commission, released Wednesday, becomes final in 40 days, an agency spokeswoman, Lauren Patrich, said. Verizon Wireless, the nation's second-largest cellphone operator, will use the airwaves to send more calls and Internet traffic across its network. The company is eager to win back its spot as the No.1 cellphone company, when ranked by customers, which it lost to Cingular Wireless in October. NextWave filed for bankruptcy protection in 1998 after it was unable to pay the F.C.C. for the licenses it won in auctions. On Tuesday, NextWave, based in Greenwich, Conn., won court approval of a plan to exit bankruptcy by giving shareholders as much as $3.2 billion and repaying creditors. Most of the funds are coming from Verizon Wireless, which in October bought another NextWave license to airwaves in the New York metropolitan area for $930 million.

headline: In Subway, Long Silence For Cellphones Is Nearing End
summary: It may be that no technological advancement in New York transportation history has been so equally desired and dreaded, but the ability to chat on a cellphone in the subway will finally be available - though in a very limited way - next week. The wired underground project will begin on Tuesday at four stations in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan, where subscribers to the AT&T and T-Mobile networks will be able to talk away on station platforms, transportation officials said.

headline: The Droid Razr, A Worthy Heir To a Classic Name
summary: The new Droid Razr has a lot to live up to. The original Razr was a flip-phone marvel of sleek design. It became the best-selling phone in the United States until the iPhone knocked it from its perch. The new Razr, while lacking the wow factor of the original, is still a credible heir to the name. Two things - speed and battery life - set the phone apart.

headline: Popular Demand
summary: Digital music has gone wireless. Verizon Wireless joined Sprint last week in offering songs users could download directly to cellphones. The audience is potentially a large one. Songs-to-go, most readily available on portable music players, seem to appeal to fans across the board. Pop stars like Kelly Clarkson (''Since U Been Gone''), rappers like Kanye West (''Gold Digger'') and rock 'n' roll bands like Green Day (''Boulevard of Broken Dreams''), above, are all represented on the list of last year's top digital songs. SHELLY FREIERMAN

headline: At Virgin, Raising Revenue Without Raising Hackles
summary: Into the summer squall of new phone plans, add Virgin Mobile (is owned by Sprint), which is changing the price of its no-contract plans. The change raises the prices of two tiers of service but lowers the cost for the unlimited voice plan. Data remains unlimited in all of the plans. The new plan takes effect on July 20, so you have a week to sign up under the old deal if you prefer it.
