headline: Many Competing Paths on the Road to the Phone Wallet
summary: The idea of using a smartphone as a wallet has been slow to catch on in the United States. A big part of the problem has been that most stores do not have the proper physical equipment to allow customers to pay by tapping their phone. These stores also do not have the right equipment to allow the use of smart cards, credit cards embedded with computer chips that are much less susceptible to fraud.

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Peacekeepers in Darfur Hampered by Limitations The African Union, deployed to Darfur in 2004 to monitor a cease-fire, has been hamstrung by inadequate equipment, too few troops and a limited mandate that often prevents it from engaging the combatants and stopping the bloodshed that has killed at least 200,000 people. A1 Recent Violence Eases in Brazil Widespread violence between the police and organized crime in São Paulo, Brazil, eased after five days of attacks on police headquarters, buses and public buildings that left 115 people dead. A12 Judge Rules on Beslan Attack A Russian judge, in a statement short of a formal verdict, said the sole surviving assailant from the siege at a Beslan public school in 2004 had participated in terrorism and murder during the attack, bringing the trial near its conclusion. A6 23 Killed in Shiite Area of Iraq Gunmen shot dead 5 militiamen working as guards in a Shiite neighborhood, and then left behind a car bomb that exploded minutes later, killing at least 18 others who had rushed to the scene. A10 New Iran Proposal Considered The leading nations of Europe, working with the United States, are preparing to offer Iran new assistance in building a light water nuclear reactor for civilian use in return for Iran's ending activities suspected as a cover for a weapons program, American and European diplomats said. A6 Europe's Tentative Invitation The European Commission gave a qualified yes to having Romania and Bulgaria join the European Union, but it delayed a final decision to try to press the countries to make greater inroads on reform. A5 NATIONAL A14-19 Bush Faces Resistance To Immigration Changes President Bush pushed forward with his immigration plan but faced renewed resistance from conservatives who said they were not swayed by the case he made to give many illegal workers a chance to become citizens. A1 Rebuilding the C.I.A. For all its dysfunction and recent failures, the Central Intelligence Agency that Gen. Michael V. Hayden stands to inherit is far along a path toward rebuilding its network of foreign stations and replenishing ranks that were eviscerated during the years after the cold war. A1 A Call to End Medicare Penalty A bipartisan group of senators announced that they would push legislation to eliminate the penalty for people who sign up late for Medicare's prescription drug benefit. A18 Verizon Denies Sharing Data Verizon said it had not provided local phone records to the National Security Agency as part of its efforts to compile calling data to track terrorist activities. A15 Schools Plan Draws Suit In a constitutional challenge to a state law that would divide the Omaha public schools into three racially identifiable districts, the N.A.A.C.P. sued the governor of Nebraska and other state officials in federal court. A17 Same-Sex Marriage Decision A state constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage in Georgia was struck down by a state judge who upheld voters' right to limit marriage to heterosexual couples but cited procedural flaws in the way the amendment, which was approved by more than three-quarters of voters, was written. A17 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Two Types of Diabetes, Little Common Ground The victims of Type 2 diabetes, a disease that largely affects the overweight and elderly, are often stigmatized as undisciplined. Parents of children with Type 1 diabetes, a disorder of the immune system, fear that their children and their own efforts to raise funds for medical research are being muddied by the stigma that clings to Type 2. A1 Convention Arrests Studied The F.B.I., as part of an ongoing criminal civil rights investigation of the New York Police Department, is seeking to interview protesters who were arrested during the Republican National Convention and then had the charges against them dismissed. B1 Cleared Inmate Is Freed Douglas Warney, who served 10 years for a murder he did not commit, was freed in Rochester after being exonerated by DNA evidence. And in Tennessee, Mr. Warney's case led the governor to grant a two-week stay to an inmate there who was to be executed today. B1 ARTS E1-10 Tony Nominations Announced In a year crowded with new musicals, ''The Drowsy Chaperone,'' a postmodern paean to the tinny musicals of the 1920's, led the field with 13 Tony Award nominations. In the new-play category, Alan Bennett's ''History Boys,'' led the way with seven nominations, three of them for acting. ''The Lieutenant of Inishmore,'' a comic bloodbath by the Irish playwright Martin McDonagh, above, was close behind with five. E1 BUSINESS DAY C1-16 Hewlett Reports Profit Gain Hewlett-Packard said that strong sales of laptop computers and printer supplies combined with cost-cutting helped push its profits up 51 percent in the second quarter. C1 Defense Rests in Enron Case In the closing arguments of the Enron fraud trial, defense lawyers ripped into the government's case, accusing prosecutors of pushing at all costs to punish Enron's top two officers for the failure of a company. C1 Law Firm May Be Charged The securities class-action law firm Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman faces the possibility of an indictment in connection with a six-year federal investigation into whether the firm made illegal payments to clients. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: An American embassy in Tripoli; environmental battles; DNA is good for the soul; Andrew Rosenthal on his father. Columns: Thomas L. Friedman, Maureen Dowd. Crossword E2 TV Listings E9 Obituaries A20 Weather D7

headline: Facebook Users to Put Views Up in Lights on Times Square
summary: As the country prepares for this year's presidential election, political devotees have been following the nuances of every debate, caucus, straw poll and primary. A new application for Facebook users, however, is intended to encourage those who are not as engaged to talk about the election issues that are most important to them. The new app was created during a 24-hour ''hackathon'' this month with engineers from Facebook and representatives from the advertising agency R/GA, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, at Facebook's Manhattan headquarters. The goal was to create a social application that could share users' political views on digital billboards in Times Square.

headline: KNICKS AT THE TURN
summary: A half-season of diligent progress cannot be undone in 2.2 seconds, but Isiah Thomas's grim expression and grave tone made it seem so Wednesday night. Caron Butler's late dunk had just turned an uplifting Knicks victory into a crushing 99-98 loss to the Washington Wizards. Thomas, standing in a dull hallway at the Verizon Center, sounded like a coach who had just lost the championship, rather than a mid-January game. He took only three questions. His answers were brief, his voice lifeless.

headline: Why AT&T Pursued A Big Merger
summary: About an hour after AT&T announced its $39 billion acquisition of T-Mobile in March on a Sunday afternoon, I got a call at home. It was Randall L. Stephenson, AT&T's chairman and chief executive. Mr. Stephenson, an affable man with a wry sense of humor, knew he would face a battle persuading regulators the deal should be approved. And with me. As I peppered him with questions about why the government would possibly allow the No. 2 and No. 4 telephone carriers to merge - a textbook example of creating a duopoly between AT&T and Verizon if there ever was one - he deftly stood his ground. He was convinced the deal would happen.

headline: For Sale
summary: $14.25 MILLION 1623 Kings Highway (at East 17th Street)

headline: BUSINESS BRIEFS
summary: FALLOUT OF LAWSUIT -- The attorney general of Ohio, Jim Petro, dismissed the law firm of Milberg Weiss Bershad & Shulman as his special counsel yesterday, one day after the firm was indicted on charges of paying more than $11 million in kickbacks to clients. Mr. Petro also removed Milberg Weiss from representing the Ohio Tuition Trust Authority, the state's college savings plan, in lawsuits against Putnam American Government Income Fund, which is run by Putnam Investments. The 300 suits claim Putnam and other mutual fund companies engaged in improper trading. A spokeswoman for the firm, Marina Ein, said in a statement that ''Milberg Weiss regrets that the attorney general of Ohio has asked the firm to withdraw as counsel for the Ohio Tuition Trust Authority.'' (BLOOMBERG NEWS) IN-FLIGHT INTERNET SERVICE -- Three more companies -- Unison Spectrum, AMTS Consortium and Intelligent Transportation and Monitoring Wireless -- have dropped out of an auction for licenses to provide in-flight Internet services. With offers now at more than $28 million for the larger of two licenses, Unison and the other two firms are reaching their limits. Verizon Airfone, a unit of Verizon Communications, dropped out of the auction earlier this week. There are now four eligible participants. Most recently, the bidding was led by AC BidCo, which is associated with Ripplewood Holdings, a private-equity fund. AC BidCo had offered $28.4 million for one license, while LiveTV, a unit of the JetBlue Airways Corporation, had offered $615,000 for a smaller amount of spectrum. (DOW JONES) NEW CHIEF AT TYSON -- The world's largest meat processor, Tyson Foods, promoted its president, Richard L. Bond, to chief executive, succeeding John H. Tyson. Mr. Tyson, 52, will remain chairman, focusing on strategy and supervising the chief financial officer, general counsel and senior vice president for external affairs. He had been chief executive since October 2001. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) SUPPORT FOR AOL -- Time Warner, the media conglomerate, is committed to turning around its AOL Internet business even as the unit loses customers at a faster-than-expected pace, the chief executive, Richard D. Parsons, below, said. AOL's dial-up subscribers have been defecting to high-speed services largely provided by cable and phone companies as it works to revamp its business as an online provider of entertainment and other services supported by advertising revenue. Mr. Parsons said AOL ''is in a space that the marketplace thinks is contracting and needs to migrate its business to another part of the Internet landscape where the market is growing,'' referring to efforts to move AOL from a subscription model to an advertising-supported operation. (REUTERS) HEWLETT DIRECTOR QUITS -- Thomas J. Perkins has resigned as a director of Hewlett-Packard, the computer equipment company. Mr. Perkins, a founder of the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, rejoined the board in February 2005, having served after the buyout of Compaq Computer in May 2002. Before starting the venture firm in 1972, Mr. Perkins led Hewlett-Packard's early computer operations. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) ANHEUSER ACQUIRES ROLLING ROCK -- The Anheuser-Busch Companies agreed yesterday to buy the lager-style beer Rolling Rock from InBev of the Netherlands for $82 million. The acquisition will bring Rolling Rock to more consumers beyond the Northeast, where the brand is strongest, Anheuser-Busch said. Rolling Rock's volume has fallen 25 percent in the last two years, an analyst at UBS Securities, Caroline Levy, said in research note. Anheuser-Busch wants Rolling Rock because it sells for about $19 a case, or 16 percent more than Budweiser and Bud Light. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) EXXON PROXY FIGHT -- The Institutional Shareholder Services Inc. called on shareholders of the Exxon Mobil Corporation to withhold votes from four of the five members of the compensation committee after the former chairman, Lee R. Raymond, received a $98.4 million retirement payment. I.S.S. said shareholders should withhold votes from the directors James R. Houghton, William R. Howell, Reatha Clark King and Walter V. Shipley. Mr. Raymond, who retired in January, received a $357 million retirement package. Exxon Mobil said I.S.S. misinterpreted the company's compensation formula, according to a letter sent to shareholders. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) STRONG QUARTER FOR RETAILER -- The AnnTaylor Stores Corporation said yesterday that first-quarter profit more than doubled on stronger demand for its women's suits, dresses and casual wear. The company, which owns the Ann Taylor and Loft apparel chains, had earnings of $39 million, or 53 cents a share, for the first quarter ended April 29, from $17 million, or 24 cents a share, a year earlier. Analysts surveyed by Reuters Estimates had expected earnings of 40 cents a share. Sales jumped almost 17 percent, to $556.2 million. (REUTERS) RECORD FOR FRENCH BANK -- BNP Paribas became the latest French bank to report a record first-quarter profit as higher revenue at its investment banking division drove a surge in earnings that beat forecasts. The bank said net profit rose 17 percent from a year ago, to 2.01 billion euros ($2.57 billion). Revenue rose 22 percent, to 6.82 billion euros. BNP's first quarter net profit was the highest among banks in the euro zone. Its results beat the first-quarter net profit of 1.49 billion euros at Spanish lender Santander. BNP Paribas said all its main activities contributed to its growth, although its corporate and investment banking units led the way with a 49 percent rise in profit. (REUTERS)

headline: Ruling Backs Internet-Phone Wiretapping
summary: Comcast, Vonage and other companies that provide telecommunications services over the Internet must allow wiretapping of phone calls by law enforcement officials, a federal appeals court ruled Friday. In a 2-to-1 decision, the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit upheld a Federal Communications Commission directive treating such companies the same as conventional phone companies for law enforcement purposes. Comcast and other cable companies offer Internet service over their networks, and Vonage is the biggest provider of Web-based phone service.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: BUSH IMMIGRATION PUSH -- President Bush pushed ahead with his effort to bring Republicans in the House and Senate together on a plan to reduce illegal immigration. But he ran into renewed resistance from conservatives who said they were not swayed by the case he made to give many undocumented workers a chance to become citizens. [Page A1.] BERTELSMANN WEIGHS FUTURE -- Sometime next week, executives of Bertelsmann, a trans-Atlantic media colossus and arguably Germany's most influential privately owned enterprise, expect to receive a letter from their sole outside shareholder, calling on them to take the company public. [C1.] ENRON TRIAL -- In their closing arguments in the Enron trial, defense lawyers ripped into the government's case, accusing prosecutors of pushing at all costs to punish Enron's top two officers for the failure of the company that became synonymous with corporate malfeasance in the late 1990's. [C1.] IN THE HOT SEAT -- For years, the securities class-action law firm Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman inspired fear and uncertainty in executive suites and boardrooms. Now the firm faces the possibility of an indictment in connection with a six-year investigation into whether it made illegal payments to clients. [C1.] HEWLETT PROFIT RISES 51% -- Hewlett-Packard said that strong sales of laptop computers and printer supplies, along with cost-cutting, helped push its second-quarter profit up 51 percent. The company also said its market share in personal computers increased 1.4 percent. [C1.] GAS PRICES DON'T DETER SHOPPERS -- Defying predictions that rising gasoline prices would rein in consumer spending, the nation's two largest retailers, Wal-Mart Stores and Home Depot, reported sharply higher first-quarter profit. The chains account for more than 10 percent of United States retail sales. [C3.] VERIZON DENIES IT GAVE RECORDS -- Verizon, the country's second-largest phone company, said it had not provided local phone records to the National Security Agency. A day earlier, BellSouth had issued a similar statement in response to a report in USA Today. [A15.] CABLEVISION CALLING PLAN -- Cablevision is expected to announce a new flat-rate plan for international calls. [C3.] WHOLESALE PRICE REPORT -- Two economic reports indicated that wholesale prices remained tame and the housing market continued to cool. The government said that the Producer Price Index rose 0.9 percent in April but that the core index, which excludes food and energy, edged up 0.1 percent. [C3.] OPEN-SOURCE JAVA -- The new chief executive of Sun Microsystems, Jonathan Schwartz, below, said the company was working toward making its Java programming language available free as open-source software, providing further evidence that Sun's new management sees it as more of a services company than a network computer maker. [C7.] STOCKS EDGE LOWER -- Inflation fears pushed stocks modestly lower. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 8.88 points, to 11,419.89. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 2.42 points, to 1,292.08, and the Nasdaq fell 9.39 points, to 2,229.13. [C13.] EUROPEAN UNION SAYS YES, BUT -- The European Commission gave a qualified yes to Romania and Bulgaria joining the European Union on Jan. 1, but it delayed a final decision until October to try to pressure them to make greater inroads in fighting corruption and in judicial reforms. [A5.] SMALL SCREEN THINKS BIG -- A major trend becoming evident this week, as broadcasters present their 2006-7 schedules to agencies and advertisers, is the increasing ''cinema-zation'' of prime-time network programs. Many new series are seeking to emulate theatrical films. Stuart Elliott, Advertising. [C8.] ECUADOR OIL TAKEOVER -- Ecuador began to take over operations of Occidental Petroleum, the latest move in Latin America against foreign energy producers. [C12.] HYUNDAI CHAIRMAN CHARGED -- The chairman of Hyundai Motor of South Korea was charged with embezzling more than $100 million and causing far larger financial damage to companies under his control. [C12.] F.D.A. REPORT FAULTS BAUSCH -- Bausch & Lomb failed to notify United States regulators within 30 days about 35 serious bacterial infections reported in Singapore in users of one of its contact lens solutions, the Food and Drug Administration said. [C6.] TIME EDITOR PROMOTED -- Jim Kelly, managing editor of Time magazine for more than five years, was named to the newly created position of managing editor for Time Inc. [C7.] ONLINE ONLINE: DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook. WORKING IN THE PARK -- New York City officials have set a July deadline for a city contractor to have a wireless network up and running in Central Park. An update is at www.nytimes.com/technology. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. PRESIDENT ÁLVARO URIBE of Colombia said the government would sell the country's largest state bank, Granbanco-Bancafé, with more than $3 billion in assets, in a public offering. (REUTERS) THE FEDERAL RESERVE CHAIRMAN, Ben S. Bernanke, said stiffer hedge fund regulation could make financial markets less stable, as he backed the current focus on ensuring that hedge fund trading partners manage their risks well. It was his first comment on the subject since taking the post on Feb. 1. (REUTERS)

headline: A Way to Free Your Laptop From Wi-Fi, at a Cost
summary: What it is: Your smartphone has a high-speed, 3G data connection. Your laptop may only have Wi-Fi. Tethering turns your smartphone into a wireless router, sharing the phone's 3G connection with other devices over Wi-Fi. No more wireless data cards for laptops, and devices like Wi-Fi-only iPads can get on the Internet via a phone. With the arrival of iOS 4.3 for iPhones and iPads, AT&T subscribers are now able to use their iPhones as wireless hot spots for up to five people, something that Verizon users have been able to do for a few weeks now. But what does tethering mean for the average user and should you enable it on your phone?

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LEFKOWITZ, HOWARD N.
summary: LEFKOWITZ--Howard N. The attorneys and staff of Proskauer Rose, LLP, mourn the passing of Howard N. Lefkowitz, a senior partner in Proskauer's Corporate Department. We have lost not only a colleague and a friend but also a lawyer's lawyer who was known for his scholarship and pioneering spirit. In the 43 years Howard worked at Proskauer, he developed an impressive and diverse practice. A visionary in the emerging field of private equity, which would evolve into one of the firm's most active practice areas, he represented institutional investors-including Verizon, JPMorgan and others-in their investments in private equity funds that totaled in the billions. Nationally recognized for his work in partnership and limited liability company law, Howard authored the New York Limited Liability Company Forms and Practice Manual and co-authored Transactional Lawyers Deskbook: Advising Business Entities. He had extensive experience with alternative investment vehicles, and he lectured frequently on limited partnerships, limited liability companies and fiduciary obligations. In 2006, the American Bar Association presented Howard with the Martin I. Lubaroff Award in recognition of his work on partnership law. Howard, known for his love of the law, was a tremendous resource to his colleagues, who relied on his deep knowledge, particularly of New York law and Delaware partnership issues. As his friend and colleague Bruce Lieb remembers, Howard knew the answers to questions that many of us did not realize were questions. Howard retired in 2006 but continued to practice. He spoke and wrote frequently, and he contributed his professional time to organizations including the Private Investment Fund Forum, the ABA and the TriBar Opinion Committee. An expert on wine as well as the law, Howard enjoyed an extensive wine collection and contributed articles to food and wine magazines. Howard received his B.A. from Cornell University and his law degree from Columbia University Law School, where he was a Kent Scholar and an editor of the Columbia Law Review. Howard, who is survived by his wife, Midge, his two children and five grandchildren, will be greatly missed and affectionately remembered. Allen I. Fagin Chair, Proskauer Rose $(6$)LEFKOWITZ--Howard N., 70, born and raised in Utica, NY, now of New York City and Great Barrington, MA, died on March 12 of multiple myeloma. Survived by wife Midge; daughter Sarah and husband Ted; son David and wife Laurie; grandchildren Alex, Zachary, Adam, Anna Kate, and Talia; brother Manny and sisters Betty and Elinor; many nieces and nephews, and by a wonderful extended Sitrin family. Howard graduated Cornell University where he met Midge. Served as an officer in the US Navy in the destroyer fleet at Newport, RI, and graduated from Columbia Law School, where he became an editor of the Law Review and a Kent Scholar. Howard practiced corporate and partnership law at Proskauer, Rose, Goetz and Mendelsohn (now Proskauer Rose) his entire career of over 40 years, retiring as a senior partner in 2005. He enjoyed active participation in the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, the ABA Section of Business Law Parnership Committee, the Tri-Bar Opinion Committee, and the Private Investment Fund Forum. He insisted that his avid interest in, and consumption of fine wine did not hasten his demise. Funeral Wednesday, 12 noon, at Gramercy Chapel, 152 Second Ave. at 9th Street. Contributions to Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation, 383 Main Ave, Norwalk, CT 08651, would be appreciated.

headline: Please Stay Tuned
summary: SportsNet New York faced more technical problems yesterday when a power surge in its Rockefeller Plaza building caused the Mets' new station to run a continuous loop of announcements promoting itself. The problem began around 4 p.m., wiping out programs like ''Daily News Live'' and ''Sportsnite''; the network was planning to return to power in time for the Mets' exhibition game against the Dodgers at 7 p.m.

headline: Corrections
summary: An illustration in Business Day yesterday with an article about expansion plans by Yahoo and Google used a picture of a cellphone with a misleading label about the company that is working with Yahoo to market cellphones with enhanced software. Its partner is Cingular Wireless, not Verizon Wireless.

headline: T-Mobile Out in the iPhone Cold
summary: T-Mobile must feel like the only kid in the class who didn't get invited to the party of the year. It's the only one of the nation's four major wireless carriers that won't be selling the iPhone 4S, the new Apple device that officially goes on sale Friday and has already generated record numbers of pre-orders. The other big domestic carrier that was previously left out of the iPhone party, Sprint Nextel, finally struck a deal with Apple to carry the iPhone, joining AT&T and Verizon Wireless.

headline: Verizon Moving From Landlines
summary: Roll over in your grave, Alexander Graham Bell. That was in effect what Ivan Seidenberg, below, the chief executive of Verizon Communications -- one of the largest descendants of the old Bell System -- declared last week.

headline: Verizon Wireless Expands High-Speed Data Network
summary: Verizon Wireless said on Wednesday that it would expand its wireless high-speed data network into 14 additional cities, including New York and Los Angeles, starting on Monday. The move is part of an acceleration by wireless companies to expand the reach of their broadband Internet services.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International U.S. APPROVES TRAINING TO EXPAND AFGHAN ARMY

headline: THE CHATTER
summary: ''Verizon has had the advantage of seeing the challenges and problems AT&T has faced.'' Charles S. Golvin, an analyst at Forrester Research, after Verizon announced that it would begin selling the Apple iPhone 4 next month. Some question whether the phone will strain Verizon as it has AT&T,which has struggled to address customer complaints. ''Inflation will be an endemic problem in the emerging markets.'' Russell Napier, a strategist at the investment firm CLSA in London. Some Asian countries are battling high and still-rising inflation, especially in food and energy, and their policy makers are worried about bubbles forming in their financial systems.

headline: Tortorella Says He Regrets Game 5 Incident With Fans
summary: Rangers Coach John Tortorella said Thursday that he regretted squirting water on a heckling Capitals fan and throwing a water bottle that struck another fan in the head during Game 5 at Verizon Center. ''It's a bad mistake by me,'' said Tortorella, speaking to reporters at the Rangers' practice rink in Greenburgh, N.Y., according to The Associated Press. ''I regret it. I put the New York Rangers organization in an embarrassing situation. I'm embarrassed by it.''

headline: AT&T Makes Deal To Buy T-Mobile For $39 Billion
summary: 12:16 a.m. | Updated AT&T announced on Sunday that it had agreed to buy T-Mobile USA from Deutsche Telekom for $39 billion, in a deal that would create the largest carrier in the nation and promised to reshape the industry. The transaction - one of the largest since the onset of the financial crisis - is expected to start a fierce battle in Washington as regulators scrutinize the impact of the deal on competition and consumers. The deal would leave just three major cellular companies in the country: AT&T, Verizon and the much smaller Sprint Nextel.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths KELBY, PATRICIA
summary: KELBY--Patricia, 73, of Larchmont, passed away Sunday, March 20, 2011 at her residence. Please contact brojuda49@verizon.net.

headline: A Plan to Remake The Book, Again
summary: A technology company announces plans to reinvent higher education by encouraging the creation of a new kind of textbook. Students will learn better, faster, cheaper. They will be spurred to new triumphs that will finally reverse the persistent decline in American education and the American way of life. That is more or less the presentation Apple made on Thursday, but it is a song that has been sung before. Nearly three years ago, in May 2009, Amazon said much the same thing when it came up with the Kindle DX, a souped-up e-reader.

headline: Motorola's Revival Includes an Entry in the Tablet Market
summary: 6:30 p.m. | Updated Adding more on the Xoom and other new products. LAS VEGAS -- Motorola, which has fought its way back into the cellphone market, is now taking on Apple's iPad.

headline: Looking Beyond Set-Top Boxes
summary: ''Set-top box'' is one of those puzzling anachronisms, like ''record industry,'' that seems to persist for no clear reason. Perching a cable tuner, TiVo or Apple TV on top one of today's slim television sets would require either amazing balancing skills, very strong adhesive or a bit of both. For the last several years, Roku has been one of the companies selling devices that let users stream Internet video to their televisions from a big lineup of programming sources, including Netflix and Hulu Plus. Even though you can't balance them on top of a modern television set, the Roku boxes are tiny things, roughly the size of a hockey puck.

headline: LOOKING AHEAD
summary: BACK IN THE SPOTLIGHT -- Richard M. Scrushy, the HealthSouth founder, goes on trial today in federal court in Birmingham, Ala. He is charged with participating in a political bribery scheme unrelated to HealthSouth's accounting problems. MAY DAY -- Financial markets in some countries are closed for the May Day holiday, including those in Britain, China and India. ECONOMIC PULSE -- The main economic news for the week will be the unemployment report for April, due out on Friday. Other major reports include auto sales for April, out tomorrow, and same-store retail sales for April, out Thursday. Also on the schedule: Today, personal income and spending for March, the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing index for April and construction spending for March; on Wednesday, factory orders for March and the I.S.M. service index; on Thursday, productivity for the first quarter; and on Friday, consumer credit for March. PROFIT WATCH -- As the corporate earnings season starts to trail off, the big names still scheduled to report include Verizon tomorrow, Procter & Gamble and Time Warner on Wednesday, and Kodak, Royal Dutch Shell and Unilever on Thursday.

headline: Verizon Open to Rival Apps, Too
summary: Being open doesn't mean being ordinary, at least according to Lowell C. McAdam, the chief executive of Verizon Wireless. Verizon announced on Tuesday a partnership with Google to develop phones with the Android operating system for its network. In a conference call, Mr. McAdam, above right with Eric Schmidt, head of Google, endorsed the openness of Android and said Verizon would support Android applications, like Google Voice, that competed with its own services.

headline: AT&T Revises Privacy Policy for Customer Data
summary: The nation's largest telephone company, AT&T, has revised its privacy policy for its television and Internet customers, clarifying that the personal information it collects is owned by the company and may be shared in response to court orders and other legal processes. ''While your account information may be personal to you, these records constitute business records that are owned by AT&T,'' the statement said. ''As such, AT&T may disclose such records to protect its legitimate business interests, safeguard others, or respond to legal process.''

headline: Hewlett-Packard Adds McCann to Agency Roster
summary: Hewlett-Packard in Palo Alto, Calif., has added to its agency roster McCann Erickson Worldwide, part of the McCann Worldgroup unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle creative assignments, with spending estimated at $200 million. The London and San Francisco offices of McCann will create campaigns for products like personal computers, to appear in Africa, Europe, the Middle East and the United States.

headline: AT&T's Cost For Getting T-Mobile
summary: ''We have never seen a deal with more regulatory risk be attempted in the U.S.'' That was the initial assessment of AT&T's $39 billion agreement to acquire T-Mobile, from Jonathan Chaplin, one of the most thoughtful telecommunications analysts on Wall Street.

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Verizon To Sell Canadian Unit To Bain
summary: Verizon Communications has agreed to sell its Canadian telephone-directory unit to Bain Capital, based in Boston, for $1.54 billion to invest in faster-growing businesses. The sale is subject to regulatory approval and is expected to be completed by the end of 2004, Verizon said yesterday. The service, SuperPages Canada, is the country's second-largest directories publisher. It had sales of $293 million in 2003. Verizon is investing in new services including high-speed Internet access and video over fiber optic lines as demand for traditional service declines. Shares of Verizon, which also has a majority stake in the nation's biggest mobile phone company, rose 2 cents to $40.42. SuperPages Canada produces 118 directories.

headline: INSIDE
summary: 2 Suicide Car Bombers Kill 14 Near Baghdad Airport At least 14 people were killed by two suicide car bombers at a checkpoint near Baghdad's airport, as violence across Iraq left at least 32 people dead and 60 wounded. PAGE A6 Struggle on School Data Nearly all states are building data systems to collect, categorize and crunch attendance logs, test scores and other information on students in public schools. But the projects are costing billions, and in some states they have gone off track. PAGE A17 Spying Programs Defended A top adviser to President Bush said the National Security Agency's surveillance programs were lawful and had not invaded the privacy rights of Americans. PAGE A15 Pyramid Fever in Bosnia An amateur archaeologist says he has discovered a huge ancient pyramid buried in Bosnia. Although professional archaeologists and historians say it is a hill, pyramid fever is sweeping through Bosnia. PAGE A8 Plotting the New TV Season The embrace of new media by the big broadcast television networks is altering the plans of advertisers. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 NBC is expected to announce a fall schedule that will rely heavily on drama. THE ARTS, PAGE E1 A Formidable Set of Pipes The Philadelphia Orchestra welcomed a new collaborator over the weekend: a huge pipe organ, billed as the nation's largest, installed in Verizon Hall at the Kimmel Center. A Critic's Notebook by James R. Oestreich. THE ARTS, PAGE E1

headline: Stopping Unwanted Mobile Text Ads
summary: Q. I saw an offer at a restaurant that if I texted a number I would get a free soft drink. As I was enjoying my 20 ounces of Cherry Coke, I noticed the fine print on the offer: the restaurant would send me texts on promotions and offers. Help! Each text message costs me 20 cents and that Cherry Coke is now costing me money. How do I stop it?

headline: Arenas Incident And N.B.A.'s Image
summary: As the N.B.A. closed out a decade that included a brawl involving players and the crowd and a referee betting scandal, a fresh incident threatens the league's image. The latest headache revolves around Gilbert Arenas, once one of the game's most colorful personalities and dazzling stars. He is at the center of an investigation of whether he drew a gun in an argument with his teammate Javaris Crittenton in the Washington Wizards' locker room.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths KELBY, PATRICIA
summary: KELBY--Patricia, 73, of Larchmont, passed away Sunday, March 20, 2011 at her residence. Please contact brojuda49@verizon.net.

headline: To Match Profit With Popularity, Skype Looks to New Markets
summary: SAN FRANCISCO -- Skype has become one of the Internet's most popular services -- so much so that it is even used as a verb to describe a phone call over the Internet, as in ''Skype me.'' The seven-year-old company, however, is still a work in progress on the financial front. It was sold to eBay, then taken private and now aims to complete the round trip with an initial public offering.

headline: Fresh Faces in Digital Picture Frames, Sent by Cell Carrier
summary: That digital photo frame seemed like a really great holiday gift. But by now you're probably tired of driving to your parents' house to deliver a new SD card that refreshes the photos. Soon, you won't have to. In mid-October, Isabella Products will introduce a service called Vizit that will let you send photos to its 11-inch LCD digital photo frame remotely, using a cellular network.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: THE FOOD CHAIN A few big private investors are buying farmland, fertilizer, grain elevators and shipping equipment, betting that the world's need for food will greatly increase. Monsanto said it would develop by 2030 new strains of corn, soybeans and cotton that could yield twice as much while consuming less water. [C3.]

headline: 'Bad Judgment' Cited By Arenas in Gun Case
summary: Gilbert Arenas stood at his locker with his back to about 20 reporters and cameramen. He smiled as he dressed after the Washington Wizards' 97-86 loss to the San Antonio Spurs on Saturday, seemingly amused by the fuss. ''I wish it was like this every day,'' Arenas said.

headline: PETA STANDS BY ADS FEATURING ARENAS
summary: Gilbert Arenas continues to make news even when he is not on the court. This week, Arenas started to appear in advertisements run by the People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals. The pictures show Arenas shirtless, exposing tattoos on his chest. The ad is part of PETA's, ''Ink, Not Mink'' campaign. The picture's tagline reads, ''Be comfortable in your own skin, and let animals keep theirs.''

headline: Take a Few Hours And Unlock Some Cash
summary: To be a modern American consumer is to be plagued by a never-ending, guilt-inducing stream of undone tasks. There's the nagging feeling that you don't have the most cost-effective plan with the cable company and the vague sense that the money in your bank account could be earning more interest. Perhaps that flexible spending account reimbursement keeps slipping down your list of things to do, and you know in the back of your mind that you could save some money by raising your insurance deductibles.

headline: Net Neutrality
summary: Brian Stelter and David Gallagher discuss Google and Verizon.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: THE $100 LAPTOP A nonprofit project to build a $100 laptop for children in the developing world is winning over many skeptics. Five countries have made tentative commitments to put the computers into the hands of millions of students, with production in Taiwan expected to begin by mid-2007. [Page A1.] HARD TIMES FOR WAL-MART Wal-Mart is expected to announce next week that sales for November fell for the first time in a decade, leading some industry experts to wonder whether the retailer is changing too fast, acting more like a start-up than a 44-year-old company with 6,000 stores, 1.3 million employees and sales of $312 billion. [A1.] GAUGING THE IMPACT OF $4 DRUGS Wal-Mart says that its $4 generic drug program is attracting new customers to its stores and starting the nation on a road that will squeeze billions of dollars from prescription drug spending. But two months into the program, it is unclear whether Wal-Mart is meeting its stated goal of making a profit on those drugs. [C1.] BUYOUTS COSTLY FOR FORD The Ford Motor Company expects to burn through $17 billion -- nearly half of its cash reserves -- by 2009, mostly in the next year as 40 percent of its hourly workers voluntarily leave their jobs. [C1.] WORRIES OVER KIDNEY DRUGS An expert panel of doctors for the National Kidney Foundation plans to assess whether hundreds of thousands of patients with kidney disease are being dangerously overtreated with drugs for anemia. [C1.] TROUBLE WITH PATROL BOATS After spending $100 million to renovate eight of its workhorse cutters, the Coast Guard will announce that it is suspending the use of the Florida-based patrol boats because of chronic hull cracking and engine problems. [A22.] CARBON DIOXIDE ON TRIAL A Supreme Court argument on the Bush administration's refusal to regulate carbon dioxide in automobile emissions offered three intertwined plot lines to the audience that had come to watch the court's first encounter with the issue of global climate change. [A23.] A NEW CLASS SYSTEM India, once divided chiefly by caste, is creating a different divide by skills. Those with marketable skills are sought for service call centers and software houses; those without are ensnared in drudgery. [C3.] VERIZON PLAYS HOST Verizon's newest store in Southlake, Tex., lets consumers play the latest video game, practice downloading music or kick back and watch football in high-definition, making Verizon the latest electronics retailer to open an outlet that feels more like an arcade than a phone store. Advertising. [C3.] EDUCATIONAL PUBLISHERS IN DEAL Riverdeep Holdings, an Irish maker of educational software, agreed to acquire the American textbook publisher Houghton Mifflin for $1.75 billion. [C9.] AUSTRALIA BALKS AT BIDS A recent flurry of multibillion-dollar takeover bids by international buyers for Australian companies has touched a nationalistic nerve and drawn some calls for a more protectionist government stance. [C13.] SHARES RALLY Wall Street rallied for a second consecutive session after the government's latest gross domestic product reading showed the economy was in better shape than expected, easing concerns that growth was slowing too sharply. [C15.] GRASSO REQUESTS JUDGE'S REMOVAL Richard A. Grasso, the former New York Stock Exchange chairman, has asked an appeals court to remove the judge presiding over a lawsuit seeking the return of some of his $190 million pay package from the Big Board. [C15.] A PROPOSAL TO SCALE BACK RULES An independent committee formed with the endorsement of Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., left, will call today for a sweeping overhaul of securities market regulations, including making it harder for companies to be indicted by the government or sued by private lawyers. [C1.] SOARING PROFITS FOR INSURERS Auto insurance companies are reaping extraordinary profits from rising premiums in New York City, even as they pay out less in claims, because state regulators have not adequately policed the industry, according to a report released by the city comptroller. [B5.] ONLINE DIGITAL HOLIDAYS Designers and engineers have come up with enticing new devices, and scores of them are set to reach the store shelves in time for the holiday shoppers. A special report is at nytimes.com/technology/circuits. RULES FOR THE ROAD Relocating? Find tips for choosing a moving company at nytimes.com/realestate. Business Briefing An article on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. YAHOO HAS REBUFFED Google's attempt to learn more about its efforts to create digital copies of books, dealing Google another setback as it prepares to fight a copyright infringement suit. In rejecting Google's request, Yahoo adopted the same stance taken last month by the Internet retailer Amazon.com, and called Google's request a brazen attempt to pry into its trade secrets. (AP)

headline: Verizon Executive Pay
summary: To the Editor: Re ''Outside Advice on Boss's Pay May Not Be So Independent'' (front page, April 10):

headline: Assemblyman Criticizes Verizon's Repair Service
summary: Verizon's service on Long Island is ''among the worst in the state'' when it comes to restoring telephone service after a storm or some other problem, Assemblyman Richard Brodsky, the chairman of the State Assembly's Committee on Corporations, Authorities and Commissions, said on Wednesday. Under Public Service Commission regulations, Verizon is supposed to restore service to 80 percent of its affected customers within 24 hours. Citing Verizon's own figures, Mr. Brodsky said the company frequently failed to make the necessary repairs within that time frame.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LYND, SUSAN CROSBY THOMPSON
summary: LYND--Susan Crosby Thompson, 66, died August 16, 2009 in hospice at Scarborough, ME. She and her husband Richard B. Lynd had lived in Brooklyn Heights for 36 years before retiring to Susan's childhood home near Albany in 2003. She was the daughter of the late William Leland Thompson Jr. of East Greenbush, NY and the late Maris Wistar (Townsend) Thompson of Bryn Mawr, PA. She studied at Chatham Hall, Colby and Firenze. Susan worked for thirty-three years for TIME and LIFE, the last twenty-six at TIME, rising to News Desk Manager. She loved her home, her garden, her "Bear", her "Wiglet", cooking, swimming, and especially her Westies, "Gus" and "Agnes." For 55 years she enjoyed her summer times in Kennebunkport. With enormous courage Susan for three years maintained the life she wanted despite a struggle with cancer. She is survived by her husband, Richard, (email: windward22@ verizon.net), her sister Maris Wistar Thompson, many cousins, godchildren, loved ones and friends. A graveside memorial service will be held in late October at the Church of the Redeemer, Bryn Mawr, PA. Contributions in Susan's memory to Gosnell Memorial Hospice, 11 Hunnewell Rd., Scarborough, ME 04074 would be appreciated. Services are in care of Bibber Memorial Chapel, 67 Summer Street, Kennebunk, ME 04043. www.bibberfuneral.com

headline: Speedier Internet For Minneapolis
summary: Speedier Internet For Minneapolis Minnesota sports teams are not known for coming in first. But the Twin Cities are now out in front in at least one respect: Comcast announced Thursday that it was beginning the introduction of a new broadband Internet technology in the Minneapolis-St. Paul region.

headline: Many Demands On New Tower At Ground Zero; Seeking Better Security At a Symbol of Resolve
summary: Once intended as a shimmering, soaring declaration of political resolve and architectural ambition, the Freedom Tower at the site of the World Trade Center is being reimagined as something more impregnable. So the challenge now faced by its designers is to keep it from looking like a high-rise bunker. The Freedom Tower may end up with a structurally massive base that is distinctly different from the upper office floors. The designers may use stainless-steel cladding, reinforced glass or even translucent concrete, a new material embedded with strands of glass that transmits light and shadow through seemingly impervious walls.

headline: App of the Week: A Free Guide for Stargazers
summary: Google Sky Map, a free app available only on Android phones, merges a phone's GPS and compass with date and time to show you a map of the sky from where you are standing. It charts stars, constellations, planets and Messier objects (that's basically everything else in the sky), oriented with or without a grid and horizon line. Rotate the phone and celestial bodies pan by. Manual mode lets you move the map without waving the handset.

headline: Verizon Hub
summary: David Pogue discusses the pros and cons of the Verizon Hub.

headline: A Is for Amazon, B Is for Best Buy . . .
summary: Back in the old days, a sign that a corporation had hit the big time was when it got a single-letter stock symbol on the New York Stock Exchange. For example, Ford has ''F,'' AT&T has ''T'' (for telephone) and United States Steel has ''X.'' On the Web, there's another way a single letter can enhance a company's prestige. Go to Google's home page or browser toolbar and type a single letter into the search box. The search engine will then drop down a list of suggestions, based on overall search activity. There are 26 sites that have the distinction of being Google's first suggestion for each letter of the alphabet.

headline: Before Rush, One Tablet Stands Out
summary: It's an old pattern by now. Phase 1: Apple introduces some new gadget. The bloggers and the industry tell us why it'll fail. Phase 2: It goes on sale. The public goes nuts for it. Phase 3: Every company and its brother gets to work on a copycat. It happened with the iMac and the iPhone. Now the iPad is entering Phase 3. Apple sold 15 million iPads in nine months, so you can bet that 2011 will be the Year of the iPad Clone.

headline: A New Wait-Time App For Disney Theme Parks
summary: Want to find Mickey Mouse for an autograph? Want to know the wait time for Space Mountain? Well, there's an app for that -- sort of. Disney Parks has released a mobile app, Mobile Magic, which delivers real-time updates of wait times, where to find characters and GPS-enabled maps for both Disneyland and Walt Disney World. But the app, $9.99 for a 180-day subscription, works only on Verizon Wireless phones.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International CABLES OFFER GLIMPSES

headline: Merrill Hires Former Lehman Banker
summary: Merrill Lynch & Company is expected to announce on Wednesday that it has hired George H. Young III, a veteran Wall Street banker, to run its technology, media and telecommunications investment banking practice. Mr. Young, known as Woody, had previously led the communications group at Lehman Brothers, and was that firm's biggest rainmaker. He advised AT&T, Verizon and Sprint on some of their biggest deals during the wave of telecommunication mergers that swept that industry over the last decade.

headline: Chatter Box
summary: 'It's a bad mistake by me. I regret it. I put the New York Rangers organization in an embarrassing situation. I'm embarrassed by it.' JOHN TORTORELLA, the Rangers' coach, who squirted water on a heckling Capitals fan and threw a water bottle that hit another fan in the head during Game 5 at Verizon Center.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Rowe, Donald C.
summary: ROWE-Donald C., 51. Of Ridgefield, CT. Jan. 24, 2002. A regulatory attorney with Verizon Corporation of NYC. Survived by his wife, Carolyn Harris Rowe of Ridgefield, 3 sons, Robert Andrew, William Harris & David Alexander Rowe, his father William Elijah Rowe of Brooklyn, NY, his brother William T. Rowe, his nephew Joshua Rowe and his niece Sara Rowe of Baltimore, MD. Funeral services, Monday, 11 AM, Temple Shearith Israel, Ridgefield, CT. Memorials in Donald's memory may be made to Temple Shearith Israel Building Fund, 46 Peaceable Street, Ridgefield, CT. 06877, or the Boy Scouts of America, CT. Yankee Council, 60 Wellington Road, Milford, CT 06460.

headline: Popular Demand
summary: Mobile carriers like Verizon, which pitches seamless viewing from computer to television to cellphone, and Cingular, which has an exclusive with ''The Sopranos,'' conjure a world in which people are glued to their cellphones. But, only 656,000 users out of 207 million customers downloaded video to their mobile devices. On the tiny, tiny screen, users watched news segments like ''Where in the World is Matt Lauer?,'' above, and other TV highlights, but only 250,000 viewed a full show or film, well out of the top 10. SHELLY FREIERMAN

headline: For Beachcombers, The Tropical Storm Whipped Up Hopes
summary: Ana Ramirez, 35, of Coney Island swung her metal detector over the sand just off the Coney Island Boardwalk in the shadow of the Wonder Wheel ride. -''People say that storms sweep a lot of sand away, so it's a good time to look for things on the beach,'' Ms. Ramirez said as she walked on the beach a few days after Tropical Storm Irene lashed the city.

headline: Equity Firms to Buy Alltel In Biggest Telecom Buyout
summary: Alltel, the wireless phone company, agreed last night to be sold to a consortium of private equity firms for $27.5 billion, marking the largest buyout ever in the telecommunications industry. The consortium includes the Texas Pacific Group and the private equity arm of Goldman Sachs. The deal would make Alltel, based in Little Rock, Ark., the latest large public company to seek to go private amid a frenzy of deal-making among private equity firms.

headline: Verizon and Town Agree on Cable TV Pact
summary: Verizon Communications obtained approval from the Town of Oyster Bay on Tuesday to begin offering cable television service to most of the town's 100,000 households once the State Public Service Commission approves their franchise agreement. The move follows similar approvals by the Village of Cedarhurst on May 1 and the Town of Hempstead in April. The Village of Massapequa Park signed a franchise agreement with Verizon in September and received state approval three months later to begin offering service.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: MAJOR PATENT RULING -- The Supreme Court, in its most significant patent ruling in years, made it more difficult to get a patent on new products that combine elements of existing inventions. [Page C1.] SAFEGUARDING FOOD -- As Food and Drug Administration inspectors head to China to investigate contaminated pet food, critics in Washington are warning that the agency is wholly understaffed and underfunded to safeguard America's food supply. [C1.] DELTA EXITS BANKRUPTCY -- Delta Air Lines has emerged from bankruptcy protection after cutting billions in costs during a 19-month reorganization. Its board must now find a new chief executive to replace Gerald Grinstein, above, and decide whether to sell or spin off Comair, its regional feeder carrier. [C6.] LURE OF LASALLE -- For Bank of America and the Royal Bank of Scotland, acquiring LaSalle Bank of Chicago would offer each an efficient way to gain a strong foothold there and throughout the Midwest, where LaSalle has 140 branches. [C1.] QUESTIONABLE TECHNIQUE -- An accounting technique called gain on sale is haunting New Century Financial, a subprime mortgage lender now facing bankruptcy and investigations by federal prosecutors and securities regulators. [C1.] PROMISE OF PLANKTON -- Some Silicon Valley technocrats are betting plankton can save the planet. Several groups are working on ventures to grow vast floating fields of plankton that could absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and carry it to the depths of the ocean. [C1.] WOLFOWITZ DEFENDS HIMSELF -- Paul D. Wolfowitz, the president of the World Bank, told bank directors it would be unfair and hypocritical to dismiss him, but he hinted he might be willing to resign if he was cleared of any misconduct. [A3.] HALLIBURTON DENIES BREAKING LAW -- A Halliburton executive insisted during a Senate hearing concerning the company's business dealings in Iran that it had done nothing wrong. [A6.] DEBATE OVER CHANGES FOR F.D.A. -- he Senate debated legislation that could fundamentally change the way the F.D.A. operates by providing it with more power and more money to insure that drugs are as safe as advertised. [A18.] AN ENERGY CHALLENGE -- With the increasing use of coal inevitable, clearing a hurdle to burn it on a big scale -- separating the carbon dioxide and sequestering it -- could turn out to be one of the major engineering challenges of the century. [Science, F3.] CHINESE WEB COMPANY TO GO PUBLIC -- China's leading e-commerce company, Alibaba.com, is planning to go public later this year in what could be the biggest initial public offering there for an Internet company. [C10.] GROUP CRITICIZES WAL-MART -- Human Rights Watch contends that Wal-Mart's efforts to keep out labor unions have often violated federal law and infringed on workers' rights. Wal-Mart, with more than 1.3 million workers at nearly 4,000 stores in the United States, strongly defended its practices. [C3.] UPDATING 'OL' LONELY' -- The Maytag repairman, who started appearing in national commercials in 1967, is becoming more active and gregarious in a change meant to update the concept of ''Ol' Lonely'' for a new generation of shoppers. [C3.] GOOGLE RESPONDS TO VIACOM SUIT -- In an initial response to the lawsuit filed in United States District Court in Manhattan, Google says Viacom's $1 billion copyright infringement suit over video clips on YouTube is unfounded and ought to be dismissed. [C2.] PROFIT DECLINES AT VERIZON -- Verizon's profit declined in the first quarter, but the company continued to have strong growth in wireless and broadband subscriptions as it begins to offer Internet and television services. [C2.] GOOD NEWS FOR TWO TABLOIDS -- With the exception of two New York tabloids that showed solid gains -- The New York Post and The Daily News -- newspaper circulation continued a sharp decline nationally, new figures show. [C10.] KELLOGG'S EARNINGS RISE -- Kellogg's first-quarter earnings climbed 17 percent, helped by stronger snack sales and a tax benefit. The company, which makes food like cereal, cookies and waffles, also raised its full-year outlook. Kellogg's North American sales rose 7 percent as revenue rose 9 percent. Excluding the tax benefit, earnings were 70 cents a share. [C11.] DEUTSCHE BÖRSE BUYS EXCHANGE -- The German stock exchange operator Deutsche Börse has agreed to buy International Securities Exchange Holdings, an options exchange in New York that is the largest after the Chicago Board Options Exchange, for $2.8 billion. [C10.] WHEN THE BACKUP FAILS -- When the editorial computer system crashed at Business 2.0, a Time Inc. magazine that has written about the importance of backing up computer files, its back-up server failed to do its job. Luckily, the monthly magazine has been able to recover. [C11.] LESSONS FOR HEDGE FUNDS -- Hedge and equity funds are discovering the they may need to develop a credible public persona to capitalize on the keen interest in their high-returning funds and to go public. [C10.] WHEN TRAVELING, TAKE FOOD -- Dieticians and nutritionists recommend taking along a stash of food, which can help relieve stress if you should get stuck on the tarmac. [C5.]

headline: Secondhand Phones That Look Like New
summary: In the car industry, the preferred term for ''used'' is ''certified pre-owned.'' It would appear the term is becoming popular in the phone industry as well. Here's the lay of the land. Sprint has announced a new program that will sell previously owned phones at a deep discount. The inaugural deal offers a BlackBerry Tour for $80, a Samsung Reclaim for $50, or a Sanyo 2700 for $50. The Sprint refurbs carry a 30-day warranty, compared with one year for the same phone new. Also like new phones, refurbs come in a box with all of the accessories and manuals.

headline: A Digital Niche for Indie Film
summary: So many independent films, so few ways to see them. Now an investment arm of Comcast, the cable giant, and New Enterprise Associates, a venture capital firm with a broad technology portfolio, are placing a bet on the digital future of indies. On Monday, the two companies are expected to announce an investment of $10 million in the expansion of SnagFilms, Rick Allen, its chief executive, said.

headline: Mobile Start-Up Aims To Upstage Text-Messaging
summary: When people were seeking to contribute money after the earthquake in Haiti last year, the Red Cross offered a simple solution: text-message the word ''Haiti'' to 90999. That's when it became clear to many that text-messaging could work for commerce. A company called Zoove contends there is an even simpler way to reach customers than asking them to remember a text-message address of five random digits.

headline: Google's Coup Shifts Mobile Alliances: In the World of Wireless, It's All About the Patents
summary: Google, in announcing a $12.5 billion deal for Motorola Mobility on Monday, saved its warmest words not for Motorola Mobility's management or its products, but for one valuable asset: the company's roughly 17,000 patents, as well as an additional 7,500 patents that are under government review. That intellectual property portfolio is a treasure trove for Google because the battle in wireless is one that is increasingly being fought in court.

headline: Comcast Blurs High Def Image
summary: Comcast Blurs High Def Image

headline: RANGEL INQUIRY FINDS EVIDENCE BEYOND DISPUTE
summary: The House ethics committee ruled on Monday that there was evidence to support 13 counts of misconduct by Representative Charles B. Rangel, and began considering whether to formally convict and recommend punishment against him. The ruling came after a dramatic and puzzling appearance by Mr. Rangel, 80, in which he protested that he could no longer afford to pay his lawyers, and indignantly walked out of the proceedings, calling them unfair.

headline: Today in Business
summary: BUSH PUSHES STIMULUS PLAN In his final State of the Union address, President Bush called for Congress to pass his economic stimulus plan quickly. REVELATIONS ABOUT TRADER Management at Société Générale had new questions to answer when Jérôme Kerviel, the renegade trader who lost $7.2 billion, told French prosecutors that his trading spree started as in 2005 -- a year earlier than the bank had said. [A1.]

headline: INSIDE THE TIMES: August 7, 2008
summary: INTERNATIONAL VULNERABLE FOR H.I.V.,

headline: INSIDE THE TIMES: August 19, 2008
summary: International U.S. DECLINES TO ACCELERATE

headline: Kips Bay Co-op
summary: KIPS BAY CO-OP $599,000

headline: U.S. Backs Apple In Patent Ruling That Hits Google
summary: A federal agency ruled on Monday that a set of important features commonly found in smartphones are protected by an Apple patent, a decision that could force changes in how Google's Android phones function. The ruling, by the United States International Trade Commission, is one of the most significant so far in a growing array of closely watched patent battles being waged around the globe by nearly all of the major players in the mobile industry. These fights reflect the heated competition among the companies, especially as Android phones gain market share.

headline: Verizon Rejects Traffic Cop Role
summary: Verizon Rejects Traffic Cop Role More often than not, companies in similar positions have similar views. But when Hollywood asked the two big phone companies to help with its fight against movie piracy, they responded in opposite ways. AT&T is talking about developing a system that would identify and block illicitly copied material being sent over its broadband network.

headline: A Big Wi-Fi Aggregator Will Offer Monthly Flat-Rate Service
summary: As Wi-Fi hot spots proliferate, it has become possible to open a laptop and connect to the Internet in just about any major airport as well as in thousands of hotels, restaurants, cafes and bars. Yet logging on can sometimes be onerous, and pricing is likely to be expensive and opaque. This has created an opportunity for what are called aggregators, companies that bring together the Wi-Fi networks of many different operators and allow clients to connect in the same manner and at the same price whether they are at a cafe in Los Angeles, an airport in Milan or a hotel in Bangkok.

headline: For PayPal, The Future Is Mobile
summary: SAN JOSE, Calif. -- When Scott Thompson, the president of PayPal, chats with executives at its parent, eBay, he is diplomatic about the size of his business compared with eBay's marketplace. ''I hope -- honestly, genuinely -- that we never get bigger than you,'' he tells them.

headline: E-Policy Expert Joins the F.T.C.
summary: The Federal Trade Commission on Tuesday named Tim Wu, author of the book ''The Master Switch,'' a senior adviser for consumer protection and competition issues that affect the Internet and mobile phones. Mr. Wu, a law professor at Columbia University, is best known for coining the term ''net neutrality,'' which refers to the principle that consumers should have unfettered access to all kinds of Internet content.

headline: AT&T Faults F.C.C. on Auction
summary: You've got to hand it to AT&T. They don't like Julius Genachowski's plan to apply network neutrality rules to wireless networks, and they aren't shy about saying so. Not so for Verizon and Sprint, which declined to answer a direct question about whether they think wireless systems should be covered by net neutrality rules.

headline: New Jersey Has Settled With a College It Sued
summary: The embattled president of Stevens Institute of Technology, Harold J. Raveché, will step down in July, the college said Friday. And under the terms of a settlement ending a lawsuit by the State of New Jersey that questioned his $1.1 million salary, the institute said it had accepted extensive governance changes that would stiffen oversight of its financial management. Dr. Raveché will be paid his salary, which exceeds those earned by the presidents of Harvard, Princeton and M.I.T., for a year after he leaves office July 1, Attorney General Anne Milgram said. And under the terms of his contract, Dr. Raveché will be compensated as a consultant through June 2014, she said.

headline: Still Waiting for Hewlett-Packard to Make a Splash in Smartphones
summary: Still Waiting for Hewlett-Packard To Make a Splash in Smartphones

headline: Inside The Times
summary: International HOLDING STRATEGIC CHECKPOINTS,

headline: Getting a Head Start on an iPad 3G
summary: The price of a new 3G-connected iPad just dropped. That version of the iPad isn't due out for about a month, but new discounting by Palm means you could have a 3G-connected iPad sooner and a lot cheaper.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International IN RUSSIA, ORTHODOX CHURCH

headline: Like Apple, TV Explores Must-Have Applications
summary: The cable and satellite TV business has a big case of iPhone envy. Apple has been able to popularize its cellphone in a crowded field by giving away or selling specialized applications that make the phone more useful. So far, independent developers have written more than 65,000 apps.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: A LOSS OF INFLUENCE Oil production by the major Western oil companies is declining as they lose their influence and along with it, their ability to increase supplies. TIME'S UP Electronic Arts has withdrawn its $2 billion offer to buy rival Take-Two Interactive, ending its hostile takeover bid for the maker of the popular Grand Theft Auto video game. E.A. said it did not believe it could absorb the company in time for the critical holiday selling season. [C1.]

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: AID FOR AN AUTO MERGER The Bush administration is looking at a number of options for providing emergency financial help to facilitate a merger between General Motors and Chrysler. ALSO TOO BIG TO FAIL? ''The current financial crisis goes far beyond any one industry,'' Rick Wagoner, left, the chief executive of General Motors, wrote in an e-mail message to employees almost a month ago. Now Mr. Wagoner wants the government's rescue plan to help his company merge with Chrysler. DealBook: Andrew Ross Sorkin. [B1.]

headline: F.C.C. Faces Challenges To Net Rules
summary: 8:52 p.m. | Updated Want to watch hours of YouTube videos or sort through Facebook photos on the computer? Your Internet providers would be forbidden from blocking you under rules approved by the Federal Communications Commission on Tuesday. But if you want to do the same on your cellphone, you may not have the same protections. The debate over the rules, intended to preserve open access to the Internet, seems to have resulted in a classic Washington solution - the kind that pleases no one on either side of the issue. Verizon and other service providers would prefer no government involvement. Public interest advocates think the rules stop far short of ensuring free speech. Some Republicans believe the rules are another instance of government overreach.

headline: It's a Tablet. It's Gorgeous. It's Costly.
summary: Every time there's some new hot, heavily hyped gadget from Apple, it takes only a few months for the copycats to crop up. IPod? Zune! IPhone? Android! The iPad? Well, it came out in March, and the iPad alternatives are just landing in stores now.

headline: BlackBerry Throws a Curve At the Apple iPhone
summary: The iPhone lost its spot as top-selling smartphone to the BlackBerry Curve in the first quarter of 2009, but that doesn't necessarily spell the end of the iPhone's market dominance, said Ross Rubin, an analyst with the NPD Group, a research firm. According to an NPD survey, the five top-selling smartphones from Jan. 1 to March 31 were the BlackBerry Curve, the Apple iPhone 3G, the BlackBerry Storm, the BlackBerry Pearl (not including the Pearl Flip) and the T-Mobile G1 using the Android operating system.

headline: Verizon Wireless and Broadcom in Deal
summary: Verizon Wireless will pay the Broadcom Corporation as much as $200 million to bypass a possible ban on some handsets that use Qualcomm chips. The agreement will give Verizon Wireless the right to use a patent found to have been infringed by Qualcomm, the companies said in a statement yesterday. Verizon Communications and the Vodafone Group jointly own Verizon Wireless.

headline: Bedbugs Bad for Business? Depends on the Business
summary: Recent reports that bedbugs have infiltrated office buildings, movie theaters and stores in New York did not come as a surprise to Wes Tyler, general manager of the Chancellor Hotel on Union Square in San Francisco. ''Short of putting a bedbug-sniffing beagle at your door to check everyone before they come in, you're going to get bedbugs,'' he said. ''Dealing with them is the cost of doing business these days.''

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: SEVERE RECESSION ANXIETY Fear that the United States is in a recession is reverberating around the world as stock markets plummeted and took with it the hopes of many investors that Europe and Asia will be able to avoid an American downturn. [Page 1A.] For investors lured to overseas markets by the promise that growth and solid economic fundamentals in Asia and the Middle East would protect them from the credit squeeze in the United States, a realization that an American recession and the fallout from subprime loans will have global repercussions. [C1.]

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Lynd, Susan
summary: LYND--Susan Crosby Thompson, 66, died August 16, 2009 in hospice at Scarborough, ME. She and her husband Richard B. Lynd had lived in Brooklyn Heights for 36 years before retiring to Susan's childhood home near Albany in 2003. She was the daughter of the late William Leland Thompson Jr. of East Greenbush, NY and the late Maris Wistar (Townsend) Thompson of Bryn Mawr, PA. She studied at Chatham Hall, Colby and Firenze. Susan worked for thirty-three years for TIME and LIFE, the last twenty-six at TIME, rising to News Desk Manager. She loved her home, her garden, her "Bear", her "Wiglet", cooking, swimming, and especially her Westies, "Gus" and "Agnes." For 55 years she enjoyed her summer times in Kennebunkport. With enormous courage Susan for three years maintained the life she wanted despite a struggle with cancer. She is survived by her husband, Richard, (email: windward22@ verizon.net), her sister Maris Wistar Thompson, many cousins, godchildren, loved ones and friends. A graveside memorial service will be held in late October at the Church of the Redeemer, Bryn Mawr, PA. Contributions in Susan's memory to Gosnell Memorial Hospice, 11 Hunnewell Rd., Scarborough, ME 04074 would be appreciated. Services are in care of Bibber Memorial Chapel, 67 Summer Street, Kennebunk, ME 04043. www.bibberfuneral.com

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: BID FOR DOW JONES CRITICIZED -- Members of the Ottaway family, which owns a minority stake in Dow Jones & Company, released scathing statements yesterday saying that a takeover by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation would ruin Dow Jones and its crown jewel, The Wall Street Journal. [Page C1.] INVESTORS ASSIST PENTAGON -- The Defense Department is using some of the nation's top technology investors to help it find innovations from tiny start-up companies, which have not traditionally been a part of the military's vast supply chain. [C1.] CELLPHONE ADVERTISING LAGS -- Short multi-episode cellphone series, like the ''Smallville Legends'' series from Warner Brothers Television Group, are growing in popularity. But advertising, which studios rely on for profit, been slow to migrate to the supersmall screen. [C1.] 3-D PRINTING AT HOME -- In a few years, it will be possible to download three-dimensional plans online, then push the print button. Hours later, a solid object -- a replica of the lost battery cover for your cellphone, perhaps -- will be ready to remove from your printer. [C1.] NEW ABSURDITY IN VIOLENCE -- In the last couple of weeks, the ''Lazy Sunday'' parody on ''Saturday Night Live'' has been supplanted by something even more viral and revealing of the popular mindscape. On YouTube it has been given the tag ''SNLOCmeme.'' Link by Link. [C4.] REPLAY THAT PLAYOFF GAME -- The National Basketball Association is preparing to announce a new video download store that allows fans to download playoff games from this season and last for $3 apiece. E-Commerce Report: Bob Tedeschi [C9.] AN ALMA MATER CELLPHONE? -- A start-up company called Sonopia is trying to apply the concept of affinity groups to the cellphone market, as banks have long done with credit cards. Instead of sharing space on the screen with a brand name like Sprint, Verizon or T-Mobile, an alumni association or nonprofit group can put its own logo on the phone. [C7.] JOURNALISTS TO SUE HEWLETT -- In an unusual step for the news media, three journalists whose private phone records were scrutinized by investigators working for Hewlett-Packard intend to sue the company for invasion of privacy. [C4.] BID FOR QANTAS FALTERS -- Qantas Airways said that it considered a takeover bid for the airline to have failed after regulators refused to step in and save it. But the bidder, a private equity-backed group named Airline Partners Australia, said it would appeal the regulators' decision. [C4.] RECORD FIRST, PRINT LATER -- Audio books are fast, inexpensive and easy to record, leading publishers to look to the audio format to fuel interest in paper books that are not quite ready for the printing press, like one from Mignon Fogarty, above, who is host of a popular podcast called Grammar Girl. [C6.] LIMIT ON CREDIT SCORE CLAIMS -- A proposed settlement of a class-action lawsuit means that Suze Orman, the personal finance guru, can no longer claim that the credit-score kit with her name and face on it can actually improve the creditworthiness of the person who buys it. [C6.] OPRAH'S PRESIDENTIAL PICKS -- Oprah Winfrey's book club can catapult titles to the top of best-seller lists, but does her magic touch extend to the realm of presidential politics? Last week, for the first time, Ms. Winfrey endorsed a political candidate, Senator Barack Obama, Democrat from Illinois. [C6.] INFLUENTIAL WHO? -- Time magazine declared ''You'' the person of the year, paying homage to everyone who had blogged or contributed to sites like YouTube, MySpace and Wikipedia. This year Time again reached out to ''You,'' asking the online community to choose the most influential person in the world. The winner was Rain, a 24-year-old South Korean singer whose real name is Jung Ji-hoon. [C6.] AUTOMATED RADIO RATINGS -- Philadelphia is the first American city to abandon the pen-and-ink diary system of collecting radio ratings data. Philadelphians being surveyed by Arbitron, the ratings-measurement firm, now wear pager-size devices that register hidden audio tones in nearby radio sound. [C4.]

headline: Operating Profit Falls at Times Co.
summary: The New York Times Company said today that its second-quarter operating profit fell because of weakness in newspaper advertising but that net income doubled because of a gain from the sale of its television stations. Highlighting the challenge faced by the entire newspaper industry as ad dollars shift away from newspapers to the Internet, the company also said it plans to cut operating costs by $230 million over the next two years.

headline: Netflix-Verizon feud slows video
summary: A standoff between Netflix and broadband providers like Verizon is reportedly behind a slowdown in streaming time for Netflix's video service. Fred Katayama reports.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Jaffe, Phyllis S.
summary: JAFFE--Phyllis S., an early practitioner of education labor law and wife of the late Frederick Jaffe, died at home in Ossining, NY, on December 22, 2008. She was 83. Mrs. Jaffe served in the Women's Army Corps during WWll, graduated from Columbia Law School in 1949, and served as the president of the Ossining Board of Education 1966-69. Mrs. Jaffe led Plunkett and Jaffe's Westchester County office from 1975 until her retirement in 2003. Her cases included Immediato v. Rye Neck School District in which the U.S. Supreme Court upheld the right of high schools to require community service as a graduation requirement. Mrs. Jaffe was preceded in death by her brother Edwin Shelley. She is survived by and will be missed by her sons Paul, David (wife Leslie); and Rick (wife Kim) four grandchildren, Dara, Gary, Eli and Julian; her brother, Heywood, (wife Maritza), their daughter and granddaughter; and sister-in-law Florence, her children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. Donations can be made in the name of Phyllis Jaffe to The Clear View School (serving children with special needs), 480 Albany Post Road, Briarcliff Manor, NY 10510. The family (pauljaffe@verizon.net) is planning a memorial service to be held at a later date.
