[C4] NICKELODEON'S NEW SITE -- Nickelodeon, the popular children's cable network, is starting a new Web site, aimed at children aged 6 to 14, that plays heavily to their appetite for games. [C10.] A PLANELOAD OF ANGRY FLIERS -- After weather delays in Dallas on Dec. 29, American Airlines diverted Flight 1348 to Austin, Tex. There it sat, with 100 or so passengers aboard, for 9 1/2 hours. Now those passengers are fighting back. On the Road: Joe Sharkey. [C8.] HOTEL MENUS ARE CHANGING -- With an eye to keeping up with their guests' increasingly sophisticated palates, nonstop work schedules and desire for healthful meals, many hotels are offering many more options for the discerning traveler ordering room service. Everything from smoothies to a breakfast you can eat on a plane are offered. [C8.] STICKING TO YOUR GUNS -- Nothing gives your principles a workout like a business trip. Taking a stand for what you believe is not easy when you're traveling, but can be rewarding. Frequent Flier. [C9.] ONLINE VIEW FROM THE TOP -- Some top-performing fund managers recently talked about some of their stocks and offered their thoughts about the year ahead. You can check their returns and read their philosophies at nytimes.com/business. MORE THAN MERE ADS -- Times Square isn't just for billboards anymore -- advertisers are turning to on-the-ground marketing stunts to grab attention. An audio slide show is at nytimes.com/business. A CORPSMAN IN IRAQ -- C. J. Chivers travels with Weapons Company, Second Battalion, Eighth Marines and reports on a sniper shooting in Anbar. Audio and photos are at nytimes.com/multimedia. SPEAK, MEMORY -- A 1930s diary, fished out of a Dumpster, brings to vivid life the world of a New York teenager. An audio report and photos are at nytimes.com/multimedia.

headline: Today in Business
summary: SECURITIES BACKUP FUND With agreement among the country's three largest banks on how to structure a $75 billion fund to prop up distressed securities, the big question becomes, will it help? PRINCE'S BONUSCharles O. Prince III, who resigned as chairman and chief executive of Citigroup, can expect a cash bonus of at least $12.5 million, determined largely on his performance in 2006 rather than a less-than-stellar 2007. [C5.]

headline: AOL Chief on Verizon Deal
summary: Tim Armstrong, chief executive of AOL, on Arianna Huffington’s role at the Huffington Post after the Verizon deal closes.

headline: VONAGE CHIEF RETURNS
summary: THE flameout of the radio host Don Imus dominated the discourse this week, but there was other intrigue, including what Dow Chemical said were unauthorized merger talks held by two of its officials and the continuing investigation into the practices of student loan companies. Vonage Holdings, the Internet telephone company, announced that Jeffrey A. Citron had returned temporarily to run the company he founded seven years ago. Michael F. Snyder, chief executive since January 2006, also resigned his board seat, amid growing concern that Vonage's battle with Verizon was starting to take a toll.

headline: It's a Phone, It's a Laptop, It's a Fast and Fancy Atrix
summary: If there has been a muted response to what is arguably the most powerful mobile phone currently made - the Atrix - it may be due to its parentage. The phone comes from Motorola. The once-mighty Motorola dominated the mobile phone market quarter after quarter with products like the reliable and stylish Razr, but was knocked off its pedestal by the iPhone.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths KLUND, JEFFRY
summary: KLUND--Jeffry, 68, born LaCrosse, WI, retired from Verizon HQ to Sun City West, AZ. Died June 9, 2010.

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONALA3-17 U.S. Witnesses Say Guard Continued Firing

headline: Popular Demand
summary: Research in Motion, the company that makes the BlackBerry Storm phone, above, announced a share buyback last week, after weak third-quarter results led to a drop in the stock price. The Storm, and its successor, Storm 2, released in mid-October, work on Verizon's network and were meant to compete with Apple's iPhone. Some 23.8 million users owned touch-screen phones in August, an increase of 159 percent from August 2008. Still, it seems the iPhone, with a larger share than the next four competitors combined, has an insurmountable lead. SHELLY FREIERMAN

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONALA3-9 Musharraf Sets No Date To End Emergency Rule

headline: Verizon Wins Cheap Bandwidth
summary: Verizon Wins Cheap Bandwidth An analysis of last week's government's auction of wireless spectrum shows that Verizon got the best deals, beating its rival, AT&T.

headline: A Pocket Darkroom, With LED Flash, That Also Makes Calls
summary: HTC has designed a phone for people who like to take pictures with a phone. It has just announced the modestly named Droid Incredible, which pairs an 8 megapixel camera with a bright 3.7-inch AMOLED screen. AMOLED screens - for Active Matrix Organic Light-Emitting Diode -- are known for their bright colors and fine detail, as well as for low power consumption.

headline: Spending More on Cellphones
summary: Nowhere is the relentless reduction in prices for technology products more visible than in the cellphone market. It seems that only months pass from the time a phone is offered for sale at $300 to the point that it is ready to be given away free in cereal boxes. (O.K., not quite, but that's not a bad marketing idea.) What's odd is that people are actually spending more on cellphones than they did a year ago, according to new data from the NPD Group. Americans bought 38 million phones in the third quarter, up only 4 percent from the third quarter of 2006. But they spent a total of $3.2 billion on those phones, up from $2.2 billion a year earlier.

headline: Inside The Times
summary: International OPPORTUNITY BECKONS IN IRAQ'S KURDISH REGION

headline: Inside The Times
summary: international U.S. AND CHINESE OFFICIALS AGREE TO CONTINUE TALKING

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: DARK SCENARIOS As the economy continues to show signs of a slowdown, many financial experts say a recession could dig deeper and last longer, even into next year. HEADLINE NEWS Rupert Murdoch, the chairman of the News Corporation, and two other moguls are reportedly interested in buying the Long Island newspaper Newsday from the Tribune Company. [C1.]

headline: What Companies Are Doing With Their Savings From the Tax Law
summary: The tax overhaul has prompted hundreds of employers, including at least 40 members of the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index, to pass on savings to workers.

headline: ADDENDA
summary: Verizon Consolidates Agencies And Adds Wireless Assignments In one of the largest recent account consolidations, Verizon Communications is combining duties for its consumer and business services with assignments for Verizon Wireless to increase effectiveness and efficiency. Verizon, which spends about $1.9 billion a year on advertising, will reduce its agency roster to 10 from more than 20. Gaining the most in the consolidation is the McCann Worldgroup division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. For instance, McCann Erickson Worldwide, which creates ads for Verizon Wireless, gains the consumer assignment from McGarry Bowen in New York and the business assignment from Euro RSCG Worldwide in New York, part of Havas.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: BUSH MOVES ON FLIGHT DELAYS President Bush ordered transportation officials to work with airline executives to reduce flight delays, beginning in New York. Options being considered include capping the number of flights and allowing airports to charge higher fees to airlines for landing at the busiest times of the day. CHINESE LINK TO STEROIDS

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: FED CUTS INTEREST RATE Hoping to stabilize the financial markets, the Federal Reserve lowered its federal funds rate by three-quarters of a percentage point, to 2.25 percent. How is it that a mess in subprime loans has left the economy on the brink of the worst recession in a generation? Economic Scene: David Leonhardt. [A1.]

headline: On a TV Near You, Some New Competition
summary: To the Editor: Re ''A Wiring War Among Giants'' (Dec. 10):

headline: Thousands of Verizon Employees Strike
summary: Close to 36,000 Verizon workers on the East Coast have gone on strike after the company and two unions failed to reach an agreement on Wednesday. This is one of the largest strikes in recent years.

headline: Arts, Briefly; No Parthenon in Ads
summary: The Greek government said yesterday that Verizon Communications had agreed to scrap an advertisement featuring a photograph of the Parthenon. The Greek culture minister, George Voulgarakis, had accused Verizon of ''commercial exploitation'' of that 2,500-year-old temple in a print advertisement published in the American edition of The Financial Times. Greece bans commercial use of images of its ancient monuments unless authorized by the country's supreme archaeological council. ANTHEE CARASSAVA

headline: Popular Demand
summary: Research in Motion, the company that makes the BlackBerry Storm phone, above, announced a share buyback last week, after weak third-quarter results led to a drop in the stock price. The Storm, and its successor, Storm 2, released in mid-October, work on Verizon's network and were meant to compete with Apple's iPhone. Some 23.8 million users owned touch-screen phones in August, an increase of 159 percent from August 2008. Still, it seems the iPhone, with a larger share than the next four competitors combined, has an insurmountable lead. SHELLY FREIERMAN

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONALA3-12 Wave of Cuban Migrants

headline: On a TV Near You, Some New Competition
summary: To the Editor: Re ''A Wiring War Among Giants'' (Dec. 10): I applaud the fact that Verizon and AT&T are moving into the television business. Few companies have been able to create monopolies in their industries, but unfortunately the cable companies have been able to do just that.

headline: INSIDE THE TIMES: February 2, 2009
summary: INTERNATIONAL TOLL IN KENYA EXPLOSION

headline: Really, Really Short Workouts
summary: Think you’re too busy to work out? We have the workout for you. In minutes, high-intensity interval training (H.I.I.T.) will have you sweating, breathing hard and maximizing the health benefits of exercise without the time commitment. Best of all, it’s scientifically proven to work.

headline: Today in Business
summary: LITTLE INVESTMENT, LITTLE RISK The biggest banks in the United States, with active encouragement from the Treasury Department, have announced a plan to keep the housing-related debt crisis from worsening -- taking little risk and not actually investing any of their own money. AN ASSIST FROM TREASURY Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., left, and other top Treasury officials are pushing Wall Street and the mortgage industry to come up with solutions to the credit crunch -- and helping devise some of them as well. [C1.]

headline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Officials Support Union Effort
summary: City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. and Representatives Jerrold Nadler and Anthony D. Weiner put their weight behind an effort to unionize 362 Verizon telephone workers yesterday, confirming that a majority of the workers had signed cards saying they wanted to join the Communications Workers of America. The three political leaders confirmed that 219 of the 362 workers had signed pro-union cards as union officials called on Verizon to grant union recognition because of this majority showing. But Verizon is invoking its right under federal law to ask for a secret-ballot election overseen by the National Labor Relations Board to determine whether a majority wants a union. The 362 employees, who install telephone equipment for businesses, work for a unit called Verizon Business. They worked for MCI before Verizon acquired MCI last year. The group was not unionized under MCI. STEVEN GREENHOUSE

headline: In Galleon Trial, Arguing Greed Vs. a Picture of Diligent Research
summary: ''Greed and corruption - that's what this case is all about,'' a federal prosecutor said on Wednesday at the trial of Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire hedge fund manager accused of being at the center of a huge insider trading ring. Mr. Rajaratnam's lawyer countered that ''the government has it wrong,'' portraying his client as one who made his fortune through ''shoe-leather research, diligence and hard work'' and who ''conducted the best research in the business.''

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: MARKETS GET RATTLED Shares tumbled after the head of AT&T suggested that consumers may be cutting back and Countrywide Financial denied that it was tumbling into bankruptcy. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.84 percent, its lowest close since March 5. WHERE'S THE MONEY? The Federal Trade Commission, concerned that some marketing assertions on environmental causes are not substantiated, held a hearing to address where the $54 million spent last year by businesses and shoppers on carbon offset credits had been spent. [C1.]

headline: Accelerate Android With Tips And Tricks
summary: Mobile phones that run Google's Android operating system come in various shapes, sizes and features, unlike Apple's iPhones. And while iPhone buyers are limited to AT&T and Verizon service, Android phones are also available from Sprint, T-Mobile and Boost Mobile, where a data plan can cost as little as $35 a month. But despite the variety of Android phones, and of carriers, there are a lot of useful features common to all. Here are some tips on finding them:

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths QUINTAS, PARQUET, DAVID
summary: QUINTAS-PARQUET--David, October 5, 1949 to June 27, 2007. David's bereaved family and friends announce a Memorial Mass for their beloved brother, uncle, partner and friend at The Lady Chapel behind the main altar of St. Patrick's Cathedral, (50th St. and 5th Ave.) on September 14, 2007 at 4pm. David's diverse professional career with Verizon spanned more than 30 years. When he retired he was serving as Community Affairs Manager for Queens, overseeing stakeholder relations, philanthropy, issues management and economic development initiatives, along with special projects involving education, healthcare and Hispanic affairs. All of the artistic, political, healthcare and community groups he supported in his life are too numerous to name. He had a great heart and a burning passion for social justice. Memorial donations to Hispanic AIDS Forum, 213 West 35th St., NY, NY 10001 and The American Run for the End of AIDS, 2350 Broadway, NY, NY 10024.

headline: Verizon offers free mobile TV
summary: Verizon's "go90" mobile app will stream web and TV programming for free to all users. It's supported by advertising. Fred Katayama reports.

headline: ARENAS SENTENCING FRIDAY
summary: Gilbert Arenas of the Washington Wizards is scheduled to be sentenced on Friday for a felony count of carrying a pistol outside his home without a license. In preparation, both sides filed court memorandums on Tuesday. Prosecutors recommended that Arenas serve three months in jail, according to The Washington Post. Arenas pleaded guilty on Jan. 15 to storing four unloaded guns in the Wizards' locker room at the Verizon Center, and using them in a joke with his teammate Javaris Crittenton. As part of his plea agreement, prosecutors filed only a single gun possession charge. The Post reported that the Assistant United States Attorney Christopher R. Kavanaugh was seeking a jail sentence because Arenas provided inconsistencies in his dealings with prosecutors and showed little remorse other than how the incident impacted his career. ''If any other individual without fame, power and the wealth of this defendant, brought four firearms into the District for the purpose of a similar confrontation, the government would seek their incarceration and the court would almost certainly give it,'' Kavanaugh wrote, according to The Post.

headline: Videoconference In the Home
summary: So, there's kind of clunky but blissfully free PC video chat on Skype and any number of other Web services. And now there's superhigh-quality chat over your TV from Cisco for $898.88, for a year of service. On Wednesday, Cisco unveiled its long-awaited Umi (you-me) videoconferencing system aimed at consumers. The Umi rig includes a camera that fits on the top of a high-definition TV and a rectangular appliance that connects to the TV and Internet, while also handling the processing of the video data. The hardware costs $599, while Cisco's calling service will cost $24.99 a month.

headline: U.N. Gridlock Hard on Nerves And Eardrums
summary: So how bad was it yesterday -- the traffic, that is -- on the busiest day of the meeting of world leaders at the United Nations? Police Officer Clyde Williams, who gives a lot of thought to such things, advised against looking at the obvious: Do not count cars or track the labyrinth of road closings dotting Manhattan's East Side. Do not pay undue attention to the 45-minute backup at the 63rd Street exit of the southbound Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive or to the simultaneous swarms of limousines outside Radio City Music Hall (stars attending the MTV awards) and the Metropolitan Museum of Art (dignitaries attending President Clinton's goodbye bash).

headline: AN AVENGER'S PATH: A special report.; Lawyer in Holocaust Case Faces Litany of Complaints
summary: Less than four years ago, a little-known personal-injury lawyer named Edward D. Fagan stood next to an Auschwitz survivor at a news conference in New York and announced an audacious lawsuit, accusing Swiss banks of stealing money 50 years ago from those who died in the Holocaust. Today, Mr. Fagan has a new and glamorous career and is likely soon to earn millions of dollars in legal fees. He has since filed lawsuits against banks, insurers and other companies in Austria, Germany and elsewhere, charging that they too profited from Nazi ties or exploited victims. Settlements of actions against Swiss banks and German industry worth over $6.2 billion were recently approved.

headline: With Some Victories in Hand, Battered Labor Flexes Muscle
summary: It has been a big month for big labor, judging from the bargaining results at some of the nation's best-known companies. Bridgestone/Firestone, the embattled tire maker, averted a strike earlier this week by granting its 8,000 workers raises that will run from 15 percent to 30 percent over three years -- raises that are far above the inflation rate.

headline: Verizon to Grant Stock Options to Most Workers
summary: Verizon Communications said in a statement yesterday that it would grant 210,000 employees options to buy 55 million shares of stock, giving them a stake in the telephone carrier's financial performance. The ''founders' grant'' options are priced at $43.34 a share, about equal to the current share price, according to the company, which was formed this year by the merger of Bell Atlantic and the GTE Corporation. The options will vest in three years.

headline: Business; A Not-So-Little Phone Company From Little Rock
summary: A FAVORITE story of Joe T. Ford, chairman and chief executive of the Alltel Corporation, involves a real yet proverbial little old lady. He tells it to every new group of employees. Back in 1948, Alltel, then known as Allied Telephone, bought a group of tiny independent phone companies in southwest Arkansas, including one in the hamlet of Amity. ''It had 200, maybe 250 customers,'' Mr. Ford recalled. It also had an employee named Edna Nunn, who, despite being restricted to a wheelchair by childhood polio, operated the company's manual switchboard, collected all its bills and handled customer complaints.

headline: Those Raises, Adjusted for Oil Inflation, Are a Mirage
summary: HARDLY any description of the booming economy fails to include this upbeat observation: Wages have been rising faster than inflation for most workers since January 1996. The boom has lifted all boats, and that is its great social gift. But this year, hardly noticed until now, the lifting stopped. Wages are still rising, but no longer faster than inflation.

headline: A Chronicle of Uneasy Access
summary: FOR the last six months, I have been stalled on the entrance ramp to the information superhighway. Back in February I signed up for my very own digital subscriber line, or D.S.L., an Internet connection so fast that it leaves last century's must have, the 56K modem, in the dust. At least that's what the ads say. When and if I ever get D.S.L., I hope it's faster than the companies that supply it. The arc of all technology is from indulgent to indispensable. In between there is an interminable moment when everyone must have ''it'' but not everyone can get ''it,'' when the potential becomes bogged down by the infrastructure. That's why we all listened to endless busy signals on AOL several years ago.. And now that we've all become more computer savvy -- spoiled by ISDN lines and T-1 lines at the office and impatient to bring that speed home -- many of us have war stories to tell about the wait for D.S.L.

headline: Metro Business; Employment Fell During Phone Strike
summary: The number of people working in New York fell sharply in August, but government economists attributed most of the decline to striking telephone workers. In New York City, the number of private-sector jobs fell by 11,400 last month, according to an analysis by the city comptroller's office, which adjusts the figures for seasonal factors. But if it had not been for the temporary loss of 17,800 jobs because of the strike against Verizon, formerly Bell Atlantic, the job count would have risen. Government jobs declined for the third month as census workers were laid off.

headline: UNEMPLOYMENT UP
summary: New Jersey's unemployment rate rose to 4.0 percent in August, up from 3.7 percent in July. The national unemployment rate was 4.1 percent. According to the New Jersey Department of Labor, jobs in the private sector rose by 2,000 employees despite the Verizon workers' strike, while 2,800 government employees lost their jobs because of the completion of the census. John Holl

headline: The Values Statement vs. Corporate Reality
summary: At the heart of the recently settled strike between Verizon Communications and its telecommunications workers were the high stress levels experienced by service representatives. One possible culprit -- and something not explicitly addressed by the settlement -- was the fact that a companywide values statement clashed with reality in the area of customer service. The conundrum is common in business: How can a company ensure that a stated set of values, put into place to help drive it forward, does not conflict with that goal or with how employees are treated?

headline: As Hot Economy Pushes Up Overtime, Fatigue Becomes a Labor Issue
summary: In his last two and a half days of life, Brent Churchill slept a total of five hours. The rest of the time he was working. Mr. Churchill, a lineman on call one stormy weekend for Central Maine Power, worked two back-to-back shifts on Friday, went to bed at 10:30 p.m., was called back at 1 a.m. Saturday, caught a quick nap around dawn and went back to his job clambering up and down poles for almost 24 hours straight. Taking a break for breakfast on Sunday morning, he got yet another call.

headline: 'Dr. Laura' Pulls In Weak Ratings and Ads
summary: The marketers that did not buy commercial time on Dr. Laura Schlessinger's new syndicated daytime television show may want to thank the gay and lesbian activists who pressured them to bypass the show. The series so far seems to be as big a miss with viewers as it has been with advertisers. Throughout the summer, activists urged marketers not to support ''Dr. Laura,'' which went on the air last Monday on more than 200 stations across the country, because of what they deemed hurtful and harmful remarks about homosexuals by Dr. Schlessinger on her radio show. As a result, virtually all the big packaged-goods and retail advertisers that typically buy spots on daytime talk shows did not become sponsors.

headline: Verizon Awards Work To Burrell Agency
summary: Verizon Communications, formerly Bell Atlantic, has named the Burrell Communications Group in Chicago, 49 percent owned by the Publicis Groupe S.A., to handle its brand introduction campaign. Spending was estimated at $20 million to $30 million. John Bonomo, a spokesman at Verizon Communications in New York, said the decision came after a three-month informal consideration of Burrell and four other Verizon roster agencies: Arnold Communications in Boston, part of Snyder Communications, which is being acquired by Havas Advertising; the Lord Group in New York, a joint venture of Dentsu Inc. and Young & Rubicam Inc., which agreed to be acquired by the WPP Group; the Dallas office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of WPP; and Temerlin McClain in Irving, Tex., part of True North Communications.

headline: As New Geeks Seek Chic, Gadgets Get Fashionable
summary: LAUREL WELLS, a co-founder and the marketing director of Gurl.com, an Internet magazine for teenagers, is a study in bohemian chic. Dressed in a raspberry silk shirt from India, her hair a nimbus of coppery curls, she looks like an anti-geek, not at all the type you would expect to be besotted with gadgetry.

headline: Boring 50 Percent of the People 80 Percent of the Time, or Vice Versa
summary: PERHAPS it would interest you to know that during the first quarter of this year, 50.4 percent of Internet users were women. You might be intrigued by the recent news that the number of people who visited Gov. George W. Bush's official Web site, www.georgewbush.com, soared 522 percent after a new version opened last month. Or maybe you will find it fascinating to learn that the money spent on business-to-business online advertising is expected to reach $3 billion by 2005. Then again, you may not care in the least.

headline: Food; A Taste for Seduction
summary: My first writing jobs were for the David Frost and Dick Cavett talk shows -- which were extremely exciting because whatever I wrote was usually seen the very night I wrote it on national television. This instant gratification spoiled me. When I was, ahem, excused from the Cavett show and began to write plays and movies, there was either no feedback at all or it would dribble in months after the work was completed. I don't have now, and didn't have then, the inner reserves of self-confidence to shore up a fathomless need for reinforcement, so I took up cooking. It was creative, sensual, filled my tiny apartment with wonderful smells and became a much-admired way to avoid writing. And the reinforcement was as instantaneous as a daily talk show, unless I was preparing thousand-year-old eggs.

headline: High-Speed Web Access Creeping Along
summary: Kevin Newman knew that his small Chelsea advertising company could not be competitive while relying on slow-speed computer modems. The company designs Web pages that often include streaming video and animated graphics. But its dial-up modems, which received data over regular telephone lines, were so slow that it often took minutes to get online access to some of the Web pages his employees had created. So last year, Mr. Newman ordered four high-speed Internet digital subscriber lines, or D.S.L.'s, from Bell Atlantic for his ad agency, the William H. Brown Company. Sometimes, he wishes he had not. ''There would be days I would come in when I had no phone lines and no Internet access at all,'' he said last week.

headline: Verizon Wireless Offers Free Phones
summary: Verizon Wireless Inc., the largest United States mobile-phone company, said yesterday that it would give customers who choose two-year contracts for digital cellular service new phones at no cost when they renew their service agreements. The program, called New Every Two, is intended to retain customers for longer periods while letting them keep up with new technology, Verizon Wireless said.

headline: Suffolk Votes to Ban Cell Phones on the Road
summary: The county that could be considered Cell Phone Central -- home of the Hamptons and other enclaves where the phones are as popular on playgrounds as at poolside -- moved last night to curb the use of the phones in cars. In a 12-to-6 vote, the Suffolk County Legislature made driving with a hand-held cell phone a crime, carrying a $150 fine. Officials said that even if the county executive, Robert J. Gaffney, vetoed the bill, there were enough votes to override the veto.

headline: Ground Zero, an agency founded on the West Coast, is now expanding to New York.
summary: A creatively focused Los Angeles agency is opening in New York with ambitious plans for the new outpost to someday be much larger than the home office. The agency is Ground Zero, a six-year-old shop in Marina del Rey that handles accounts with billings estimated at $95 million to $100 million for clients like the Atlantis resort in the Bahamas, part of Sun International; the ESPN cable network owned by the Walt Disney Company; Gloss.com, part of Estee Lauder; iXL Enterprises, an Internet consultant; and The Los Angeles Times, owned by the Tribune Company.

headline: Treasuries Are Mixed; Analysts Focus on Oil and Job Outlook
summary: Bond prices were mixed yesterday, a day after the Federal Reserve left short-term interest rates unchanged but reaffirmed its belief that low unemployment and high oil prices could lead to higher inflation.

headline: Speaking in Bar Code; Personal Scanners Link Products Directly to Consumers
summary: Most shoppers at the Virgin Megastore in Times Square who listen to cuts of, say, Macy Gray's new album, ''On How Life Is,'' essentially have two choices if they want to buy it: purchase the CD there for $17.99 or walk out and search elsewhere. But up-to-the-minute shoppers equipped with Verizon cellular phones capable of connecting to the Internet have another option. They can click on the icon for BarPoint.com Inc., an Internet database service, and punch in the CD's bar code. Those digits, unique to each product, can now be used as a shortcut to find a range of product-specific information: other CD's by the artists, for example, snippets of reviews, or exactly how much it costs at online stores. Later this year, BarPoint.com promises to list prices from the music store down the street as well.

headline: Jobless Rate Fell to 3.9% In September
summary: Unemployment fell to 3.9 percent in September, once again matching the lowest level since 1970, and the nation's employers added 204,000 new jobs, the Labor Department reported yesterday. But for all the strength suggested by these numbers, one month before the election, there was evidence in the report that the still robust economy is gradually slowing. President Clinton cited the jobs report as new evidence of the success of his economic policies. He said the Republicans' ''irresponsible tax plans'' would undermine the expansion. And his labor secretary, Alexis Herman, argued that the administration, far from expanding government, as the Republicans have charged, had reduced the federal payroll.

headline: Financial and Technology Stocks Send Markets Lower
summary: Stocks plunged yesterday, led by declines in financial and technology stocks, as investors worried about corporate earnings disappointments and dismissed what was generally a positive employment report for September. Despite a small rally at the end of the day, the Nasdaq composite index fell 3.2 percent, or 111.09 points, to 3,361.01, and is off 17.4 percent for the year. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 1.9 percent, or 27.29 points, to 1,408.99, and is off 4.1 percent for the year. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.2 percent, or 128.38 points, to 10,596.54, and is down 7.83 percent for the year.

headline: So, Who Wants Long Distance If Even AT&T Spurns It?
summary: IN his heart of hearts, C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman and chief executive of AT&T, still probably wants folks to phone home. But if he has his way, they will do so on someone else's network. Last week, Ma Bell said that it was considering various ways to get rid of its consumer long-distance business, through a sale to another carrier or a spinoff to shareholders.

headline: SBC Is Going National With Its Local Service
summary: East Wareham, Mass., near the Cape Cod canal about an hour south of Boston, is not generally known as one of the telecommunications industry's hotbeds of competition. But do not tell that to Gary D. Powers. Mr. Powers is president of Abbey Glass, a small glass installer and distributor in East Wareham. His company, with nine employees and perhaps a half-dozen phones, is also a pioneer of what could be the most ambitious plan yet to give consumers and businesses across the country a choice in local communications providers.

headline: Loans Tightening to Young and Deeply Indebted Businesses
summary: As the stock market gyrates and rumors are heard about Wall Street firms' incurring losses on high-yield bonds, investment worries are spreading to new markets. A quiet credit squeeze is under way for the most heavily indebted corporate borrowers. Banks and other companies are increasingly wary of lending to start-up businesses, companies undertaking leveraged buyouts and other leveraged enterprises. The volume of new loans to such companies, which typically carry bond ratings below investment grade, was 25 percent lower in the first nine months of this year than it was in the corresponding period a year earlier, according to S & P/Portfolio Management Data, an affiliate of Standard & Poor's.

headline: VERIZON RAISES STAKE IN WEST COAST COMPANY
summary: The nation's largest wireless carrier, Verizon Wireless, will increase its stake in Sacramento Valley L.P., a company that serves several cities in Nevada and Northern California. Under the terms of the transaction, Verizon Wireless will pay $236 million to acquire 24.2 percent of Sacramento Valley from Roseville Communications of Roseville, Calif., effectively increasing its interest in the company to more than 76 percent. Sacramento Valley serves an area with 3.8 million potential customers, including the cities of Sacramento and Modesto in California and Reno, Nev. Simon Romero

headline: Vodafone Said to Be in Talks To Buy Irish Wireless Stake
summary: The Vodafone Group is in talks with Eircom, Ireland's telecommunications conglomerate, about taking a majority stake in or buying all of Eircell, its mobile subsidiary, people close to the discussions said today. A bid for all of Eircell would probably be valued at 5 billion euros, or about $4.3 billion, these people said -- more than 80 percent of the market value of the entire parent company. Discussions with Vodafone, which began in September, are likely to be completed within the next month, a person close to Eircom said.

headline: U.S. May Pressure Landlords to Allow Digital Competition
summary: The Federal Communications Commission is considering issuing new rules today that would take a step toward forcing commercial landlords to open their buildings to almost any communications carrier that wants access to their tenants, according to people close to the commission. As new forms of digital communication have swept the nation and hundreds of companies have emerged to provide them, landlords of apartment buildings and office towers have had an almost inviolable right to determine which companies may set up shop inside their properties. Now that may begin to change. Government officials and industry executives said commission members and their staffs were still battling over the proposals yesterday afternoon and it was possible the F.C.C. could postpone any action. But whether the issue is addressed today or in the near future, the battle lines have been drawn. Consider 450 Lexington Avenue in Manhattan, a building near 44th Street that includes the offices of Davis Polk & Wardwell, a law firm, and Cline Davis & Mann, an advertising agency. Hines Interests, the building's manager, holds stakes in Broadband Office and Allied Riser Communications, young companies that wire office buildings and offer advanced communications services. Hines has allowed the two to install equipment at 450 Lexington and has yet to give other carriers the same access. Davis Polk and Cline Davis refused to comment, as did Broadband Office. But communications companies that think they are being shut out, as well as some consumer advocates, have not hesitated to attack a system they say is unfair. ''Given the paucity of local communications competition that has emerged since the telecommunications deregulation act of 1996, it's absolutely critical to use every mechanism possible to jump-start greater consumer access to multiple telecommunications providers,'' Gene Kimmelman, co-director of the Washington office of Consumers Union, said yesterday. ''This would be one step forward for breaking down barriers to local competition.'' Others see the matter differently. ''To us, a building is a community,'' said Steve Peterson, a vice president at Hines, a commercial real estate company based in Houston. ''In Texas alone there are 419 registered CLEC's,'' he added, using industry jargon for competitive local exchange carriers. ''Can we have 419 carriers and their equipment in our building? The answer is no.'' ''We're not trying to exclude anybody,'' he said. ''But we want to make sure that all of the carriers are there for the long haul, and yes, we want to maintain a little bit of control over the process. It's our building, after all.'' The Telecommunications Act of 1996 directs the commission to foster increased competition in local markets, and the F.C.C. chairman, William E. Kennard, a Democrat, has made that a primary goal. But realizing that any attempt to exert direct jurisdiction over landlords would be fraught with political and perhaps legal difficulties, the commission appeared to be leaning toward trying to deal with the controversy indirectly. Rather than regulate landlords, the F.C.C. was considering issuing rules that would prohibit carriers from agreeing to exclusive real estate deals, according to industry executives and people close to the commission. Under the proposal, the carriers, who almost always are subject to regulatory certification, would not be allowed to sign a contract under which they would be the only company allowed to install a network in an office building. In addition, the commission appeared to be leaning toward requiring communications carriers to share their space within office buildings with competitors. To serve business customers who spend thousands of dollars a month on communications services, some companies prefer to install advanced antennas on roofs. Others like to put some sort of switch or router in the basement. Many want to install wiring throughout the building. The landlords control a company's ability to deploy its system. If this fight sounds familiar, it should. In many ways, the debate is just the latest variation of AT&T's battle to retain control over Internet services delivered over its cable system, or, for that matter, the fight over whether America Online must open its instant messaging system to rivals. With some exceptions, landlords have almost the same power in apartment buildings as in office towers. But the issue has become ripe in the business sector because some carriers prefer to install equipment in the buildings of businesses they serve. Such equipment is generally not required to serve residential consumers. The conflict over access to commercial buildings is bubbling over just now because the real estate industry is more involved than ever in the communications business. Landlords are taking financial stakes in new carriers in exchange for giving those carriers the sometimes exclusive right to install equipment. Phone giants like Verizon Communications and SBC Communications, which already have lines into almost all the roughly 750,000 office buildings across the nation, have not been on the front lines of this debate. Those with complaints are generally smaller, newer companies. ''We're seeing an increasing amount of landlords who are interested in choice only to the extent that they have taken a financial interest in a carrier,'' said David S. Turetsky, a senior vice president at Teligent Inc., a new local communications company, and a former deputy assistant attorney general at the Justice Department. ''What they all have in common is that none of those models respects the ultimate choice of the tenant.'' Broadband Office was formed by a consortium of real estate companies, together with Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the venture capital firm. Joey D. Mooring, a spokesman for Allied Riser, said his company had granted warrants, a form of equity ownership similar to stock options, to some real estate companies that have opened their buildings, but would not be specific. ''Tenants within the buildings should have the ability to choose who their provider is,'' he said. As a business proposition, lobbyists for the real estate industry tend to agree. But as a matter of regulation, they say the government has no right to tell landlords who can and cannot come in. ''This is something that's driven by the tenant market, and tenant choice is the way for people in the real estate industry to be successful,'' said Roger Platt, spokesman for the Real Access Alliance. This group, formed by many of the nation's biggest real estate companies, has lobbied the F.C.C. to back off. ''Building owners are being portrayed as evil characters out of a Dickens novel,'' he said. ''One of the fundamental aspects of being a manager of property is you have the right to both include certain people and to exclude certain individuals. There are narrow constitutional restrictions on that, but otherwise the Constitution is very clear.'' That argument has found some resonance at the F.C.C. At least one commissioner, Harold W. Furchtgott-Roth, a Republican, has made it clear from the start that the case for forced access is weak at best, said Helgi Walker, a legal adviser to Mr. Furchtgott-Roth. ''Even if such statutory authority were within the discretion of the commission,'' she said, ''the exercise of that discretionary authority would at least raise questions about the constitutionality of its action.'' Taking a page from AT&T's playbook, the Real Access Alliance has suggested voluntary guidelines for preserving competition. In addition to other rules, the commission may make a point of trying to hold the alliance's members to those commitments. Some communications experts suggested that having taken intermediate efforts would be a necessary building block in any future effort to regulate property owners more directly. In the end, however, the companies that have complained appear more interested in getting fast access to buildings than in helping the F.C.C. expand its jurisdiction. ''The point is really to create a process that shortens something that already works,'' said William J. Rouhana Jr., chairman of Winstar Communications, a new local carrier. ''We get access to a lot of buildings, but it takes us an average of nine months to do it. Almost every landlord starts out wondering if they shouldn't consider doing an exclusive, and once that's off the table then the whole process is shortened.''

headline: BEST BUY TO SELL AT&T SERVICES
summary: Best Buy, the operator of the nation's largest chain of electronics stores, will begin offering AT&T's high-speed Internet and digital cable television services next month. The deal, considered a boost for AT&T's ambitions to offer a variety of broadband communications and entertainment services, is part of a wider trend. RadioShack has similar agreements with Verizon Communications, Sprint and Microsoft, while Best Buy stores already offer Microsoft's MSN Internet service. ''Retail will be important,'' said Doug Seserman of AT&T's broadband division, ''as a source of information that will help us work with consumer electronics manufacturers on innovative products for the future.'' Simon Romero

headline: Micki Chen, Steven Gross
summary: Micki Mai-hsi Chen and Prof. Steven Allan Gross are to be married today at the Sequoia, a restaurant in Washington. Judge Emily Hewitt of the United States Court of Federal Claims in Washington is to officiate. The couple, both 35, graduated from Harvard University, from which the bride also received a law degree and the bridegroom a Ph.D. in philosophy.

headline: Did Verizon Have the Wrong Number!
summary: Verizon Communications sent letters to 250,000 customers in the state of New York earlier this month, telling them how the company was ''shaking things up.'' Little did the recipients suspect how truly hot the offer was. The Verizon pitch was for a lower-cost international calling rate plan, and a toll-free sign-up number was provided at the bottom of the letter. But callers to that number instead heard a recording directing them to another toll-free number. This second number is operated by a phone-sex company calling itself Intimate Encounters, which offers one-on-one discussions with women, on a variety of sexual topics, for $2.99 a minute, payable by credit card.

headline: Metro Business Briefing
summary: BLAME FOR HIGH BILLS -- A consultant to the Independent System Operator, a group that administers the wholesale energy markets in New York State, yesterday attributed much of the summer increase in electricity prices in the metropolitan area to the shutdown of a Con Edison generating plant. The consultant, David B. Patton of Capital Economics, challenged Con Edison's position that much of the increase resulted from the group's rules, which discourage economical imports of electricity. Mr. Patton said the shutdown of the Indian Point 2 power plant after an accident in February forced Con Ed to buy more expensive replacement power. A Con Ed spokesman, Joseph Petta, said the utility stood by its position. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

headline: New Media Meets An Old Medium In the Phone Book
summary: ''WHAT'S your e-mail address?'' may soon have a new answer: ''It's in the book.'' In the phone books that will be distributed next year by Verizon Communications, people will be able to include their e-mail addresses, as well as personal Web page addresses, along with their home telephone listings, for an annual fee of $36 for each additional item.

headline: EMPLOYMENT RISES
summary: Unemployment in New York City continued to drop last month, and has declined sharply over the last year, according to figures released yesterday by the New York State Department of Labor. After adjustment for seasonal factors, the jobless rate in the city fell to 5.6 percent, from 5.8 percent in August and 6.7 percent a year ago. The rest of the state did not fare as well in September; the unemployment rate rose slightly, to 3.9 percent, which was also the national rate. A year ago, both upstate New York and the nation had jobless rates of 4.2 percent. The end of the communication workers' strike against Verizon caused an unusually big increase in the number of people working in September. But job growth has been strong over the last year, rising by 2.1 percent in the state and 2.5 percent in New York City. Rockland County experienced the fastest pace of job growth in the state, at 2.9 percent; in Buffalo and Niagara Falls, the number of jobs edged up only 0.3 percent. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

headline: This Season, A Tense Knot In the Belly
summary: I am going to need some mantras to get through this Subway Series. The sort murmured by people who are afraid to fly, like, ''I have a better chance of being kicked to death by a mule than dying on this aircraft.'' I will twist that soothing phrase to apply to the odds of losing to the Mets. I'm not kidding myself, of course. I have spent years mocking the Mets and their haplessness, and I know things are different this year. I've caught their games, I've suffered our slumps. The hurt of a perpetually tight stomach is on.

headline: Another Kind of E-Book
summary: No, the Internet isn't everywhere, but it will be by next year. That's when when Verizon Communications, the corporate successor to Bell Atlantic, sends out its new phone books, in which people will be able to list e-mail and personal Web page addresses, along with their phone numbers. The annual cost is $36 for each listing. Verizon plans to make the service available throughout its territory -- New York, New England and the mid-Atlantic state.

headline: Hands Off; Proposal for a State Law on Driving While Phoning
summary: Verizon Wireless regional president Rick Conrad essay on debate over use of wireless phones by motorists; offers reasons to oppose local legislation like that enacted recently in Marlboro and Carteret, NJ, and in Suffolk County, NY; drawing (M)

headline: Not the Real Thing
summary: The police said yesterday that they had seized hundreds of counterfeit World Series tickets and arrested 14 men in three schemes. And the police warned fans that if they bought from scalpers, they could end up with bogus tickets. Chief of Department Joseph J. Esposito, speaking at a news conference where he displayed dozens of sheets of phony tickets, said that the counterfeiting schemes were widespread and that some of the tickets were very good reproductions.

headline: A Wounded Giant, AT&T Is Weighing A Split Into 4 Parts
summary: AT&T's board intends to consider a plan today to divide the company into four parts and focus more closely on specific segments of the fast-changing telecommunications market, people close to AT&T said yesterday. Wall Street has been demanding evidence lately that the company, the nation's biggest long-distance and cable television provider, is willing to take strong and persuasive steps to revive the value of its stock, which has traded around half the price of a year ago.

headline: AT&T Is Planning To Split Up Again
summary: The board of AT&T, the nation's largest communications company, approved a plan late yesterday to split up the company in what would be AT&T's most significant overhaul since the court-supervised breakup of the company's Bell System in 1984. Under the plan approved yesterday, people close to the company said, AT&T intends to spin off the company's cable television business and wireless units as separate companies over the next 12 to 24 months.

headline: Communications Lobby Puts Full-Court Press on Congress
summary: As Congress nears adjournment, some of the nation's most powerful corporations have enlisted important lawmakers to tuck provisions into spending bills that could reshape the balance of power among telephone companies, Internet companies, broadcasters and cable operators. The measures would relax restrictions that have made it impossible for AT&T to expand further in the cable industry. They would save the regional Bell companies billions paid to local carriers that some rivals and groups say would be shifted to Internet users. And they would kill a plan to create hundreds of new low-power FM stations for churches, schools and community groups.

headline: Where to Find Gifts for Your 2,000 Closest Corporate Friends
summary: WHEN Nancy Petralia wants to rev up the sales agents at Verizon Communications, she doesn't dangle a trip to Aruba. She just goes to the corporate account at Flooz.com and sends her team online gift currencies. ''This offered a wide selection,'' said Ms. Petralia, the manager of channel development in Philadelphia for Verizon, which was recently formed by the merger of Bell Atlantic and GTE. ''And it's very convenient.''

headline: AT&T, IN PULLBACK, WILL BREAK ITSELF INTO 4 BUSINESSES
summary: Running out of time with impatient investors, AT&T yesterday pulled back from an expensive three-year effort to become the first one-stop shop selling long-distance, wireless, cable television and Internet services across the nation as a single package with a single bill. It announced that instead it would break itself into four parts. The nation's eighth-largest company, which only two decades ago dominated the telephone business and ranked with General Motors and Mobil among the nation's very largest companies, will become four much smaller businesses competing against many formidable, and sometimes larger, rivals.

headline: Hold That Listing
summary: To the Editor: Verizon's decision to let people list personal e-mail addresses in the phone directory is ill conceived (''New Media Meets Old Media in the Phone Book,'' Oct. 26). Anyone who has unfortunately listed an e-mail address in a newsgroup or other public forum has been the victim of people who troll for e-mail addresses and sell the lists.

headline: The Devolved AT&T: Are 4 Parts More Promising Than One?
summary: Shortly after announcing on Wednesday that AT&T was going to split into four units, C. Michael Armstrong, the company's chairman, was asked in an interview if anything good would be lost as a result of the overhaul. He considered the question for at least 10 seconds, then responded, ''I can't think of anything.'' But in fact, AT&T may be losing something that if not necessarily good, has been a powerful force in its favor for more than 100 years: the fear that its size and power has inspired in competitors. The AT&T-brand companies that remain after the breakup plan is completed by 2002 will be smaller than the AT&T the communications world has known. And the competitive landscape will change accordingly.

headline: SBC MOVES ON LONG DISTANCE
summary: SBC Communications Inc., which is known to most of its customers as Ameritech, Southwestern Bell or Pacific Bell, asked the Federal Communications Commission for permission to sell long-distance service to its customers in Kansas and Oklahoma. The Telecommunications Act of 1996 allows local phone companies to enter the long-distance market on a state-by-state basis as they convince the F.C.C. that they have opened their local networks in those states. So far, Verizon Communications Inc. has been allowed to offer long distance in New York and SBC in Texas. SBC is known as an aggressive company, and yesterday's application was an aggressive regulatory move. There is less local phone competition in Kansas and Oklahoma than in either New York or Texas, so the commission's approval could set a new and potentially lower bar for the other Bells to clear. Seth Schiesel (NYT)

headline: Verizon's Profit Is Nearly Flat After an Increase in Spending
summary: Verizon Communications said yesterday that its third-quarter profit was almost unchanged as it spent more money on new services like long distance and high-speed Internet access. Profit from operations at Verizon, which was formed in June when the Bell Atlantic Corporation bought the GTE Corporation, was $1.99 billion, or 73 cents a share, compared with $2 billion, or 72 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.

headline: Metro Business Briefing; ZAGAT'S CHIEF EXECUTIVE
summary: Zagat Survey in New York, the purveyor of information about restaurants and night life, said yesterday that it had named Amy B. McIntosh as its first chief executive since the company was founded by Tim and Nina Zagat in 1979. Ms. McIntosh, who had been group president at Verizon's Internet and data services division, has five years of Internet, technology and marketing experience at Bell Atlantic and 11 years in senior marketing and operating roles at American Express.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Primedia to Buy About.com For $690 Million in Stock Primedia, the magazine conglomerate controlled by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, agreed to buy About.com, one of New York City's largest Internet companies, for $690 million in stock. The companies serve a sprawling and eclectic list of specialized interests. Primedia has a few big titles, including New York and Seventeen, but it has largely collected about 100 consumer fan magazines. About, formed in 1996 as the Mining Company, is a Web guide created by independent, mostly part-time guides who earn a share of the site's advertising. It now comprises more than 700 sites on topics from astrology to woodworking. [Page C14.] Have Strong Dollars, Will Travel The strong United States economy is driving a vast holiday migration to Europe, helped by the dollar's rise against the euro, which has shrunk the costs of shopping, accommodations and dining for traveling Americans. [A1.] PepsiCo to Acquire 90% of SoBe PepsiCo agreed to buy a 90 percent stake in South Beach Beverage for $370 million in cash, beating its archrival Coca-Cola again in one of the most dynamic segments of the beverage industry. Sales of SoBe's herb-laden ''elixirs'' with names like Edge, Power and Tsunami have jumped to $225 million this year from $1.2 million in 1996. Shares of PepsiCo rose $1.13, to $49.25. [C2.] Dow Gains 2.3% as Nasdaq Slides The Dow Jones industrial average registered its biggest one-day gain in six months as investors put money into blue-chip issues and sold technology shares. The Dow rose 245.15 points, or 2.3 percent, to 10,835.77. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also moved higher, rising 19.08 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,398.66. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 86.96 points, or 2.7 percent, to 3,191.40. [C18.] Smirnoff Seeks to Improve Image The 12-member global marketing team for Smirnoff vodka is moving to Stamford, Conn., from London as part of an effort to improve the brand's image in the United States. [C2.] Microsoft Tries to Prevent Filings Microsoft asked a federal appeals court to forbid nine organizations and individuals who support the government antitrust suit against the company, including America Online, to file court briefs in the case. Alternatively, Microsoft said all nine should be asked to combine their thoughts into one 25-page brief. [C4.] Share Sale in Sky Global Delayed The News Corporation, which had been planning to sell part of its global satellite businesses, Sky Global Networks, to the public next month, has postponed the sale because of market conditions, a person close to the company said. Despite the delay, News Corporation, controlled by Rupert Murdoch, is in talks with Microsoft about selling a nearly $1 billion stake in Sky Global, which would give Microsoft 3.5 percent of the company. [C4.] Auction Settlement Details Payouts A $512 million formal settlement of the class-action lawsuit against Sotheby's and Christie's lays out for the first time how the proceeds are to be divided among the plaintiffs, according to Sotheby's court papers. [C17.] Verizon Posts Flat Quarterly Profit Verizon's third-quarter profit was almost unchanged as it spent more on services like long distance and high-speed Internet access. [C2.] Spending and Incomes Show Gains Spending by consumers surged 0.8 percent in September, the Commerce Department reported, and an election-year package of farm aid pushed up incomes 1.1 percent. [C16.]

headline: Blue Chips Stage Strong Rally While the Nasdaq Slides
summary: The Dow Jones industrial average registered its biggest one-day gain in six months yesterday, as investors plowed money into blue-chip issues and sold highly priced technology shares. Cyclical stocks like Alcoa, International Paper and DuPont led the Dow's advance, but the breadth of the rise in the index was impressive: 26 of the 30 stocks that make up the Dow average rose in price yesterday, while 4 posted declines.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Napster to Change Service With Aid From Bertelsmann Napster, which has terrified the recording industry by letting its users copy music from one another online, agreed to change course and charge a fee for its service and distribute part of the fee as royalties to copyright holders. The plan would be financed partly by one of the companies that tried to shut it down -- the German media giant Bertelsmann, which lent Napster an undisclosed sum to help change the service and received an option to buy a stake in the company in return. [Page A1.]

headline: Hong Kong Mobile Unit Raises $7.2 Billion
summary: China Mobile (Hong Kong) Ltd. has raised $7.2 billion selling debt and equity to help pay for new wireless networks, in the biggest sale of shares to overseas investors by a state-owned Chinese company. The company, the largest mobile-phone carrier in China, raised $6.6 billion selling stock and $600 million from bonds that are convertible into stock, according to Goldman, Sachs, one of the investment banks involved in the transactions. The shares were sold at a price of 48 Hong Kong dollars, or $6.15, a 4.5 percent discount to the closing price here today.

headline: With WorldCom's Breakup Plan, Eerie Similarities to AT&T
summary: Mr. Armstrong, meet Mr. Ebbers. A week after AT&T announced that it would split itself into four parts, WorldCom Inc., the No. 2 long-distance carrier, announced a similar plan yesterday, saying it would separate the company's fast-growing Internet and business services unit from its relatively stagnant operation that serves consumers.

headline: PROFITS LEAP AT CANTV
summary: The national phone company, Nacional Telefonos de Venezuela, said third-quarter net income soared fivefold on the strength of its rapidly growing mobile phone and Internet units. Net income rose to $26 million from $4.7 million in the quarter last year, when results were hammered by the country's recession. The company is 40 percent owned by a group led by Verizon Communications.

headline: What's a Verizon, Anyway?
summary: When the voice of Darth Vader told callers last summer that the familiar ring of Bell Atlantic was being replaced by what sounded like a far off galaxy in a B-movie, there was little they could do but wince. ''What's Verizon?'' asked 28-year-old Ashli Hulick of Bound Book, crinkling her nose. ''Bell Atlantic sounds better. It was just so All-American, you know?''

headline: F.T.C. Review Of AOL Deal In Final Stage
summary: After months of negotiations, the antitrust review of the America Online and Time Warner merger now enters an endgame that, no matter its outcome, seems certain to set the government's competition policies for the largest Internet and telecommunications players for years to come. Executives at the two companies had been hoping to conclude the talks with two regulatory agencies, the Federal Trade Commission and the Federal Communications Commission, in the coming weeks and close the deal before the end of the year. But while negotiators have made significant progress, the F.T.C. and the companies remain at odds over crucial details. Reflecting the uncertainty of the outcome, the trade commission continues to prepare to seek a court order to block the merger.

headline: Corzine Wins Costly Bid for Senate in New Jersey
summary: Jon S. Corzine, a liberal Democrat who made a fortune as a Wall Street executive and spent about $60 million of it on his first campaign for public office, won election to New Jersey's open seat in the United States Senate yesterday after shattering the national spending record for a statewide race. Mr. Corzine fended off a determined but poorly financed challenge from Representative Bob Franks by outspending him 10 to 1, unleashing a nine-week barrage of television advertisements and an army of political foot soldiers who searched out votes in inner-city housing complexes and sprawling subdivisions across the state.

headline: Metro Business Briefing; TELEPHONE BACKLOG CLEARED UP
summary: Verizon Communications says it has cleared up a backlog of nearly 60,000 orders for telephone service that piled up in New York State during a 15-day strike by its workers in August. The company has told the state's Public Service Commission that the backlog of requests for new lines and added features like call waiting was whittled down to 6,000 by the end of September and eliminated altogether by Oct. 23. A backlog of thousands of repair orders in the state ''was pretty much overcome by the end of September,'' William Allan, vice president for regulatory affairs for Verizon in New York, said yesterday. The 4,034 customer complaints lodged against Verizon with the New York Public Service Commission during the first nine months of this year are one-third more than during the comparable period last year. Mr. Allan attributed this to the strike and to the ''wet spring and early summer this year,'' saying damage to cables and other equipment is more frequent with extended rain and flooding. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

headline: 718 Plus 347 Minus 1 Equals 6,711 Wrong Numbers
summary: Frank Chironno has received almost 7,000 telephone calls since April. But he is hardly a popular guy. Most of the calls have been for someone else. ''The majority of them hang up on you,'' said Mr. Chironno, a retired automotive repair store manager from Bellerose. ''Ten to 20 seconds later they call back. It's really too much.''

headline: Corrections
summary: An article last Sunday about Verizon's request for a telephone rate increase misspelled the surname of a spokeswoman for the company in some references. She is Soraya Rodriguez, not Rodriquez.

headline: Media Buying Duties For Verizon Are Set
summary: Verizon Communications, formed by the merger of Bell Atlantic and GTE, has consolidated the media buying duties for Verizon Communications, Verizon Wireless and Verizon Information Services -- with billings estimated at more than $500 million -- at the New York offices of Draft Worldwide and Zenith Media. John Bonomo, a spokesman for Verizon in New York, said the decision came after a three-month review that had been narrowed to the Draft/Zenith combination and four finalists he declined to identify. Draft is part of the Interpublic Group of Companies and Zenith is owned by the Cordiant Communications Group and the Publicis Groupe S.A.

headline: A Start, but Only a Start, Toward an Inevitable Transition
summary: There is little doubt that one of the main reasons America Online Inc. wants to acquire Time Warner Inc. is potential access to Time Warner's extensive cable television network, the second biggest in the nation. America Online is the leviathan of the dial-up Internet, with almost 25 million subscribers worldwide, but has almost no presence in the business of providing links to cyberspace over high-speed, or broadband, connections, which can be as much as 30 times faster than standard analog modems. The pressure on America Online arises from the fact that, one way or another, the majority of its United States subscribers will probably migrate to broadband over the next five years or so. If America Online does not migrate with them, the company could be left behind.

headline: VERIZON IN $1.5 BILLION DEAL
summary: The nation's largest wireless carrier, Verizon Wireless, will increase the size of its Southeast business with an agreement to acquire Price Communications Wireless. Verizon Wireless, a venture of Verizon Communications and Vodafone, will exchange stock worth $1.5 billion for Price after a planned offering of shares, in addition to assuming $550 million in debt. Simon Romero

headline: Verizon Unit Picks Hill, Holliday
summary: Verizon Wireless, a joint venture of Verizon Communications and Vodafone said yesterday that it had named the New York office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle its Northeast retail account. Billings were estimated at $50 million. Nancy Stark, a spokeswoman for Verizon in Bedminster, N.J., declined to identify the finalists in a review for the assignment. Adweek listed them as Hill, Holliday and two other New York agencies: Berenter Greenhouse & Webster, part of the Bozell Group unit of True North Communications, and Lowe Lintas & Partners, part of the Lowe Group unit of Interpublic.

headline: How Easy Cash Became Hard Debts
summary: IN a Nov. 2 report, ''The Other Side of Leverage,'' Ravi Suria, a convertible bond analyst at Lehman Brothers, examined the consequences of the recent surge in debt at telecommunications companies at a time when intense competition for customers had reduced revenue growth. It is a sobering piece of research. Mr. Suria began by pointing out that in the past four years, debt at a group of seven high-grade telecommunications companies, including AT&T, Verizon and SBC, exploded from $93 billion, to $210 billion, an annualized rate of almost 23 percent. At lesser-quality telecom and media services companies, like Global Crossing, Nextel Communications and PSI Net, high-yield corporate debt and convertible bond issuance ballooned to $275 billion, a compounded annual rate of 60 percent, in the period.

headline: More Than a Name Change: A Foundation Goes Digital
summary: IF you want a grant from the Verizon Foundation, there is only one way to go about it -- online. From application through processing and financing, the Web is the route to this multimillion-dollar foundation's heart. ''Everything we fund is about new technology,'' said Suzanne DuBose, the president of the foundation, which is in New York. ''For us to be a leader, we have to operate the way we preach, using new technology.''

headline: For Most Local Phone Users, Choice Is Not Yet an Option
summary: AT&T's plan to break itself into four pieces has many experts worried that nationwide competition in local telephone service is at risk. Four years after a grand political compromise among telecommunications interests was supposed to usher in a new era of consumer choice, only about 3 percent of household and small-business telephone lines are served by a competitor to the longstanding local phone company, according to recent preliminary Federal Communications Commission data. At most, some experts believe, no more than 1 in 10 households has any real choice at all.

headline: DoCoMo Reported Near to Buying Stake In AT&T Wireless
summary: NTT DoCoMo, Japan's largest wireless carrier, is nearing an agreement to acquire a minority stake in AT&T Wireless, a unit of the United States telecommunications giant AT&T that is being spun off as part of AT&T's recent restructuring, according to executives close to the negotiations. DoCoMo is close to taking as much as a 20 percent stake in AT&T Wireless, the executives said, and the price tag could exceed $9 billion. Though the executives cautioned that the deal could still fall apart, they said the two companies planned to announce the transaction as early as next week.

headline: Luxury Tenants Yearn For Phones They Don't Have
summary: ''The Ultimate in Brooklyn Heights Luxury,'' reads the brochure for 180 Montague Street, the 33-story tower now undergoing its final touches. A white-gloved concierge, a ''state of the art'' gym and dazzling views are included, says the publicity material, as are satellite television and high-speed Internet access. But don't try to call too many people there.

headline: With the Polls Closed, Political Sites Seek a New Focus
summary: Just a few months ago, the Democracy Network, one of the first nonprofit Web sites to provide election information online, caused a stir in nonprofit political circles by selling itself to Grassroots.com, a commercial portal for news and information about political issues. But now that the election is over, executives at Grassroots.com may be about to shake things up again. The company is planning to shift from an advertising-supported political information site to an Internet campaign consulting concern. And so the fate of the extensive candidate information collected for the Democracy Network site is uncertain.

headline: New Economy; Phone Mergers That May Help Competition
summary: And now, a cheery holiday message for the nation's underprivileged investment bankers and takeover lawyers: the long-distance communications industry may need more consolidation. After nearly five years of headlong deal making in telecommunications, it now appears that the long-term health of the $80 billion-plus long-distance sector depends largely on even more mergers.

headline: NEXTWAVE APPEAL IS DENIED
summary: The Supreme Court declined to hear an appeal yesterday from NextWave Telecom in which the company, a bankrupt wireless carrier, was seeking to overturn the forfeiture of nearly 100 licenses for potentially valuable wireless spectrum to the Federal Communications Commission. The move by the nation's highest court is expected to ease the way for an auction of the spectrum licenses to proceed next month, a necessary step in the deployment of next-generation wireless networks. Still, even as large carriers like Verizon Wireless and AT&T Wireless welcomed the court's decision, analysts warned that NextWave might succeed in persuading Congress to postpone the auction while an appeals court examines the F.C.C.'s handling of the matter. ''There is still concern over what will happen with air space that's the equivalent of untouched beachfront property,'' said Todd Harrington, an analyst with Current Analysis, a consulting firm based in Sterling, Va. Simon Romero

headline: Verizon Abandons NorthPoint Deal
summary: Less than four months after Verizon Communications agreed to acquire control of the NorthPoint Communications Group and barely a week after NorthPoint restated its latest financial results, Verizon pulled out of the deal yesterday. The planned acquisition, announced in August, would have linked Verizon -- formed by Bell Atlantic's acquisition of GTE -- with NorthPoint's broad network of high-speed Internet systems. NorthPoint is one of a cadre of companies that have invested heavily to deploy systems that deliver Internet data at high speeds over phone wires using a technology known as digital subscriber lines, or D.S.L. The idea has been to sell access to those D.S.L. systems to other companies, like Internet access providers.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Chase Offers Big Investors Chance to Join Venture Fund At a time when returns from the venture capital business are flagging, Chase Capital Partners, the private equity arm of Chase Manhattan, is inviting wealthy outside investors and institutional investors to join it in a new fund. Chase Capital's move could lower some of Chase Manhattan's exposure to the profitable -- but volatile -- returns from the venture capital business. [Page C12.]

headline: Japan's Top Mobile Phone Company to Buy AT&T Wireless Stake
summary: NTT DoCoMo, Japan's largest mobile phone company, agreed yesterday to buy a minority stake in AT&T Wireless for almost $10 billion. For AT&T Wireless, which has 15 million customers and is the third-largest cellular telephone company in the United States, the deal would provide money for growth as it plans to spin off from its parent, AT&T. The investment also comes at a time when all of the nation's wireless companies are preparing to spend heavily to update their networks with new generations of technology.

headline: MANAGEMENT: A Status Symbol Under Siege; Big Plush Offices Make Way for More Humble Space
summary: Dick Poladian, a managing partner for Arthur Andersen in Los Angeles, received several angry e-mail and voice mail messages from distraught managers when he decided to get rid of their large windowed offices. And he acknowledged that his own children thought their dad ''wasn't as important'' when he, the boss, gave up his lavish corner office with credenza and conference table. ''They clearly thought I'd lost it,'' Mr. Poladian said about his family and the more than 200 managers that report to him.

headline: U.S. Is Lagging Behind Europe In Short Messaging Services
summary: THERE are places, like Europe and Japan, where short text messages sent by cell phone are as common as e-mail. Students use them to send notes in class. Business people zap messages back and forth during meetings. The unattached use them to scout for dates. The United States, however, has lagged behind in bringing Short Messaging Service, or S.M.S., to cell phones. Until recently, short messaging in this country was available only one-way -- users could receive messages sent via e-mail. And although in recent months, AT&T Wireless, Cingular Wireless and several other United States carriers have announced two-way service, which allows mobile customers to exchange up to 160 characters of text at a time, it still faces difficulties.

headline: Giuliani Leads New Effort to Take Control of the Schools
summary: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced a new offensive yesterday in his longstanding campaign to gain control of the school system, recruiting two Democratic mayoral candidates along with top corporate leaders to press Albany legislators for a shift of power away from the Board of Education. The new drive, which will be orchestrated by a new group called Independent Committee for Education, raises few new arguments in favor of the power shift, a move that has been advocated by City Hall since at least Edward I. Koch's tenure as mayor. As before, the game plan is either to abolish the seven-member Board of Education outright or to change its makeup so that the mayor's appointees -- now only two of the seven -- would dominate.

headline: A Prized Spectrum Goes on the Block; Wireless Licenses Expected to Raise $15 Billion for U.S.
summary: After months of legal tussling, the most precious natural resource of the information age -- a large new batch of licenses to use the airwaves for wireless communications -- will finally go on sale next week in what experts say could become the largest auction ever held by the federal government. Based on auctions held by Europeans for licenses earlier this year and the growing needs of American wireless companies to fill out their national networks and augment service in their existing digital wireless telephone markets, some Wall Street analysts and industry executives estimate that the auction, which is scheduled to begin on Tuesday, could raise more than $15 billion.

headline: In Town of Contaminated Wells, Outrage and Fear
summary: One Sunday afternoon in mid-October, Daniel Whalen was helping a neighbor saw a limb off a tree when the neighbor said something disturbing: state environmental officials had told him to stop drinking water from his well, and to stop cooking and showering with it, too. Alarmed, Mr. Whalen called the state's Department of Environmental Conservation. He discovered that his own well, as well as several others in the area, was contaminated with methyl tertiary butyl ether, or M.T.B.E., a gasoline additive that is a possible cause of cancer and other health problems. The source appeared to be old leaks from underground storage tanks at four gas stations just up the hill, on Route 9G, state officials said.

headline: Pay Phones Have Improved In Subways, Study Finds
summary: It was just one of those subway moments, a petty annoyance having nothing to do with crowded platforms, slow trains or inaudible announcements. This time, it was the phone that didn't work. ''I shouldn't even have bothered,'' Michelle Kim of Brooklyn said on Saturday as she slammed down the receiver of a pay phone at the Chambers Street-World Trade Center subway station. ''These things never work when you need them.''

headline: No End to Upheaval In Telecom Industry
