summary: Things are seldom quiet in the telecommunications business, and 2000 was as eventful a year as any of its recent predecessors, with the WorldCom-Sprint merger deal falling apart and AT&T and WorldCom each planning to split themselves into separate units. And as competitive pressure mounts and profit margins narrow, 2001 is likely to experience further upheaval. Here is a quick look at three of the major sectors in telecommunications, with an eye to possible developments in 2001.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Aetna to Raise Premiums And Eliminate 5,000 Jobs Aetna, the nation's largest health insurance company, said that it would shed 2 million of its 19 million members over the next year as it raises premiums and tries to make its troubled managed-care business more profitable. The company also announced plans to eliminate 5,000 jobs, about 13 percent of its work force. The cuts, more than half from attrition, will include some in New Jersey. [Page A1.]

headline: Investors Show Displeasure As the Fed Lets Rates Alone
summary: Apparently disappointed that the Federal Reserve did not cut short-term interest rates immediately, investors drove down stock prices yesterday even though the Fed clearly signaled that it was likely to reduce rates soon. Before the Fed's announcement at around 2:15 p.m., major market averages were trending higher, with the Dow Jones industrial average up nearly 140 points shortly before the decision of the Fed's Open Market Committee was released.

headline: In a Nod to Slower Economy, SBC Cuts Earnings Forecast
summary: SBC Communications, the nation's second-largest provider of local telephone service, lowered its forecasts yesterday for sales and earnings next year in a sign of how the slowing economy is beginning to affect large telecommunications companies. SBC said its problems were caused in part by regulatory hurdles it faces in introducing long-distance service in states like California and also by high-speed digital subscriber line problems at Ameritech, the company with operations in Illinois, Michigan, Ohio, Indiana and Wisconsin that SBC bought in 1999.

headline: Lucent Lowers Expectations For 3rd Time
summary: In what has become an unwelcome routine, Lucent Technologies warned yesterday that it would lose more money than expected in the current quarter, the third time the company has revised its outlook for the period. Lucent also expects revenue to decline about 20 percent in the quarter as customers reduce purchases of the company's products. And Lucent said it would cut $1 billion in costs in the coming year in an effort to return to profitability, in part through large-scale layoffs.

headline: Those Black Holes in Your Mobile Phone Service
summary: WHEN Andrea Levy signed up for cellular telephone service, she thought she was getting seamless coverage for the entire country. But Ms. Levy, a marketing executive from Manhattan, complains about being cut off intermittently everywhere from Westchester County to New Mexico, and she sometimes finds unexpected roaming and long-distance charges on her monthly bill. Stewart Cheifet, an independent video producer from Mountain View, Calif., also laments about coast-to-coast disruptions. ''I can drive around the San Francisco Bay area and lose service,'' he said. In New York, he added, ''I couldn't get a signal from a skyscraper on Wall Street.'' He said that he, too, had encountered unexpected charges.

headline: Phone Plan Prompts Anger On East Side
summary: In a city exploding with ever more pedestrians who are digitally muttering over cell phones, a city department has given its blessing to 2,262 new public pay phones, more than 1,000 of them on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. But since many of the phones are to be housed in large booths providing space for advertising, some Upper East Side residents would just as rather disconnect. ''People are very upset about this,'' said Eva S. Moskowitz, the City Council member who represents the area. She said she has received more than 50 complaints about the issue.

headline: New Economy; Bringing Competition Policy Into the Age of the Internet
summary: So let's see if this makes any sense. The government allows the No. 1 Internet provider, America Online, to acquire the No. 2 cable company, Time Warner, but the No. 1 long-distance carrier, AT&T, was not allowed to acquire the No. 2 local phone company, SBC.

headline: TECHNOLOGY: High-Technology Stew; D.S.L. Service For Linking to Internet Is Problem Ridden
summary: Lauri Salladay had heard the horror stories of how high-speed Internet access can be as much of a curse as it is a blessing. But she never thought it would happen to her. Then one day last month Ms. Salladay, the creative director of a Manhattan company that designs logos for network television channels, found that her company's Internet connection, over something called a digital subscriber line, or D.S.L., was not working. Suddenly, she was unable to quickly retrieve images from the Internet or respond to e-mail messages from clients.

headline: 400 Channels and (Click); Digital Television Changes City's Cable Landscape
summary: There are seven channels of HBO, five channels of Showtime, four channels of Starz and six channels of Discovery. There is ''NBA League Pass,'' ''NHL Center Ice,'' ''WNBA Season Pass'' and ''MLS/ESPN Shootout.'' There is a channel just for westerns and one just for love stories. Speak Greek, Japanese, Russian, Arabic or Hindi? Try Channels 509, 510, 506, 507 or 77. If more people seem to be walking around the city glassy-eyed these days, it may be a symptom of remote-itis. Or more precisely, from the more than 400 channels of television that come from the click of those buttons.

headline: Bush Cheers Fed's Action And Tax Cut
summary: Surprised and buoyed by Alan Greenspan's sudden cut in interest rates, President-elect George W. Bush and a group of American business leaders he was meeting with today said the Federal Reserve chairman's action underscored the need for a deep, across-the-board tax cut to sustain economic growth. ''One of the messages Mr. Greenspan sent was that we need bold action, not only at the Fed, but I would interpret that to mean bold action in the halls of Congress to make sure this economy stays vibrant,'' Mr. Bush told reporters today, shortly after an aide interrupted his lunch with the executives to pass on the news that the financial landscape had changed as they were meeting. John F. Welch Jr., the soon-to-retire chairman of General Electric, said the group responded by ''raising a glass of water'' in a toast to Mr. Greenspan.

headline: Food; Raw Power
summary: Since this is the first column you read in the Sunday paper (or should be), it is possible that if you act right now -- not when you finish this literary morsel, but right now, midparagraph, dropping everything where you stand, yes, the whole tome, even though it may be a Saturday midnight, 12 degrees below, or a Sunday morn with visions of brunch dancing in your head like sugarplums -- and yard it over to a produce supplier, there's a good chance you can still just barely get one or a dozen of nature's most electrically colored and yet subtly flavored fruits, the persimmon. And not incidentally, you will be able to get a healthy dose of Schadenfreude by leaving in the dust your friends who foolishly turn to The Week in Review section first. If your greengrocer is out of persimmons, demand that he or she get a pile by sunup tomorrow (or an equally melodramatic time line) because their season ends this month -- may end . . . right NOW! -- unless you're on the West Coast, where it ended last month. You've no doubt seen persimmons around, but the most common response I get when I chomp into one is, ''So that's what those things are called.'' They are a stunning fruit visually, growing from pale to deeply saturated orange as they ripen, finally arriving at a near-neon glow, the only fruit I know that a 50-story tower of which would be quite at home in the Las Vegas skyline.

headline: Court Invalidates Part of SBC-Ameritech Pact
summary: In a decision that could allow more companies to deliver high-speed Internet service over ordinary phone lines, a Federal appeals court yesterday invalidated an important part of the deal that SBC Communications Inc. made with regulators when it won approval for its 1999 acquisition of the Ameritech Corporation. The Telecommunications Act of 1996 says that the nation's big local phone companies, including Ameritech and SBC, generally must provide access to various parts of their networks to other companies. That arrangement is known in the communications industry as unbundling because it allows a smaller competitor to pay for the use of a big company's copper telephone wires, for instance, without having to buy a bundle of other network services.

headline: Witness of League's Near-Death Experience
summary: SNUGGLED on a slip-covered sofa between two cats -- one real, the other a snoozing fake that tickles her funny bone and tricks visitors -- Barbara Barr, who cut her political teeth in 1965 as a Lindsay volunteer and keeps them plenty sharp at 71, is explaining why she almost pulled the plug on a New York institution dear to her heart, the League of Women Voters, two weeks back. ''We didn't want to broadcast the fact that we were broke,'' says Ms. Barr, a widow for a decade who shares her Jackson Heights, Queens, apartment with her son, Kenneth, temporarily back during a rough patch between jobs and marriages. Of course he's in the league, too (she buys the $65 family membership).

headline: A new campaign will try to identify a company's cellular phones with the idea of self-expression.
summary: PEOPLE may be tempted to refer to a big campaign to introduce a national brand of wireless service, which begins Sunday, as ''The joy of talk'' campaign. And why not? The campaign is upbeat, even humorous, focused far more on what is said on cellular telephones than on the technology enabling that speech. Besides, the agency creating the ads, with a budget estimated at more than $200 million, produces the big, upbeat Pepsi-Cola commercials carrying the theme ''The joy of cola.''

headline: Critics Say a Cellular Tower Will Drown Out a Soft View
summary: Environmentalists and civic groups in Riverdale are fighting a plan to build a 135-foot cellular telephone tower across the Hudson River on parkland atop the Palisades. The 13-story tower would be erected atop the Palisades just west of Route 9W in Alpine, N.J. The planning board of Alpine has approved the plan, submitted by three telecommunications companies, Omnipoint, Verizon and Sprint.

headline: New Economy; A device to link old media to the Web struggles to make good on the promise of an Internet revolution.
summary: WHEN the Digital Convergence Corporation introduced a device called the CueCat last summer, it promised to ''revolutionize the way people interact with the World Wide Web'' -- specifically, through technology designed to link print and broadcast media to relevant pages on the Internet. But as with many Internet ventures with lofty goals, Digital Convergence has run into a few roadblocks.

headline: Changes of agencies and accounts may affect the marketing of meat and motoring.
summary: CHANGES are affecting marketers that advertise everything from talk to pork -- which may rhyme, depending upon your regional speech patterns -- on accounts with combined billings estimated at more than $500 million. Verizon Wireless in Bedminster, N.J., a joint venture of Verizon Communications and Vodafone named the New York office of the Bozell Group, part of True North Communications, as agency of record on its account, including its national brand advertising. Billings were estimated at $300 million.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: White House to Press Airlines on Consolidation The Clinton administration plans to issue a last-minute call to police the airline industry more closely in the wake of deals that would consolidate the airline industry in the hands of a few giant carriers. The departing transportation secretary, Rodney E. Slater, intends to release three studies criticizing the state of competition in air travel and lay out a blueprint for how the government can improve the situation. But after receiving strong criticism from the airlines, some academics and the White House itself, Mr. Slater will stop short of issuing a controversial set of guidelines first proposed three years ago that would have put airlines on notice about how aggressively they could respond to low-fare competitors. [Page A1.]

headline: VERIZON REAPPLIES FOR LONG-DISTANCE IN MASSACHUSETTS
summary: Verizon Communications said yesterday that it had resubmitted an application to sell long-distance phone service in Massachusetts after compiling new data for federal regulators. The Federal Communications Commission has 90 days to review the application. Verizon withdrew its first application last month after criticism from the Justice Department that Verizon was not providing rivals with speedy access to its network. Competitors like WorldCom have also accused Verizon of overcharging for leased lines and switches. Verizon said it was confident its new application would pass muster.

headline: Burned Again
summary: To the Editor: I had a similar experience several years ago when I tried to get my air- conditioner repaired. I relied on a name listed in the Yellow Pages and was unable to get in touch with anyone again when the repair proved unsatisfactory.

headline: Court to Hear Net and Phone Pricing Cases
summary: The Supreme Court decided today to review a group of cases that could have profound implications for how much consumers will pay for local telephone and high-speed Internet services. In the telephone cases, the court will review which method is the most appropriate to use to determine how much the regional Bell operating companies -- the so-called Baby Bells -- charge newer, smaller companies to lease equipment in markets that regulators have struggled to try to open to competition.

headline: Next Step for Cell Phones: Adding Pictures to the Conversation
summary: WEBCAMS and Internet videoconferencing programs have made it possible for people to see one another on their computer monitors while they are talking. It has also become possible to download and view movie trailers and news clips. But away from the desktop, the picture is not as clear. While the concept of adding video capability to wireless phones has been tossed around since digital cellular service was introduced in the mid-1990's, wireless video has proved elusive for carriers and handset manufacturers.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Large Companies Prevail In U.S. Auction of Airwaves Taking advantage of rules intended to help the smallest telecommunications companies and bolster competition, the nation's largest wireless phone services and their partners are on the verge of winning scores of new licenses in a $17 billion auction of airwaves. The small companies that were supposed to have received special treatment to promote competition are complaining that they lost at the expense of giants like AT&T Wireless, Sprint PCS, VoiceStream and Cingular. Verizon Wireless, which refused to form a partnership with a small company, appears likely to pay the highest price. [Page A1.]

headline: Wariness and Optimism Vie As Gays View New President
summary: It was a first for gay Republicans. Last week's inaugural events included a breakfast honoring the Republican Unity Coalition, a new political group that includes gay members of the party. The master of ceremonies at Friday's celebration was a respected Republican elder, former Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, a close friend of both the Bush and Cheney families. In his opening remarks, Mr. Simpson noted, ''Not one of us doesn't have someone close to us who is gay or lesbian.'' Then he invoked Mary Cheney, the daughter of the vice president, who attended the inauguration with her partner. Mr. Simpson said that after Ms. Cheney said she was a lesbian, her father, Dick Cheney, ''protected and loved her as his very special, special daughter.''

headline: Neglected Gems Seek Angels For Renewal; Central Park-Like Rebirth Is Sought for Other Parks
summary: Baisley Pond Park in Jamaica, Queens, is full of promise. A taste of nature near Kennedy International Airport, it is 110 acres of canopy-tree-lined walkways, baseball and cricket fields and a lake big enough to row on. But the lake is choked with tall phragmite weeds. The walk under the canopy trees leads to a vandalized flagpole. In the summer, clouds of dust rise from the ball fields. The tennis courts have been unusable since their nets and poles were stolen last year.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: After Greenspan's Blessing Comes Quibbling on Tax Cut Now that Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has backed a tax cut, Republicans and Democrats are quibbling over exactly how much the reduction should be.

headline: January 21-27; Airwave Auction Ends
summary: The largest auction ever conducted by the Federal government ended with $17 billion in bids for a share of the airwaves, mostly from the nation's largest wireless telephone companies and their partners. Small entrepreneurs that were supposed to receive special treatment in order to encourage competition complained that the giants dominated the auction through alliances with startups. The big winner, and the only major company not to team up with a small business, was Verizon. It will pay almost $9 billion for more than 100 licenses, including two in New York for more than $4 billion. Stephen Labaton

headline: Limousines Get a Curb They Can Call Their Own
summary: So many mysterious black Lincoln Town Cars pile up at the Condé Nast building on an average evening, double-parked, even triple-parked, that if one were not attuned to the needs of the leggy, rich and editorially connected, one might think the United States government was covering up a U.F.O. crash inside the place. The knots of black cars have been a longstanding problem in congested Times Square, but after months of wrangling a solution has finally surfaced. Early next month, the city's Department of Transportation will set aside the northern curb of 41st Street between Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas solely for black cars for hire from 4 p.m. to midnight, when, officials say, the problem is most severe. They estimate that the curb will provide space for 25 cars to wait at once.

headline: A Fight for Survival in the Broadband Wreckage
summary: UP to its knees in uncollected bills from customers that resell its high-speed Internet connections, suffering from a battered stock price, relying on competitors to deliver its product and caught in a severe market downturn, Covad Communications may be facing a technology-sector version of the perfect storm. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., has become a case study in the tumultuous history of the market for broadband Internet access, a market spawned by the 1996 Telecommunications Act.

headline: Weak Reception; U.S. Lagging Behind in Wireless, And That May Be Just as Well
summary: IT is well documented that in the wireless revolution, the United States has fallen behind Europe and parts of Asia. But while the United States is unaccustomed to being a technology laggard, a closer look at the new uses for wireless phones overseas indicates that Americans may not be missing much. In South Korea, women can use their cell phones to calculate their ovulation cycles. In Britain, the user of a mobile phone can book restaurant reservations by laboriously linking to a Web site by typing on the phone's keypad (even though it would probably be faster to call the restaurant). And in Finland, arguably the most cell-phone-obsessed country in the world, consumers can use phones for such edge-of-the-envelope experiences as buying a soft drink from a vending machine.

headline: As Industrial Jobs Decline, Training Programs Grow
summary: CHERYL SPAIN, a member of the Communications Workers of America union and a computer network associate at AT&T's Middletown, Va., EasyLink billing center, figures she has taken at least three dozen training courses over the years to pick up new skills. At 44, Ms. Spain is now certified to work with Microsoft office software programs, like Word and Excel, and various databases. She has passed the Data Technician Knowledge test and is eligible for promotion to the next job grade, computer network associate Level 3, which pays more than her Level 2 job. She is currently enrolled in a distance learning course at Penn State to earn a customer relations certificate.

headline: Re-entry Means Resetting Their Sights
summary: WHETHER they left the workplace for four months or 14 years -- or are considering a leave -- women will find that re-entry takes planning, ingenuity and flexibility regarding salaries, schedules and even the work itself. Resilience doesn't hurt, either, when it comes to the emotional burden of working in a society in which 64 percent of respondents, as measured by a 1996 national Gallup poll, said they believed children were better off if their mothers stayed home. The statistics tell the story. Labor Department data show that working mothers are becoming an American cultural norm, with 70.6 percent of married women with children under age 18 working full or part time. The rate of growth in the labor force is expected to increase 1 percent yearly until 2015, while women, as part of the labor force, will increase to 48 percent from 46.3 percent during that period.

headline: Luring the Best in an Unsettled Time
summary: FOR much of the last century, employment in America rested on an exchange that contemplated far more than a day's wages for a day's work: it was all about a bundle of unspoken long-term commitments. Employees gave companies their loyalty -- however grudgingly -- in return for training, promotions, steady raises, job security and identity. Smirk all you like about the Organization Man; his trade-off made possible the 30-year mortgages and college educations that the great American dream was historically made of. In its day, the pact could reinforce itself for a lifetime, for the higher one climbed in a company, the greater the rewards and the stronger the incentive to stick around and try for more.

headline: Verizon's Earnings Rise 1.3%; Sprint's Profit Is Down 11%
summary: Verizon Communications said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 1.3 percent, while Sprint reported an 11 percent decline in profit. Verizon, which was formed in June when Bell Atlantic bought GTE, said profit from operations climbed to $2.11 billion, or 77 cents a share, compared with $2.08 billion, or 75 cents a share, in the period a year earlier as it spent more to add long-distance customers in New York and sell more data and wireless services. Fourth-quarter sales rose 6.7 percent, to $16.9 billion from $15.8 billion.

headline: VERIZON COMMUNICATIONS TAKES STEPS TO CUT COSTS
summary: Verizon Communications plans to cut some jobs, limit overtime and dismiss contractors in an effort to reduce costs, the company president, Lawrence T. Babbio Jr., said yesterday. Verizon will achieve 40 percent of the cuts by dropping contractors and reducing overtime, Mr. Babbio said. Much of the rest, the company said, will come through attrition, with some layoffs, although it declined to be more specific. Mr. Babbio said Verizon expected to have 6.4 million to 6.6 million long-distance customers nationwide by year-end, a rise of 31 percent to 35 percent from the 4.9 million at the end of 2000. Verizon started selling long-distance service in New York about a year ago and enrolled 1.4 million customers by December.

headline: Ambitious Plans At Chase Manhattan; Retail Banking Chief Aims For Big Gain in Consumer Business
summary: For New Yorkers, the local Chase Manhattan branch is as familiar as Con Edison or Verizon. With more than 1,000 branches or A.T.M.'s around town, Chase controls one of every three New York banking dollars. Chase is by far the leading consumer bank in the New York metropolitan area. Yet despite its dominance in the nation's No. 2 banking market (behind Los Angeles), Chase has done little to capitalize on opportunities to sell its other products, like credit cards, mutual funds or mortgages.

headline: Unit of BellSouth Accused of Bias
summary: The BellSouth Corporation's telecommunications subsidiary is being sued by a government agency over suspected racial bias against black workers at the company's office in Mobile, Ala. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said it filed the lawsuit last week in Federal District Court in Mobile, contending that BellSouth failed to promote its black employees.

headline: F.C.C. Auction Hit With Claim Of Unfair Bids
summary: George D. Crowley Jr., a longtime telecommunications entrepreneur, recalls the day last fall when an old friend contacted him about an intriguing opportunity. The friend represented SBC Communications. As Mr. Crowley knew, the Federal Communications Commission was preparing to begin an auction in December of wireless airwave frequencies that the largest telephone companies desperately needed. But many of the licenses were being set aside for small companies like his, while others available to any buyer could be bought by such companies at a deep discount. What if, the friend proposed, SBC's wireless phone venture, Cingular Wireless, helped to bankroll him in the auction?

headline: A Flawed Wireless Auction
summary: The Federal Communications Commission's recent auction of wireless airwave frequencies raised $17 billion for the Treasury but failed almost completely to encourage the entry of small companies that could foster price competition and technological innovation. The commission set aside some licenses for smaller companies but then allowed those bidders to be financed by the industry's leading players, as reported yesterday in The Times by Stephen Labaton and Simon Romero. The F.C.C. and Congress ought to rethink their approach to these auctions to determine if there is some way to develop genuine set-aside programs. If not, the pretense should be dropped before it erodes public confidence in the regulatory system. The commission, in auctioning off 422 wireless licenses in 195 markets, set aside 170 of them for start-ups and smaller companies. The bids of the small companies for other licenses were accorded a 25 percent bidding credit, which amounts to a federal subsidy. There is an enormous pent-up demand for broadband spectrum among the nation's biggest wireless companies, which are eager to build national networks and roll out new wireless Internet services.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Debt Rating For Lucent Is Cut Again
summary: The news continues to worsen for Lucent Technologies, which has been effectively shut out of the short-term financing market. The nation's biggest credit-rating companies, Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Service, yesterday lowered their ratings on the debt of Lucent to one notch above the junk level. Since October, when the company's board fired its chief executive, Lucent's debt ratings have been cut four times as questions have mounted about past revenues and regulators have begun looking into its accounting practices.

headline: Metro Business Briefing; NO VERIZON INCREASES
summary: In what consumer advocates hailed as a victory yesterday, Verizon New Jersey said it would not seek an increase in its basic service rate of $8.19 a month for local phone service or for add-on services like caller ID. Across the board, there will be no increases, said Dennis Bone, president of the company, which is based in Newark. In December, Verizon withdrew an application to the State Board of Public Utilities that if approved would have forced most residential callers to accept bundled service packages starting at $15 per month. Verizon did ask the utilities board yesterday to deregulate rates charged to businesses with more than one phone line, asserting that dozens of companies had expressed interest in providing such service and therefore the market was competitive. But Michael Schweder, president of AT&T New Jersey, said that only a handful of companies, including his own, actually provide business phone service in New Jersey, meaning that Verizon could raise rates significantly. Verizon also said yesterday that it would contribute $20 million to provide Internet access to schools and libraries. Steve Strunsky

headline: Deaths Spur Laws Against Drivers on Cell Phones
summary: Mardy Burns learned the blessings of the cell phone when a stranger called for emergency help from the roadside in Kansas where her 18-year-old daughter, Sara, was in a car wreck. But Mrs. Burns soon learned the curse of the cell phone, too. She said that investigators found that the driver of the wrecked car, who survived, had been distracted while on his phone and crashed, killing Sara and her boyfriend. The 17-year-old driver was not charged with any violation in the single-car accident.

headline: VERIZON BID RAISES QUESTIONS
summary: The Justice Department said yesterday that significant questions remained about whether Verizon Communications, the nation's largest local telephone company, had proved that its dominant local network was open to competitors that provide high-speed data service in Massachusetts. Verizon is seeking clearance to begin selling long-distance voice and data service to its local customers in the state -- a $2 billion market. The Justice Department voiced its concern in a filing to the Federal Communications Commission, which will have final say on Verizon's bid for long-distance service. Department officials urged the F.C.C. to be cautious in resolving the application, which it must decide by April 16.

headline: Agencies Selected On Two Accounts
summary: Two advertisers are making decisions on accounts. The AARP in Washington, formerly the American Association of Retired Persons, selected HeadQuarters Advertising in San Francisco to handle image advertising, direct marketing, public relations and special events aimed at Spanish-speaking Americans ages 50 and older. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

headline: Questioned About Finances, Jackson Will Amend Taxes
summary: Faced with questions about the finances of his nonprofit organizations, the Rev. Jesse Jackson this week released for the first time detailed information about expenses and salaries paid by the groups and said today that he would file an amended tax return to reflect money paid to a staff member with whom he had an extramarital affair. The name of the woman, Karin L. Stanford, was omitted -- along with the names of other staff members -- in the 1999 tax return filed by the Citizenship Education Fund, one of Mr. Jackson's four interconnected groups. Mr. Jackson and his accountant called the omissions inadvertent.

headline: Putting Palm and Phone in One Hand
summary: IT would have been a fascinating bonus question on the 2000 census questionnaire: ''What battery-powered equipment do you have in your pockets right now?'' The most popular answer, given by 80 million respondents, would certainly have been, ''A cell phone.'' About 11 million would have replied, ''A Palm organizer.'' But a third group would have answered with an outburst: ''A Palm and a phone. And you can also write on your little form that I'm sick and tired of carrying around both -- I clank like Robocop when I walk. If they can put a man on the moon, why can't they combine a Palm and a phone?''

headline: Companies at Career Fair Seeking Technology Workers
summary: The Westchester Information Technology Cluster and the Westchester County Association will hold a technology career fair on Tuesday from 5 to 8 p.m. at The Landmark at Eastview in Tarrytown. ''Every company needs to find good talent,'' said Art Zuckerman, co-chairman of the Information Technology Cluster. ''The demand for employees is so high that there's never enough people available to fill the jobs.'' Dr. Norman Jacknis, Mr. Zuckerman's co-chairman, said he was not concerned about the economic troubles in the technology sector.

headline: Full-Court Press by Robots, for Engineering
summary: AT the driver station behind a glass partition, Steven Ellinghaus and Randy Earle maneuvered their joysticks. On the playing field in front of the Farmingdale High School students, SCAG -- an acronym for Second Chance at Glory -- a robot that looked like an upright vacuum cleaner zipped across the carpet only to get stuck midfield by the dividing rail. Steven and Randy veered SCAG to the right, then the left, unable to move him to the other side. Suddenly, EInstein, a low-slung robot built by the Red Jammers, East Islip High School's robotics team, charged right across the seesawing midfield ramp. As Bryan Prosek worked its remote controls, EInstein grabbed a large neon ball and placed it on a seven-foot goal. Then the robot pushed the goal onto the pivoting bridge, balancing it. Pulsating music and the play-by-play blared. Colored lights flashed. Robots from Longwood and Hampton Bays high schools hovered in the end zones. Umpires watched the mechanical gladiators, scrutinizing each movement. And in the stands, 3,000 fans cheered wildly as the buzzer signaling the end of the two-minute round went off.

headline: Community Leader to Head Economic Group in Bed-Stuy
summary: A community leader with deep roots in Central Brooklyn was named yesterday to head the troubled Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation, a nonprofit organization that once served as a model for neighborhood revitalization throughout the country. Restoration, as the organization is known, has been without a president since August, when Roderick B. Mitchell stepped down after 12 years. Under Mr. Mitchell, the organization had been widely criticized for running large deficits and accused of losing its sense of purpose.

headline: METRO BRIEFING
summary: NEW YORK ALBANY: PANEL FAILS TO RESOLVE IMPASSE -- A bipartisan legislative committee, impaneled to reconcile Republican and Democratic versions of a women's health bill, has dissolved without an agreement. The chief sticking point is a requirement that insurers cover contraceptives, a provision that the Roman Catholic Church opposes. The Republican-controlled Senate has said any such bill must exempt religious groups from having to provide birth control services to their employees. The Democrat-controlled Assembly maintains that it will not countenance such an exemption. Fewer than a dozen such committees have been created in the last six years, but this is the first one that has come up empty-handed. Somini Sengupta (NYT) MANHATTAN: STATE OFFICIAL'S DAUGHTER CHARGED -- The daughter of State Comptroller H. Carl McCall was arrested last night and charged with larceny and issuing bad checks, the police said. The woman, Marcella McCall, 37, who lives on the Upper West Side and works for Verizon, was arrested at her workplace at 1095 Avenue of the Americas at 6:20 p.m., the police said. The larceny charge stems from Ms. McCall's using her corporate credit card for nonbusiness purposes, said Sgt. William Stiles, a police spokesman. Mr. McCall, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for governor, would not comment on the arrest. Andy Newman (NYT)

headline: McCall Confronts Questions on His Daughter's Arrest
summary: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for governor, found himself yesterday confronting questions about his daughter's arrest Wednesday evening on charges of larceny and issuing bad checks. Marcella McCall, a Verizon employee, was accused of using corporate credit cards for nonbusiness purposes and of writing almost $100,000 in bad checks to cover those expenses, the police said. Ms. McCall, 37, was released without bail yesterday morning from Criminal Court in Manhattan.

headline: Taking Phones Out of The Hands Of Drivers
summary: JOYCE BENNETT used to enjoy long walks on the beach near her West Haven home and trips to theaters in New York City. But that changed on a summer morning in 1999 when a motorist talking on a cellular telephone struck her with his car as she crossed an intersection on her way to work. The accident damaged her back and pelvis. Now, she relies on a cane to walk long distances and must limit her exercise, a restriction she said caused her petite frame to expand from 115 to 150 pounds.

headline: New Economy; Hyperbole still outruns reality when it comes to the state of the wireless Web.
summary: IN Las Vegas one evening last week, when a group of executives from the wireless industry repaired to a bar in a sprawling Venetian hotel and gambling complex, the mood was grim. ''Get your barf bag out,'' said Josh Newman, senior editor of Unstrung, an online magazine covering the wireless industry, who had surveyed some of the hundreds of companies in town for the Cellular Telecommunications and Internet Association's annual conference. ''I wish companies would start making money instead of generating hype.''

headline: A Turf Fight for the Airwaves; The Military Holds. Wireless Is Hungry. Small Users Worry.
summary: Msgr. Michael J. Dempsey of Brooklyn came to Washington earlier this month, hoping to save his small educational television network from becoming a casualty in a fight between the nation's largest telephone companies and the Pentagon. The monsignor founded the network 35 years ago and it now provides educational and Roman Catholic religious programming not only to 70,000 children in parochial schools in Queens and Brooklyn, but to hundreds of thousands more around the nation as well. Within his tight budget, he has decided to allocate $500,000 to retain a former top telecommunications adviser to Vice President Al Gore, a former member of the Federal Communications Commission and the public relations man representing Marc Rich's embattled Washington lawyer.

headline: A Computer? Funny, You Don't Sound Like One
summary: EVERY day, Tom Glynn has conversations with hundreds of thousands of people. He chats about investments and stock trades with customers of the brokerage firm CSFBdirect. To owners of broken-down bulldozers calling the equipment supplier Caterpillar looking for help, he is unfailingly polite: ''Sorry, I didn't understand. Please say 'locate dealer' or 'warranty look-up.' '' And Mr. Glynn invites callers to United Airlines' flight information line to barge in at any time: ''Here's a hint. If you know the answer to any question I ask, please interrupt me.''

headline: NEWS WATCH
summary: HIGH-ALTITUDE SURFING -- Everyone knows that business travelers are the chosen people of air travel. As a result, several airlines have experimented with ways for business travelers to go online in the sky. But Virgin Atlantic says it will be the first airline to offer e-mail and Internet access to all its passengers. By December 2001, all passengers will be able to visit 10 to 20 sites, including some for news, sports and children's entertainment. That will be free, but e-mail will mean a per-message or per-flight charge. ''We'll add a fun element as well,'' said Richard Branson, the always cheeky chairman of the company, ''with e-mail messages sent from the plane showing up as being from something like 'passenger's name@emailhighclub.com.' ''

headline: Metro Business Briefing; PENALTIES WAIVED
summary: The New York State Public Service Commission voted yesterday to waive $25.8 million in potential penalties that Verizon Communications faced for service failures in August and September. Verizon had requested the waivers, saying that an 18-day labor strike in August and the backlogs it caused had been responsible for the company's inability to meet the commission's standards for repairs, installations and other activities in those months. Under the commission's regulatory system, penalties, returned to customers as rebates, are imposed if Verizon does not meet various monthly, quarterly and annual performance requirements, though the penalties may be waived when the company shows that the shortfalls resulted from circumstances beyond its control. The commission denied additional waiver requests that Verizon had requested for reasons other than the strike. Verizon's penalties for the regulatory year ended Aug. 31 now total at least $17.6 million, much more than the total in each of the three previous regulatory years. Joseph P. Fried

headline: Web Users Left Scrambling as Big D.S.L. Network Shuts Down
summary: The first bankruptcy of a major provider of fast Internet access sent more than 100,000 computer users scrambling to find new service yesterday as the nationwide network of NorthPoint Communications was shut down. The closing of NorthPoint's system -- which offered Web service to small Internet service providers in cities across the country, including hundreds of homes and businesses in New York -- came after AT&T reached a $135 million deal to acquire most of NorthPoint's assets, but not its customers.

headline: Leaders Favor Ban on Driving While Dialing
summary: The state's two top lawmakers and the governor endorsed a prohibition today on using hand-held cell phones while driving, making it likely that New York will be among the first states in the country to adopt such a ban. At separate news conferences, Joseph L. Bruno, majority leader of the State Senate, and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver said they supported the idea in concept, the first time either one had publicly taken that position. Neither house has ever voted on such a proposal.

headline: In a major consolidation, Verizon places most of its creative campaign work under one umbrella.
summary: IN one of the largest shifts ever of advertising assignments, Verizon Communications, the nation's biggest local telecommunications company, unexpectedly announced yesterday that it would consolidate most tasks involved with creating campaigns aimed at consumers and businesses by naming the New York office of Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide to handle those duties. Verizon, formed last year by the merger of Bell Atlantic and GTE, spends $400 million to $500 million a year on ads for local, long-distance and broadband services; products like call waiting; promoting the Verizon brand name; and burnishing its corporate image.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Stocks Decline on Tension Between U.S. and China Stocks declined broadly and sharply as worries about weak corporate earnings continued and concern mounted about rising tension between the United States and China. The Nasdaq composite index fell 57.29 points, or 3.1 percent, to 1,782.97. The Dow Jones industrial average did little better, closing at 9,777.93, down 100.85 points, or just more than 1 percent. And the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 14.46 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,145.87. [Page C12.]

headline: Stranded D.S.L. Customers Weigh Options
summary: LORI WESTIN, the manager of Oasis Family Practice in Denver, has weathered her share of headaches while coordinating her medical office's high-speed Internet service, but the past few days have been especially trying. Her service provider, HSA, relied on NorthPoint Communications for digital subscriber line, or D.S.L., service. And last week NorthPoint, in bankruptcy, said it was shutting down. Oasis was left without Internet access, and without access to its patient schedules, which were online.

headline: Invent a Brand Name
summary: As of December, Bill Nguyen had nearly everything he needed to start a successful business. He had a grand vision for the post-PC world: the current technobabble of cell phones, PDA's, pagers and other wireless gadgets could be woven into a unified global data-information network by a single company offering the right software. He had a proven record; at age 29, he had already been a key player in five start-ups, three of which had gone public. He had $34 million in venture capital and 60 eager employees. What he still didn't have, with his company's March inaugural date just two months away, was a name. With the Nasdaq's swoons causing widespread intestinal flutter, Nguyen knew a lot would hang on the first impression his company made. He wanted a name that would radiate strength and credibility, something with a dawn-of-an-era feel. He didn't even know where to start.

headline: METRO BRIEFING
summary: NEW YORK QUEENS: A REPRIEVE FOR RENTERS More than 1,000 residents who were in danger of losing their homes in the federally subsidized Marine Terrace apartments in Astoria have won a 10-year reprieve. The managers of the 440-unit complex, Marine Terrace Associates, threatened a year ago to drop out of the government's subsidy program, known as Section 8, and raise the rents sharply to market rate. But now the management has agreed to stay in the program for another decade, said Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a Queens Democrat. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

headline: Marketers are continuing their search for efficient haven in a storm-tossed economy.
summary: THREE large advertisers -- Dell Computer, Goodyear and PepsiCo -- are changing agencies on assignments with billings estimated at $220 million to $280 million. The Dell Computer Corporation is consolidating its account, with billings estimated at $150 million to $200 million, by naming agencies owned by the Omnicom Group to handle creative and media assignments.

headline: No Time to Put Your Feet Up As Retirement Comes in Stages
summary: Tom Griffiths retired as a telephone repairman at the end of his shift at the New York Stock Exchange one Friday last fall, ''just as if I was going home to put my feet up on the porch,'' he said. Come Monday morning, though, he was back on the trading floor, fixing the same telephone lines, this time as a part-time worker, with his pension making up for the lost income. ''I was a little leery'' of accepting the offer to ''sort of'' retire, admitted Mr. Griffiths, a 52-year-old Staten Island resident. But his employer, Avaya -- a recent spinoff of Lucent Technologies -- offered cash bonuses to encourage older workers to exchange their job security and full-time compensation for a novel blend of work and retirement.

headline: SOAPBOX; Frustrations of the Internet Age
summary: I GIVE up. I live in Bronxville, only 28 minutes from New York City, arguably the center of the world, and I still can't get D.S.L. in my home. What year is this? After two years of calling Cablevision (from the president's office on down) and always hearing ''next summer, in another six months, mid-2001, we're working on it,'' I bit the bullet and subscribed to Verizon D.S.L. last October and eagerly awaited my release from my agonizingly slow dial-up service. First, the service was scheduled to start Nov. 10. I called my friendly computer tutor, Jim Mulcahy at Computer Tutor@PCI. ''You do it, Jim,'' I said. ''Hardware is your department, I don't want to deal with it.''

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Spy Plane Crew Members Describe Ordeal in China On their first full day back home at the Whidbey Island Naval Air Station in Washington State, some members of the Navy spy plane crew detained in China gave the fullest account yet of their experiences, from the time their EP-3E surveillance plane was bumped by a Chinese fighter on April 1 to their release 11 days later. A9 Language Poses Security Peril Military, diplomatic and intelligence officials are warning of critical shortages in their ability to understand the languages of other nations, and so unravel their secrets. One of the reasons is that, with English increasingly becoming the world's lingua franca, the study of foreign languages has suffered. A1

headline: A New Festival of Jazz . . . and More
summary: The jazz impresario George Wein, chief executive of Festival Productions, and Bruce Gordon, president of retail markets for Verizon Communications, have announced a new festival of jazz and other music to be held in three cities, including New York. Called the Verizon Music Festival, it will take place from Aug. 8 to 11 in New York, Sept. 28 to Oct. 2 in Los Angeles and Oct. 24 to 27 in Tampa, Fla.

headline: Another F.C.C. Clearance For Verizon Long-Distance
summary: Verizon Communications received approval yesterday from federal regulators to provide long-distance service in Massachusetts, bringing to five the number of states where large Bell local telephone companies can enter into the fast-changing long-distance communications business. The approval by the Federal Communications Commission of Verizon's request in Massachusetts comes after the F.C.C. approved similar petitions in New York, Texas, Kansas and Oklahoma. By next year, analysts expect that the Bell companies, created from the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in the 1980's, could compete with AT&T and other long-distance companies in as many as 20 states.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Cisco Issues a Warning On Its Sales and Earnings Offering fresh evidence that economic growth is slowing sharply, Cisco Systems said that its sales and profits were falling far short of expectations. Cisco, whose stunning success in the 1990's mirrored the rise of the Internet, cited a worldwide economic slowdown as the reason for its problems. ''This may be the fastest any industry our size has ever decelerated,'' John Chambers, the company's chief executive, said in a statement. In a conference call later, Mr. Chambers compared the slowdown to a 100-year flood. ''We never built models to anticipate something of this magnitude,'' he said. [Page A1.]

headline: Sitting Pretty: How Baby Bells May Conquer Their World
summary: HERE is what the United States telecommunications industry may well look like in 2004: Of the Baby Bell local phone carriers, once seven in number, three remain -- Qwest Communications, SBC Communications and Verizon Communications -- and they are by far the most powerful and important communications companies in the nation. The corporations once known as long-distance carriers, like AT&T, are shells of their former selves.

headline: 2 Big Accounts Move Within Lowe's Orbit
summary: Lowe Lintas & Partners in New York, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is gaining and losing two large assignments in shifts that involve a Lowe Group sibling, the Martin Agency in Richmond, Va. Lowe Lintas is being assigned all national and regional creative, strategic and account management duties for Saab Cars U.S.A. in Norcross, Ga., part of the Saab unit of General Motors, with billings estimated at $60 million to $65 million. Those assignments had been handled until February by Martin, when Saab shifted them to Lowe Brindfors in Stockholm, the Swedish office of Lowe Lintas.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Compaq to Cut More Jobs As Profit Comes Up Short Compaq Computer reported first-quarter earnings that missed Wall Street's already lowered expectations by a penny. The company also said it would eliminate 2,000 more jobs than it had announced last month, increasing its cuts to 10 percent of its work force. Compaq made the cuts because of a steep decline in sales in the United States. But it cited double-digit growth in Europe and Asia as a sign of encouragement. [Page C4.]

headline: Verizon Would Extend Connecticut Long Distance
summary: Verizon Communications said yesterday that it would seek permission from federal regulators to offer long-distance telephone service in Connecticut, an initiative aimed at building on the company's modest foothold there. If approved, the application would allow Verizon to sell long-distance service to Connecticut's 2.4 million customers. Verizon, the nation's largest regional phone company, already provides long-distance service in New York and last week gained approval to offer it in Massachusetts.

headline: I.B.M. Will Acquire Database Unit of Informix for $1 Billion
summary: Stepping up its already intense battle with Oracle for supremacy in the world of software to manage huge databases, I.B.M. said yesterday that it would acquire the Informix Corporation's database operations for $1 billion. I.B.M. and Oracle have generally been rated by market researchers like Gartner Dataquest and International Data Corporation as neck-and-neck in the race for leadership in the $8 billion database market, with each company holding a share of more than 30 percent.

headline: Share Prices Gain on Better-Than-Expected Housing Sales
summary: Stocks gained yesterday for the first time in four days after housing sales rose faster than expected in March, lifting investor optimism that the economic slowdown may end soon. Pulte and other home builders were among the biggest gainers in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. General Electric led the advance on optimism that it would soon complete the purchase of Honeywell International. Philip Morris rallied on a report that the Justice Department might not have adequate financing for its lawsuit against the tobacco industry.

headline: Metro Business Briefing; STATE STEPS INTO VERIZON DISPUTE
summary: New York State's Public Service Commission said yesterday that it would order Verizon New York and the Communications Workers of America to set up procedures for handling employee contentions of inaccuracies or falsifications in Verizon's service-performance reports to the state. The union has said the reports contain inaccuracies and ''direct falsification,'' basing its charge, in part, on complaints that workers phone in on a union hotline. The company has called the charge false and the complaints unsubstantiated. A commission spokesman, David C. Flanagan, said the parties were also to work out procedures to prevent retribution against hotline users. A union research director, Kenneth Peres, said that in ordering the parties to resolve the dispute instead of doing its own investigation, the commission would ''default on its responsibility.'' A Verizon spokesman, Mark Marchand, said the commission's staff had found the company's procedures ''adequate to prevent any significant misreporting.'' Joseph P. Fried

headline: Vodafone Is Said to Be Close To a Deal on Japan Telecom
summary: The Vodafone Group of Britain is near a deal to acquire the stake that British Telecommunications holds in Japan Telecom and its affiliate, J-Phone Communications, for about $4.3 billion, executives close to the discussions said yesterday. The transaction comes on the heels of a similar deal Vodafone reached with AT&T to acquire its 10 percent stake in Japan Telecom for about $1.35 billion, which it completed yesterday.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
summary: BOEING CO., Seattle, which develops, produces and markets commercial jet aircraft, said that International Lease Finance Corp., an aircraft leasing company, was the initial customer for its longer-range 747-400 freighters with an order for five aircraft valued at $1 billion at list prices. RADIOSHACK CORP., Fort Worth, the consumer electronics retailing giant, said it would open a Verizon Wireless store-within-a-store at almost 4,400 of its locations across the United States. Verizon Wireless, Bedminster, N.J., is the nation's largest wireless communications provider.

headline: Sports of The Times; U.S. Teenager Brings Hope To Davis Cup
summary: I'VE got A-Rod right here,'' the public relations person from the men's tennis tour said on the telephone the other day. A-Rod? Had Alex Rodriguez got lost on his way to the Ballpark in Arlington, Tex., and wandered into the Westside Tennis Club in Houston? ''I'm the poor man's A-Rod,'' Andy Roddick explained, with an 18-year-old's chortle.

headline: Vodafone to Buy Stakes Held by British Telecom
summary: Vodafone said today that it would issue $4.3 billion in new stock to help it snap up important stakes in phone companies in Japan and Spain that British Telecommunications must sell. The stakes are high for both companies. Selling the positions represents an embarrassing reversal for Sir Peter Bonfield, British Telecom's chief executive, who had insisted his company was in the Japanese market for the long haul. But British Telecom's $43 billion in debt leaves it little choice.

headline: In the Region/New Jersey; A Few Telco Hotels Are Still in the Works
summary: HAVING served as a manufacturing plant that turned out aluminum cans and milk cartons and as an industrial building with myriad tenants, a hulking 72-year-old structure on Dey Street in Jersey City is again starting a new life. This time, it is being reshaped as a telecommunications hotel, despite a shakeout in the industry and dips in the Nasdaq stock index. Basically, a telecommunications hotel is a building where a number of Internet-based and communications businesses can lease space for their computers, switches and other equipment. While different carriers, like AT&T and MCI WorldCom, are rivals, they prefer to be grouped together so they can interconnect quickly and inexpensively. ''Telco hotels,'' like similar operations called server farms and data centers, provide security and extensive backup equipment that protects against power failure.

headline: Texan Finds That Pay Phones Can Pay Off
summary: Wireless phones do not frighten Charlie Sullivan. He has one himself and talks on it all day long while he drives around Texas seeking new places to put pay phones. He has 1,375 of those. Lots of people say wireless phones ought to scare Mr. Sullivan, president of ComChoice, a privately owned pay phone company based in Canyon Lake, in central Texas, about midway between San Antonio and Austin. But Mr. Sullivan intends to belie the widespread notion that cell phones are pushing pay phones off the American landscape.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
summary: RADIOSHACK CORP., Fort Worth, said Verizon Wireless will sell wireless telephones and service plans at almost 4,400 RadioShack stores as part of an alliance. SPECIALTY CATALOG CORP., South Easton, Mass., said it would go private through a sale to a company formed by several major shareholders. The new company will be called Specialty Acquisition Corp.

headline: Woods And Nelson Compare Notes
summary: One day when Tiger Woods was a teenager, he was pulled aside by Byron Nelson, who offered Woods some thoughts about the golf swing. It was a living legend offering advice to a legend in the making. Nelson, now 89 years old, holds the longest winning streak in professional golf history, winning 11 consecutive starts in 1945. When Woods won the Masters last month, he became the first player in golf history to win four consecutive professional majors, giving him six major championships at age 25.

headline: Flood of New Corporate Debt Pushes Down Treasury Prices
summary: Treasury prices posted their biggest losses in two weeks yesterday as investors sold government debt to buy more than $20 billion of bonds issued by companies including Viacom, WorldCom and the CIT Group. ''There's just no significant upside to Treasuries,'' said Mark MacQueen, who helps manage $1.7 billion of fixed-income assets at Sage Advisory Services in Austin, Tex., ''especially since there's a huge supply of corporate bonds coming to market.''

headline: Glimmers Of New Life In Initial Offerings
summary: IN the market for initial public offerings, nuclear winter appears to be over. But so far, it is a relatively silent spring. Just 24 companies sold shares publicly for the first time in the first quarter, according to Thomson Financial; they raised $7.5 billion. And only seven deals have been priced since the start of April, raising $2.5 billion.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Basque Nationalists Win Despite a Spanish Warning Basque nationalists won a vitriolic regional election, crushing the hopes of mainstream Spanish parties to seize the initiative in the country's troubled northern region. Voters rejected warnings from the national government that a victory for moderate nationalists would mean support for the armed separatist group E.T.A., which is blamed for almost 800 killings in the past 30 years. A7 Alliance Victory in India Jayalalitha Jayaram, a flamboyant politician convicted six months ago on corruption charges, led an alliance of parties to a landslide victory in Tamil Nadu. A3

headline: Weaving Dreams, or Webs?; Michael Dorf of Knitmedia, the Entrepreneur of the Musically Avant
summary: On a bright, cold afternoon in mid-January, Michael Dorf, owner of the Knitting Factory clubs in New York and Hollywood, strode into Odeon, a restaurant on West Broadway. His cell phone was attached to his ear, as always. To a harmless greeting -- ''How are you?'' -- Mr. Dorf, small, 38 and cyberhippie-ish, responded without his normal impish gleam. ''That's a loaded question,'' he sighed. His company was $2 million in debt, was how he was. Still, in an interview he summoned up a characteristic performance marked by optimism, nerve and apparent guilelessness.

headline: For E-Mail On the Go, Or the Sly
summary: DON'T let anyone tell you that two-way wireless messaging is a new technology -- using smoke signals, American Indians once sent instant messages to colleagues miles away. Of course, smoke signals had their drawbacks: reception was spotty in rainy weather, Microsoft Word attachments almost never came through, and the blankets got all sooty. Thanks to a recent invention that may best be described as an e-mail pager, the situation has improved enormously. These devices send and receive e-mail wirelessly, indoors or out, from almost anywhere in the country.

headline: AOL TIME WARNER AGREES TO ACQUIRE INFOINTERACTIVE
summary: AOL Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy InfoInterActive Inc. of Canada for $28.2 million to gain software that alerts people that they have a phone call while they are on the Internet. AOL Time Warner, based in New York, will pay 2.18 Canadian dollars ($1.42) for each InfoInterActive share, the company said. The price is a 45 percent premium to Thursday's closing share price of 1.50 Canadian dollars. InfoInterActive, based in Bedford, Nova Scotia, provides a service to phone companies known as Internet Call Manager. Its customers include Verizon Communications Inc.

headline: College Foundation To Honor Verizon
summary: Over the last nine years, Verizon (formerly Nynex and Bell Atlantic) has donated $75,000 to Westchester Community College. On Wednesday, the college foundation will honor the company for its contributions at an awards dinner. Why would a telecommunications company take such a strong interest in a community college? In part, the answer lies in the fact that the college trains many of Verizon's employees.

headline: Warm-Weather Blues, With Pop and Jazz
summary: The first three-city Verizon Music Festival, which is to include free outdoor concerts in New York in August, was announced yesterday by Verizon and Festival Productions, the event's producer. The New York festival, from Aug. 7 to 11, will begin with a free concert, ''Verizon Spotlight on Emerging Talent,'' in Bryant Park. It will showcase little-known local musicians with Chuck Mangione as headliner.

headline: Corrections
summary: An article on Tuesday about the first Verizon Music Festival in New York misstated the site for one series of concerts. ''Forward Motion: 50 Years of 'New' Music'' will take place Aug. 7 to 9 at the Pace Downtown Theater, 3 Spruce Street, in Lower Manhattan, not at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center.

headline: Wireless Wanderer: A Field Study
summary: I'M not much of an apostle for the wireless cause. Whether it's because I feel my life is busy enough or because of my upbringing in rural New Mexico -- my family didn't get a telephone until I was 8, and then it was a party line -- I seem to have an inherent skepticism of new devices. So up to now I've gotten through life -- and my job as a reporter covering telecommunications -- as a wireless innocent. Aside from a cell phone, I don't carry or own any mobile gadgetry. Perhaps I've been missing something.

headline: Pride and Practicalities Loom Behind Failed Lucent 'Merger'
summary: How many billions of dollars is appearance worth to Lucent Technologies? That is one of the many questions that investors might have asked after Lucent and Alcatel of France, two of the world's biggest makers of communications equipment, called off their merger talks Tuesday.

headline: AT&T to Raise Some Rates By as Much as 11 Percent
summary: AT&T said yesterday that it would raise basic residential phone rates as much as 11 percent, beginning July 1. The company, facing a decline in consumer long-distance revenue this year, will increase basic weekday rates to 30 cents a minute from 29.5 cents; night-time rates to 25 cents a minute from 22.5 cents; and weekend rates to 16 cents from 14.5 cents. A basic rate for calls made at any time will rise to 17.5 cents a minute from 16 cents.

headline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Case Of McCall's Daughter
summary: Larceny and other charges against the daughter of H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, were dismissed yesterday and the court records sealed. Marcella McCall, 37, a former business manager at Verizon, was arrested in March and accused of misusing Verizon credit cards and writing nearly $100,000 in bad checks, the police said. But a lawyer for Verizon said the complaint had been premature. Katherine E. Finkelstein (NYT)

headline: Software Failure Halts Big Board Trading for Over an Hour
summary: A failed software upgrade left investors unable to trade shares on the New York Stock Exchange for nearly an hour and a half yesterday morning. The shutdown, the second the exchange has suffered in three years, prevented many stocks from opening for trading. As a result, the exchange shut its trading floor at 10:10 a.m. Trading resumed in most stocks by 11:35 a.m., but shares in the most severely affected companies, including I.B.M. and Verizon Communications, did not open until the afternoon.

headline: Metro Business Briefing | Verizon's Plans For New Jersey
summary: Verizon Communications may ask in the next few weeks for New Jersey's endorsement of its plan to sell long-distance service in the state, an executive said yesterday. Verizon needs the endorsement of the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities and approval from the Federal Communications Commission to offer the service, the executive, Dennis M. Bone, said. Mr. Bone is state president of Verizon New Jersey. Verizon, which is based in New York, will file its application after state regulators complete a two-year examination of local-phone networks, perhaps within two weeks, Mr. Bone said.

headline: A First for I.B.M: On-Site Day Care
summary: CELESTINA BEAKES looked like a cherub as she napped in her crib at the Country Children's Center here, a vision of serene babyhood. Small wonder that her father, Michael, couldn't resist the impulse to pick up his 16-month-old daughter and cuddle her. ''I needed to give her a hug,'' said Dr. Beakes, a senior engineer at the I.B.M. Thomas J. Watson Research Center here.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Collapse of Talks With AOL Could Imperil Microsoft The collapse of talks between Microsoft and AOL Time Warner over bundling their software threatens consumers with having to choose between two competing online worlds and leaves Microsoft on a perilous course. In walking away from a stronger partnership with AOL, Microsoft is running the risk of another round of legal challenges related to its new operating system, Windows XP, and it is gambling that the opposition of AOL and its 30 million users won't hurt the system's introduction this fall. [Section A.]

headline: Accounts
summary: Verizon Wireless, a joint venture of Verizon Communications and Vodafone, expanded its relationship with the Irvine, Calif., office of Campbell Mithun, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, by naming the agency to handle its reorganized account for an enlarged Western region. Campbell Mithun was previously the agency of record for the Southwest. Billings for the combined account were estimated at $40 million.

headline: Union Says Verizon Broke Organizing Accord
summary: Hundreds of union protesters rallied yesterday at the headquarters of Verizon Communications in Manhattan, asserting that the company was violating a labor contract in which it agreed not to fight organizing drives at nonunion operations. At the rally, officials of the Communications Workers of America said that Verizon had sought to block various organizing drives despite a ''neutrality'' clause agreed to after a 18-day strike last August by 35,000 members of the union.

headline: Metro Business Briefing | Telephone Access Fees Attacked
summary: State consumer advocates in New Jersey and New York urged on Monday that their states' telephone regulators cut the fees that Verizon Communications charges other companies needing access to its lines to provide competing local phone service. In New Jersey, Blossom A. Peretz, the ratepayer advocate, called on the Board of Public Utilities to reduce Verizon's charges for such access to less than $10 per line a month, from the $16.21 the board set in 1997. That fee was voided last year by a federal judge saying that they have been set in an arbitrary and capricious manner. Bruce Cohen, general counsel for Verizon New Jersey, said yesterday that Ms. Peretz was asking his company to ''subsidize our competitors'' by providing them access ''at a rate below our cost.'' In New York, the attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer, urged the Public Service Commission to adopt access-fee cuts recommended by an administrative law judge. Cliff Lee, a Verizon New York spokesman, said his company would respond in a brief that it would submit to the commission. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

headline: Is There Life After AOL
summary: AN overprotective parent. Comfortable old shoes or pajamas. A bad marriage. People who subscribe to America Online, America's largest Internet service provider, use a variety of metaphors to describe their feelings about it. Like McDonald's, the fast food purveyor that people love to hate, AOL has many ambivalent customers. ''What surprises me is that so many people use AOL but no one seems to like it,'' said Rose Miller, a potter in Sandia Park, N.M. ''A lot of people complain about it.''

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Long-Distance Petition
summary: Verizon Communications said yesterday that it had requested federal approval to offer long-distance service in Pennsylvania. Verizon is barred from offering long-distance and data services to its local customers unless it can prove that competition exists in the local telephone market. A Verizon spokesman said about one million telephone lines in Pennsylvania -- roughly 14 percent -- were served by competitors. The Federal Communications Commission must rule on the application within 90 days. The F.C.C. has cleared the way for the company to offer long-distance service in New York and Massachusetts. Verizon is also seeking clearance in Connecticut.

headline: The Gift of Gab Comes at a Cost
summary: PHYLLIS HUGHES, a 58-year-old widow, looked out from a window of her freshly painted ranch house and gestured toward the end of the street where a 115-foot cellular tower could soon loom over this middle-class neighborhood. ''Sure,'' she said. She and her husband, Joe, knew they were moving next to a public works yard when they bought their home here 30 years ago -- he has since died -- but they felt that was the price of being able to afford a house in what Worth magazine recently listed as the 248th wealthiest community in the country.

headline: New York to Be First State to Ban Holding Cell Phone While Driving
summary: New York will become the first state to ban talking on a hand-held cellular telephone while driving, under a bill that the Assembly passed today and that the governor promised to sign later this week. ''It's a good bill,'' said Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker. ''This is going to save lives, I'm sure.''

headline: The 4-Letter-Word Patrol Is in Pursuit
summary: Several years ago, Carl Jaskolski and a few employees he supervised at a Milwaukee social services agency put a quarter into a ''cussing jar'' every time they swore. His weekly contribution averaged $3. But today, Mr. Jaskolski, a specialist in human resources at the Concordia University business school in Mequon, Wis., has become a self-described antiswearing zealot.

headline: Dial M for Muddle: A Cell-Phone Story That Never Ends
summary: These days, when Claudine Barbot's telephone rings, she approaches with trepidation. She's never sure what she might hear. Some callers apologize for bothering her. Others do not. ''I'm an old lady,'' said Ms. Barbot, 70. ''I can't even repeat what they say. I am French. We don't speak like that.''

headline: Metro Business Briefing | Long-Distance Expansion
summary: Verizon Communications says it intends to seek approval from the Federal Communications Commission to provide long-distance phone service in New Jersey by the end of the year. Verizon, based in New York, made the announcement on Saturday in a wide-ranging statement on the anniversary of its formation by the merger of Bell Atlantic and GTE on June 30, 2000. Verizon and other companies derived from the breakup of AT&T in 1984 are barred from long-distance service until they can show regulators that their local calling markets are open to competition. Verizon expects to seek long-distance approvals this year in Rhode Island, New Hampshire and Vermont, said Ivette Mendez, a Verizon spokeswoman. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

headline: Market Place; As AT&T Wireless strikes out on its own, the other bits and pieces of AT&T remain in play.
summary: THE complex breakup of AT&T could become a bit less complicated today when the company plans to complete its spinoff of AT&T Wireless to shareholders. Under the transaction, AT&T shareholders who opted last month not to exchange all of their shares for AT&T Wireless stock will receive about a third of a share in the wireless company for each share they own of AT&T.

headline: AT&T Wireless shifts its big account to Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide from Foote, Cone & Belding.
summary: IN one of the largest changes by a big advertiser in recent memory, AT&T Wireless said yesterday that it had named Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, part of the WPP Group, to handle its advertising account. The move ended a three-year relationship between AT&T Wireless and Foote, Cone & Belding, now part of the FCB Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Billings were estimated at $400 million. AT&T Wireless was spun off from the AT&T Corporation on Monday as part of a larger reorganization at AT&T.

headline: Left at the Altar; Jilted Merger Partners Increasingly Turn to the Courts
summary: When a big merger broke down in years past, as they often did, the last thing corporate managers wanted was costly, distracting, time-consuming, risky litigation. But some companies recently ditched at the altar are preparing to drag their runaway merger partners into court.

headline: The Fabled No. 7, Not So Lucky These Days
summary: SUBWAY riders in the city need a strategy. For many riders of the No. 7 train, whose sassy red cars shuttle between Times Square and Flushing, Queens, the big decision in the past year has been whether to squeeze onto a crowded morning rush-hour car or wait several minutes for another train that might be a beat less packed. Call it speed versus space, in a city in which commuters crave both. The trains come often and they are clean, riders say, but the borough has grown so much and so quickly that even at one train every 2.5 minutes (according to city transit officials) it's not enough.

headline: Against All Odds, A Telecom Rebirth
summary: BY the time Theodore B. Olson walked into a Washington courtroom on a cloudy morning in March, it would have taken close to a miracle to save his client, NextWave Telecom, from ruin. Founded by a former top executive at Qualcomm, Allen B. Salmasi, and financed by a group of veterans of Drexel Burnham Lambert, the defunct investment banking firm, and a coterie of hedge funds, NextWave had been stuck in bankruptcy since 1998; the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia was its last hope.

headline: Silver Picks Group to Study School Control
summary: In a sign that the State Assembly's opposition to mayoral control of New York City schools may be softening, Speaker Sheldon Silver has appointed a committee to study the issue and make recommendations. Mr. Silver, who has long and staunchly defended an independent Board of Education to which the mayor appoints a minority of the members, is to introduce the lawmakers, business executives and education officials who will make up the committee at a news conference today. A news release yesterday afternoon said only that the group would explore ''policy options for the Assembly regarding governance of the central administration of New York City's public schools.''

headline: In the Region/New Jersey; In Newark Urban Desert, New Homes Begin to Rise
summary: THE rundown blocks in the area off Route 78 near Newark Airport, splotched with boarded-up buildings and lacking such urban amenities as shopping and playgrounds, seem an unlikely nest for dreams of home ownership and community. Yet the place is proving to be a fertile incubator for visions of a better life.

headline: Wireless Settlement Offered
summary: Five major wireless telephone carriers urged federal officials today to offer NextWave Telecom $4 billion to $5 billion to relinquish its claim to wireless licenses that it acquired several years ago for $4.7 billion, said a spokesman for one company, Verizon Wireless. The companies were among those that bid nearly $16 billion for the licenses at an auction in January after NextWave filed for bankruptcy protection and defaulted on its payments. The money from the auction would have gone to the Treasury Department.

headline: Those Charming Steeples Aren't So Quaint Anymore
summary: THE Connecticut skyline has always been defined by its church steeples, those towers that rise about the trees and give so many of the state's communities their charm. But in a 21st century twist, these old spires that were originally built to resemble Christopher Wren's stone steeples in London are becoming the camouflage to hide microwave antennas for cell phone companies. What started slowly just a few years ago is becoming much more common, with church after church in town after town turning over the rooftops to the telephone companies. In return, cash-strapped churches not only receive monthly rent from the companies, but also get their steeples, often in desperate need of repairs, renovated for free. It is a gift many churches just can't pass up. ''We are a very poor church, trying our best to help the people in the community,'' said the Rev. Allison B. Cook of St. James Episcopal Church in Derby, where Verizon Wireless installed an antenna in 1997. ''This was, for us, a gift. And it was going to go somewhere.''
