Despite concerns about the health effects of microwave radiation and the queasiness over letting commercial ventures use their space, about 20 churches have cut deals with the phone companies and more are in negotiation.

headline: The Bills Are Paid
summary: Tucked away in a nondescript office park outside of town is a technological powerhouse with plenty of financial backing that is poised to revolutionize the way people pay bills and manage their finances. Just three years old in its current iteration, the company, Princeton eCom, is fast becoming a leader in the emerging field of electronic bill paying.

headline: Internet Services Must Help Fight Online Movie Pirates, Studios Say
summary: Anyone who wanted to see 20th Century Fox's ''Planet of the Apes'' over the weekend had a choice: pay to see it in a theater or get it free over the Internet, where pirated copies surfaced within hours of its release on Friday. The instant Internet availability of illicit copies of new Hollywood films has become commonplace over the last year. And Internet providers, which are legally obligated to remove pirated material from Web sites they host once a copyright holder asks them to do so, are accustomed to quickly complying with such requests.

headline: Mixed Data on Economy Give Dow an Early Rally
summary: Stocks rose yesterday as investors took heart from economic data showing unexpected strength in consumer spending. But the rally faded somewhat in the afternoon, and some analysts questioned how sustainable yesterday's gains would be. ''People are very skittish,'' said Jon B. Brorson, director of equities at Northern Trust in Chicago. ''Even though they put money to work, there was not a great deal of conviction. We're very tenuous, too.''

headline: Verizon Posts a Loss and Cuts 2001 Forecasts
summary: Verizon Communications lowered its profit forecast for the year yesterday, citing falling demand for business phone services, and it posted a second-quarter loss as the value of some investments dropped. Verizon, one of the regional Bell giants, said that before write-downs it expected a profit of $3.07 to $3.12 a share, down from the $3.13 to $3.17 it had forecast earlier.

headline: AT HOME WITH/George Wein; Art, Life and All That Jazz
summary: IF you go deep enough into the East Side apartment of George and Joyce Wein -- through a long corridor hung with luminous African-American artwork and into the farthest, smallest bathroom -- you'll come upon a black-and-white photograph of Mr. Wein with Bill Cosby and a group of jazz musicians. Mr. Wein is in the center of the picture, and everyone is poised in a mixture of bonhomie and anticipation. In a home built by jazz, the photograph is one of the few mementos hinting at the pivotal role Mr. Wein (he pronounces it WEEN) has played in jazz during his half-century as a pianist, club owner and festival promoter.

headline: Phone Firms Seek More Time on 911 Locator
summary: Several major mobile phone companies say they may not meet Oct 1 Federal Communications Commission deadline for being able to pinpoint location of subscribers making emergency 911 calls on specially equipped phones; say new phones and systems for receiving and interpreting site data are unlikely to be in broad use until sometime in 2002; Verizon Wireless and other carriers are seeking extensions (M)

headline: A Call for Broadband
summary: To the Editor: Re ''Shakeout in Fiber Optics'' (editorial, July 29):

headline: Digitally Disenfranchised; Bell Companies Are Blamed For the Slow Start Of a Fast Internet Service
summary: A year ago, Hossein Farmani, president of aNet Communications, a small Internet service provider in Los Angeles, catered to a loyal group of longtime customers. ANet was no AOL, but Mr. Farmani was content to preside over a small community of 5,000 or so users. Yet the customer loyalty proved to be highly elastic. Mr. Farmani discovered that providing competitively priced D.S.L. service -- a form of high-speed Internet connection -- had become close to impossible. Lured by lower prices to Pacific Bell Internet, the big telephone company's own Internet unit, half of Mr. Farmani's customers had deserted aNet.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Ericsson Wins Verizon Order
summary: The Swedish phone equipment maker Ericsson will supply Verizon Wireless, the biggest United States mobile phone operator, with wireless handsets that allow high-speed access to the Web, e-mail and other services. The two companies are testing new handsets that use code-division multiple access, or C.D.M.A., technology to increase the transmission capacity of digital networks. Ericsson says its C.D.M.A. handsets transmit information at up to 144 kilobits a second. Most current cell phones run wireless Web applications at around 11 kilobits a second. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

headline: United Way Is Reporting 3.8% Increase in Donations
summary: The 1,400 local United Ways raised $3.91 billion in the year ended June 30, an increase of $140 million or about 3.8 percent over a year earlier, Ellie Ferdon, chairwoman of United Way of America, the national organization, will announce today. It is the fifth consecutive year that giving to the fund-raising organizations increased faster than inflation. The modest real growth in donations to the nation's largest private financier of social services comes as demand for the services is rising and as President Bush promotes the idea that charities are better suited than government to provide many social services.

headline: Footlights
summary: All This Jazz Playing jazz, talking about jazz and evoking jazz through photographs are all on the schedule at Columbia University as part of the 2001 Verizon Music Festival. On Friday from 9 a.m to 6:30 p.m. in room 312 of the university's Mathematics Building, a symposium of jazz scholars, musicians, poets and photographers will consider ''The Sources of Jazz,'' and from tomorrow through Aug. 23, the LeRoy Neiman Gallery in Dodge Hall will be the site of ''Jazz in the City: New Orleans and Harlem,'' a show of jazz photographs by Michael P. Smith and Gerald Cyrus. On Saturday, as the closing attraction, a free outdoor concert from 4 to 9 p.m. in the Columbia Quadrangle at 116th Street and Broadway will feature the vocalist Abby Lincoln, the Wayne Shorter Quartet, the James Carter Chasin' the Gypsy Band and the Big 3 Palladium Orchestra, with Tito Puente Jr., among others.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
summary: SUMMA INDUSTRIES, Torrance, Calif., a maker of engineered plastic products, has hired U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray, Minneapolis, an investment bank, to assist it in considering strategic options, including the sale of the company. FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES , Cincinnati, owner of Macy's and Bloomingdale's, signed agreements with stores in Australia, Chile and Peru to supply private-brand merchandise. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: SPARE TIMES
summary: Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. A performance and film series through tomorrow, ''Indigenous Peoples: Old Ways and New Challenges,'' offers the film ''Wisdomkeepers,'' at 1 p.m.; Mohawk Singers and Dancers, at 3 p.m.; and readings by the Native American Writers Circle, at 4 p.m, in the Linder Theater. Imax films include ''Bears,'' along with screenings of ''Shackleton's Antarctic Adventure'' and ''Lost Worlds: Life in the Balance.'' Call for screening information. Separate admission for Imax films: $15; $11 for students and 60+; $9 for children under 12. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and 60+; children 12 and under, $6; under 2, free. Combination tickets are available. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Verity Shares Tumble On Loss Forecast
summary: Verity Inc., a maker of search-engine software that had been forecasting a fiscal first-quarter profit, said it now expects a loss as a result of reduced orders by its customers, which include AT&T Wireless and Verizon Communications. The company's shares fell $3.08, or 24.3 percent, to $9.62. The loss will be as much as 12 cents a share on sales of $20 million to $24 million, in the quarter ending Aug. 31, the company said. Verity, which previously forecast sales of about $36 million, had been expected to earn 13 cents a share, according to analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call.

headline: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
summary: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert. CLAUDIA ACUÑA, EDITUS, Queens Theater in the Park, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, near Exit 9E, Grand Central Parkway, (718) 760-0064. Claudia Acuña, a jazz singer from Chile who has made her way onto the New York club circuit, shares a bill with Editus, which is taking a night off from its collaborations with Rubén Blades. This classically trained group from Costa Rica brings its virtuosity to music with deep Latin American roots. Sunday night at 7; tickets are $20 in advance, $25 on Sunday, $23 for 65+, $18 for members (Jon Pareles).

headline: An Exalted Position
summary: IF doo-wop music had not faded, Arthur Mayer Jr. might have gone on from his debut on ''American Bandstand'' in the late 1950's to a recording career. Instead he spent his life working for the telephone company and rising through the ranks of Elkdom, until last month, July 12 to be exact, when he achieved the national title of Grand Exalted Ruler of the Elk.

headline: Author and Telephone Repairman Finds Art in Imitating His Life
summary: Whatever the merits of that well-worn advice to aspiring authors to ''write what you know,'' it's guidance that Michael Ledwidge of Kingsbridge has clearly taken to heart. Mr. Ledwidge, 30, wrote ''Bad Connection,'' a thriller published by Pocket Books in April that features an Irish-American telephone cable splicer from the Bronx who roams Midtown climbing into manholes to fix phone lines. Mr. Ledwidge happens to be an Irish-American splicer who repairs phone lines for Verizon in Midtown. Mr. Ledwidge wrote his first crime novel, ''The Narrowback,'' published in 1999 and reissued in April in paperback by Pocket, while working the night shift as a doorman and freight elevator operator at a luxury apartment building at East 58th Street and Park Avenue. That book, by the way, features a blue-collar Irish-American protagonist and starts off at a luxury Midtown hotel.

headline: 5 Groups in 6 Hours, From the 30's to the 90's
summary: Musical eras flashed by and intermingled like happily jumbled memories at the Verizon Jazz Festival's finale, a free concert Saturday afternoon on the Columbia University campus. The 1930's, 50's, 60's and 90's were all up for grabs as five first-rate groups appeared during the six-hour concert. The saxophonist Wayne Shorter's quartet was back in New York after a JVC Jazz Festival appearance, and it had been honed by touring in between. Mr. Shorter's 1960's and 70's compositions are revered in modern jazz, and his new quartet revisits those pieces by shattering and reassembling them. Where Mr. Shorter once wrote songful melodies and richly devious harmonies, his new quartet also works with moods, juxtapositions and a rigorous sense of flux. The music was always headed somewhere new.

headline: Ricochet Network Lived Fast and Died Young
summary: IN the Ricochet wireless network, more than 50,000 customers believed they had found fast, reliable Internet access. But last week they became the latest victims of the telecom shakeout as Ricochet's operator, Metricom, shut the network down, a month after filing for bankruptcy. For $69 to $79 a month, plus $200 to $300 for a Ricochet wireless modem that connected to most desktop, laptop or hand-held computers, Ricochet users could get online and browse the Web from anywhere, without dialing out on a phone line. What's more, Ricochet's access rates of 128 kilobits per second were twice those of regular phone lines.

headline: School Plan: Basic Change
summary: For weeks, as Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy prepared a long-awaited restructuring of the Board of Education's central administration, the focus of both the chancellor's supporters and his critics was on how many jobs would be cut and how much money saved. The elimination of 1,500 administrative positions over three years, producing anticipated savings of $300 million to $500 million, was large enough to impress many. Even Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani scaled back his criticism of the chancellor, at least for a day, after the plan was announced on Wednesday.

headline: Cooperating for Art's Sake
summary: THE Hammond Museum in North Salem, known for its Japanese Stroll Garden and an esoteric collection of fans, was struggling in the early 1990's, after the death of its founder, Natalie Hammond. Just when it seemed the museum would go under, help came in the form of a municipal challenge grant from the Westchester Arts Council. This was not the usual matching grant, in which an arts group finds a private or corporate donor. To receive the $5,000 grant, the museum had to raise at least that much from the Town of North Salem.

headline: New Economy; Despite the free minutes, low rates and other sale pitches, quality of service remains an issue for wireless customers.
summary: OPEN just about any publication these days and there are likely to be advertisements for wireless phone service, promising hundreds, if not thousands, of monthly minutes, equipment rebates, free long distance and advanced digital services like Web access or the ability to send and receive e-mail messages. With the number of wireless subscribers in the United States hovering at about 40 percent of the population, and 25 percent of those users switching providers every year, wireless companies are scrambling to entice more consumers to sign up for a cell phone or jump ship from a competing provider in exchange for a better deal.

headline: Foraging for Music in the Digital Jungle
summary: I've been spending a lot of time crawling around on my hands and knees lately. The reason is a self-assigned experiment: to spend two weeks listening only to music streamed or downloaded from the Internet. These were not consecutive weeks. The first took place last winter, just before a United States Circuit Court of Appeals upheld a lower court's ruling ordering Napster to halt unauthorized exchange of copyrighted songs. The second took place a few weeks ago, in a post-Napster online universe.

headline: Metro Business Briefing | AT&T To Add Monthly Charge
summary: Beginning on Sept. 1, AT&T will add a monthly charge of $1.35 for in-state long-distance service to most residential customers' bills, the company has said. It said the charge was needed because it had to pay fees to local phone companies, predominantly Verizon, for access to networks to complete in-state long-distance calls. A Verizon spokeswoman, Ivette Mendez, said yesterday that there was no justification for the fee increase because the access fees Verizon charges have gone down. The disagreement is the latest in a dispute between AT&T and Verizon over fees AT&T pays to use Verizon's system. AT&T customers whose long-distance bills are less than $1 will not have to pay the new fee, nor will customers in its program for low-income customers. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

headline: Private Sector; Better to Talk with Him by Phone
summary: A word of caution if you're planning to speak with Ivan G. Seidenberg, co-chief executive of Verizon Communications, the nation's largest local telephone company. Don't say bottleneck. ''It makes me fire-engine red,'' Mr. Seidenberg, 53, said in an interview last week. ''I don't like it because it's a label and I hate labels.''

headline: Joan Keating and James Durning
summary: FAMILY ties do bind, but sometimes in unexpected ways. In August 1996, Joan Carole Keating, now 40, was invited by an old pal, Eileen Brady, to spend the weekend at a large share house in Westhampton Beach, N.Y. There she noticed James Richard Durning, 39, a friend of Ms. Brady's husband, Steve Geary. Initially, Ms. Keating, who is divorced, thought the woman with Mr. Durning was a date. But when Ms. Keating and Mr. Durning, a field technician for Verizon, started talking, she learned the woman was his cousin, Deirdre Durning. By the wee hours of the morning, Ms. Keating and Mr. Durning were swimming in the pool overlooking Aspatuck Creek.

headline: Vivendi: La Différence
summary: Jean-Marie Messier, the chairman of Vivendi Universal of France, was flying over Belgium on Aug. 17 when he began his survey. It was a topological study, not of the farmland far below but of the global media landscape. ''What are the groups which are building direct relationships with customers and which are not?'' he said. ''I think you have clearly in one camp AOL Time Warner and Vivendi Universal, building these direct customer relationships. And on the other side you have another group which is not doing it, where you find Disney, where you find Viacom. And you have someone in the middle, which is News Corp.''

headline: In Capitol, AT&T and Bells Fight to Control Web Access
summary: The country's regional Bell telephone companies and the cable giant AT&T are engaged in a furious fight on Capitol Hill over the rules managing the rollout of high-speed Internet access into Americans' homes, in the process reopening one of the most bitter lobbying clashes of the last decade. The battle is over the two main technologies that give consumers high-speed, or broadband, Internet access: cable modem service offered by companies like AT&T and digital subscriber lines, or D.S.L., provided by phone companies. Both sides say they have consumers' interests at heart.

headline: Nearest Cross Street? Divide by 2, and Subtract 31, or See the Phone Book
summary: As many New Yorkers know, it's not hard to find a building, even if you don't know the cross street. For, say, 1622 First Avenue, all you have to do is drop the last digit, divide what's left -- 162 -- in half and add 3. Presto! Of course, if you want to pinpoint the street nearest 2245 Broadway, the formula is slightly different. You just drop the last number, divide 224 in half and subtract 31. A cinch! And so it goes -- a different mathematical formula for finding an address on almost every avenue and sometimes more than one per avenue.

headline: BellSouth's Down-Home Strategy; Local Telephone Service Has Become a Haven For Cautious Company
summary: The oak furniture. The neckties and starched shirts. The hushed banter of secretaries outside large corner offices. And the steady, predictable stream of profits generated by the dominant local telephone company in the Southeast. At its corporate headquarters in a nondescript high-rise here, it seems as if BellSouth remains untouched by the frenzied changes that have shaken the telecommunications world in recent years.

headline: 6 Democrats Seek Council Nomination in an Increasingly Diverse Area
summary: In a Brooklyn Council district that stretches from the Coney Island Boardwalk up to the historic houses of Gravesend, what had once been a contest of one is now a race among six candidates who say they want to unify an increasingly diverse area. The contest in the 47th Council District to succeed Howard L. Lasher, who is leaving office because of term limits, at first had, in essence, just one participant, Marsha Rapaport. But after she died last fall, ''the race was busted wide open,'' in the words of one candidate, Domenic M. Recchia.

headline: It Is Third and Long For Fox's Summerall
summary: Pat Summerall does not want to stop being John Madden's partner on Fox's National Football League broadcasts, nor does he think he deserves to be left dangling by network officials who refuse to commit to him beyond this season. ''I'm not challenging anyone,'' said Summerall, whose contract ends after this season. ''But they gave me three options in July, and I was told the possibility of working with John was very remote. The other two were not with John.''

headline: Federal Agency Says Verizon Broke Law Regarding Union
summary: The National Labor Relations Board is preparing a complaint against Verizon Communications saying the company violated federal labor law by seeking to prevent efforts to unionize employees, according to a letter sent to union officials. After investigating several dozen reports of irregularities from employees of Verizon -- the nation's largest local telephone company, formed when Bell Atlantic acquired the GTE Corporation -- the N.L.R.B. said it had found 86 labor violations in New York State.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cisco and Verizon In Deal
summary: Cisco Systems and Verizon said they were teaming up to provide high-speed Internet services for employees working at home. The companies said they would focus on Fortune 1000 companies and governments seeking network access at home and the office. Cisco said it would provide equipment from the Cisco 800 and SOHO product lines, while Verizon would provide service over a network. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

headline: National Briefing | Northeast: Massachusetts: Lawyer Challenges F.B.I.
summary: A lawyer for a North Carolina bank robbery suspect charged with killing three men in Massachusetts and New Hampshire said there was evidence that his client, Gary Sampson, left, called the Boston office of the F.B.I. offering to turn himself in the day before the slayings began. The lawyer, Stephanie Paige, said she would ask a judge to force the F.B.I. and the Verizon telephone company to turn over records of a call she said Mr. Sampson made on July 23. An F.B.I. spokeswoman said the bureau was investigating the matter. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

headline: Still Reeling From Losses, New York Looks for Makeshift Solutions
summary: New York City and State struggled yesterday to provide critical services to the five boroughs, patching holes in staffing and equipment with borrowed suburban firefighters and National Guard troops, police officers on 12-hour shifts, and makeshift headquarters for agencies forced to flee the destruction downtown. But some holes could not be filled. City schools were closed yesterday for a second day, but most -- excluding those below 14th Street -- were expected to open today, two hours late. Most of the bridges and tunnels linking Manhattan to the outside world were closed, a few opened, and officials predicted still more openings in the coming days.

headline: A Few Moments of Hope In a Mountain of Rubble
summary: They found themselves in the landscape of nightmare, with jagged stumps marking where mighty buildings once stood, with the sky shrouded by smoke and the ground coated in ash, and search dogs overwhelmed by the smell of flesh in the acrid air. But there was no time to comprehend it all, not with the driving if faint hope that buried somewhere beneath there breathed survivors. And every now and then, word of a miracle raced through the ranks -- of a man asking about his children, of a woman with hair still neatly braided -- inspiring hundreds of soot-covered, weary rescue workers to continue digging into the debris and steel that once were the World Trade Center towers.

headline: Bond Trading Set to Resume; Stocks Delayed
summary: A reeling financial community decided late yesterday to resume trading of bonds today but to delay the resumption of stock trading for at least one more day. ''We want to be what we have been for 200 years, the finest capital market in the world,'' said Richard Grasso, the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, as he announced the decision, which was reached after a prolonged meeting of government and financial industry officials.

headline: Phone Service Improving, But Many Still Lack Power
summary: Telephone service in Manhattan apparently improved yesterday, but it was far from normal and many people still had trouble placing calls. Most telephone disruptions have been caused by the extraordinary volume of calls, which remained high as many people returned to work.

headline: Amid Anxiety, Markets Edge Back Toward Routines
summary: Citing new figures suggesting that the economy was tipping into recession even before the terrorist attacks on Tuesday, economists said yesterday that the ripple effects from the assault would almost surely bring to an end the record-setting expansion that began more than a decade ago. Though many Americans were slowly returning to work and to normal shopping patterns, car dealers reported that their lots were empty, real estate agents said buying had slowed, and deal makers said corporations had put off just about every major decision.

headline: Big Board and Nasdaq Report Successful Tests for Tomorrow's Resumption of Trading
summary: The New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq stock market, twin centers of American capitalism, said yesterday that they had successfully tested their communications systems and would be open for business tomorrow. Communications, utilities and transportation systems remain fragile in Lower Manhattan, and at least two major securities firms will have to conduct their trading from backup sites. Given these challenges, concerns linger about whether trading can possibly be smooth on what may prove to be a very heavy day of buying and selling with unusual volatility.

headline: A Black Cloud. A Shower of Glass. A Glimpse of Hell. Run!
summary: Dawn drew pink edges on the twin towers of the World Trade Center on Tuesday, Sept. 11, 2001. But as the sun rose higher, two jet planes were headed toward Lower Manhattan, determined to make it the last day for thousands. For those who could only watch, those who survived and those who tried to pull life from the ruins, some memories of the day have turned to blurs while others are icy-sharp images. What follows is a collection of raw memories, gathered while the debris still swirled. ANNE CRONIN

headline: City to Create Commission To Oversee Reconstruction
summary: New York City will form a reconstruction commission with extraordinary powers to lead the recovery from the terrorist destruction of the World Trade Center, officials said yesterday, as the city prepared for today's return of business and government to Lower Manhattan. Work crews continued to pull tons of mangled metal and crumbled concrete, along with human remains, from the smoking ruins of the trade center. But for the fourth straight day, no victims were found alive. The city's official tally of bodies reached 190, with 4,957 people missing and feared dead.

headline: For Cellphone Holdouts, Worry Closes the Sale
summary: Eloina Dominguez, a 25-year-old Queens resident, has never owned a cellphone and had not really wanted one. ''I don't want to be made part of other people's conversations,'' she said. That changed last week. First she heard the accounts of how survivors from the World Trade Center attack had called relatives and let them know they were alive. Then came a bomb scare at 4 Times Square, where Ms. Dominguez works as an accounts payable clerk at the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. After she left the building, the only way she could get in touch with her boyfriend had been to borrow a friend's cellphone.

headline: A Week Later, Living In an Altered World
summary: Suddenly, it was Tuesday again. A week's distance from the terrorist attack that destroyed the World Trade Center has not brought whatever the current and inadequate catchphrase is for healing. Not with 218 people confirmed to be dead and 5,422 more who are gently described as missing. Not with the faces of those missing staring out from photographs on thousands of posters plastered everywhere. Not with a piece of Lower Manhattan fuming like an immense funeral pyre.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Long-Distance Service Approved
summary: Verizon Communications, the dominant local telephone company in the eastern United States, gained approval from the Federal Communications Commission to offer long-distance service in Pennsylvania. The F.C.C. required proof that Verizon had sufficiently opened its network to competition on the local level in Pennsylvania. The company already has approval to offer long-distance service in New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts. Simon Romero (NYT)

headline: Using a Cellphone Signal to Hunt For a Victim in Desperate Need
summary: SOME people in or near Lower Manhattan were surprised last week when they turned on their cellphones and were almost immediately called by their wireless carriers. The companies, it turns out, were monitoring cellular signals near the collapsed World Trade Center towers to try to find survivors who might have been trapped or were otherwise unaccounted for. Pinpointing the location from which a cellphone might be transmitting is far from an exact science, but any signals in the area were reason for hope. After a week, however, the search operations of companies like AT&T Wireless and Verizon Wireless proved fruitless.

headline: Jennifer White, P. J. Piper
summary: Jennifer Lynn White, a daughter of Carol and John White of North Salem, N.Y., was married yesterday to Patrick Joseph Piper, a son of Pamela Piper of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, and Thomas J. Piper of Milwaukee. The Rev. Daniel J. Gray performed the ceremony at St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church in Portsmouth, R.I. Mrs. Piper, 28, works in the Boston office of Goldman Sachs & Company, selling investment research to institutional clients. She graduated from Colgate University. Her father is an executive director in network services at Verizon in New York. The bride's mother teaches the second grade at the Lewisboro Elementary School in South Salem, N.Y.

headline: Nine Miles Away
summary: NINE miles lie between the World Trade Center and Highbridge, a Bronx neighborhood of 34,000 just north of Yankee Stadium. The streets here are a jumble of bright sunflowers, broken glass, six-story brick apartment buildings, neat row houses and sagging porches. An occasional rooster pecks at the sidewalks, most of which are cracked with weeds. By other measures, Highbridge seems more distant from the city's financial core. Although once a solidly middle-class neighborhood, Highbridge has a median family income of $20,700, compared with $48,200 citywide. The unemployment rate is nearly three times the city average. Nearly 40 percent of families in Highbridge are headed by single mothers. The neighborhood, once mostly Jewish and Irish Catholic, is largely Dominican and Puerto Rican. Most other residents are black.

headline: Talk to Me
summary: I could not reach anyone. I was at home in Boston. I did not know what had happened. The messages on my answering machine were cryptic: ''I hope you weren't on that plane to New York today,'' and from my sister, ''Is Mom in New York, is Mom in New York?'' and then click. I called my friend Nell, but the phone line was dead. I called my friend Rosie, but the phone line was dead. I called my husband, but the phone line was dead. I looked at the phone. I love my phone. It is one of those see-through gizmos, revealing the raw anatomy of connection, blue and coiled wires, sparkling red chips. But it was useless.

headline: Private Sector; The Ties That Bind In Telecommunications
summary: The Bradys. The Waltons. The Partridges. The Bells. Just one big family. At least that was how Henry B. Schacht, chairman of Lucent Technologies, said he felt after companies spawned from the old Ma Bell system scrambled to repair the telecommunications systems of Lower Manhattan that were damaged in the collapse of the World Trade Center. Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., moved quickly to supply clients with the switches, transmitters and services needed for the smooth functioning of land-based or wireless communications networks.

headline: Recession's Harbinger Is a Missouri City Not Prone to Boom or Bust
summary: The economy is sinking in this, the biggest city in central Missouri. Since the terrorist attacks on New York and the Pentagon, Mary and Bill Hires's notions of buying anything nonessential have evaporated. Ms. Hires, 69, whose husband was a professor at the University of Missouri here before he retired, was putting a bag into her van in the Wal-Mart parking lot near Columbia's new southwestern subdivisions. ''We felt very secure,'' she said. ''We were at the point of getting into the 21st century.''

headline: New Economy; Straining communications systems to the limit.
summary: WHEN tragedy strikes, people want to communicate -- immediately and copiously. After the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, how well did our publicly available communications networks perform? So far, the reviews are mixed. And there are lessons that the public, communications executives and policy makers should learn from. The star performers were online: e-mail, instant messaging and bulletin boards. But Internet news sites and the wired and wireless telephone networks could stand improvement. And it is clear that there need to be new ways to set up emergency information systems.

headline: Saving Precious Voice Mail
summary: One of the first things Verizon Communications officials did after the World Trade Center attack upon arriving at their heavily damaged switching station at 140 West Street was to begin preserving the voice mail system that serves thousands of local customers. On Friday, Verizon asked voice mail customers todelete messages they did not need, in order to avoid overtaxing the system. What Verizon did not say was that it wanted as many messages discarded as possible so it could turn off the so-called electronic janitor that automatically deletes messages, and allow people to retain last-minute messages they received from loved ones who may have perished in the twin towers, according to Eric Rabe, the chief spokesman for Verizon.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 During a Yearlong Intifada, Fear Has Gripped Mideast Among the facts upon which Israelis and Palestinians disagree is what day the intifada began. Palestinians say Sept. 28, 2000, when Ariel Sharon, now the Israeli prime minister, visited a site sacred to Muslims; Israelis tend to say the day before or the day after. But people on both sides describe similar effects of the events since: fear and desperation. A3 Shooting Rampage in Swiss Hall A 57-year-old gunman stormed into a crowded regional legislature in Zug, killing 14 people and detonating a hand grenade before shooting himself dead. It was the bloodiest episode in the normally tranquil country's recent criminal history and prompted talk of tightening Switzerland's relaxed security. A6

headline: Destroyed Computer Links Leave Thousands of Poor People Without Welfare Benefits
summary: The terrorist attack that toppled the World Trade Center also destroyed crucial links to the state computers that manage welfare, Medicaid and food stamp cases, leaving thousands of poor people in New York City and nearby counties without normal access to emergency cash, food and health care. ''Nothing's normal at this point,'' said Dennis Nowak, a spokesman for the Suffolk County Department of Social Services, which has scrambled to provide supermarket vouchers to the neediest applicants. Like many public assistance offices in Brooklyn, Staten Island and Queens and in Nassau, Westchester and Putnam Counties, most of Suffolk's centers have been unable to provide regular benefits to eligible families seeking help.

headline: Once, It Was a Monument to Preparedness; Officials Seek Best Location, and a Backup, for a New Command Center
summary: At 8:47 a.m. on Sept. 11, New York City's crisis command center, a $13 million emergency bunker on the 23rd floor of 7 World Trade Center, was a celebrated monument to disaster preparedness, a fortress judged ready to withstand hurricanes, bombs, blackouts, even a nuclear assault. But, as was learned in the next few hours, it was not impervious to two jumbo jets fully laden with fuel. When the exploding planes toppled the towers across the street, the command center was reduced to rubble, and so was the city's notion that it had created an emergency response system capable of handling the full gamut of disasters.

headline: With Cellphones, Who Knows Where the Time Goes?
summary: A PROFESSOR I had in college once remarked that Americans are not adequately schooled in making estimates. And if my experience in trying to gauge how many cellphone minutes I've used up is representative of the rest of the population's, we may be in worse trouble than my professor thought. Most cellphone plans limit customers to a specific number of minutes each month covered by a set fee. Users who exceed the limit can incur steep charges per minute, yet few people know how to keep track of how much time they have spent on the phone.

headline: In Crisis Zone, a Wireless Patch
summary: MOST people looking up at Lower Manhattan's skyline the week after the World Trade Center attacks were contemplating what was no longer there. Nathanial Freitas was looking for help. Hoping to find a way to restore his company's downed Internet connection, he stared up at the windows across the street from his firm's SoHo office and wondered who might be browsing the Web over there. What he hoped to find was a company that was still online and would be willing to share its high-speed link to the Internet. Like a few other small businesses in downtown Manhattan whose Internet connections were lost, Mr. Freitas's company, ThinAirApps, a software developer for mobile phones and hand-held computers, has been experimenting with a new wireless technology called Wi-Fi to restore its service. It has not worked perfectly, but it has shown how nascent technology and human cooperation can bridge gaps in times of need.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent Wins Big Cingular Contract
summary: Lucent Technologies said it had won a five-year contract to provide wireless equipment to Cingular Wireless, the nation's second-largest cellular carrier. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but the contract was said by people close to the companies to be worth at least $1 billion. The deal with Cingular, a venture formed last year by BellSouth and SBC Communications, comes after Lucent signed similar contracts with two other big carriers, Verizon Wireless and Sprint PCS. Simon Romero (NYT)

headline: Deadline Set on Cellphone Emergency Calls
summary: The Federal Communications Commission gave Verizon Wireless Inc. and four other mobile phone companies more time today to start installing gear that pinpoints the location of customers dialing 911, and expressed disappointment at the delays that caused the decision. The commission approved new timetables that the companies proposed. The commission also criticized AT&T Wireless Services Inc. and Cingular Wireless, accusing them of neglecting requirements and saying the companies may be fined.

headline: Taking the Pulse of Landmark Buildings Caught in the Collapse of the Towers
summary: While they stood, the long shadows of the World Trade Center fell on some of New York's most historic buildings. And when they fell, several landmarks suffered damage from the shock to their foundations and the barrage of debris. Preservationists say most of the 67 city landmarks below Chambers Street emerged ash-laden but unscathed from the attack. But they want to assess several buildings close to the collapsed towers, where access is still limited.

headline: New York's True Heart
summary: ONE of the myths Manhattan likes to tell about itself is that it runs on ideas alone. It's true that this rather unremarkable island managed to turn itself into the most important place on earth through sheer brainpower. The ability to juggle words and numbers and images and emotions made it the publishing and financial and communications and advertising center of the globe, gradually replacing, in the last century, the manufacturing and the shipping and the actual doing that underpin most economies.

headline: What Now for Wireless? Facing Harsh Realities; An Industry Adopts a New Pragmatism
summary: In Manhattan last June, Discover magazine convened a panel of technology experts from companies that included I.B.M., Walt Disney and Nokia to hold forth on the future of wireless technology. Among the blue-sky predictions were cellphones that would let prospective home buyers find a house's price simply by pointing the device at the building. Another brainstorm involved a wireless toaster that would burn an image of the day's weather forecast right onto a piece of bread.

headline: Phone Providers Near Ground Zero Are Still Frantically Scrambling to Catch Up
summary: At 5:20 p.m. on Sept. 11, telephone service in Lower Manhattan was knocked out when a 47-story World Trade Center building toppled onto a Verizon telephone center on West Street. Cellular antennas and data lines had already been out; now, all of a sudden, land lines went, too, and everyone from court officials to F.B.I. agents were scrambling to get phone service. More than three weeks later, it is clear that some solutions emerged quickly, and also that the easy part is over, with the hard part just beginning. The damaged Verizon building, a switching center in a 32-story Art Deco building on West Street, has equipment in five sub-basements that were flooded by a water-main break and firefighting efforts even before 7 World Trade Center collapsed into the side of the building, ripping gaping holes into walls lined with millions of dollars in equipment.

headline: A Firefighter's Dream, an Ice Cream Truck, a Date at F.A.O. Schwarz
summary: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. PEGGY ALARIO Time for Her Sons Because Peggy Alario's Bronco was always the first one in the commuter lot and the last out, her friends on Staten Island staved off alarm as the hours passed on Sept. 11 and her little green truck was still parked there. But Mrs. Alario, a manager at Zurich American Insurance Company, had been at a meeting on the 105th floor of 2 World Trade Center. With only a high school diploma and some college courses, Mrs. Alario, 41, put in 12-hour days and Sundays, proudly building a career that had her working on national and international corporate policies.

headline: For Some Lawyers, Lost Case Files and Lost Clients
summary: It was a week before Lawrence H. McGaughey could get back inside his law office at Broadway and Vesey Street, and then for only 30 minutes. He and his secretary retrieved what they could -- two computers and some files -- loaded them onto two luggage carriers, bumped their way down six flights of stairs, and headed for the subway. Since then, Mr. McGaughey has been struggling to keep his law practice afloat, as his clients wondered where he was and how they could contact him.

headline: Preserving the Voices of the Twin Towers
summary: AS they watched news accounts of the World Trade Center disaster, a detail caught the attention of Davia Nelson and Nikki Silva, two independent radio producers in California. ''There were sheets of paper strewn all over,'' Ms. Nelson recalled. The scraps of paper that blanketed Lower Manhattan -- photographs, letters, depositions, résumés -- were like scattered pieces of a jigsaw puzzle that formed a picture of daily life in the trade center towers before the attacks.

headline: Fight Enters Another Round Over Takeover in Venezuela
summary: The AES Corporation of Arlington, Va., said yesterday that Venezuela's largest telephone company had failed to provide investors in the United States with precise information in the latest chapter of one of Latin America's most visible hostile takeover disputes. AES, which operates power companies around the world and does not have experience running a phone company, recently submitted a takeover bid for C.A. Nacional Teléfonos de Venezuela, or CANTV. AES said yesterday that the Venezuelan company had failed to provide details of a share buyback in a statement recently submitted to shareholders.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Merchants Posted No Gain In Overall September Sales Over all, sales at the nation's merchants did not increase at all in September, according to the first industrywide figures since the Sept. 11 attacks. It was the worst month since Goldman, Sachs started keeping its retail index in 1988 and the worst September performance comparison since Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi began keeping its index in 1970. But the numbers underscored that retail is a tale of two types of stores: the discounters and everyone else. Sales at specialty apparel stores declined by 8.5 percent, but discounters' sales increased 4.4 percent. [Page C13.]

headline: Rivals Worry About Access As Verizon Seeks Buffer
summary: Verizon Communications, the nation's largest local telephone company, is raising the ire of competitors who worry that its efforts to increase security in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks will restrict their access to Verizon work locations. Verizon, which was formed last year in the merger of Bell Atlantic and the GTE Corporation, has told the Federal Communications Commission and the New York State Public Service Commission that it needs additional protection against attacks on its property.

headline: A Beloved Store Was a Casualty Too
summary: JAMES WAGNER, a retired insurance underwriter who lives in Chelsea and once worked at No. 7 World Trade Center, doesn't know the names of the countless salespeople who have helped him choose gently tailored European suits and eye-catching accessories at Century 21, the beloved discount department store nestled in the shadow of the trade center. But two weeks after the attack on the twin towers, with Lower Manhattan in ruins, he was moved to e-mail this message to the store. ''Dear people of Century 21,'' the message said. ''I was incredibly happy to hear that the Century 21 family was safe. I have enjoyed being a tiny part of your world as a customer for the past 15 years. Of course your institution is an enormous boon to my wardrobe and my budget, and in fact, I have gradually become dependent on Century 21 for almost 100 percent of my clothing.''

headline: In an Urban Underbelly, Hidden Views of Terror's Toll
summary: The devastation above ground at the World Trade Center site is obvious to anyone with a television set. But below the street, in spaces that are home to much of what keeps New York City running, billions of dollars of damage remains unseen. The repair work needed in the utility tunnels underneath the area around the trade center could take years to complete, utility executives said last week. Those officials declined to estimate the cost because they did not want state and federal officials who are providing aid to hold them to an amount that could end up being a gross underestimation.

headline: Attacks Expose Telephone's Soft Underbelly
summary: Joseph Pennell, the prolific illustrator who often depicted the cityscape of Lower Manhattan in his prints, called the New York Telephone Building ''the most impressive modern building in the world'' when it was completed in 1926. How antiquated it now seems.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Company Plans a Buyback
summary: The board of Venezuela's largest telecommunications company approved a share buyback yesterday in the latest wrinkle of a takeover dispute involving several multinational investors, people close to the company said. The company, Cia. Nacional Teléfonos de Venezuela, or CANTV, said it would offer $30 a share for about 15 percent of its outstanding stock, in addition to a dividend of $550 million to be paid in two installments. The offer by CANTV, whose large shareholders include Verizon Communications and Teléfonica of Spain, comes after a hostile bid by the AES Corporation of Arlington, Va., to seek control of the company for $24 a share. Simon Romero (NYT)

headline: Accord Seen With F.C.C. On Licenses Of NextWave
summary: Federal officials and several of the nation's largest wireless communications companies may announce as early as today a settlement in a dispute over who owns more than 200 valuable licenses to provide wireless service, according to people involved in the negotiations. Under the settlement, NextWave Communications, a bankrupt wireless company in Hawthorne, N.Y., agreed to pay what it owes for the licenses before it went out of business, as well as interest on that amount and related taxes. In exchange, NextWave would get the money raised when the government auctioned the licenses after the company had failed to pay for them.

headline: Businesses Finding That Good Security Is No Longer Optional
summary: They are hiring security guards, requiring employees to wear identification badges at all times, taking X-rays of packages and reviewing evacuation plans. Businesses across the country are trying not only to make their employees and offices safe but also to reassure people, perhaps the hardest job of all. For help, they are often turning to outside security firms and consultants to identify which measures they need right away and what changes should be made permanently. The most common advice is to examine current security and then to spend more on equipment and on people with better training.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 An Israeli Minister Is Slain, Threatening Peace Process Tourism Minister Rehavam Zeevi, who advocated the voluntary ''transfer'' of Palestinians across the Jordan River, away from the West Bank and Gaza Strip, was shot to death at a Jerusalem hotel. The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine took responsibility. Prime Minister Ariel Sharon blamed Yasir Arafat, and American and European diplomats worked to preserve the peace effort. Early today, Israeli troops entered the West Bank. A1 Russia to Shut Cuba Post The Kremlin said it would abandon its largest electronic eavesdropping post in the West, at Lourdes, Cuba, and spend much of the savings on modern weapons for the military. A9

headline: Companies Start Fund to Reward Hospitals for Better Care
summary: Within days after the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences shocked policy makers in late 1999 by reporting that mistakes in hospitals were killing tens of thousands of Americans each year, some of the nation's largest companies met and agreed to throw their weight behind efforts to make hospitals safer. Now, putting cash behind that commitment for the first time, four big New York companies will announce a $2 million incentive program today to encourage hospitals in the state to improve patient safety by requiring doctors to use computerized systems that guard against errors. To receive the bonuses, the hospitals will also have to hire physicians who specialize in intensive care to supervise their sickest patients.

headline: U.S. Wireless Talks Go On, With Court Deadline Today
summary: Federal officials and executives from several wireless communications companies were still trying to reach a settlement yesterday over the disputed ownership of $16 billion worth of wireless spectrum licenses. The government has a filing deadline today if it wants the Supreme Court to hear the dispute.

headline: Fear, the New Virus Of a Connected Era
summary: In that distant world far, far away that was America before Sept. 11, much was written about how the Internet and cable television were creating a newly fragmented, decentralized world -- a culturally splintered world of niche marketing, special-interest publications and identity politics. As one 1990's survey of Internet politics concluded, virtual communities ''resemble the semiprivate spaces of modern health clubs more than the public spaces of agoras'': ''instead of meeting to discuss and debate issues of common concern to the society, members of these virtual communities meet largely to promote their own interests and to reinforce their own like-mindedness.'' As a result, the cultural critic David Shenk wrote in his book ''Data Smog,'' ''It appears that rather than our world becoming a cozy village, we are instead retreating into an electronic Tower of Babel, a global skyscraper. Instead of gathering us into the town square, the new information technology clusters us into social cubicles. There are fewer central spaces, and not even a common channel.''

headline: U.S. Appeals Phone-Case Ruling
summary: The United States government asked the Supreme Court today to review a June appeals court decision that returned mobile phone licenses worth $16 billion to NextWave Telecom Inc. The Federal Communications Commission said the ruling cheated the Treasury of billions of dollars and gave the licenses to ''entities that value the spectrum less highly.''

headline: When Terrorists Log On
summary: Even as it responds to the public health challenges posed by the spreading anthrax threat, the Bush administration needs to shore up defenses of the nation's information infrastructure, its central nervous system controlling financial markets, power grids and telecommunications. Terrorism experts warned about the threat of cyberattacks in the aftermath of Sept. 11, as they did about biological ones. Many of the same weaknesses exposed in the public health system also hamper the nation's ability to protect its information systems. These include a lack of coordination among overlapping jurisdictions and an inadequate appreciation for potential threats. Tom Ridge, director of the new Office of Homeland Security, will have to forcefully address these weaknesses in a manner that reduces America's exposure to a digital Pearl Harbor.

headline: One Was Saintlike, One Was Fearless, One Was a Fiend for Chocolate
summary: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. GREGORY A. CLARK A Sailor and a Gentleman For months, the shy young Japanese woman working at the snack stand at the United States naval base in Yokohama knew Gregory A. Clark as ''pizza man,'' the name she had given him because he always ordered the same thing. It was the summer of 1987, and by the time that fall came, they had begun dating. Eventually, the handsome petty officer second class left the Navy and the couple married, moved to New Jersey and had four children, who are now between the ages of 5 and 11. Mr. Clark, 40, was a computer technician for Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Corrections
summary: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day last Monday about the Verizon Communications office damaged by the Sept. 11 attacks referred incorrectly to the abilities of telephone networks to reroute traffic. Like information on the Internet, such traffic can indeed automatically reroute itself if it encounters a damaged path. The Internet's ability to do that is not unique.

headline: CENTURYTEL BUYING 675,000 VERIZON PHONE LINES
summary: CenturyTel Inc., which sells local and wireless phone service in 21 states, agreed to buy about 675,000 telephone lines in Alabama and Missouri from Verizon Communications Inc. for $2.16 billion. The transaction expands CenturyTel's local-phone market in rural regions by 37 percent, and lets Verizon focus on selling phone service mostly in metropolitan areas, Verizon said. The additional lines are expected to generate $530 million to $550 million in annual revenue, and per-share earnings of 4 cents to 7 cents in the first year, CenturyTel said. The company, which is based in Monroe, La., is getting lines in growing cities like Branson, Mo., and Dothan, Ala. Verizon, which is based in New York, said in September it wanted to sell 1.2 million rural phone lines in Alabama, Kentucky and Missouri.

headline: CANTV Shareholders Approve Buyback of Stock
summary: The shareholders of Venezuela's largest telecommunications company approved a share buyback and dividend yesterday in the latest chapter of a takeover battle involving two prominent American companies, the AES Corporation and Verizon Communications. The shareholders of C.A. Nacional Teléfonos de Venezuela, or CANTV, agreed to management's plan to repurchase 15 percent of the company's stock for $30 a share. Shareholders also agreed to a dividend of about $550 million to be paid in two installments.

headline: G.O.P. Wants to Step on Suozzi's Coattails
summary: WHEN Democrats in Nassau County look ahead to Election Day on Nov. 6, they see a chance to make history. With Thomas R. Suozzi, their county executive candidate, actively campaigning for the 19 Democrats running for the Legislature, they could win control of the county's executive and legislative branches and take undisputed control for the first time since 1917. In contrast, the Republicans seem to have all but given up on the county executive race. Republican mailings for their legislative candidates barely mention their nominee for county executive, Bruce R. Bent, and the word ''Republican'' can't be found on Mr. Bent's campaign literature.

headline: Oysters Rockefeller? They'd Prefer Crab Legs Bronx
summary: If the latest census had included a question about crab legs eaten per capita, there is little doubt as to which New York neighborhood would have ranked first. Welcome to Morris Heights, home of the Crabman. On weekday afternoons between March and October, the Crabman, a k a Speedy Davis, 42, can be seen pushing a shopping cart full of his peppery, home-cooked crab legs through this mostly low-income neighborhood. A plastic bag containing at least a dozen legs, along with a newspaper page with which to wrap the shells, goes for $1.

headline: Ground Zero Volunteers Get a Chance to Play Tourist
summary: THE SETTING -- Tuesday morning, anywhere but ground zero. A dozen Red Cross volunteers boarded a double-decker, open-air bus near Times Square to tour their adopted city. The relief team, all out-of-towners, had been working 8- to 12-hour shifts, delivering supplies and hot food to World Trade Center rescue workers.

headline: NextWave, Seeking Settlement, to Pay Wireless Companies
summary: Verizon Wireless, the nation's largest wireless carrier, and AT&T Wireless have reached a deal with NextWave Telecom that will hasten a broader settlement over the ownership of more than $16 billion in licenses to provide wireless services, people close to the negotiations said yesterday. The agreement was in addition to other progress the federal government and several wireless carriers made over the weekend in their effort to reach a settlement.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
summary: R. R. DONNELLEY & SONS CO., Chicago, a commercial printer, said it had extended its directory contract with the information services unit of Verizon Communications, New York, the nation's largest local phone company, and would print and bind about 850 titles for Verizon through 2013. ENTERPRISE PRODUCTS PARTNERS, Houston, said it would acquire, pending regulatory approvals, 30 salt dome storage caverns capable of storing 77 million barrels of liquid fuels from Diamond-Koch and Diamond-Koch III. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: A Pivotal Choice for Cingular Wireless
summary: Cingular Wireless, the nation's second-largest mobile phone carrier, intends to announce broad changes in its technology today, people close to the company said yesterday. The decision will benefit some of Europe's largest communications equipment companies at the expense of competitors in the United States and Canada. Cingular, which has 21.3 million customers, has decided to overlay a cellular communications technology called global system for mobile communications, or GSM, across its nationwide network, the people close to the company said. The decision is part of a shift to a technology that is widespread in Europe and Asia but that has only recently gained ground in the United States.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Reports A Loss
summary: Verizon Communications, the nation's largest local telephone company, said yesterday that earnings fell 46 percent in the third quarter, to $1.86 billion, or 69 cents a share, from $3.47 billion, or $1.27, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. Verizon, which was formed last year by Bell Atlantic's acquisition of the GTE Corporation, said sales in the quarter had climbed 2.8 percent, to $17 billion. The company's financial performance was hurt by the Sept. 11 attacks, which destroyed switching equipment in Lower Manhattan, and by weaker demand for telephone services. Simon Romero (NYT)

headline: Everyday People, Extraordinary Day
summary: There were heros who had jobs to do that day and did them, whatever the cost. And there were other, unsung heros who did not have the jobs they knew had to be done and did them anyway. Paul Amico, a construction supervisor with NY Waterway, was working at the dock in Weehawken, N.J., across the Hudson River from Manhattan, when he saw the smoke billowing from the World Trade Center. Without consulting his boss, he grabbed a two-way marine radio and hopped a ferry bound for Lower Manhattan.

headline: ALLTEL TO BUY ABOUT 600,000 PHONE LINES FROM VERIZON
summary: The Alltel Corporation agreed to buy about 600,000 local telephone lines in Kentucky from Verizon Communications Inc. for $1.9 billion in cash, an Alltel spokesman said. The transaction follows CenturyTel Inc.'s agreement last week to buy 675,000 Verizon lines in rural Alabama and Missouri for $2.16 billion. Alltel is a rural telephone services provider based in Little Rock, Ark.

headline: Corrections
summary: A headline in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day on Wednesday about the third-quarter financial results of Verizon Communications misstated them. Profit declined by 46 percent; the company did not report a loss.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Acquires Wireless Operations
summary: Verizon Wireless said it had agreed to acquire wireless operations in California, Georgia, Ohio and Tennessee from Dobson Communications for about $465 million. Simon Romero (NYT)

headline: Business; A Phone Upstart, Still Annoying the Giants
summary: THROUGHOUT Chicago, where Ameritech is the reigning local telephone company, billboards popped up during the summer showing the face of the tough-talking football legend Mike Ditka. ''Make the smart call -- bench Ameritech,'' he says on one of them. ''Staying with Ameritech is just plain dumb,'' he advises on another. And last week, a new series of billboards began appearing in the city, as well as in Detroit and Pittsburgh, recommending: ''Choose Wisely. Because Now You Can.'' The billboards are part of a major advertising campaign by Z-Tel Technologies, a small, publicly traded residential-phone company based in Tampa, Fla., that is struggling to make a name for itself. Z-Tel is also taking on other regional phone giants like Verizon Communications, based in New York, and SBC Communications, the parent of Ameritech, based in San Antonio, using direct mail and advertising on radio and television.

headline: Suddenly, Love in a Hurry
summary: DAIL METZGER, who runs a Connecticut and Westchester matchmaking service, says that in a post-Sept. 11 world, people are looking for love. Not only did calls from her clients double after the terrorist attacks, but also Ms. Metzger herself is re-examining a longtime platonic friendship for romantic possibilities. Deborah Schwartz, originally from Rye, became engaged to Dr. John Meer only four days after the hijackings. Suddenly just a five-month engagement will do.

headline: VERIZON WIRELESS NEAR TO COMPLETING PUBLIC OFFERING
summary: Verizon Wireless Inc., the biggest American mobile-phone company, said yesterday that it hoped to complete an initial public offering to raise as much as $5 billion by the middle of next year. The sale was postponed a year ago. Verizon will use part of the money to pay for wireless licenses obtained in a proposed $16 billion settlement with the bankrupt NextWave Telecom and the government. Verizon's share is $8.8 billion, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company is based in Bedminster, N.J.

headline: Verizon Charges Many Customers Without Service Since Sept. 11
summary: Verizon has continued to charge a number of residential and commercial telephone customers whose phone service still has not been restored in the wake of the World Trade Center attack on Sept. 11, customers and company officials say. Even though customers are eligible for rebates upon request, the billing for unusable phone lines has increased animosity. The customers say that Verizon has been unclear about when service might be restored and that it is lethargic compared with its competitors. Charging customers for lines that are down for more than 24 hours would normally violate state regulations, but Verizon lobbied for a suspension of rebate requirements.

headline: Pay Phone Rates To Increase 15 cents
summary: Verizon increased rates for its 62,000 pay phones in New Jersey to 50 cents for a local call of unlimited time, up from 35 cents for a timed call, company officials said yesterday. Lacy Yeatts, a Verizon spokeswoman, said the company needed to increase rates to offset declines in pay phone income caused by use of cellular telephones, calling cards and collect calls. Pay phone revenues had gone down by 23 percent in the past 36 months, she said. ''We are increasing the price so we can keep the phones out there and keep it a viable business,'' Ms. Yeatts said.

headline: It's On With the Show, for Those Who Need It
summary: NOT long after Sept. 11, the full vision came to the director Jeff Cohen -- in a dream. No, really. His reverie was all about Queen Esther, a downtown cabaret diva, who was the M.C. for a U.S.O.-style variety show for World Trade Center disaster workers. ''I usually never even remember my dreams,'' Mr. Cohen said. ''This one I remembered. Two weeks later, the dream was reality.'' And so it happened that on Monday night, for the fourth week in a row, a queue of workers from the World Trade Center site filed into Mr. Cohen's 75-seat TriBeCa Playhouse at 111 Reade Street. It is the playhouse closest to the disaster scene, and they were there to be entertained at the Stage Door Canteen. The basic idea is to bring Broadway and Off Broadway talent to ground zero. Of course, as in the days when Bob Hope and Betty Grable tore up U.S.O. stages, the show was free, but the volunteer talent could not have been at a higher level. Filling the Bob Hope slot was Colin Quinn, former headliner of ''Saturday Night Live,'' who got stressed-out emergency workers howling with jokes such as, ''If you receive a letter addressed Occupant-slash-Infidel, don't open it!''

headline: Phones Out of Place: Funny, You Don't Sound Like 212
summary: MIRANDA SIELAFF, a Minneapolis native, graduated from college last spring, spent the summer with friends in Boston and moved to New York in the early fall. Throughout those transient months, she had a cellphone number starting with her hometown area code, 612. ''I could talk to my family wherever I was and it was a local call for them,'' said Ms. Sielaff, a graduate student at the Juilliard School. ''I did have one Boston friend who was annoyed. She didn't want to pay for a long-distance call, so she would hang up before the phone answered.''

headline: Disputed Phone Licenses Transferred to Big Carriers
summary: The Federal Communications Commission reached a deal yesterday to transfer ownership of $16 billion worth of disputed mobile phone licenses to some of the nation's biggest wireless carriers, while providing a windfall for the bankrupt NextWave Telecom. The settlement, which must be approved by several federal authorities, would end five years of wrangling over the licenses and allow the wireless carriers to expand service in urban areas like New York, Los Angeles and Washington.

headline: Routines And Plans, And Friends And Family
summary: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. EUGENE CLARK From the Terrace In life, Eugene Clark observed the three D's: dance, drama and divas. He started early: Roberta Flack was his music teacher in Washington, D.C., during the 1960's. He could sing like Jennifer Holliday in the musical ''Dreamgirls,'' he could emote like Norma Desmond in ''Sunset Boulevard'' and he danced ''like Tina Turner,'' said Larry Courtney, Mr. Clark's partner for the last 13 years. ''And he had legs almost as good.''

headline: Once Proudly Carried, and Now Mere Carrion
summary: A MACABRE spectator sport has emerged in the mobile communications industry: identifying devices that may become relics of the heady days of the 1990's wireless boom. The practice follows a burst in creativity in which designers and engineers developed an outlandish array of mobile phones, hand-held computers and pagers. Investors backed ambitious low-orbiting satellite systems and spent billions preparing cities for wireless high-speed Internet access. But while the devices designed to function on such networks often looked interesting, many were expensive and did not work well.

headline: Attacks at Hubs Could Disrupt Phone Lines
summary: Public safety experts and telecommunications executives are growing increasingly concerned about the possibility of attacks on the telephone system, a century-old network of copper wires and newer fiber optic strands that wind their way through critical but vulnerable hubs. Most of the concern involves the prospect of physical attacks on the 100 or so most important central offices that route voice calls and Internet traffic. Service for more than 30 million phone lines in the largest cities could be interrupted if such attacks were successful.

headline: New Economy; The time may have come for a national corps of technology experts to protect and repair vital information systems.
summary: IN the aftermath of Sept. 11, a new spirit of civil service is sweeping the country. Volunteers and donors have swamped the Red Cross, the Salvation Army and other agencies with offers of help. Seizing on the national mood, President Bush has called for the creation of a civil defense service that would supplement security efforts by the police, fire departments and public health agencies. That call to civic duty mirrors a bipartisan Senate proposal that would quintuple the size of AmeriCorps, the domestic Peace Corps initiated by President Bill Clinton. But even with those efforts, there is a sense that something more is needed. National security is no longer just about patrolling borders and securing airports, bridges and ports; it is also about protecting the nation's information infrastructure.

headline: Committee Leader Says Victims' Memorial Will Be Main Priority
summary: The newly appointed chairman of a commission charged with rebuilding Lower Manhattan said yesterday that establishing a memorial to the victims of the World Trade Center attacks would be among the first priorities for the panel. John C. Whitehead, the former co-chairman of the investment firm Goldman Sachs & Company, was named chairman of the Lower Manhattan Redevelopment Corporation yesterday by Gov. George E. Pataki. Beyond the memorial, Mr. Whitehead urged patience for the residents, small businesses and cultural institutions that, along with the financial district, make up the neighborhood most affected by the attacks on Sept. 11.

headline: Fines Begin for Drivers Holding Cellphones
summary: People who talk on hand-held cellphones while driving can now be fined up to $100 under a New York State law. New York was the first state to ban this activity under a law enacted in early summer. Talking with a headset or a speaker phone is allowed. The ban went into effect on Nov. 1, though violators only received warnings until yesterday.

headline: Small, Stunned
summary: VINCENT AU'S mother says that God messes with her son. Twice he has faced death. Twice he has lived. He has given both those lives to his work. Mr. Au, a 31-year-old stockbroker, founded a small brokerage firm called Avalon Partners in 1998. The next year, he and two employees moved into a modest office on the 18th floor of 2 World Trade Center. On Aug. 13, 2001, the company relocated to a spacious new office on the 84th floor of the north tower.

headline: Wounded Buildings Offer Survival Lessons
summary: At some indefinable hour during an interminable night, the fires that had raged for nearly two days in the skyscraper at 90 West Street still puffed and flared when Derek Trelstad, a structural engineer, walked into the building and cautiously began climbing the stairs, the double snout of his respirator wheezing in the haze. Charred wreckage dangling from the ceilings and heaped on the floors cast strange shadows in the light streaming from rescue equipment outside through punched-out windows on the building's northern facade. On Sept. 11, flaming steel debris from the south trade tower had smashed against the thick terra cotta of that facade and started the fire within.

headline: A Taste in Fine Red Wines, an Unlikely Romance and a Fast Response
summary: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. STEPHEN L. ROACH A Certain Taste in Shoes He was very cute. And charming. An athletic six feet, 200 pounds. But those white Capezios he was wearing had to go.

headline: Footlights
summary: On the Move Since 1908 the Philadelphia Orchestra has been planning to leave its home, the Academy of Music, which was designed for opera. On Saturday the dream will come true when Wolfgang Sawallisch leads the ensemble in its inaugural concert in the new $265 million, 2,500-seat Verizon Hall. Designed by Rafael Viñoly, the hall occupies an entire block -- 2.3 acres -- in the heart of Philadelphia. Saturday's concert is to include the world premiere of a piece by Aaron Jay Kernis commissioned for the occasion, and on Sunday comes the official opening, a daylong open house featuring an assortment of free performances. Besides housing the Philadelphia Orchestra, Verizon Hall will be home the Philly Pops, and its 650-seat Perelman Theater will be home to Philadanco, the Chamber Orchestra of Philadelphia, the Philadelphia Chamber Music Society and American Theater Arts for Youth. Information: (215) 893-1999. Winners In 1926 Walter Naumburg, an investment banker and amateur cellist, established the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation to offer young musicians assistance and give them recognition by presenting them in recitals. At 7:30 p.m. Thursday at Alice Tully Hall, the Naumburg Foundation will celebrate its 75th anniversary with a gala concert featuring past Naumburg winners, including the foundation's president, Robert Mann (1941). Among other scheduled performers are the Emerson String Quartet, the Eroica Trio, Leonid Hambro, Anthony Molinaro, Joseph Silverstein, Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg, Dawn Upshaw and Carol Wincenc. Information: (212) 875-5050.

headline: U.S. Considers Restricting Cellphone Use in Disasters
summary: Federal officials are working on a plan to close cellphone networks to almost everyone but government officials in the event of another major emergency like the Sept. 11 attacks, officials said. The move is intended to prevent the networks from being so clogged with calls that emergency workers cannot communicate. But there is some concern among cellphone companies about the costs and the possible public outcry if people cannot contact loved ones in an emergency.

headline: Black Police Officers Sue City, Citing Surveillance
summary: An organization that represents black police officers announced yesterday that it was suing New York City, saying the Police Department had secretly and illegally monitored its political activities by reviewing telephone records and following members. The organization, 100 Blacks in Law Enforcement Who Care, said the monitoring was intended to intimidate and silence a group that had been critical of the department, especially of its efforts to recruit minority officers and to adequately discipline police officers guilty of brutality. ''We will not be intimidated,'' said Sgt. Noel Leader, a founder of the organization. ''We will not be scared off.''

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Wireless To Offer Auto Services
summary: Verizon Wireless is expected to announce today that it has reached an agreement to be the exclusive service provider for Wingcast, a company formed by Ford Motor and Qualcomm to provide a wireless service in automobiles. The agreement will permit Wingcast to offer consumers voice-activated services, including emergency phone calls, instant messaging, e-mail access and streaming video. Wingcast, based in San Diego, will make its service available in some Ford and Nissan vehicles next year. Simon Romero (NYT)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
summary: VERIZON WIRELESS, a partnership of Verizon Communications, New York, and Vodafone Group, Newbury, England, won a contract to carry phone traffic for Wingcast, a venture of Ford Motor and Qualcomm, that will provide voice, Internet and e-mail access in cars and trucks. Terms were not disclosed. RADIOSHACK, Fort Worth, the consumer electronics chain, said it would increase the number of shares it plans to repurchase to 25 million from 10 million. The company has repurchased 7.8 million shares since last December.

headline: In Philadelphia, New Hall's Sound Is in the Ear of the Beholder
summary: So after all the anticipation and nervousness, how are the acoustics at Verizon Hall, the new home of the Philadelphia Orchestra, the main component of the new Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts? That was the big question hovering over the three-day gala opening weekend of Kimmel Center, the $265 million complex occupying nearly an entire block on a stretch of Broad Street south of City Hall known as the Avenue of the Arts. However Verizon Hall is ultimately judged acoustically, Philadelphians already have much to be proud of.

headline: Technology & Media; Telecommunications Industry Too Devastated Even for Vultures
summary: The resounding boom in telecommunications investments from 1996 to 2000 fizzled in 2001, when at least 27 telecommunications companies, each with more than $100 million of liabilities, filed for bankruptcy protection. The industry may require a year, or perhaps even two, before a muted recovery starts to take place. Even the vulture investors, like hedge funds, private equity companies and funds within investment banks that specialize in distressed businesses, may not be attracted to the carcasses of once-ambitious companies that now litter the industry's landscape.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Citizens Ends Purchase Plans
summary: Citizens Communications, which sells telephone service in 24 states, has ended talks with Verizon Communications to buy about 63,000 phone lines in Arizona and California for $223 million. Citizens, which agreed to buy the lines in 1999, ended the deal because it could not obtain approval to operate the lines in California and had not set a closing date for the acquisition, the company's treasurer, Don Armour, said.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Seeks Response Alternative
