summary: Verizon Wireless plans to increase its network capacity and take other measures to serve the emergency communication needs of the government, rather than carry out a limited form of priority access, according to a filing last week with the Federal Communications Commission. Federal officials have been working on a plan to restrict the use of cellular networks to government and emergency personnel in the event of a major disaster, but providers are concerned about the cost and public reaction. Federal officials hoped to have a priority system operating in Washington, New York and Salt Lake City by the end of January, in time for the Winter Olympics. Verizon said it could respond by deploying portable cell sites, rerouting traffic and distributing free handsets rather than limiting access. Susan Stellin (NYT)

headline: Wireless Deal Falls Apart In Congress
summary: The $16 billion deal to transfer more than 200 highly coveted airwave licenses to the nation's largest wireless telephone carriers collapsed today after Congress failed to adopt legislation that was necessary to make it happen. The failure casts a cloud over the results of the largest government auction in history, which was completed earlier this year, and leaves in tatters an ambitious and heavily criticized plan arranged by Michael K. Powell, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

headline: L.I. @ WORK
summary: Sales and Income Rise At Hi-Tech Pharmacal Hi-Tech Pharmacal (Nasdaq: HITK) of Amityville reported on Monday that sales and net income rose for the fiscal second quarter ended Oct. 31. Net income for the pharmaceutical company increased 72 percent to $878,000, or 18 cents a share, compared with $509,000, or 12 cents a share, for the same period last year. Sales reached $8.5 million compared with $7.9 million for the same period last year.

headline: The Good, the Bad and the Totally Arbitrary
summary: Few employees can escape the annual performance review. It is a ritual of appraisal of performance and achievement of goals that is approached with dread -- sometimes by the reviewer, too. Now come these reviews of the review process. Alan Heisey, who now publishes a consumer magazine and a newspaper for the construction industry in Toronto, recalls a manager whose oral evaluation of his work many years ago was more than generous. The evaluation came while Mr. Heisey was a material control supervisor for a television manufacturing factory. He recalls the manager saying, ''If you aren't the best man who ever worked for me, you are one of the best, and I am glad I've got you.'' Mr. Heisey writes, ''That kind of praise has never occurred before or since, but it is memorable, I think, particularly because he fired me a month later.'' ''Annual appraisals for staffers in hundreds of diverse field offices across the country were a huge problem for my company,'' writes George Zucker of Haverford, Pa., remembering his days as a journalist. ''They were still working on it when I retired. ''Our personnel mavens didn't want appraisals heavy on praise and light on red flags. 'We don't become a great company by telling each other how great we are,' was an oft-quoted adage.'' He added: ''The problem was finding credible ways to grade outstanding staffers. Good people expect good reviews and can be overly sensitive to negative feedback. They might quit to find more appreciation elsewhere. ''One year the field managers were ordered to rank each of our staffers numerically. It was a disaster, and the personnel chief was livid when the managers were called to New York the next year for a post-mortem.'' As Mr. Zucker recalls it, the personnel chief ticked off some of the failures of the new system and then looked directly at Mr. Zucker as he said: ''One manager had half his staff ranked in the top 10. How can you do that?'' Mr. Zucker said he replied, ''I had a bunch tied for No. 1.'' There were no rankings after that. ''I am a human resources professional, so you would think that we would treat our own as we preach,'' says Sharon Scheirer, the human resources director at the Equinox Resort in Manchester, Vt. ''One of the positions I held was as a regional manager for a Fortune 500 company. My boss, the vice president for human relations, was located in the Midwest. One day, after my first anniversary, a confidential envelope arrived with my name on it. Surprise! It was my performance review, thanking me for my excellent work during the year. No discussion, no notice that the review was on the way -- just a one-sided appraisal with some dollars attached. ''I now use this example of how not to do it when coaching managers during performance appraisal training.'' ''I have been on both sides of the performance review process, the giver and the receiver,'' writes Joseph Stagnitta of Hyde Park, N.Y., a retired product manager in the world trade division of I.B.M. ''And yes, the task can be dreaded by both parties.'' One time, he said, he was surprised to receive a performance review based on a one-week-old plan ''delinquently submitted by my then current manager.'' ''I challenged the appraisal,'' he added, ''and it was escalated to higher management, which upheld my position that the appraisal was not fair. ''Then, in another instance I had an opportunity to provide the surprise when I declined signing an agreement about my performance review when, in response to my inquiry about what I need to do to improve my rating even further, I was told, 'Walk on water.' ''From that point on, I never rated my company a '1' in the annual opinion surveys, at least not till they showed me how they could walk on water.'' ''As a career changer, I was used to political performance reviews to keep me under the glass ceiling for my age,'' writes Karen S. Kendler, a computer consultant and freelance writer from Riverdale, the Bronx. ''However, one of the worst I ever had was one where my manager forced me to give low priority to technical growth as a career growth objective and then gave me performance feedback indicating I needed to concentrate more on technical growth. ''Damned if you do and damned if you don't.'' Kevin C. Naff of Baltimore, now a manager of business development at Verizon Wireless, knows what to do when he wants a good laugh. He pulls out a review he received seven years ago. While working as an assistant editor for a business trade magazine, he writes, he reported to an editor who was ''one of those types who feels obligated to nit-pick only so she can remind you who's in charge.'' ''She presented my review, which told glowing tales of my superior, flawless performance,'' he recalled. ''Then I turned the page. There, under the section titled 'Needs Improvement,' she wrote: 'Kevin needs to inprove his poofereading skills.' '' Mr. Naff is still laughing.

headline: Lord Group Acquired By Spier New York
summary: Spier New York, an agency that specializes in publishing, is acquiring the Lord Group in New York from Dentsu and the Young & Rubicam unit of the WPP Group. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Dentsu and Y.& R. had each owned 50 percent of Lord.

headline: Howell Is PGA's Rookie of the Year
summary: Charles Howell III was named the PGA Tour's rookie of the year after winning $1.52 million in prize money this year, the PGA said. Bob Gilder was named rookie of the year on the Senior PGA Tour after finishing eighth on the money list with $1.68 million in winnings.

headline: Cell Firms Are Asked To Improve 911 Service
summary: Responding to what state officials say is a sharp increase in the number of 911 calls from cellphones, Connecticut's Department of Public Safety has asked wireless carriers to upgrade their phones and cellular networks to allow police dispatchers to pinpoint callers' locations. The upgrades, which should begin to be phased in early in the new year, will use various technologies including the Global Positioning System and signal-strength software.

headline: Still Giving Thanks at Point Thank You
summary: To the Editor: Re ''Thank-Yous, but Fewer of Them, Await Rescuers at a Corner'' (news article, Dec. 26): Point Thank You at the corner of Christopher and West Streets in Greenwich Village is living proof that there is goodness and hope in this world, even in our darkest hours. I am proud to be a part of it.

headline: Mayor's Concern and a Departure Cloud the Lincoln Center Project
summary: Facing a crucial juncture prompted by its $1.2 billion redevelopment plan, Lincoln Center suffered two blows yesterday when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg suggested that the project would have to be delayed and the center's interim executive director told other center officials she was leaving to head a new performing arts center in Philadelphia. In response to a reporter's query, Mr. Bloomberg -- until recently a vice chairman of Lincoln Center -- raised strong questions about the city's ability to provide the center with the $240 million it had committed to the project under a 10-year timetable agreed to by the Giuliani administration. He also predicted that the plan would have difficulty raising private funds in an economic climate that has every cultural organization steeling itself for tough times.

headline: Drug Middlemen Are Facing Pressure Over Rising Prices
summary: As employers, consumers and government officials grow increasingly frustrated by upwardly spiraling drug costs, pressure is building against a handful of powerful companies that have prospered for years as middlemen between drug manufacturers and those who pay for medicines. The companies, called pharmacy benefit managers, administer drug plans for some 200 million Americans and play a critical role in determining which drugs people take for different ailments.

headline: As Cell Antennas Rise, So Do New Barriers
summary: FARIS HOWAT cruises Long Island looking for dead spots. Most cellphone users find their own when the screens on their phones read: ''Call lost. Signal faded.'' But as a manager of system performance for Verizon Wireless, it is Mr. Howat's job to measure how well the calls are getting through. Driving east on Jericho Turnpike in Woodbury, one of his passengers lost a call, so Mr. Howat pulled over and quickly checked the readings on the laptop computer attached to the dashboard. ''The signal is a little weak here,'' he said. ''Try it again.'' The call went through.

headline: Cleanup's Pace Outstrips Plans For Attack Site
summary: The gargantuan cleanup is set to be finished by June. The caved-in subway line is slated to be rebuilt and running again by November. The first new office tower could start rising as early as the end of the year. And the PATH commuter line from New Jersey, for which hundreds of millions of dollars have already been made available, is scheduled to be back in service by the end of 2003. It is a pace of progress at the World Trade Center site that was unthinkable right after Sept. 11, and that has surprised everyone from city and state officials to real estate developers to victims' families.

headline: Lucent Finally Chooses a Chief Executive
summary: Lucent Technologies, the troubled telecommunications equipment giant, ended its long search for a chief executive yesterday by naming Patricia F. Russo, who was a top executive at the company before leaving 17 months ago. By rehiring Ms. Russo from Eastman Kodak, where she was president and chief operating officer, Lucent sent a clear message: the company does not plan a major departure from its current management policies as it tries to return to profitability. Lucent lost more than $16 billion and cut or spun off more than 70,000 jobs in the last year and a half.

headline: An Earlier Start Time For the Wanamaker Mile
summary: Since the 1930's, the most glamorous race in indoor track, the Wanamaker Mile, has been run at 10 p.m., at first to accommodate Ted Husing's live radio broadcast. Now television has a voice, and the Fox Sports Network, which will televise the Verizon Millrose Games from Madison Square Garden from 8 to 10 p.m. Feb. 1, needed a change. Howard Schmertz, the meet director, announced yesterday that the Wanamaker Mile would be moved to 9 p.m. and that the meet, which almost always ended after 11 p.m., and occasionally after midnight, would end, hopefully, by 10 p.m.

headline: The Internet's Invisible Hand; At a Public Utility Serving the World, No One's Really in Charge. Does It Matter?
summary: NO one owns it. And no one in particular actually runs it. Yet more than half a billion people rely on it as they do a light switch. The Internet is a network whose many incarnations -- as obscure academic playpen, information superhighway, vast marketplace, sci-fi-inspired matrix -- have seen it through more than three decades of ceaseless evolution.

headline: Vodafone Shares Cooling With Slower Growth in America
summary: The Vodafone Group, a wireless favorite among investors, has lost a bit of its luster of late. Today, its shares fell nearly 4 percent, adding to a 12 percent slide this week, as analysts expressed concerns about disappointing growth of subscribers in the United States and the uncertain introduction of new wireless services in Europe.

headline: So How Contaminated Is the Old Nuclear Plant?
summary: IN 1952, when uranium was scarce like gold in the United States -- the Atomic Energy Commission announced a contract with Sylvania for research on nuclear reactor materials. Sylvania, one of a long list of corporations with such contracts, soon began processing uranium fuel at the Sylvania Electric Products plant on Cantiague Rock Road in Hicksville.

headline: AT&T and Others Brace for Trouble From Argentina
summary: Argentina's currency devaluation and debt default could create problems for some of the biggest United States and European telecommunications companies. Already, the international arm of the United States wireless carrier Nextel Communications has missed a debt payment to banks, mainly as a result of the Argentine crisis. And other telecommunications companies with a big presence in Argentina -- including AT&T, BellSouth, Verizon Communications and Telefónica of Spain -- all could feel the pinch of a decline in hard-currency revenue and could find themselves in uncertainty over planning as they await regulatory changes.

headline: New Director At Carnegie Eliminates Its Jazz Band
summary: When Carnegie Hall announced its 2002-3 season yesterday, the hall's jazz band was nowhere on the schedule. That is because Carnegie Hall's new executive and artistic director, Robert J. Harth, decided to discontinue the 16-member ensemble. ''It's really a question of using our resources in that area in a different manner,'' Mr. Harth said at a new conference yesterday. ''Supporting our own jazz ensemble limits our ability in terms of the varied programming to respond to changing audience tastes and provide for a wider variety of artists.''

headline: Comcast's High-Speed Web Access, the Bored Game
summary: Comcast said that about 10 percent of the 71,000 customers in North Jersey that were moved onto the new network faced either intermittent, limited service failures or could not receive or send e-mail. ''These kinds of problems are very typical when you're launching something new,'' said Dave Watson, executive vice president of Comcast Cable, which is based in Philadelphia. Mr. Watson said the most seriously affected customers -- numbering fewer than 100 -- lost service for several days. The New York Times, Jan. 4, 2002 ''That's funny, because I know about 10.'' Dan Blatt, neighbor of mine The Game of High-Speed Internet Access by Comcast

headline: Fair Local Phone Rates
summary: The New York Public Service Commission helped jump-start competition for local phone service yesterday when it ordered Verizon to further discount the wholesale rate at which it leases its lines to competing companies trying to enter the New York market. The move is not only beneficial to state consumers; it could be of vital importance to the nation's overall economy. In recent years, healthy competition has revolutionized the market for many telecommunications products, from long distance to cellphone services. Local service, however, remains a near-monopoly, firmly in the hands of the Baby Bells, including Verizon, that were created by the breakup of AT&T in 1984 and control the ''last mile'' of wire into consumers' homes and offices. Nationwide, competitors to the Baby Bells provide local service to less than 10 percent of all phone lines, and only 5 percent of all residential lines.

headline: Verizon Is Told to Cut Access Rates
summary: The New York State Public Service Commission voted yesterday to require Verizon Communications, the state's main local phone carrier, to lower the prices it charges to competitors that use its network. The decision is expected to bolster efforts to increase competition among local phone companies.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths ROWE, DONALD C.
summary: ROWE-Donald C., 51. Of Ridgefield, CT. Jan. 24, 2002. A regulatory attorney with Verizon Corporation of NYC. Survived by his wife, Carolyn Harris Rowe of Ridgefield, 3 sons, Robert Andrew, William Harris & David Alexander Rowe, his father William Elijah Rowe of Brooklyn, NY, his brother William T. Rowe, his nephew Joshua Rowe and his niece Sara Rowe of Baltimore, MD. Funeral services, Monday, 11 AM, Temple Shearith Israel, Ridgefield, CT. Memorials in Donald's memory may be made to Temple Shearith Israel Building Fund, 46 Peaceable Street, Ridgefield, CT. 06877, or the Boy Scouts of America, CT. Yankee Council, 60 Wellington Road, Milford, CT 06460.

headline: For IDT, the Big Flameouts Light Its Fire
summary: How the tables have turned. Last fall, on a business tour of Israel by a group of American executives, James A. Courter, chief executive of the offbeat New Jersey telecommunications company IDT, was on a Masada-bound bus with William J. Rouhana, chairman of Winstar Communications, a rising star in the United States telecommunications market. At the time, Winstar was a Wall Street darling with a stock market value exceeding $11 billion. IDT, toiling in the unglamorous fields of wholesale long-distance and prepaid calling cards, had a market value of $1 billion and no buzz among analysts.

headline: Fast Hookup With Cellphone Is Expected From Verizon
summary: Verizon Wireless, the largest wireless carrier in the United States, is expected to announce today the availability of the nation's first commercial ''third-generation'' wireless service, which would provide users with fast access to the Internet through cellphones, people close to the company said. The service, which will cost at least $30 a month in additional fees, will be available on the East Coast from Maine to Virginia, in the Bay Area of Northern California and in Salt Lake City in time for the Olympic Games. It will provide Internet access at speeds up to 144 kilobits a second, more than double normal connections.

headline: Spending a little to publicize the need to raise a lot to vaccinate children.
summary: IT costs only $30 to immunize an infant against preventable diseases like measles and mumps, according to the Vaccine Fund, a worldwide organization that raises money for universal immunization. So why is the organization spending dollars to advertise this week at the World Economic Forum? ''We would like to spend all our money for the immunization of the children,'' said Jacques-François Martin, president and chief executive at the Vaccine Fund, based in Lyons, France, but ''without a brand, we won't be able to raise any more.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Cheney Refuses to Release Energy Data to Congress Vice President Dick Cheney refused to give Congressional investigators a list of business leaders, including Enron executives, with whom he had consulted on energy policy. The head of the General Accounting Office said he would decide this week whether to file suit to force the White House to turn over the information. [Section A.]

headline: Board Dashes Cold Water On Public Feud at Viacom Between Top Executives
summary: Members of the Viacom board yesterday told Sumner M. Redstone, the company's chairman and chief executive, and Mel Karmazin, the president and chief operating officer, to end the personal conflict between them that has emerged into public view in the last several months, people associated with the board said. A group of outside directors made the plea in an unusual separate meeting that took place after the regularly scheduled board meeting in New York yesterday. The two top Viacom executives were said to have agreed to the board's request that they try to resolve their differences.

headline: VERIZON REPORTS FOURTH-QUARTER LOSS OF $2 BILLION
summary: Verizon Communications, the nation's biggest local telephone company, posted a $2 billion fourth-quarter loss because of investment declines and costs to eliminate 8,700 jobs. The loss, 75 cents a share, was in contrast to net income of $1.9 billion, or 70 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose less than 1 percent, to $17 billion. The number of local phone lines dropped for a third quarter as corporate layoffs crimped demand and consumers relied more on mobile phones. Phone lines in service fell 2.1 percent, to 61.6 million. Expenses included $1.93 billion from a decline in the value of investments, including Verizon's stake in Genuity Inc. It also had $1 billion in severance costs.

headline: Bloomberg Plans Quick Start of Citywide 311 Phone System
summary: In the first major policy initiative of his administration, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday outlined plans for creating a new telephone system that would allow residents to dial one phone number -- 311 -- to obtain all city services, even as he acknowledged difficulties in creating such a system in a city so large. Mr. Bloomberg also said that the plan, which envisions telephone operators fielding far-ranging service inquiries from a population that speaks more than 100 languages, would do little to reduce the number of calls to 911, an effect the Giuliani administration had hoped for when it studied a similar idea.

headline: In the Region/New Jersey; Realty Firms Offer Help in Settling in a New Home
summary: ON the list of traumatic experiences life has to offer, moving to a new home has been regularly ranked near the top, not far behind the death of a loved one, divorce and losing a job. Real estate agencies are expending extra effort these days to reduce the stress. ''We don't want our company to be associated in people's minds with an experience that produces any nightmares,'' said Fred Watkins, president of Weichert Realtors' financial services group. Weichert has begun offering mortgage clients what it calls Gold Service to smooth transitions -- including not only the usual service discounts, but actual help getting things done.

headline: POSTINGS: A Technology Management Center; New Building At Stevens
summary: The newest addition to Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken is to be a six-story building with a 21st-century design to both reflect the technology management school within and blend with its 19th- and 20th-century campus neighbors. The Lawrence T. Babbio Jr. Center for Technology Management will have such contemporary features as a soaring glass atrium and an aluminum-clad roof cornice. They will be set against a traditional brick base, linking the $29 million, 90,000-square-foot building to nearby older ones. Designed by Ecoplan Architects of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., the center will hold the latest wireless technology and be an environmentally sensitive ''green building.''

headline: The Strong Will Survive The Fallout In Telecom
summary: JANUARY was a grim month for telecommunications companies. In rapid succession, Global Crossing Ltd. and McLeodUSA filed for bankruptcy protection. Williams Companies said it was re-evaluating its debt exposure to Williams Communications Group Inc., which it spun off last year, and WorldCom Inc.'s stock took a tumble. Adam Quinton, head of global telecommunications research at Merrill Lynch, talked last week about the industry. Following are excerpts from the conversation:

headline: A Doctor for Schools Calls Philadelphia's 'Very Sick'
summary: The business executive faced with the task of halting the downward spiral of this city's public school system has pronounced it in a state of ''cardiac arrest.'' ''I did use that term in a very passionate moment,'' said James E. Nevels, the chairman of the new School Reform Commission, the five-member panel created by the state in its emergency takeover of the city's deeply troubled schools.

headline: Criticism Is Leveled At U.S. Drug Testing
summary: Dick Pound, the chairman of the World Anti-Doping Agency, yesterday urged track and field's world governing body and the United States Olympic Committee to throw out USA Track and Field for refusing to name the American athletes who had tested positive for drugs before the 2000 Sydney Olympics. But Nick Davies, a spokesman for track's world body, said, ''We will not expel the United States.'' The world agency was founded by the International Olympic Committee to coordinate drug testing in Olympic sports. Pound, a lawyer from Montreal, is an I.O.C. member and a former vice president of the organization.

headline: Carlos Is Now Making A Different Statement
summary: He is 57, and his trim beard and retreating hair are gray. He is a New Yorker who now lives in California and works with youngsters there. But no matter where he is, fair or not, John Carlos is remembered for one moment: that day when he won the 200-meter bronze medal and Tommie Smith the gold in the 1968 Mexico City Olympics and then, on the victory stand, raised a fist with Smith in a Black Power salute.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 2 Big Names Said to Drop Idea of Bidding For WorldCom
summary: Verizon and SBC Communications, the two biggest local telephone companies, each considered bidding to acquire WorldCom Inc. in recent months but backed out amid concerns that WorldCom's core long-distance businesses face continued difficulties, people close to Verizon and SBC said yesterday. Verizon and SBC may have also been scared by WorldCom's accounting practices, according to some telecommunications executives. Some investors and analysts have worried that WorldCom has used aggressive accounting techniques in the past, particularly in reporting revenue.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Powell Says Nuclear Pact With Russia Is On Track Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, testifying before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said the United States expected to meet Russia's demand for a ''legally binding'' deal on reducing nuclear warheads. A1 Military Aid Plan for Colombia The Bush administration is proposing to expand military aid to Colombia by training the Colombian Army to protect a 500-mile-long oil pipeline from leftist rebels, senior American officials visiting Colombia said. A6

headline: Footlights
summary: Encore Last year, besides topping best-seller charts with her CD's, she sang with the Boston Pops, at the Verizon Festival, at the Ravinia Festival and at the Montreal, Monterey and Clearwater Jazz Festivals. She is Jane Monheit, a jazz sensation at 24. The latest chance to hear her in person is at 8 tomorrow night at the Pace Downtown Theater-Schimmel Center for the Arts, 3 Spruce Street, between Park Row and Gold Street, Lower Manhattan, as the Highlights in Jazz series celebrates its 29th anniversary. Ms. Monheit, who first performed in the series as a surprise guest, will appear on a bill with the Cyrus Chestnut Trio. And a surprise guest is promised.

headline: Rescuing the Buildings Beyond Ground Zero
summary: Five months after the World Trade Center attack, the focus of the recovery effort is moving outward from ground zero to another trauma zone: a ring of battered skyscrapers and other buildings that once held 10 million square feet of floor space, slightly more than the twin towers. The Sept. 11 avalanche of flaming steel, shattered concrete and other debris from the towers tore through roofs, sliced giant gashes in facades, ignited fires and set loose underground floods.

headline: Some Plans That Offer More Than Minutes
summary: CHOOSING a cellphone used to be easy. You simply had to calculate which was the better value: the $40 national plan with 500 anytime minutes, 3,000 weekend minutes and roaming at 65 cents per minute, or the $35 regional plan with 400 national anytime minutes, 5,000 weekend minutes and roaming at 60 cents per minute. But these days, you're not shopping for a phone -- you're shopping for a company. Wireless carriers are knocking themselves out to lure you with exclusive features. In phone stores these days, a bulleted list of trademarked features sits next to each phone. ''Connect2Fone -- For the ultimate in on-the-go communication,'' you might read. Or ''MobileMinutes -- Four-in-one message management for the mobile professional.''

headline: The Future of Cellphones Is Here. Sort Of.
summary: FOR the last few years, ever since a cellphone became nearly as commonplace as a wallet, the telecommunications industry has promoted the potential of wireless Internet access. The idea is simple enough: beef up the wireless networks and users will flock to them to browse the Web, send e-mail with milelong attachments and even download video clips, all on their phones. But the execution has proved to be a giant technical and financial challenge.

headline: Squeezing Ever More From the Cellphone Spectrum
summary: ALTHOUGH talking on a wireless phone the size your palm may seem the image of cutting-edge technology, a cellphone is really nothing more than a radio. And like the FM stereo in your car, a cellphone can suffer from the same limitations: blocked signals and interference. ''When you go behind a mountain or down to the second level of a parking garage, a wireless signal will fade just like a radio station in your car,'' said Ed Reynolds, president for network operations at Cingular.

headline: Talking More but Enjoying It Less
summary: LISA KING bought a cellphone two and a half years ago to keep in constant contact with her husband, her job and her friends. But these days it seems like she is out of touch more often than ever. Her calls are often abruptly cut off or don't go through at all. Voice mail messages are sometimes delivered hours after they are left. She cannot even get a signal within a two-block radius of her home in Arlington, Va., just outside Washington.

headline: Verizon Wireless Will Lay Off 1,000
summary: Verizon Wireless, the largest wireless carrier in the United States, is planning to lay off 1,000 employees in a reorganization in the next few weeks, a company spokesman said last night. The cuts amount to less than 2 percent of the company's work force, which number more than 40,000 employees, divided equally around the South, West, Midwest and the Northeast, which includes Virginia, said the spokesman, Jim Gerace.

headline: Corrections
summary: A chart in Circuits last Thursday with the State of the Art column, comparing offerings from six cellphone carriers, referred incorrectly to Verizon's pricing for short text messages. While alerts from Verizon on subjects like stocks, weather and sports are free, recipients are billed for messages from other users.

headline: Verizon Proposes Increase For Its Local Phone Service
summary: Verizon, New York's local phone carrier, presented a plan to increase rates for local telephone service to the State Public Service Commission yesterday. The rate increase, presented at a commission hearing in Albany, would generate $140 million in new revenue each year. It is meant to offset nearly $190 million in annual losses that Verizon is expected to incur under a commission plan to produce more competition in the local telephone market.

headline: Correction: Sizing Up Cellphone Features
summary: A chart last Thursday with the State of the Art column, comparing offerings from six cellphone companies, omitted several features available from AT&T Wireless and VoiceStream. It also referred incorrectly to Verizon's pricing for short text messages; users are billed for incoming messages other than alerts from Verizon. Here is a corrected chart.

headline: Are Investors Too Worried About Cable?
summary: THERE are times when investors grow so worried about what might go wrong that they overestimate the chance that disaster will happen. Eleven years ago, during the last recession, investor fears crystalized around banks. After a wave of bank failures, it was clear that many banks had abused accounting rules to make themselves look healthier than they were. Many banks traded as if failure was a real possibility. Some did fail, but most did not. It was a great time to buy a portfolio of bank stocks.

headline: Shares Are Lower as Nasdaq Scrapes a 4-Month Bottom
summary: Stocks fell yesterday, driving the Nasdaq composite index to its lowest level in almost four months, on speculation that a profit rebound for telecommunications and computer-related companies might be weaker than forecast. Intel and Cisco Systems led the decline.

headline: Compressed Data; Some Junk E-Mail Has A Poor Sense of Timing
summary: If telemarketers who interrupt dinner are an annoyance, what about e-mail spam that awakens you in the wee hours? Ask Red Linton, a consultant in Philadelphia who is responsible for keeping his clients' small computer networks running smoothly. If something goes wrong with a network overnight, a computer fires off an e-mail message to Mr. Linton. His PC at home monitors a special mailbox set aside for this purpose and sounds an alarm when mail arrives.

headline: Jacobs's Indoor Career Approaching Conclusion
summary: At 38, REGINA JACOBS is still running fast. Last Saturday, four weeks after she ran the fastest indoor two-mile race by a woman (9 minutes 23.38 seconds), she ran in a special open race during a high school meet at the Armory Track and Field Center in Manhattan and won with the fastest women's indoor time for three miles (14:44.11). But her indoor career is almost over. Last year, when track and field's national indoor championships were held in Atlanta, she won the 3,000 meters. This weekend, when the championships move to the Armory, she will run the mile. Her goal is to win, not necessarily to run fast.

headline: Verizon Information Parts With Deutsch
summary: Verizon Information Services, a division of Verizon Communications, said yesterday that it would end its 11-month relationship with Deutsch in New York, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Groupof Companies. Billings for the account, for the SuperPages yellow pages directories and SuperPages.com, were estimated at $30 million. The decision came two weeks after the MCI unit of WorldCom shifted to Deutsch the consumer advertising for the MCI brand, with billings estimated at as much as $100 million. The agency had hoped the two accounts would not be considered a conflict, but executives at the Verizon parent decided otherwise.

headline: Technology; Congressional Broadband Fight Intensifies
summary: Two weeks after the House of Representatives approved legislation to limit the influence of money in politics, the House is expected to approve a telecommunications bill that is largely shaped by the huge campaign contributions it has generated. The measure, a bill to deregulate the high-speed Internet market, has become known informally on Capitol Hill as the big bucks bill of the year, although it has little chance of becoming law any time soon. As a result, experts predict it will continue to be lucrative for lawmakers for years to come, encouraging the telecommunications industry to find ways to make tens of millions of dollars in contributions long after Congress completes its work on the campaign finance legislation. Senate leaders say the bill, to be taken up by the House on Wednesday, has virtually no hope of approval by the Senate this year.

headline: 2 Utilities Say 9/11 Costs May Raise Rates
summary: With their hopes of federal aid fading, Verizon and Consolidated Edison are warning that they may make consumers pay for hundreds of millions of dollars in losses they suffered as a result of the World Trade Center attack. For the average ratepayer, the move could mean as much as an extra $40 per year on the combined utility bills. In all, the utilities expect the costs associated with the attacks to reach $1.9 billion. Insurance is expected to cover $1.2 billion, leaving about $720 million outstanding.

headline: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Verizon Rate Rise Is Approved
summary: The Public Service Commission approved a $1.85-a-month rate increase, or 4 percent, yesterday for the average Verizon telephone customer, beginning next month. The plan allows for an additional monthly increase of 65 cents in 2003 if Verizon meets performance goals set the commission. The rate increase is expected nearly to cover projected losses for Verizon as part of a commission plan to encourage more competition in Verizon's former monopoly on local service. Jayson Blair (NYT)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon To Trim Equivalent Of 10,000 Jobs
summary: Verizon Communications, the nation's largest local telephone company, plans to eliminate the equivalent of about 10,000 jobs this year, mainly through the reduction of overtime and contract positions. Ivan Seidenberg, Verizon's chief executive, told investors at a conference in Orlando, Fla., that the company was trying to cut costs because of slower sales growth caused by a sluggish economy. Verizon had about 247,000 employees at the end of 2001, compared with about 263,000 a year earlier. Simon Romero (NYT)

headline: Creditors Resist Asian Bid for Global Crossing
summary: Creditors of Global Crossing are strongly resisting an offer by two Asian companies to acquire the bankrupt company's assets after reports of a competing bid emerged over the weekend, people close to the company said yesterday. The creditors, which have strong influence over Global Crossing's future after it filed for bankruptcy protection in late January, have told the Asian companies, Hutchison Whampoa of Hong Kong and Singapore Technologies Telemedia, that their $750 million offer was unacceptable, these people said.

headline: Supreme Court To Decide Fate Of 200 Licenses For Wireless Use
summary: A long-running battle over more than 200 valuable wireless communications licenses has reached the Supreme Court, which agreed today to consider the government's argument that it had the right to seize the licenses from a bankrupt company and auction them to the nation's largest communications carriers. Since shortly after they were issued in 1996, the highly coveted licenses have been unused and at the center of a fierce legal and regulatory struggle, and the decision of the justices makes it probable that they will remain in legal limbo for at least another year.

headline: F.Y.I.
summary: Hizzoner, Aloft Q. I read that Mayor Bloomberg recently piloted a police helicopter to an event. Have there been any other ''Top Gun'' mayors? A. Mayor Bloomberg's stint at the controls, on a trip to the Bronx borough president's inauguration, has drawn comparisons to John V. Lindsay and Fiorello H. La Guardia.

headline: Cisco and Sprint Venture Has First Big Client
summary: As it tries to regain the torrid pace that briefly made it the world's most valuable company, Cisco Systems is counting heavily on winning new customers among telecommunications providers, one of the sectors hardest hit by the slowed economy. Cisco's routers and switches sit at the heart of many corporate networks, but the company has found trouble replicating that success when it comes to the huge voice and data networks run by the Baby Bells. Lucent Technologies and Nortel Networks, though struggling themselves, dominate that market.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A2-10 Sharon Prepared to Lift Travel Ban on Arafat Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel made a critical concession toward a cease-fire, saying he was prepared to lift the travel restrictions on Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, now that he had met Israel's condition of arresting all the suspects in the killing of an Israeli cabinet minister. A1 Response to Arms Report Top aides in the Bush administration, including Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Gen. Richard B. Myers, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, took to the talk shows to address international concerns over a Pentagon policy review that identifies countries like Iran, Iraq and North Korea as potential targets for nuclear attacks. Reaction from abroad was muted. A8

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Chip Developer Buys A Rival for $1.4 Billion The Intersil Corporation, a large developer of microchips that power high-speed wireless networks, agreed yesterday to acquire a rival, Elantec Semiconductor, for $1.43 billion. The deal is expected to help speed the development of high-speed networks. The networks could be used to distribute digital video and other multimedia without being tethered by wires. [Page C6.]

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Valueclick To Buy Be Free For $128.5 Million
summary: ValueClick, an online advertising company, agreed to buy Be Free Inc. for about $128.5 million in stock. ValueClick will exchange 0.65share for each Be Free share, or a total of 43.4 million shares, ValueClick said in a statement. The offer values Be Free at $1.95 a share, 26 percent more than its closing price of $1.55 on Friday. ValueClick closed at $2.96 on Friday. The purchase would allow ValueClick to offer its ad-aiming products to Be Free customers like Sprint, Verizon, Travelocity.com and I.B.M., a ValueClick spokeswoman, Elizabeth Lloyd, said. Be Free, which had about 166 employees at the end of last year, provides Internet marketing services that help businesses link and analyze the performance of Web sites, the chief financial officer, Stephen Joseph, said in an interview. Be Free has about 65.8 million shares outstanding, he said. Shareholders of Be Free will own about 45 percent of the combined company's shares outstanding; the deal is expected to be completed by the end of the second quarter. Shares of ValueClick fell 16 cents, to $2.80. Be Free shares rose 23 cents, to $1.78.

headline: Near Ground Zero, Street Surgery Starts With a Shovel
summary: Sitting in a pizza shop at Church and Murray Streets, wedged between the site of the World Trade Center disaster and his own construction crews, Matthew Ketshke is glancing out at the worker warming his gloves on the exhaust of a portable power generator. It is a cold afternoon and his men are calf-deep in dirt, mud and broken pieces of asphalt. The basic scene will not change much for months, except for taking place on different streets.

headline: New Economy; Wireless carriers battle plans to make cellphone numbers portable.
summary: TF you are a cellphone user who has waited to change service providers until you can take your phone number with you -- you may have to keep waiting. Wireless carriers are supposed to install technology by late November that will let customers keep their phone numbers when changing carriers. But the Federal Communications Commission is considering a petition by Verizon Wireless to drop that requirement -- or at least delay the deadline.

headline: Compressed Data; A Cellphone-Computer, And It Does Windows
summary: A new hybrid cellphone and hand-held computer, expected from Verizon Wireless in late spring, will be the first phone powered by an operating system from Microsoft to be offered in the United States by telecommunications companies. Made by Audiovox and called the Thera, it features components and software by the biggest names in personal computers. The Thera runs on a 206-megahertz processor by Intel. The Pocket PC operating system, a smaller version of Windows for gadgets, powers the device, which also has features like Word and the Windows Media Player.

headline: Banks Agree To Revisions In Credit Terms For Qwest
summary: Qwest Communications International Inc., which unnerved Wall Street and its banks last month by unexpectedly drawing down a $4 billion line of credit, said yesterday that the banks had agreed to relax debt restrictions in the credit agreement. Qwest, which is based in Denver, said that the amended agreement should put to rest fears that lenders could force it into a fire sale of assets or even bankruptcy later this year.

headline: Con Ed Asks Permission to Hold Rebates
summary: Consolidated Edison has asked New York regulators to let it withhold millions of dollars in consumer rebates to pay for World Trade Center-related damages, in case promised federal aid proves to be inadequate. In all, Con Ed has asked the New York State Public Service Commission to withhold $36.4 million in rebates that were set to be returned to consumers as early as this year.

headline: VERIZON SEEKS TO SELL LONG-DISTANCE SERVICE IN MAINE
summary: Verizon Communications is seeking approval from regulators to sell long-distance phone service in Maine. Verizon, based in New York, filed the request with the Federal Communications Commission yesterday, the company said. The F.C.C. has 90 days to review the bid, Verizon said. The company, which had a $2 billion fourth-quarter loss, is trying to sell long-distance throughout the United States amid slowing growth in its local-calling business. Verizon needs F.C.C. approval to offer the service in its local-phone region. It sells long-distance in 41 states and is the fourth-largest carrier, behind AT&T, WorldCom and Sprint.

headline: Bush Seeks $27 Billion Emergency Fund
summary: The Bush administration asked Congress today for $27 billion in emergency funds to strengthen domestic security, rebuild New York and wage the war on terrorism, including plans to expand that conflict beyond Afghanistan. More than half the money, $14 billion, would go to the Pentagon, mostly to pay for military operations in Afghanistan, where the United States has stationed more than 4,000 troops and continues to fly scores of combat air patrols daily. The request indicates the White House does not expect war costs to taper off from their current rate of more than $2 billion a month.

headline: Rating Services' Doubts Hurt Shares of Verizon
summary: The bond and share prices of Verizon Communications Inc. fell yesterday after two credit ratings services said the company needed to reduce its dependence on volatile short-term borrowing or increase its bank commitments backing that debt. Verizon, which has $12.8 billion in debt that matures in less than nine months, may see its financing costs rise if it shifts to more expensive longer-term notes. Dennis Saputo, an analyst for one rating firm, Moody's Investors Service, said Verizon had backed its short-term debt with $8.5 billion of cash and bank credit commitments, which might not be enough.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Volcker Proposes Andersen e Controlled by New Panel Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, proposed that the government drop its case against Arthur Andersen and allow him to put a new oversight board in charge of the accounting firm. He said the board would make management changes and focus the firm almost exclusively on auditing. Mr. Volcker's proposal steps up the pressure on plaintiffs to settle their lawsuits against Andersen, something the accounting firm considers vital to restoring confidence in its viability. In separate action, a federal mediator was appointed to try to resolve civil cases against Andersen. [Page A1.]

headline: AT&T's Decision to Withdraw From Billing for '900' Lines Leaves Call-In Industry in a Bind
summary: The long-distance ''900'' telephone number business, in which callers pay for offerings that range from computer help lines to psychic hot lines to sexual fantasies, is hearing fewer rings. Since peaking in 1992, when callers paid about $3 billion for calls to ''900'' numbers, the market has declined to about one-third of that level as competition from the Internet and the policies of long-distance companies have worked against the business.

headline: Multiple Phone Calls Overseas Surprise Recipients of the Bills
summary: The phone bills look more like ones that belong to envoys to the United Nations than to the residents of a quiet block of West 135th Street in Harlem: a 21-minute call to Pakistan, 20 minutes to India, 11 minutes to Egypt and 317 minutes to Kuwait. But the dozen or so recipients of the bills, all of whom live on the north side of West 135th Street between Adam Clayton Powell Jr. and Frederick Douglass Boulevards, say they did not make any of the calls, most of which were made in December and resulted in telephone bills totaling thousands of dollars.

headline: Verizon Shifts Debt To Longer Terms
summary: Verizon Communications said yesterday that it sold $1.5 billion of bonds with maturities as long as 30 years. Credit-rating companies have recently said the company relied too much on short-term debt. Verizon sold $1 billion of 10-year notes and $500 million of 30-year bonds through its New York unit in a sale planned for the past month, said Fred Salerno, the chief financial officer. The company is borrowing to reduce $12.8 billion in debt maturing in nine months or less.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Wide Tax Evasion Is Seen With Offshore Credit Cards The I.R.S. said that Americans in far greater numbers than it had previously expected are evading income taxes by secretly depositing their money in tax havens like the Cayman Islands, where they have set up accounts allowing them to draw on their money with credit cards from American Express, Visa and MasterCard. The I.R.S. estimates that one million to two million Americans may be using such accounts. One prominent criminal tax lawyer said that the estimate was so out of proportion that he doubted it would hold up. [Page A1.]

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Walter Hewlett Files Suit To Block Compaq Merger Walter Hewlett, who has fought bitterly to keep the company his father helped create from merging with Compaq, took his fight to court in an effort to block the $24 billion deal that Hewlett-Packard says it has won. The lawsuit is the latest chapter in an unusual and sometimes harsh campaign by a dissident director to quash a friendly merger. Though the final results of an official count are not expected for several weeks, Hewlett-Packard and Compaq have stepped up their integration efforts. [Page C2.]

headline: Defaults Seem Near for Latin Units of BellSouth and Verizon
summary: The BellSouth Corporation and Verizon Communications, two of the largest telephone companies, signaled yesterday that their Latin American operations were preparing to default on hundreds of millions of dollars of debt because of economic problems in Brazil and Argentina. The defaults would be further evidence of a shift in the business climate in South America. Foreign utilities that leapt into the region's economies in the 1990's when they opened their markets to competition have had problems after policy changes and less generous international borrowing markets limited chances for profitability.

headline: Market Place; Will Ma Bell Be Taken Over By Offspring?
summary: Will AT&T stand alone as a telecommunications company? Many industry executives say they believe that by the middle of next year, a big local phone company like SBC Communications or BellSouth will try to acquire what remains of AT&T.

headline: Metromedia Fiber Slides Toward a Bankruptcy Filing
summary: Metromedia Fiber Network, a major provider of optical fiber communications networks in and around large cities, replaced its top executives yesterday and said that it had violated several loan agreements, moving to the brink of bankruptcy. The company missed an $8.1 million interest payment Friday on $231 million in notes issued to Nortel Networks. The missed payment automatically put it into default not just on the Nortel notes but on more than $440 million in notes and other loans from major creditors and banks.

headline: The Sound of the Fury
summary: THE twin towers came down silently. Or so it appeared on television. Of course, for those who were there, how it sounded mattered most. And, like many elements of that day's events, some of the sounds were unthinkable. Inside the buildings, many died without understanding what had happened. It had been loud, though, they all surely knew that. Michael Hingson, a blind man, famously escaped from his office on the 78th floor with the help of Roselle, his Seeing Eye dog. But simply to hear that terrorists had struck wasn't enough. He needed more.

headline: Verizon Wireless Sues U.S. Over Licenses
summary: Verizon Wireless Inc. has sued the federal government in an effort to cancel an $8.7 billion agreement to buy wireless licenses. The carrier, in a filing, asked the Court of Federal Claims to force the government to return the remaining $261 million of a $1.7 billion down payment for the licenses and compensate the company for lost interest while the Federal Communications Commission held the money. Verizon Wireless has said it may be owed more than $100 million in interest.

headline: Secret List of Potential Suitors Exposed
summary: While more than 50 companies have expressed confidential interest in acquiring Global Crossing, their identities are no longer secret to one another, courtesy of an e-mail message from Global Crossing's lawyers. The e-mail message was sent to the potential bidders on March 28 by an employee of Weil, Gotshal & Manges, the New York law firm that is serving as Global Crossing's counsel in bankruptcy proceedings.

headline: Shares Drop Sharply on General Electric's Profit Decline
summary: Stocks tumbled yesterday after profit at General Electric dropped for the first time in more than seven years and a newsletter said that the Securities and Exchange Commission was questioning I.B.M. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Dow Jones industrial average had their biggest declines since Feb. 4, with stocks losing $265.9 billion of value.

headline: When Schools Learn What Businesses Teach
summary: IN 1977, Smithtown's two high schools taught business the way most high schools did in those days, offering classes in subjects like bookkeeping, shorthand and typing. Boys not heading for college might choose a work-study program at a local auto-repair shop; girls tended to choose placements at local companies where they answered the telephone or helped with the filing. Susan Gubing had already been teaching this curriculum at both schools, Smithtown East and West, for a decade when she happened to be filling out an application for a grant to buy a Dictaphone, and one of the requirements made her pause.

headline: Recent Good News for WorldCom May Only Mask Deeper Problems
summary: Things have been looking a bit brighter for WorldCom Inc. in recent weeks. The company won a major contract from the Pentagon. A federal judge in Mississippi dismissed claims that WorldCom defrauded investors. Even the company's announcement that it needed to cut costs by laying off 3,700 employees, or 4 percent of its work force, was not as drastic as analysts had predicted. Yet investors have continued to flee from WorldCom, the nation's second-largest long-distance phone company and one of the most troubled giants in the hard-hit telecommunications sector. Last week, it briefly joined equipment makers like Lucent and Nortel Networks, whose shares traded in the realm of so-called penny stocks, below $5, before rallying to close on Friday at $5.01.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Metromedia Fiber Defaults On Payment
summary: The data cable company Metromedia Fiber Network Inc. said yesterday that it had defaulted on a $30 million debt interest payment to Verizon Communications Inc. It was the second time this month Metromedia, which is controlled by the billionaire John W. Kluge, missed a debt payment. The provider of links for Internet companies including AOL Time Warner Inc. averted bankruptcy last year by securing $611 million of financing, which included a $150 million note from Citigroup Inc. and a $230 million note convertible into stock. The company is discussing a restructuring agreement with bondholders and may seek Chapter 11 protection from creditors if no agreement is reached. A 30-day grace period for the interest owed on $975 million of debt lapsed yesterday, a Metromedia spokeswoman said. Metromedia, which operates fiber optic networks in cities including New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, defaulted April 1 on $8.1 million owed to Nortel Networks.

headline: After a disappointing year, an advertising executive tells his colleagues to mend their ways.
summary: A FRANK and provocative call to arms by the chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies caused a stir here yesterday at the opening general session of the organization's 2002 Management Conference. The conference is being held as Madison Avenue struggles to recover from what O. Burtch Drake, president and chief executive of the association, described in his opening remarks as a ''crummy year, a year a lot of us would like to forget.''

headline: $7.3 Billion Vision To Rebuild Transit Near Ground Zero
summary: An overhaul of the shattered tangle of subway and commuter trains in Lower Manhattan could cost more than $7 billion, four times the amount currently allocated for downtown transportation improvements, a group of high-level New Yorkers told Congress this week. The New York officials went to Washington on Thursday to try to convince skeptical legislators that properly rebuilding Lower Manhattan's transportation system will require much more than simply repairing what was destroyed. It was the first time that the city and state have delivered a definitive list of their transit plans, with price tags and priorities attached.

headline: Is That a Flagpole? No, It's a Cell Tower.
summary: DANGLING ropes flap in the breeze and a gold ball sits atop the newly completed flagpole on a ridge overlooking Interstate 287 in Greenburgh. If a flag ever flies there, however, it will be incidental. Commerce, not patriotism, inspired the structure, which is really a cellular telephone tower. Due in part to a provision in the federal Telecommunications Act of 1996 that bars communities from objecting to cellular phone antenna installations for health reasons, opposition has shifted to the aesthetic arena. The camouflaged flagpole in Greenburgh illustrates how the industry has devised ways to mask its presence as coverage expands, but such discreet structures are rare in Westchester.

headline: Thumbs Down
summary: AT&T Wireless introduced a new service last week, called mMode, a form of Internet access whose advertisements promote the art of using one's thumbs to type on a cell phone's keypad. So far, though, Americans have shown less inclination than Europeans and Asians to use mobile phones for data communica-tions. For example, the rudimentary form of text messaging known as S.M.S. -- for short messaging service -- has been available in this country since 1998, but has been adopted by fewer than 13 million of the nation's 132.8 million wireless phone subscribers, according to Donald Longueuil, an analyst at the In-Stat Group, a research firm. Europe has 240 million S.M.S. users and Japan 22 million.

headline: Phone Companies' Woes Raise Wider Fears for Investors
summary: Stocks fell yesterday as WorldCom and Ericsson reduced their forecasts for sales and suggested that the slump for telephone and computer-related businesses might stunt a broader profit rebound. ''The few bad apples are enough to spoil the whole market,'' said Dave Briggs, head of trading at Federated Investors in Pittsburgh. He added that earnings in the first quarter had not been strong enough to convince investors that the recovery would be quick.

headline: Bypassing the Carriers, a Burg Goes Broadband
summary: DURING the Civil War, Cumberland built a fort on the hill overlooking the center of town as a bulwark against the Confederate forces just across the Potomac. Today, the city is trying to use the same high ground to strategic advantage in a different campaign: keeping pace with the Internet age. After years of waiting for the phone company, Verizon, to offer high-speed Internet service here, the local government wants to take on the job. And the hill above downtown, now the site of Fort Hill High School, has already proved to be an opportune spot for a crucial station relaying Internet traffic.

headline: A Mayor Is His Own Inspiration; James Trumpets His Record and Newark's Future
summary: Three days from now, Mayor Sharpe James will push a dummy plunger and watch as three hulking structures disappear in a cloud of dust. The implosion of the Stella Wright Homes, once the shame of this famously blighted city, will mark the end of a troubled era in high-rise public housing here and pave the way for what is billed as a quite different vision: a sprawling $200 million collection of neo-colonial town houses, gracious parkland, a new high school and a library.

headline: Pension Folly: How Losses Become Profits
summary: IN the land of executive compensation, there is nothing like being paid for profits that you can be sure will be counted, even if they do not exist. Why take chances with real earnings? Last year, Verizon Communications reported net income of $389 million after taking losses for a variety of things, among them investments in Metromedia Fiber Network, a company whose shares have plunged from a peak of more than $50 to less than 5 cents. Top officers' bonuses were reduced but not eliminated.

headline: PrivateSector; Happy to Take Credit for Once
summary: Ivan Seidenberg, chief executive of Verizon Communications, has certainly seen his company take plenty of criticism for glitches. There was the crippling strike two years ago just as Verizon was publicizing its name change from Bell Atlantic. Last November, Verizon was embarrassed again, for charging New York customers for phone service that had not been restored after Sept. 11. So it will be a refreshing change for Mr. Seidenberg to accept an honor.

headline: Law Firm and Ex-Partner Will Begin Arbitration
summary: Arbitration hearings are scheduled to resolve claims made by Rivkin Radler, law firm in Uniondale, Long Island, against former co-managing partner Arthur Kremer (S)

headline: U.S. Treasury Bills And Other Debt Planned This Week
summary: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills today and a four-week bill on Tuesday. According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.69 percent, on the six-month issue 1.83 percent and on the four-week bill 1.63 percent.

headline: Telecommunications Issues Fall Sharply
summary: Investors in the troubled telecommunications sector stepped up their pace to the exits yesterday. The hardest hit were Qwest Communications International and WorldCom, two concerns with heavy debt loads and enough questions about their accounting to be the subjects of investigations by the Securities and Exchange Commission. But companies like Verizon Communications, SBC Communications and BellSouth, which had fared well by comparison this year, also sagged under the selling pressure yesterday.

headline: CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER AT VERIZON WILL RETIRE
summary: Verizon Communications said Frederic V. Salerno will retire as vice chairman and chief financial officer by the end of the year. The company, which is based in Bedminster, N.J., said it expected to name a successor shortly. Mr. Salerno, 58, said he planned to devote more of his time to other business interests, nonprofit activities and his family after his departure.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Names Financial Officer
summary: Verizon Communications, the telephone company, has named Doreen Toben chief financial officer to succeed Frederic V. Salerno, who announced his retirement on Monday. The appointment is effective immediately, Verizon said. Ms. Toben, 52, was financial officer at the Telecom Group, Verizon's biggest unit. She is taking the job a week after Verizon reported a $501 million first-quarter loss and said profit and sales this year would be less than forecast.

headline: You Say House Arrest, I Say Paradise
summary: FIRST the judge handed down a bit of name-calling: ''common criminal,'' ''thief,'' ''convicted felon.'' Then scorn: ''You have allowed yourself to go from respected to being ridiculed.'' Then a lesson: white-collar crimes are no less serious than other crimes just ''because they are committed while wearing a business suit.''

headline: Accident Cuts Phone Service To Thousands
summary: A construction accident on Tuesday at the site of the planned Manhattan headquarters of Bloomberg L.P. cut phone service to thousands of homes and businesses, and officials said yesterday that telephone service would not be fully restored until Saturday. The accident occurred about 4:30 p.m., when workers at the building site, a block south of Bloomingdale's on the Upper East Side, severed two cement conduits housing copper and fiber-optic cable about 15 feet beneath 58th Street near Lexington Avenue, the authorities said.

headline: Warm Weather Destinations: A Nation of Stages
summary: THEATER Following is a selected list, compiled by Anna Bahney, of events through September. Performances rarely occur every day of the week, and programs are subject to change. Alabama ALABAMA SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL -- Montgomery. (800-841-4273). Productions in two theaters. Festival Stage: May 21-July 27: ''Much Ado About Nothing.'' June 11-July 28: ''Hamlet.'' Aug. 2-Sept. 1: Reduced Shakespeare Company's ''Reducers.'' Octagon Theater: May 14-July 27: premiere of ''Shiloh Rules'' by Doris Baizley. June 4-July 28: ''Sheppy'' by Somerset Maugham. Aug. 6-17: ''Merry Wives of Windsor'' with the Graduate Acting Company. www.asf.net

headline: Two Latin Americas, Two Diverging Outlooks
summary: SHUJI MATAGA could not believe his luck. Mr. Mataga, the president of MMC Automotriz, a Japanese-Venezuelan venture, had arrived in Seoul, South Korea, on April 10 to sign an agreement with Hyundai Motor to enlarge his auto assembly plant in northern Venezuela. But antigovernment protests here had turned into an uprising, and dissident military officials were about to remove Hugo Chávez as Venezuela's president in a short-lived ouster.

headline: FOLLOWING UP
summary: Out of the Assembly, But Into the Money He prefers the exciting, he says, but lives with the lucrative. In 1991, Mel Miller, speaker of the New York State Assembly and one of the most powerful figures in the state's government, was convicted of defrauding clients in his private law practice and was expelled from the Legislature.

headline: Hearing on Technology Reveals Other Heroes of 9/11
summary: In the aftermath of Sept. 11, firefighters and police officers were lionized. Rescue workers and cleanup crews were celebrated for their endurance and bravery. Politicians like former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani became international celebrities. Yesterday was a day for people like Raju Venkataram.

headline: Legend to Watch a Legend in the Making
summary: At the age of 90, the golf legend Byron Nelson has seen many great players come and go. When asked to name the best player he has ever watched, however, Nelson did not hesitate. ''Tiger Woods,'' Nelson said. ''I saw Tiger play more than once every year from the time that he was 14 until now. I never saw a player at the age of 14, 16, 18, 20, 22, 24, or 26 that played as well at that age. Whether or not he's going to beat Jack Nicklaus's major record, nobody knows. But he's working on it.''

headline: Shares of Mobile Phone Company Plunge
summary: Shares in the Western Wireless Corporation, the mobile phone company, fell 41 percent today after it said it lost customers in the first quarter. The shares fell $2.33, to $3.35 a share, on Nasdaq. Western Wireless, which sells wireless service in 19 Western states and in Europe, said late Thursday that it lost 17,000 customers in the United States in the latest quarter, surprising analysts who had forecast a gain of as many as 25,000 subscribers. The company had lower domestic revenue and its fifth consecutive loss. Some analysts said the company could violate debt covenants early next year.

headline: Kathryn Whipple, Mark Raimy
summary: Kathryn Elizabeth Whipple, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce R. Whipple of West Pittston, Pa., was married yesterday to Mark Harvey Raimy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce H. Raimy of Erie, Pa. The Rev. William Bergen performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. Mrs. Raimy, 29, is an Internet specialist in New York for McKinsey & Company, the management consulting concern. She graduated and received a master's degree in higher education from Pennsylvania State University. Her father retired as a fiber-optics service technician in the Wilkes-Barre, Pa., office of Verizon, the telephone company. Her mother, Gert Dwyer Whipple, is an assistant vice president and the manager of residential mortgage sales in Wilkes-Barre for M&T Bank.

headline: Dig It
summary: For about 300 years, Murray Street was a street. Then, last winter, after the World Trade Center went down, it was dug up and turned into a hole. Not a little hole. Not a hole with a few flags and two or three workers and a blinking yellow light. The hole that was Murray Street was a crumbling and steaming and wooden-plank-reinforced earthen gash, which, if it weren't lying sideways across the border of TriBeCa and the financial district, would have been about 100 stories tall. In January, on a cold, clear morning, just after the underground version of Murray Street had been opened up, Mike Redes, a project manager for Empire City Subway, a Verizon-owned company that maintains utilities under the street, was standing on a single-family-home-size plot of subterranean real estate in which Murray Street meets Church Street. Over the previous several weeks, the area had been excavated nearly in its entirety, revealing an open stream of cables and conduits, pipes and mains that separated the former World Trade Center from the rest of Manhattan like a moat. As Redes stood there, as he waved his arm and pointed into the man-cut crevasse, men with short shovels were scrambling into the hole, tossing up steaming dirt. ''What the heck am I gonna do?'' he says. ''I've got to put a manhole in!'' (A manhole is a vault that allows technicians to gain access to underground cables without tearing up the street. The entrance is covered by, yes, a manhole cover.)

headline: Investing; Where Telecom Bargain Hunters Turn
summary: IT has been two months since Ivan G. Seidenberg, the chief executive of Verizon Communications, mused at an investment conference that his company might bid for WorldCom ''for the fun of it'' if the stock price of that long-distance and Internet carrier continued falling. Since then, WorldCom's shares have dropped 80 percent, to $1.58 on Friday. But as Mr. Seidenberg wryly suggested, conditions in the communications sector are so tough that Verizon has no real interest in WorldCom at any price. Verizon, along with rivals like SBC Communications, BellSouth and Deutsche Telekom, all have plenty of their own problems without taking on WorldCom's, which include gigantic debt and an accounting investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Maruyama's a Winner, and Crane Feels Like One
summary: Shigeki Maruyama won a tournament today, but the runner-up, Ben Crane, felt as if he had won the lottery. On a day when the biggest stars in the Verizon Byron Nelson Classic were overshadowed, Maruyama and Crane capitalized on opportunities to take their careers to another level. Maruyama, possessing an infectious smile and a creative short game, became the first Asian-born player to win twice on the PGA Tour. And Crane, a 26-year-old rookie, secured his Tour card for next year, shooting a sensational five-under-par 65 that vaulted him into second place.

headline: Phone Start-Ups Win the Latest Round in Court
summary: The Supreme Court handed a huge victory to start-up telephone companies today by broadly affirming rules that permit them to lease equipment from the largest phone companies at relatively low costs. The pricing regulations are meant to let rivals viably compete with the entrenched local phone companies by leasing access to their networks rather than having to build expensive duplicate systems. Although local telephone competition has been slow to catch on for a variety of reasons, rivals have blamed the intransigence of the dominant local companies.

headline: Critic's Notebook; Carnegie Hall vs. the Kimmel Center
summary: When the Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts in Philadelphia opened in December, work on Verizon Hall, the new 2,500-seat home of the Philadelphia Orchestra, the largest component of the center, was barely complete. With its unusual shape, somewhat like a cello, its airy ambience, beautiful wood paneling and velour seat covers, Verizon Hall immediately felt like an inviting space to hear a concert. But you were reluctant to place your hand on a railing for fear of getting smudged with wet varnish. The air-conditioning system was stuck on high, and the hall was freezing. Given this, many critics and concertgoers were hesitant about making a pronouncement on the question that mattered most: How are the acoustics?

headline: Metromedia Fiber Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Metromedia Fiber Network Inc., a telecommunications company backed by the billionaire investor John W. Kluge, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday after failing to win enough customers for its ambitious plan to sell fast Internet service in urban areas. The filing comes after a protracted period of uncertainty. As recently as October, some of Metromedia's main investors, including Verizon Communications, injected additional capital into the company.

headline: Why choose Yellow? A publisher of phone books aims to explain how the pages differ.
summary: EVER wonder, during a search for a plumber or a car service, just who publishes your yellow pages directory? Most likely, you would guess your local telephone company, but the thick, heavy book could easily have come from one of the increasingly prominent independent publishers. In a humorous effort to explain the difference to consumers, Yellow Book USA, the largest of the independents, introduced this month its most expensive campaign since the company was founded in 1930 as a Long Island community directory. The campaign, with the theme ''Yellow Book. Not the other book,'' also has another aim: convincing advertisers that consumers are indeed using Yellow Book, not those from competitors like the Baby Bells.

headline: Verizon Unit Picks Kirshenbaum Bond
summary: Verizon Information Services in Dallas, a division of Verizon Communications, said yesterday that it had selected Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York, part of the Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network, to handle the account for the SuperPages yellow pages directory and an online directory, SuperPages .com. Billings were estimated at $30 million to $40 million. The decision came after a two-month review of strategy and creative work that had been narrowed to Kirshenbaum Bond and two other finalists: Bozell in New York, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies; and the Playa del Rey, Calif., office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group.

headline: KPNQwest Is Seeking Bankruptcy
summary: KPNQwest N.V., the Dutch provider of data services, said today that it would file for protection from creditors and that it was in talks with rivals that could lead to a takeover of the company. KPNQwest -- majority owned by Royal KPN, the Dutch phone company, and Qwest Communications International of Denver-- also said that its five-member supervisory board resigned, signaling that a group of banks had taken greater control of the company. KPNQwest said it was still negotiating with the bank group, which holds a substantial portion of its assets, including the remaining cash.

headline: Asian Suitors End Discussions On Acquiring Global Crossing
summary: Two Asian companies said yesterday that they had failed to reach an agreement in talks on acquiring the troubled fiber optic network operator Global Crossing. Hutchison Whampoa of Hong Kong and Singapore Technologies Telemedia had made a preliminary offer to buy Global Crossing for $750 million. The offer was made in January, at the same time that Global Crossing sought bankruptcy court protection from its creditors.

headline: Talks Collapse on $750 Million Takeover Global Crossing
summary: Two Asian companies said yesterday that they had failed to reach an agreement in talks on acquiring the troubled fiber optic network operator Global Crossing. Hutchison Whampoa of Hong Kong and Singapore Technologies Telemedia had made a preliminary offer to buy Global Crossing for $750 million. The offer was made in January, at the same time that Global Crossing sought bankruptcy court protection from its creditors.

headline: Music by Any Name: Live, From Mahler Hall
summary: To the Editor: Re ''What's in a Name?'' (editorial, May 23): Perhaps the problem of naming a new or renovated home for the New York Philharmonic is actually an opportunity. The latest techniques in architectural acoustics, as used in Philadelphia's new Verizon Hall, allow architects to build rooms with variable acoustics. Movable ceiling panels and detachable reverberant chambers enable conductors to adjust the sound to fit the particular music being performed.

headline: Vodafone Posts Huge Loss for Year
summary: Once the unchallenged spearhead of the global wireless business, the Vodafone Group announced today that it had a net loss of almost $24 billion in the year ended in March, largely a result of write-downs in the value of the same deals and takeovers that once fueled its growth. The loss, corporate Europe's biggest, succeeded in overshadowing the $12 billion loss in 2001 reported last month by Vivendi Universal, the French media giant, as European companies scramble to reassess the value of assets acquired at the height of the boom in technology, Internet and telecommunications stocks.

headline: Justices Bolster Patent Holders' Rights
summary: The Supreme Court today gave inventors more power to sue competitors for making modified versions of patented products. The 9-to-0 ruling partly overturns a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy said that the Federal Circuit improperly limited a legal doctrine that lets patent holders sue others who make ''equivalent'' products. The appeals court decision would ''risk destroying the legitimate expectations of inventors in their property,'' Justice Kennedy wrote.

headline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Protest Set For Verizon Headquarters
