summary: The communications workers union has scheduled a demonstration today in front of Verizon's headquarters to protest what it says are plans to lay off 2,100 workers in New York State. The protest is scheduled for 5 p.m. on 42nd Street and Avenue of the Americas. The union says such layoffs would violate its contract, but Verizon officials deny planning layoffs in New York. The company says it has 2,100 surplus workers and is negotiating with the union to try to trim that surplus without resorting to layoffs. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

headline: Investing; Beyond the Big Loss at Vodafone
summary: RECORDING the largest loss in British corporate history should not be cause for jubilation, yet shares of the Vodafone Group jumped nearly 10 percent just minutes after the company announced the news on Tuesday. The huge gain proved fleeting -- the stock has since fallen below its price before the announcement -- and many fund managers and brokers remain lukewarm about it.

headline: KPNQwest Lays Off a Third Of Dutch Headquarters Staff
summary: KPNQwest laid off nearly one-third of its employees in the Netherlands today, moving the embattled company, which owns Europe's largest fiber optic network, a step closer to collapse. Talks with potential buyers, including AT&T, have taken on the tone of a fire sale, in which the assets of KPNQwest would be sold piecemeal for cents on the dollar, people close to the company said. A buyer could still acquire KPNQwest as a going concern, but the odds of that happening grew very long when the company filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday, these people said.

headline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Union Sues Verizon Over Layoffs
summary: The union representing employees at Verizon asked a federal judge yesterday to temporarily stop Verizon from dismissing 2,100 telecommunications workers who could be laid off by summer's end. Verizon has proposed reducing its work force through voluntary and involuntary measures. But the union, the Communications Workers of America, said such cutbacks would hurt customer service, including lengthening repair time for damaged phone lines. Under the union contract, Verizon must declare a ''surplus'' of workers before layoffs can begin. ''We are claiming that the surplus is not only not real, but that this will do tremendous harm,'' said Gay Semel, a union attorney. John J. Bonomo, a Verizon spokesman, said there was no merit to the lawsuit. Jayson Blair (NYT)

headline: Verizon Reverses Increase at Some Pay Phones
summary: Verizon Communications officials said yesterday that they had decided to reverse a recent rate increase on thousands of pay phones in New York City, meaning that many phones will require only 25 cents for calls, instead of 50 cents. The company began switching back 14,000 pay phones on sidewalks, in subway stations and at other locations on Monday. The 25-cent rate for a four-minute call is the same that existed in March, before Verizon changed the price to 50 cents for a call of unlimited time. This is the first time that Verizon, which operates pay phones in dozens of markets, has reversed a pay phone rise.

headline: Watch It: If You Cheat, They'll Throw Money!
summary: THERE may be only one type of job in which somebody can commit a felony and, after being fired as a result, still receive a severance package worth many years of salary. The job is chief executive of a large corporation. Over the last decade, many top executives have quietly persuaded their boards of directors to insert a remarkable set of protections into the executives' employment contracts. The contracts have made the executives nearly immune from dismissal, ensuring that they will receive millions of dollars when they leave their posts, under almost any circumstances.

headline: Study Finds Inefficiency in Health Care
summary: Warning that a surge in costs threatens to swamp the employer-subsidized health system within a decade, a new study by a group representing large employers says that $390 billion a year is being wasted on outmoded and inefficient medical procedures. The costs pile up from several sources, according to the study, which is being published today. Among them is the overuse of surgical procedures, tests and medicines; the failure to routinely provide flu and pneumonia vaccines or appropriate tests and follow-up medicines for heart and diabetes patients; and inadequate screening for breast cancer, depression and certain venereal diseases.

headline: State's Delegation to Request More Federal Aid for 2 Utilities
summary: Several members of the New York delegation in Congress say they are planning to ask the Bush administration for an extra $150 million for Verizon Communications and Consolidated Edison to pay the cost of repairs related to the World Trade Center attack. Verizon and Con Edison officials have been careful not to ask explicitly for the extra money, which would raise the total amount of federal aid they are expected to receive to $900 million. But company officials told Congressional delegation members of their request in recent weeks.

headline: Telecommunications Outlook: First the Bad News, Then the Bad News
summary: The turmoil continues in telecommunications, making the long-awaited turnaround increasingly difficult to call. Indeed, in light of a wave of bad news last week and through the weekend, some analysts say the industry's problems could actually become worse before they become better. News over the weekend that Joseph P. Nacchio was leaving the beleaguered telecommunications company Qwest Communications International and that the fiber optic carrier XO Communications would file for bankruptcy protection came in the wake of more bad news from two more established players. Lucent Technologies, the large maker of communications equipment, said last week that its sales would decline much more than expected, about 15 percent this quarter, as its main corporate customers reduce spending. Sprint, meanwhile, had its debt rating lowered to a notch above junk status as it said it would sign up fewer wireless customers.

headline: Footlights
summary: Coming Attraction Masterpieces by Goya, El Greco and Murillo are to be exhibited at the Alexandria Museum of Art in Alexandria, La., beginning on Sept. 30, 2003, during the Louisiana Purchase Bicentennial, under an agreement signed last week in Washington by state and Spanish officials. The exhibition, ''The Heart of Spain,'' will include pre-Christian, Byzantine, Roman and Gothic art and works from the 18th and 19th centuries, when Spain's influence in Louisiana was substantial. Season's Greetings Summer, unofficially in progress since the Memorial Day weekend, is actually about to arrive, and there are those who stand ready to celebrate. In New York, where the season begins at 9:24 a.m. Friday, the Cathedral of St. John the Divine will present ''Paul Winter's Ninth Annual Summer Solstice Celebration.'' In Philadelphia, the new Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts will party all night. Sessions of celebration at St. John the Divine, built around African-inspired music, are scheduled for 7:30 p.m. on Friday and Saturday, and for those who like an early start on a really long day, for 4:30 a.m. Saturday. In Philadelphia a ticket to ''Summer Solstice Celebration,'' beginning at 8 p.m. Friday, includes access to 12 hours of entertainment at various sites in the Kimmel Center, ending with a sunrise ceremony under its 150-foot glass ceiling and a gospel performance in Verizon Hall.

headline: Keeping Eye on the Ball, Not the Skyline; At a Staten Island Ballpark, the View Has Changed, but Dreams Endure
summary: Only a pair of eyes young, innocent and newly arrived could look out across New York Harbor and conjure up a clear vision of the future. Only those eyes could gaze at the Lower Manhattan skyline and not see the scars. ''Just to see that out there behind the outfield is unbelievable, a dream come true,'' said Justin Meccage, 21, blond, blue-eyed, baby-faced and living the first day of a baseball life in the organization his father taught him to love. ''The Statue of Liberty, New York City -- it's absolutely beautiful.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Court Upholds State Review Of Health Care Decisions The Supreme Court has upheld the states' authority to protect the rights of patients in disputes with managed care companies over denial of recommended treatments. Such protections, guaranteeing outside review of a health plan's refusal to pay for a procedure, are the centerpiece of the federal patients' rights bill that has passed both houses of Congress in different versions but remains stalled there. Patients' advocates said the 5-to-4 decision did not eliminate the need for Congressional action because state laws excluded millions of people who could be protected only through federal legislation. [Page A1.]

headline: Filing Raises Concerns About Merck Unit
summary: As Merck & Company prepares the initial public offering of its unit that manages pharmacy benefits next week, a regulatory filing has raised concerns about the subsidiary's future profitability. Although by some counts the unit, Medco Health Solutions, is the nation's largest drug plan manager, it said in a filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission that its gross operating profits had been slim and were becoming slimmer.

headline: F.Y.I.
summary: Names by the Numbers Q. What's the most common surname in New York? A. While no one seems to keep an official count, a good indicator is the phone book. According to a spokesman for Verizon, John Bonomo, the most common name in New York in the phone listings is Rodriguez, with 22,712 entries (not including variations like Rodrigues or hyphenated compounds). The total includes published and nonpublished numbers.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon To Expand In New Jersey
summary: Verizon Communications, the biggest local telephone company, won Federal Communications Commission permission yesterday to sell long-distance service in New Jersey. Verizon lets rivals rent phone lines and switches at discounted prices, meeting the legal conditions to sell long distance, the F.C.C. said in a statement. New Jersey is the eighth state where Verizon has won approval to sell the service.

headline: Corrections
summary: An article in Business Day on Friday about a plan by Verizon Communications to use Microsoft's content, software and marketing support for its high-speed D.S.L. Internet service misstated the surname of a senior vice president at Yahoo, a competitor of Microsoft's MSN service, who said Yahoo would continue to explore deals with D.S.L. and cable companies. He is Jim Brock, not Grant.

headline: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Inquiry Into Verizon Marketing
summary: Federal regulators are investigating whether Verizon Communications illegally marketed its long-distance service in New Jersey before receiving government permission to sell it there. On Monday, the Federal Communications Commission announced that it had approved Verizon's petition to enter the New Jersey market. In May, Verizon said that one of its direct-marketing companies accidentally sent out a mailing urging New Jersey residents to buy its long distance service. But a rival, A T & T Corporation, complained that Verizon had also included long-distance advertisements in Verizon local-service bills sent to more than 500,000 New Jersey customers. Verizon has agreed to send letters to customers informing them that the F.C.C. had not yet approved Verizon's application. If the F.C.C. decides against Verizon, it could impose a hefty fine or even revoke the company's license for New Jersey's $2.2 billion long-distance market. Jayson Blair (NYT)

headline: Experts Say MCI Woes Won't Disrupt Service
summary: By 8:45 a.m. yesterday, WorldCom had already lost at least one customer. Joy A. Huibonhoa, a Manhattan lawyer, woke up to news on the radio that WorldCom, the No. 2 long-distance provider and owner of the MCI brand, was on the brink of bankruptcy. While on the treadmill at the gym, she watched WorldCom coverage on television.

headline: Market Place; In this bear market, there is plenty of bad news to go around.
summary: SOME bear markets look much worse than they really are for most investors, simply because the stocks that go down the most are ones that most investors do not own. But this bear market is just the opposite. The stocks that have suffered the most this year include some held by the greatest number of investors. Of the 20 stocks held by the most customer accounts at Merrill Lynch at the beginning of this year, 16 have fallen by more than the 15.2 percent decline in the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, a widely followed index of large American companies.

headline: Job Cuts Take Heavy Toll on Telecom Industry
summary: WorldCom's downfall is swelling the exodus of workers from the telecommunications industry, which alone has accounted for more than one out of every 10 jobs lost in the United States since the recession began in March last year. Most of this rapid job shrinkage in telecommunications has come through layoffs, buyouts and forced retirements. Indeed, telecommunications companies have exceeded any other industry in the number of publicly announced job cuts over the last 18 months.

headline: VERIZON WIRELESS TO GIVE $600 MILLION IN DISCOUNTS
summary: Verizon Wireless Inc. agreed to provide as much as $600 million in discounts to settle a lawsuit with customers nationwide who had claimed that the company hid service charges. Cell-phone customers sued Verizon and its predecessors two years ago in California State Superior Court in San Diego, claiming they did not fully explain special offers and hidden charges for rounding up calls to minute increments, operator assistance, busy signals, service switching, contract cancellation and local and long-distance tolls. Verizon denies the allegations in the lawsuit and plans to issue ''a new, uniform customer agreement'' approved by the plaintiffs' lawyers, according to the company's Web site and documents mailed to customers this week.

headline: Cingular Wireless arrives late in New York, but comes bearing orange umbrellas and M&M's.
summary: CINGULAR WIRELESS is hoping that its risky and expensive effort to break into the crowded New York market will be received more like the return of the Dodgers to Brooklyn than the resumption of alternate-side-of-the-street parking after a holiday weekend. Cingular, the nation's second-largest provider of wireless telephone services, plans to spend about $20 million on the extensive effort. The campaign, which begins this week with elements that include print advertisements, commercials, a dedicated Web site, promotions and retail marketing, is tailored to the tastes and ''all right, already'' tone of New Yorkers.

headline: Corrections
summary: A picture caption in Business Day on Saturday with an article about the loss of jobs in the telecommunications industry referred imprecisely to a protest by employees at Verizon Communications in late May. They were demonstrating against the company's declaration that it could lay off employees as a last resort, not an announcement of actual layoffs.

headline: Court Had Rehnquist Initials Intricately Carved on Docket
summary: If there is one phrase that best describes the Supreme Court term that ended late last week, it is this: the triumph of William H. Rehnquist. In the term that marked the chief justice's 30th anniversary on the bench, the court moved far toward accomplishing his long-term goals, lowering the barrier between church and state and elevating states' rights through expanding the concept of sovereign immunity.

headline: Now, That Ringing Cellphone May Be a Telemarketer's Call
summary: Dodging sales pitches is Michael Nencetti's game. He blocks commercial e-mail, diverts telemarketers to voice mail and even clears ads from Web pages. But Mr. Nencetti, a computer support technician from Charlotte, N.C., didn't shield his cellphone. After all, he reserved it for essential calls from people he already knew. That's why he was concerned when it rang on Easter morning as he hiked up a river bluff. Was his office's network down? Was something wrong with his aging parents?

headline: In Re 9/11: Law Firm Moves On, Still Recovering
summary: At 6 p.m. on Tuesday, phone lines and computer networks at the New York offices of Sidley Austin Brown & Wood went dead. It had happened once before, when the law firm's five floors of offices in the World Trade Center were destroyed. But this time the firm itself, not terrorists, caused the interruption: like a patient whose heart has been stilled for surgery, Sidley's systems were shut down for the move into what it expects to be its permanent home in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Emma Kress, Brody Neville
summary: Emma Carolyn Kress, the daughter of Susan Kress and Jack Kress of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., and Old Town Alexandria, Va., was married Friday to Lawrence Brody Neville, a son of Darlene and Lawrence J. Neville, also of Saratoga Springs. Kenneth Klotz, the mayor of Saratoga Springs, officiated at the Hall of Springs in Saratoga Springs Spa State Park. Ms. Kress, 27, is keeping her name. She is the learning specialist at the Berkeley Carroll School, a private school in Brooklyn. She graduated from Vassar College and received a master's degree in learning disabilities from Teachers College at Columbia. Her father is the executive director of the advisory committee on organ transplantation in Rockville, Md., for the Department of Health and Human Services in Washington. Her mother is an English professor at Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs.

headline: Nuisance Caller Persists, and Subway Train Is the Suspect
summary: Lately, when Carmela Zazzali's phone rings, she glares at it with suspicion. It might be a friend calling to say hello. But it might be the train. A year ago, Mrs. Zazzali said, New York City Transit did some work at the 25th Avenue subway stop of the elevated W line, a few houses away from Mrs. Zazzali's home on Bay 41st Street. Afterward, she noticed her phone would often ring twice whenever a train pulled into or out of the station. When she picked it up, there was no one there.

headline: Celeste Joseph, William Jennings
summary: Celeste Dianne Joseph, the daughter of Coralie Dowdye Joseph of Larchmont, N.Y., and Warneford Joseph of the Bronx, was married on Thursday in Mamaroneck, N.Y., to William Irving Jennings, a son of Dr. Ann S. Jennings-Purnell and a stepson of the late George Purnell. The Rev. Pauline Wardell-Sankoh performed the ceremony at the Mamaroneck United Methodist Church. Mrs. Jennings, 30, is an associate producer for Sunrise Media, a production company for television documentaries, in Manhattan. She graduated from the State University College at Oswego, N.Y., and received a law degree and a master's degree in communications from Syracuse University. Her father is a technician in Manhattan for Verizon. Her mother is a guidance counselor at Intermediate School 125 in the Bronx.

headline: Disaster Planner Has Lessons From 9/11 to Offer, and Boston Listens
summary: As Ralph A. Blasi remembers it, the man who was trying to enter the World Financial Center on Sept. 11 as buildings burned nearby claimed to be a Verizon employee. The man would not take no for an answer, says Mr. Blasi, the director of security for Brookfield Financial Properties, manager of the World Financial Center. ''Punch this guy in the face, as hard as you can,'' Mr. Blasi says he remembers telling one of his security guards, delivering an order that was effective in changing the man's mind before the punch itself needed to be delivered.

headline: Verizon May Not Make Global Crossing Bid
summary: Verizon Communications, the nation's largest local phone company, has decided not to submit a bid for Global Crossing, limiting the company's chances of being acquired out of bankruptcy to a bid from two buyout firms, people involved in the bidding process said yesterday. Gores Technology Group and Platinum Equity both of Los Angeles, are expected to submit a joint bid today, these people said. Offers, which are due today, are part of a process expected to conclude with Global Crossing's sale by July 30.

headline: Abigail Dixon, Justin Zandri
summary: Abigail Sarah Dixon, a daughter of Phyllis and Bartholomew Dixon of Southampton, N.Y., is to be married there today to Justin Eugene Zandri, the son of Brenda and Eugene Zandri of Orange, Conn. An uncle of the bride, Gregory Dixon, a Roman Catholic deacon, is to officiate at the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Edward J. Kiernan, a Roman Catholic priest, will take part in the ceremony. The bride, 28, was until June the manager for private client marketing at Bernstein Investment Research and Management, a unit of Alliance Capital Management in New York. She graduated from the College of William and Mary. Her father, who is retired, was the director of corporate accounting for Verizon Communications in New York. Her mother, also retired, taught English at Linwood Middle School in North Brunswick, N.J.

headline: Nicole Kaplan, David Hurren
summary: Nicole Justine Kaplan, the daughter of Susan Kardos Kaplan and Richard Kaplan of Bridgehampton, N.Y., was married yesterday in Bellport, N.Y., to Lt. David Patrick Hurren, the son of Judith Crawford of Reisterstown, Md., and Albert Hurren of Medford, Mass. Judge Louis J. Ohlig of the Suffolk County Court in Riverhead, N.Y., officiated at the Bellport County Club. Mrs. Hurren, 26, graduated from the University of Delaware and is a candidate for a master's degree in sports management at Old Dominion University. Her parents are assistant principals in Manhattan, her father at Bayard Rustin High School for the Humanities and her mother at Fiorello H. La Guardia High School of Music and Art and Performing Arts.

headline: Proposed Successor at Deutsche Telekom Chills Market
summary: The German government's trouble-prone campaign to oust Ron Sommer as the chief executive of Deutsche Telekom hit a new snag today as investors reacted harshly to his proposed replacement. Shares of Deutsche Telekom fell more than 15 percent after reports here that a longtime company executive, Gerd Tenzer, would be presented to Deutsche Telekom's supervisory board at a special meeting on Tuesday.

headline: Talks Weigh Big Project On Wireless Internet Link
summary: Several leading computer and telecommunications companies are discussing the joint creation of a wireless data network that would make it possible for users of hand-held and portable computers to have access to the Internet at high speeds nationwide. The Intel Corporation, I.B.M., AT&T Wireless and several other wireless and Internet service providers including Verizon Communications and Cingular are exploring the creation of a company to deploy a network based on the increasingly popular 802.11 wireless data standard, known as WiFi, according to several people close to the talks.

headline: Another Delay on Cellphone Numbers
summary: Cellphone users wishing they could keep their phone number when they switch carriers will have to wait another year for that option to become reality. The Federal Communications Commission yesterday extended the deadline for wireless companies to carry out the technology for so-called number portability, to Nov. 24, 2003. The decision was in response to a petition filed by Verizon Wireless last July to drop the number-portability requirement altogether.

headline: With Upgrade To Software, MSN May Nip At AOL's Heels
summary: Microsoft, which has yet to find a formula to compete profitably with America Online in the Internet market, is preparing to roll out this fall a new version of its Internet access software that is meant to exploit the perceived weakness of its rival's parent, AOL Time Warner. The new version of the MSN Explorer software, which connects MSN users to the Internet and enhances some of the features of its Web sites, is intended to match AOL's most popular offerings, like parental controls, and provide a bundle of other Microsoft products, like photo editing service.

headline: Jumping Ship (or Not); In a Rare Limited Offer, AT&T Waives Its Cancellation Fee
summary: TUCKED into every AT&T Wireless subscriber's latest bill was a notice announcing two rate increases. In the fine print was an unusual exit clause: because of the changes, customers have until the end of July to drop their phone plans without paying the customary cancellation fee. ''When you make changes in service, it's only right to offer the opportunity to cancel,'' said David P. Caouette, a spokesman for AT&T Wireless, the nation's third-largest wireless phone carrier. He added that the rate increases, which affect only some customers, would bring the company in line with competitors who bill similar charges. ''On balance, we're confident that our service remains competitive and a good value for customers,'' he said.

headline: A Wireless 911 System Finds Those in Need
summary: AS an elderly couple drove through southwestern Illinois last fall, their car suddenly caught fire. They had no idea where they were, even what county they were in, said the local director of 911 services, Norm Forshee. Luckily, though, they were in St. Clair County, the first county in the nation to install an advanced cellphone-locator system for its emergency service. When the couple called 911, dispatchers pinpointed where they were, and help arrived a few minutes later. This is one of the success stories to emerge since last October, when St. Clair County and Verizon Wireless introduced the first enhanced 911 system for wireless phones. Now any 911 call made in the county by a Verizon customer or someone roaming on Verizon's network can be located to within about 300 feet, and often even closer.

headline: Cellphone Upgrades: Digging for a Good Deal
summary: IF you drop your home phone and damage it beyond repair, you can go to any electronics retailer, choose a phone made by any manufacturer, take it home, plug it in and make the phone call you intended to place before slippery fingers spoiled your day. But if a similar accident befalls your cellular telephone, or you are in the market for an upgrade for some other reason, replacing it is a whole lot more complicated.

headline: Ideas & Trends: Look Out; Citizen Snoops Wanted (Call Toll-Free)
summary: ELI RIOS JR.is just the kind of guy Uncle Sam wanted on the front lines of Operation TIPS, the Justice Department's ill-fated plan to encourage meter readers, truck drivers, cable guys and other workers whose jobs routinely take them through the nation's neighborhoods to report signs of terrorism to a national hotline. A tough-talking, sharp-eyed mail carrier who has worked the streets of Brooklyn for 32 years, Mr. Rios said he sees more than his share of suspicious activity in the course of his job.

headline: LOCAL PHONE SERVICE
summary: The state Board of Public Utilities last week ordered Verizon Communications to cut the rates it charges competitors to lease parts of its local phone network, an order that clears the way for other companies to begin local service in the state. The ruling prompted AT&T, the nation's largest provider of long-distance service, to announce it will begin to offer local phone service to state residents. AT&T hopes to announce a start date for the service by the end of this summer. John Holl

headline: Bankruptcy's Taut Wiring
summary: The crisis in the telecommunications industry just became worse. Even though WorldCom's bankruptcy filing had been expected for weeks, its reality has created a cascade of problems in the interdependent industry of local and long-distance phone carriers, as well as their equipment suppliers. The two-year slump in telecommunications has been a major factor behind the limping economy and the falling stock market, with telecommunications stocks having lost about $2 trillion of value in the last two years. So, continued turmoil for the industry could have broader negative repercussions.

headline: Compressed Data; How One Telecom Thrives Amid Slowdown
summary: One could ask how the Harris Corporation, a 107-year-old company that once made industrial printing equipment, beat out WorldCom to win a prime Federal Aviation Administration communications equipment contract. But it might be more to the point to ask how a company is turning a profit these days in a business as beleaguered as telecommunications. While nearly every other telecommunications company is struggling to keep its head up, Harris' stock is trading up at $34.75, from a low of $26.50 a year ago.

headline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Redistricting Panel Meets
summary: The city's redistricting commission met for the first time yesterday. The panel will begin reviewing demographic changes recorded in the 2000 census to redraw the boundaries of the Council's 51 districts by the fall. The commission, which must reflect a certain political and geographic balance, elected Henry M. Calderon, a Republican mayoral appointee, as chairman. The commission adopted its rules of procedure and elected William S. Floyd, a director at Verizon and a Democrat, as executive director. He said he would take a leave from his post to serve on the panel. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

headline: Telecom Crisis? Take 2 Aspirin and No One Will Call You in the Morning
summary: Congress and the Bush administration have rushed to get tough on dishonest executives, but policy makers appear to be frozen in place when it comes to stabilizing telecommunications, the industry that has given rise to some of the worst examples of corporate misconduct. There has been no consensus among officials in Congress, the White House and the Federal Communications Commission about the causes of the telecommunication industry's problems, despite the collapses of WorldCom and Enron -- companies that played on the premise of infinite growth of Internet commerce and have yielded the two biggest American bankruptcies ever -- and the evaporation of billions of dollars in Adelphia Communications, Global Crossing, Qwest Communications and other companies.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Congress Reaches a Deal To Rewrite Bankruptcy Law Congressional negotiators have reached agreement on a bill that would rewrite the bankruptcy law, making it harder for people to escape their debts. The agreement, a victory for the nation's credit card companies and other lenders, came after members of a conference committee reached a compromise on the wording of an abortion-rights provision. The bill, which has passed both houses of Congress, now appears destined for final approval in the House and Senate, and the White House has suggested that President Bush will sign it. [Page A1.]

headline: Day Is Frenetic As Investors Start Looking For Bargains
summary: In another day of stock market sound and fury, the Nasdaq composite index took a pounding, but the broader market averages closed with only modest losses. Portfolio managers, encouraged by the action, said investors seemed to shift out of a sell-everything mode and were beginning once again to differentiate between stocks that are cheap and those that are not.

headline: Strong Demand For Store Space In Manhattan
summary: NEW YORKERS and visitors to the city have kept shopping despite an weakened economy and the events of Sept. 11, and as a result demand for retail space in most locations has been strong even as the office market has sagged, according to real estate executives. The surge in demand in the retailing market has been led by bank branches that stress convenience to customers who need to conduct transactions outside traditional banker's hours, drugstore chains that seem to want to be on every other street corner and a proliferation of wireless stores that sell cellular telephones and the bewildering variety of calling plans attached to them.

headline: Once Upon A Time, A Restless C.E.O. . . .
summary: WELCOME to story time in corporate America. The old story went like this: chief executives were in such demand that they were apt to jump ship at any moment.

headline: Can AOL Keep Its Subscribers In a New World Of Broadband?
summary: Is America Online's subscriber base about to peak? For its owner, AOL Time Warner, most of the concern last week that drove its stock below $9 a share for a day revolved around the precipitous decline in the company's online advertising, and a government inquiry into the accounting for some of those ads.

headline: Microsoft Seen In Wireless Deal
summary: Microsoft plans to announce a partnership today with AT&T Wireless Services to offer wireless software and services, a person close to the talks said last night. The deal would be part of Microsoft's drive to sign up wireless carriers to use its so-called smart phone software -- a pared-down version of the Windows operating system -- and services that Microsoft is developing as part of its .Net Internet strategy.

headline: REGIONAL MARKET: The Bronx; Fordham Revival Where Alexander's Once Ruled
summary: A large Caldor sign still sits atop the five-story building at 2 Fordham Square on the northwest corner of Fordham Road and the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, even though Caldor vacated the 300,000-square-foot building in 1997, two years after it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Before Caldor moved into the building, in 1993, 2 Fordham Square was occupied by Alexander's department store, which declared bankruptcy in 1992. A white elephant for the better part of a decade, the building was bought by Fordham Associates in January 2001 for $25 million in cash from Vornado, the national real estate investment trust. Since then, nine tenants have signed leases of 10 to 20 years, including four that are already open on street level. The three on the Fordham Road side of the building are North Fork Bank (with 3,500 square feet), Verizon Wireless (1,800 square feet) and The Children's Place (5,500 square feet). Seagull Fashions (2,800 square feet), a women's apparel shop on the Creston Avenue side of the building, is also open.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: CenturyTel Completes Sale Of Wireless Unit
summary: CenturyTel Inc., which sells telephone service in 22 states, yesterday completed the sale of its mobile-phone business to its rival, the Alltel Corporation, for $1.65 billion. The sale lets CenturyTel focus on selling local and Internet services, the company said in a statement. Alltel will bill customers under the CenturyTel name until it completes a billing system conversion later this year. CenturyTel agreed in March to sell the business to Alltel after spurning its $9.2 billion offer for all of CenturyTel. Alltel yesterday also completed the purchase of 600,000 local phone lines in Kentucky from Verizon Communications, the largest American local-phone company, for $1.9 billion. The acquisition increases the Alltel's local-phone lines to more than three million, the company said. Shares of CenturyTel fell 30 cents, to $26.30. They had fallen 19 percent this year. Alltel dropped 32 cents, to $40.20.

headline: Verizon to Group Products
summary: Verizon, the nation's No. 2 local phone company, is expected to announce a set of new products today that will tie together voice, data and wireless services. In some ways, the announcement may harken to the heyday of the telecommunications boom in the 1990's, when many companies and investors tried to stitch together seamless ''bundles'' of communications services. Many of those companies have failed, but the regional Bell companies have survived as dominant local carriers as well as major wireless providers.

headline: Funds Sought To Monitor The Health Of Rescuers
summary: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and a number of medical experts yesterday urged President Bush to quickly approve $90 million in financing for a program that would monitor the long-term health of thousands of rescue workers who assisted in the World Trade Center recovery effort. The program is part of a $5 billion emergency spending package to fight terrorism that Congress approved by overwhelming margins last month.

headline: Pulling Communications Into the 21st Century
summary: LONG ISLAND may be making progress in attracting high-tech companies, but the failure to modernize telecommunications at the region's largest business park bodes ill for the region's future and tarnishes its image, the park's tenants and building owners say. Now, a group of executives and owners at the complex, Hauppauge Industrial Park, have abandoned efforts to convince Lightpath and Verizon to revamp the rat's nest of aging cables lying underneath the buildings and instead are looking to wireless technology as a solution. Several people involved with those efforts say they are close to announcing a pilot project that will solve what is called the ''last mile'' problem, bridging the gap between the national broadband cable network and the buildings in the park.

headline: Bush's Forum on Economy: More Than the Usual Crowd
summary: The White House moved today to counter criticism that President Bush's economic forum here on Tuesday was a public relations vehicle by releasing a list of participants that included a sprinkling of prominent Democrats and some influential corporate leaders not usually associated with politics. While the list was heavily weighted toward the Bush-friendly South and West, it also included Franklin D. Raines, the chief executive of Fannie Mae and the budget director under former President Bill Clinton; Carleton S. Fiorina, the chairwoman and chief executive of the Hewlett-Packard Company; Kenneth I. Chenault, the chairman and chief executive of the American Express Company; and Jeffrey L. Bleustein, the chairman and chief executive of Harley-Davidson Inc.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Genuity Gets Extension To Renegotiate Credit Line
summary: Genuity, a seller of high-speed Internet access that defaulted last month on $3 billion in loans, says lenders have given it 30 more days to renegotiate the credit line. As part of the ''standstill'' agreement, the second since July 29, Genuity will pay $50 million, according to a statement. The company also said it would no longer finance Integra, a manager of data for corporate Web sites that is 93 percent owned by Genuity. Last month, Verizon Communications chose not to buy a controlling stake in Genuity, causing a default under the company's credit agreement. The new accord gives Genuity time to renegotiate repayment of the loans. Genuity, based in Woburn, Mass., has drawn down $1.87 billion of a $2 billion credit line from banks, as well as a $1.15 billion loan from Verizon, a spokeswoman, Susan Kraus, said. Verizon had made $2 billion available, but it said last month that it would not extend the remaining $850 million, Ms. Kraus said. On July 29, Genuity said it had been given two weeks to renegotiate its credit line. Under that agreement, Genuity paid $100 million.

headline: Executive Thaw May Be Under Way at Viacom
summary: The relationship between Sumner M. Redstone, the chief executive of Viacom, and Mel Karmazin, its chief operating officer, appears to have thawed in recent weeks, according to several executives close to both men. Investors have closely monitored how Mr. Redstone, who controls Viacom, gets along with Mr. Karmazin, whose contract is up next year. While Mr. Redstone, who is 79, is credited with building a formidable collection of assets -- from radio and TV stations to MTV and Paramount Pictures -- Mr. Karmazin is widely viewed as a disciplined and strong manager of those businesses. He joined Viacom when it merged with CBS two years ago.

headline: Corrections
summary: An article last Sunday about the absence of cellular phone service in the New York City subways misstated the name of the cellular company that advertises ''Can you hear me now?'' It is Verizon Wireless, not Horizon.

headline: Anise Strong, Adam Morse
summary: Anise Keyssar Strong, the daughter of Prof. Tracy B. Strong of La Jolla, Calif., and the late Prof. Helene Keyssar, was married yesterday to Adam Holden Morse, a son of Pam McLevy Morse and Robert W. Morse of Madison, N.J. The Rev. Reynolds C. Jones, a Pentecostal minister, officiated at the White House Inn in Wilmington, Vt. The bride, 24, and the bridegroom, 26, graduated from Yale, she cum laude.

headline: Corrections
summary: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the relationship between Sumner M. Redstone, the chief executive of Viacom, and Mel Karmazin, the chief operating officer, misstated the title of Ivan Seidenberg, a Viacom board member. He is chief executive of Verizon Communications, not co-chief.

headline: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Basking Ridge: AT&T Offers Local Service
summary: AT&T began offering local telephone service yesterday to New Jersey consumers currently served by Verizon. AT&T was already providing local service to about 1.5 million residential customers in seven states. It decided to seek New Jersey customers in July after the Board of Public Utilities forced Verizon to lower rates it charges competitors who lease its lines. Jayson Blair (NYT)

headline: How to Make Yourself Reachable in 5 Places at Once
summary: IN the quest to be always within reach, many people have resorted to carrying a cellphone at all times. But a cellphone isn't a perfect solution: for one thing, unless people know to call you on it, they may miss you by calling a land-line number instead. Even eliminating the land line at home won't necessarily help; callers may still miss you by dialing only your office phone. But there are other ways to ensure that you are never out of touch no matter what phones you use. A variety of services are available that make it easy for callers to find you. These services can be particularly useful for families in which one member travels a lot, the children are away at school or elderly relatives need to stay in touch.

headline: Some Signs of Gains In Spending on Ads
summary: There were some encouraging signs for Madison Avenue yesterday as a forecaster predicted advertising spending this year would increase at a rate on the higher side of recent estimates and a company that tracks ad spending reported better-than-expected results. David Wyss, chief economist for Standard & Poor's, a division of the McGraw-Hill Companies, predicted that ad spending this year would increase 2.7 percent from 2001, led by gains in revenue by media like television networks and newspapers. The figure of 2.7 percent -- revised upward from a 1.3 percent increase he forecast in the spring -- is above estimates made recently by other forecasters, who predicted ad spending in 2002 would rise 1 percent to 2.5 percent.

headline: ON THE GROUND: Newark; A Gateway to New York Is Enjoying a Renaissance
summary: Newark -- a 15-minute train ride from Manhattan -- is a leading gateway to New York. But this third-oldest major American city has been enjoying a renaissance, and there are several reasons to stay in town. Newark is aggressively fighting to eradicate its reputation for crime; in fact, crime has decreased more than 50 percent in the last six years. In recent years there has also been an influx of businesses, including the IDT Corporation, MBNA and the SBLI USA Mutual Life Insurance Company, which join stalwarts like Verizon, PSE&G, Merrill Lynch and Horizon Blue Cross and Blue Shield. The city has begun an effort to revitalize its waterfront, with the Faneuil Hall area of Boston and South Street Seaport in Manhattan as models. The F.B.I. will become the first organization to establish a presence there when construction is completed on its new office building.

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Connecticut; New England Icons Are Serving a Hidden Purpose
summary: Hidden in plain sight in suburban towns throughout Connecticut, cellular phone antennas have been engineered into the good graces of once-hostile communities. Eager to avoid lengthy battles over the installation of unattractive towers, telecommunications companies prefer to hide antennas within or on existing structures, using what are known in the industry as ''stealthing'' techniques. The soaring steeple that serves as a historic landmark for so many Connecticut towns has become one of the more common disguises for cellphone antennas. Telecommunications companies pay $1,000 or more a month to lease the steeples, creating welcome revenue for congregations.

headline: Morris Heights Journal; Youths Find Hope in Jobs Academy
summary: The unemployment rate in the Bronx was 9.2 percent in June, the highest of any borough in New York. If a softball team were to take the field in Melrose, Clason Point or Bedford Park, the odds would be that someone in the lineup did not have a job. While this number may be striking, it does not give a complete picture. Government statistics tell part of the story, but they do not tell it all.

headline: When the Cellphone Is the Home Phone
summary: WHEN my wife and I moved recently from the Upper West Side of Manhattan to a larger apartment in Harlem, it was a short hop on the map. Technologically, however, it was a journey to the heart of the current turmoil in the telecommunications industry. Of all the troubles associated with a move, we expected phone service to be the least of them: a routine order for a telephone line and two jacks. But when I called Verizon Communications, our local phone company, I was told that it would take a week and a half to fulfill the request, at a cost of $250.

headline: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Union Seeks New Rate Hearings
summary: Verizon's union has charged that the company used flawed data to help persuade state regulators to grant it a rate increase. The union, the Communications Workers of America, yesterday filed a petition with the regulators, the New York Public Service Commission, requesting that the commission reopen hearings on a performance plan that was adopted in February. The commission approved a $1.85-a-month rate increase for Verizon based in part on the performance plan. The union argues that proposed workforce reductions at Verizon will worsen performance. But John J. Bonomo, a Verizon spokesman, said the most recent report by the state said Verizon was ''on track'' to meet or exceed its quality requirements. Jayson Blair (NYT)

headline: Executive Life; Squeezing Yourself Out (for the Company)
summary: HALFWAY into it, Hugh C. Martin realized that the merger he had initiated to protect his fiber optic company would cost him his job. Mr. Martin had joined the company, ONI Systems of San Jose, Calif., as chief executive in 1998, shortly after it was started. By 2000, ONI, a maker of equipment for routing phone calls and computer data, had become one of the fastest-growing companies in Silicon Valley.

headline: Raising the Roof
summary: THE houses of this village have been levitating, rising one by one above their earthen foundations in an act of collective local will. But it was no parlor trick when homeowners here recently joined hands -- not literally -- to uproot and begin lifting their creaking Colonial, Federal and Victorian structures into the air.

headline: Barbara Simeone, Kenneth Maiese
summary: Barbara A. Simeone, the daughter of Nancy and Gerard Simeone of Belleville, N.J., is to be married today to Dr. Kenneth Maiese, the son of Margaret Maiese of Mount Laurel, N.J., and the late Charles Maiese. The Rev. William F. Gavin, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony at Old St. Joseph's Church in Philadelphia. The bride is a vice president and the director of planning and administration at Verizon Capital Corporation, an investment subsidiary of Verizon Communications in New York. She graduated from Seton Hall University and received an M.B.A. degree from Fairleigh Dickinson University. Her father retired as an electronic technician for AlliedSignal, a maker and supplier of automotive components, in Teterboro, N.J. Her mother retired as an employment counselor at Snelling & Snelling, a personnel services company in Bloomfield, N.J.

headline: Eva Ogielska, Paul Zei
summary: Dr. Eva Marya Ogielska and Dr. Paul Cameron Zei were married yesterday at the Compass Rose Gardens in Bodega Bay, Calif. The Rev. Nancy Hargis, a nondenominational minister, performed the ceremony. The couple, both 32, met at Stanford University, where the bride earned a Ph.D. in neuroscience and the bridegroom a medical degree and a Ph.D. in molecular and cellular physiology.

headline: A Guardian of Jobs or a 'Reverse Robin Hood'?
summary: IT is hard to imagine why Thaksin Shinawatra, a billionaire who is Thailand's prime minister, would need a helping hand from the United States government for his family business, an Asian telecommunications giant called the Shin Corporation. The Shin business empire, which Mr. Shinawatra founded and is still majority owned by his family, spreads from India to Indochina. It is Thailand's largest telecommunications company. But last May, to the consternation of competitors, Shin Satellite, a subsidiary, won a $160 million loan guarantee from the Export-Import Bank of the United States to buy a new telecommunications satellite and strengthen its grip in Southeast Asia.

headline: Verizon Completes $1 Billion Line Sale
summary: Verizon Communications, the biggest United States local-telephone company, has completed the $1.1 billion sale of phone lines in Missouri to CenturyTel and said it would use the money to pay down debt. Verizon, which sold the 371,000 lines on Saturday, announced the agreement in October 2001. The company, which is based in New York, also said in a statement yesterday that it received $1 billion on July 1 for 305,000 lines in Alabama, and $1.9 billion July 31 for 596,000 lines in Kentucky.

headline: 2 Companies Reduce Roles In Lobby Group For Generics
summary: Two corporate members of a powerful coalition that is lobbying for legislation to bring generic drugs to market more quickly have left the group or reduced their roles after companies that make brand-name medicines threatened to end contracts with the companies, a spokesman for the lobbying group said yesterday. The spokesman, Brad Cameron of Business for Affordable Medicine, a coalition of the governors of 12 states and about a dozen large corporations, said that Georgia-Pacific, the paper company, had asked yesterday that it no longer be listed as a member on the coalition's Web site after receiving pressure from Eli Lilly.

headline: Wider WorldCom Case Is Called Likely
summary: Federal prosecutors said yesterday that their investigation of accounting practices at WorldCom might result in new charges and indictments against executives involved in the company's effort to hide billions of dollars of expenses. Two executives who were charged in the case last month were arraigned yesterday and pleaded not guilty.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: AOL To Use Covad High-Speed Network
summary: Covad Communications said yesterday that AOL Time Warner would use Covad's network to provide high-speed Web connections to America Online customers. The five-year agreement gives AOL Time Warner, based in New York, access to a network covering 40 million homes and businesses in the United States, Covad said in a statement. Shares of Covad, which emerged from bankruptcy in December, rose as much as 29 percent, before ending the day at $1.32, up 18 cents, or 15.8 percent. As the number of new consumers using dial-up Internet access slows, AOL Time Warner is trying to add customers through agreements with companies like Verizon Communications and SBC Communications, which have regional high-speed networks. Covad sells high-speed links to the Internet through digital subscriber lines. AOL Time Warner will pay Covad an undisclosed amount a month for each subscriber. A Covad spokeswoman, Martha Sessums, declined to give the amount. An AOL Time Warner spokesman, Ed Adler, did not return phone calls seeking comment.

headline: Live Horns, English Punk and Jobim's Old Piano
summary: September ELVIN JONES -- This great drummer who played with John Coltrane's quartet in the 1960's makes rhythms roll and simmer, creating a lurking collective of beats wherever most drummers would place one. He turns 75 tomorrow, and for the rest of the week he'll be playing with his regular Jazz Machine group, but heavy-duty guests are just about assured every night. Tuesday-Sunday. Blue Note. DAVE HOLLAND BIG BAND -- This bassist is using his quintet -- one of the very best working bands in jazz -- as more or less the core of a big-band; the music has been brewing quietly for a decade and more intensely for the last two years. ''Goes Around,'' Mr. Holland's first album with this group, is imaginative, swinging, to-the-point. Tuesday. ECM. (The band performs Oct. 9-12 at Birdland, 315 W. 44th St. (212-581-3080) www.birdlandjazz.com

headline: Deposit Another 50 Cents, Please. Many Subway Phones Don't Work.
summary: Nearly one in three pay phones in the city's subway stations do not work, according to a recent report by the Straphangers Campaign, a transit advocacy group. That is a striking deterioration in service from last year, when the group found that only one in five telephones did not work. ''We are living in an era when people want to have the best communication possible, particularly during times of emergency,'' said Neysa Pranger, who oversaw the study.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon To Cut Debt
summary: Verizon Communications plans to reduce debt by 10 percent this year, Ivan Seidenberg, the chief executive, said yesterday. Net debt, or borrowing minus cash and equivalents, fell to $58.6 billion in June from $63.3 billion at the end of last year. A 10 percent reduction would cut that figure to $57 billion in December. Verizon had its first sales drop in two years last quarter as businesses and consumers canceled phone lines. Mr. Seidenberg reiterated a forecast that sales would be little changed or fall 1 percent this year.

headline: With ad revenue down, Yahoo tries to win agencies' favor.
summary: ONE hot Friday last month, 40 people from three advertising agencies in Manhattan boarded a chartered bus for a hilly estate in the Westchester town of Purdy's. Their destination: Camp Yahoo, where the wine flowed liberally, the lobsters were boiled by the dozens and the pool offered a chance to lounge on giant purple-and-yellow beach towels being given away. Though such shindigs for advertisers and agencies have long been a staple of more traditional media like magazines and television networks, they are new to Yahoo. During the Internet boom, when the ad dollars seemed never-ending, Yahoo did not do much coddling of its clients. But when advertising hit the wall early last year for Yahoo, one of the three big Internet portals, the company decided it was time to be friendly, really friendly.

headline: For a Change, Commentators Let Coverage Unfold Without Too Much Talk
summary: Nothing any television commentator said could have been as moving as the words of Marianne Keene, a teenager whose stepfather was lost in the World Trade Center, at the memorial service at ground zero. She ended her brief tribute: ''I miss you, and I hope you didn't hurt too much. Love, Marianne.'' For once, the commentators simply let us listen to her and to the procession of people reading the names of the dead.

headline: Lucent Plans To Eliminate More Positions
summary: Lucent Technologies, the nation's largest maker of communications equipment, warned yesterday that it would continue to eliminate jobs as sales plunge, an indication of worsening problems in the telecommunications industry. A Lucent spokeswoman declined to provide figures for the cuts and said the company would elaborate on its plans on Oct. 23, when it discusses quarterly financial results. Analysts expect the company, which is based in Murray Hill, N.J., to cut about 5,000 to 10,000 more jobs, leaving the work force at 33,000 to 38,000 employees, down from a peak of more than 123,000 two years ago.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A2-9 Bush Says He Doubts Iraq Will Meet Demands President Bush said that it was ''highly doubtful'' that Saddam Hussein would meet demands to disarm, while American officials said they would seek to write into any new United Nations resolution an authorization for the United States to enforce disarmament if Iraq did not comply. A1 The United States made rapid headway today toward persuading the Security Council to confront Iraq, as Russia hardened its position against Baghdad and the European Union supported a new resolution to force the return of weapons inspectors. A6

headline: Lost to 9/11, 377 Names from Across the Island
summary: For months the rumors swirled around Garden City: 65 residents, 100 residents of the village had been killed in the World Trade Center attacks. Similar stories made the rounds in other Long Island locales. Not until Sept. XX, when the New York City medical examiner's office released the first official list of the dead in the disaster, did it become possible to lay the rumors definitively to rest. By comparing the medical examiner's list, which included only names, with databases compiled by The Times, The Associated Press and other sources, it was possible to sort victims according to their place of residence. The lists for Nassau and Suffolk counties appear here.

headline: New Approach for AOL Broadband Unit
summary: When Richard D. Parsons, the chief executive of AOL Time Warner, talks about the company's prospects for its high-speed Internet service, he suggests simply that the company has to treat America Online like its pay cable network, HBO. It is meant to reassure investors, who have seen AOL Time Warner transform HBO from a package of second-run movies to some of the hottest original programming on television. He implies that any company that could come up with ''Sex and the City'' and ''The Sopranos'' will be able to invent something equally compelling to persuade people to buy America Online's high-speed broadband service.

headline: Ruling Favors Phone Providers In White Plains Fee Dispute
summary: The city of White Plains cannot take a portion of the revenues from the telephone companies that want to provide local service to residents and businesses in the city, a federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled last week. The ruling came in a case that was brought by a subsidiary of AT&T, which wanted to provide service in White Plains. The city imposed a fee of 5 percent of future revenues on phone companies offering local service. But Verizon is exempt because a past deal gave the city access to underground conduits for cables in exchange for monopoly status for Verizon.

headline: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
summary: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert. RAY BARRETTO'S NEW WORLD SPIRITS, Iridium, 1650 Broadway, at 51st Street, (212) 582-2121. Mr. Barretto, the conguero, showed up on a lot of jazz albums from the 1960's, was a hero of the salsa generation in the 1970's and has more recently taken up a Latin jazz band full time. Tonight through Sunday night at 8 and 10, with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow; cover charge is $25 (Ben Ratliff).

headline: A Relaxed Tony Bennett Is a Master of Surprise
summary: Tony Bennett is not a vocalist given to pumping personal psychodrama into a song. A supremely confident swinger, he would rather play the genially reverent custodian of the American popular songbook, concentrating on the pleasure to be found in his material. He is so comfortable on the stage that he makes relaxation and rhythmic command appear synonymous. Yet because he relishes abrupt dynamic shifts and stylistic juxtapositions, his singing is full of surprises. A song that begins as a half-whisper can build to a fierce final shout, and jazz riffing can transform into flowery semioperatic flourishes. When Mr. Bennett chooses to zero in on the raw emotion of a ballad, however, the payoff is usually electrifying. During the Duke Ellington segment of his Carnegie Hall concert on Wednesday evening in the Verizon Music Festival, Mr. Bennett introduced ''Mood Indigo'' as his favorite Ellington song and bit into it with a keening vengeance. Pitching it near the top of his upper register, he turned it into a sustained cry of anguish that culminated in a rending melismatic descent on the final word: ''die.''

headline: Qwest Overstated Up to $1.48 Billion in Revenue
summary: Qwest Communications International, which faces criminal and regulatory investigations of its accounting, said last night that its accounting for trades and sales of capacity on its fiber optic network overstated revenue in 2000 and 2001 as much as $1.48 billion. Qwest said that the restatement of its previously filed reports might force it to reduce reported revenue for last year by $1.02 billion, or 5.2 percent of the total. The adjustment for 2000 could cut reported revenue by $464 million, or 2.8 percent.

headline: A Modern Musician Plays the Host While Playing the Piano
summary: The young pianist Vijay Iyer isn't known for making superfriendly tonal harmony and swing rhythm; in his own quartet as well as in his cooperative trio, Fieldwork, there is plenty to hang on to in the way of rhythms and compositional structure, but the music isn't especially cozy. Still, during his solo piano set on Thursday night at the Jazz Standard -- part of a five-day series within the Verizon Music Festival, which is presenting a fine array of solo jazz pianists -- he played short pieces, paused to introduce new songs, welcomed the audience a few times and played host. This is what young jazz musicians do these days: it is an effect of having heard all your life the two contradictory, mindless pseudo-truisms that jazz is America's great music of the people and that it can be understood only by a narrow, smug elite. In fact, jazz is a viable art, and much remains to be said in it. But if your presentations are too obfuscatory, nobody is going to listen, and living in New York is too expensive to pretend otherwise.

headline: Market Place; Tyco Took Profit on Bad Deal, Then Paid Bonuses to Executives
summary: Tyco International claimed a profit on an investment even as the company lost money on it, a review of the transaction shows. Tyco then used that profit as an excuse to pay almost $24 million in bonuses to top managers. Most of that went to L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chief executive, and Mark H. Swartz, the former chief financial officer.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
summary: VERIZON COMMUNICATIONS INC., New York, won permission from the Federal Communications Commission to offer long-distance voice and data services in Delaware and New Hampshire. EMC CORP., Hopkinton, Mass., a maker of network data storage systems, agreed to buy the closely held Prisa Networks Inc., San Diego, a software maker, for $20 million in cash.

headline: McCall Denies Impropriety in Helping Daughter Get Company Job
summary: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall today denied any impropriety in helping his daughter get a job at a telecommunications company by writing on his official stationery to an executive and noting that millions of shares of the company's stock were held by the state pension fund that Mr. McCall controls. With the election five weeks way, Mr. McCall, the Democratic challenger to Gov. George E. Pataki, tried to minimize questions about the letter. But it became the issue of the day in the governor's race after it appeared on the front page of today's New York Post.

headline: McCall Defends Letters to Two Companies
summary: With five weeks left until Election Day, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall yesterday dismissed mounting accusations that he used his influence as the steward of New York State's $105 billion pension fund to help relatives in their job searches. ''I pass along résumés of qualified people all the time,'' Mr. McCall said after a speech on educational policies at Columbia University.

headline: Ethics Is Again Focus of Governor's Race
summary: Questions about patronage and influence peddling overshadowed the governor's race today, as the Democratic challenger, H. Carl McCall, and the Republican incumbent, George E. Pataki, sparred over the use of political offices to help friends and relatives. Mr. McCall continued to be dogged by questions about two letters he had written as state comptroller to executives at Verizon and Coca-Cola. The letters noted that the state pension fund, which is overseen by Mr. McCall, has large investments in the companies and then said Mr. McCall was sending along a résumé they had discussed earlier. Verizon later hired Mr. McCall's daughter, Marcella. Coca-Cola decided not to hire a cousin whom Mr. McCall recommended in the second letter.

headline: 2 Outside Ties Cut by Chief Of Citigroup
summary: The chief executive of Citigroup, Sanford I. Weill, said yesterday that he would resign from the boards of AT&T and United Technolgies, whose chief executives sit on the board of Citigroup. The announcement is the latest effort by Mr. Weill to raise business standards at Citigroup, at a time when regulators are investigating possible conflicts of interest at the company's investment bank, Salomon Smith Barney.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Expects To Meet 2002 Forecasts
summary: Verizon Communications, the nation's largest local telephone company, said it expected to meet a forecast to earn $3.05 to $3.09 a share in 2002. The company also expects to have debt of $56 billion to $57 billion at the end of the year, down about $8 billion from the end of 2001, when it was $64.3 billion, according to a statement. Verizon shares rose $2.14, or 7.8 percent, to $29.58.

headline: VERIZON WEIGHS SALE OF FOREIGN ASSETS TO TRIM DEBT
summary: Verizon Communications Inc., which owns stakes in telephone companies in countries including Italy and Venezuela, may sell foreign investments to trim debt. ''We're reviewing all of our international properties,'' Peter Thonis, a spokesman for Verizon, the biggest local-phone company in the United States, said in an interview. Verizon owns 23 percent of Vodafone Omnitel, Italy's second-biggest wireless carrier. The Vodafone Group owns most of the rest. Verizon also owns 29 percent of Compañía Nacional Teléfonos de Venezuela, that country's biggest phone company. Verizon, based in New York, is planning more than 8,000 job cuts by the end of the year and is selling assets to trim $61.6 billion in debt.

headline: Suzanne Boudreau, Brian Doherty
summary: Suzanne Catherine Boudreau, a daughter of Susan and Donald L. Boudreau of Larchmont, N.Y., was married on Friday in Scarsdale, N.Y., to Brian Andrew Doherty, a son of Patricia and John Doherty of Worcester, Mass. The Rev. Walter L. Pitman officiated at the Scarsdale Congregational Church. The Rev. Joseph S. Dietz, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony. Mrs. Doherty, 31, is a special-education teacher at the Churchill School and Center, a private school for the learning disabled in New York. She graduated from the University of Hartford and received a master's degree in special education from Fordham. Her father retired as the vice chairman for consumer business and commercial banking at J. P. Morgan Chase in New York.

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Once a Sure Bet, Utilities Funds Now Pose More Risks
summary: INDIVIDUAL investors have been moving out of utility mutual funds, one of the worst-performing sectors recently. But some fund companies are joining the exodus, too. The Vanguard Group, the second-largest American mutual fund company, behind Fidelity Investments, announced plans last month to replace its utilities fund with one that focuses on dividend-paying companies from a wide range of industries. Shareholders will vote on the change, from the Vanguard Utilities Income fund to the Vanguard Dividend Growth fund, in early December.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: As Baby Bells Struggle, A Debate Over What to Do Investors, lawmakers, regulators and consumers are debating what should be done with, or for, the Baby Bells, the large local phone carriers that are struggling with their first decline in customers since the Depression. The erosion is fueling talk of whether the government should step in. At the heart of the debate is regulation that forces Verizon Communications, SBC Communications, BellSouth and Qwest to sell access on their networks to competitors at prices that can be determined by state regulators. Market Place. [Page C2.]

headline: Environmentalists Identify New Menace: Discarded Cellphones
summary: As the nation's fondness for cellphones grows, the environmental effects do, too. According to industry figures, cellphone use in the United States has surged, to more than 128 million subscribers last year from 340,000 in 1985. Typically, each phone is used for 18 months before being dropped for a newer model.

headline: Supreme Court Seems Skeptical Of F.C.C. Position on Next Wave
summary: The Supreme Court gave a skeptical hearing today to the Federal Communications Commission's contention that it acted within its rights in 1998 when it confiscated more than 200 valuable wireless communications licenses from NextWave Telecom, which had won them at auction but fell behind in its payments and filed for bankruptcy protection. Under federal bankruptcy law, which is aimed at giving troubled companies a chance to reorganize and return to financial health, the government may not revoke a license ''solely because'' the holder has sought protection from its creditors. The federal appeals court here ruled last year that the F.C.C. violated this law by seizing the licenses for which NextWave had promised to pay more than $4 billion. Catching the telecommunications roller coaster at a high point, the commission then reauctioned the licenses to Verizon Wireless and other major companies for $16 billion. But the licenses have never been released because of the legal battle. A victory for NextWave would allow the company to use the licenses to finish building its wireless network or sell them to another company.

headline: No E-Mail In Listings By Verizon
summary: VERIZON has stopped offering residential telephone customers the option of adding an e-mail or Web address to their phone-book listings.

headline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Union Rally Set For Today
summary: Two labor organizations plan a multiunion rally today near Bryant Park to protest what they call unfair corporate policies. The organizations, the New York City Central Labor Council and the A.F.L.-C.I.O., are calling the event ''No More Business as Usual.'' It will focus on the Enron and WorldCom scandals and will protest high salaries paid to corporate executives, large-scale layoffs at scandal-plagued companies, and the damage to workers' retirement plans. The rally is scheduled for 5:30 p.m. outside Verizon's headquarters at 42nd Street and Avenue of the Americas. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

headline: Commercial Property/Lower Manhattan; Seeking More Reliable Telecommunication Backups
summary: MANY businesses in Lower Manhattan were shocked when they lost their telecommunications after the Sept. 11 attack. They thought they had guarded against such interruptions by signing up with several different carriers, so that if one was interrupted, the others would keep them in touch. But many of these alternative carriers had simply leased fiber-optic lines and central office facilities from Verizon, a successor to the Bell company that once had a monopoly on local service. When the 7 World Trade Center building partially collapsed onto Verizon's adjacent central office at 140 West Street, it severely damaged the building and the equipment inside.

headline: F.C.C. Chief Says Telecom Isn't Doomed By Cutbacks
summary: Don't send out an S.O.S. for the telecom equipment industry just yet. Michael K. Powell, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, urged in a speech early this month that telecommunications companies spend more on new equipment to insure the survival of big suppliers like Lucent Technologies, Nortel Networks and Cisco Systems. The carriers' own recovery, he said, depended on the ability of those and smaller equipment makers to remain solvent enough to continue developing new technology.

headline: AT&T Posts a Small Profit After Three Quarters of Losses
summary: AT&T said yesterday that it had a small profit in the third quarter after three consecutive periods of losses, and attributed it to cost-cutting and improved sales of communications services to large businesses. The company, the nation's largest long-distance carrier, reported net income of $207 million, or 5 cents a share, compared with $11.3 billion, or $3.13 a share, a year earlier, when it had a large one-time gain from the spinoff of AT&T Wireless.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; New WorldCom Losses Hint at a Disputed Future
summary: Despite its troubles, WorldCom is still an immense company, generating about $80 million in revenue daily, according to data WorldCom released yesterday. It is also a deeply unprofitable company. So how WorldCom may behave if it emerges from bankruptcy protection next year has become a hotly debated question in the telecommunications industry in recent weeks. It is a debate with important ramifications for consumers, business customers, WorldCom's myriad creditors and its competitors.

headline: A Live Ballgame Unfolds On a Cellphone Screen
summary: Awaiting applications for the so-called 3G (for third-generation) wireless protocol is a bit like wondering when electric cars will take over the nationrsquos highways. That technology, which will harness enough bandwidth to allow the transmission of streaming video and audio at rates of 2 megabits per second and higher, has yet to reach the mainstream consumer. But a team of companies is delivering graphics-rich content on wireless devices without the 3G bandwidth: Verizon and FoxSports.com have joined with ActiveSky to present live sports events and sports news to Internet-enabled cellphones for a monthly fee. ActiveSky, based in San Mateo, Calif., has created multiscene presentations that integrate visual action, sound, text and low-tech graphics in a facsimile of a live sports broadcast, as well as schedules, scores and standings. The service, available to Verizon Get It Now customers for $3.99 a month, provides baseball-game broadcasts in which tiny icons move around a color diamond while a box score and running text provide real-time updates on the game. For football games, a time clock and a tiny gridiron track the action.

headline: The Floor Shook, But They Didn't
summary: When times are tough, do the tough really get going? The answer is: Sometimes. As the mail indicates, maybe the best strategy for maintaining business in a weak economy is simply to sit tight. But when the outlook is bleak, well-planned action may also pay off in a big way. Catherine E. Sutter, the president and owner of Pro-Tec Mobile Communications of Casa Grande, Ariz., was facing fierce competition in difficult economic times. Owning and operating wireless radio stations that allow hundreds of business clients throughout Phoenix and Tucson to dispatch their fleets of vehicles, Miss Sutter was up against six major wireless carriers: AT&T Wireless, Sprint PCS, Nextel Communications, Verizon Communications, Alltel and Western Wireless.

headline: Private Sector; Chasing the Americas' Pastime
summary: LIKE many other baseball fans, Carlos Peralta Quintero was in Southern California last weekend to watch the Anaheim Angels in the World Series, and he liked what he saw. But he was as interested in what went on in the stands as in what happened on the field. ''The fans in attendance were extraordinary,'' he said, ''and at first glance, the team is being managed very well.''

headline: Through a Credit Lens, Stocks Aren't Alluring
summary: THE credit health of the 500 companies in the Standard & Poor's index is deteriorating. That may be a signal to investors that a rebound in stocks may take longer than they had hoped. While the three main stock gauges have risen for three consecutive weeks, they are still below the levels reached in the summer rally that ended with the Dow Jones industrials closing over 9,000 on Aug. 22. The market then plunged and is now trying to bounce back.

headline: Want Bills By Snail Mail? It Might Cost You Money
summary: You may dread monthly bills in the mailbox, but consider them a perk. Some companies are charging for them. For years, businesses have cajoled customers to view their bills online, mostly by offering cash, gift certificates, sweepstakes prizes and other incentives in return. A tough economy, though, has led to an even more aggressive stance.

headline: REGIONAL MARKET -- Newark; Prime Office Space Heading to Market
summary: The vacancy rate for the most desirable class of office space in downtown Newark has remained low in recent months, but a number of large spaces are to be vacated over the next year. Brokers representing owners of the space are optimistic, however, saying that the amount of interest in the soon-to-be-vacated offices is high, especially among small and midsize users.

headline: 2 Big Advertisers Made Account Changes
summary: Two big advertisers are making changes to their accounts. Verizon Communications, in a potentially serious blow to Lowe & Partners Worldwide in New York, named McGarry Bowen in New York to handle corporate brand and image advertising, duties that had been Lowe's domain.

headline: Generic Drug Sales Flourish Thanks to Big Companies
summary: Pushed by big employers like General Motors and Verizon Communications, as well as health plans and managed care drug plans, sales of low-cost generic prescription drugs are surging to new highs. More than 4 in 10 prescriptions filled at retail pharmacy counters are generic. Medco Health, the big pharmacy benefit management unit of the drug manufacturer Merck, said retail pharmacists and its own mail-order unit were substituting generics more than 92 percent of the time for brand-name drugs that had lost patent protection.

headline: A Museum of Natural History Well to the West of the Park; After 17 Years, Science Hall Will Open in Newark
summary: It's back. It's bigger. And now there are brown bats. Seventeen years after the closing of New Jersey's oldest and largest natural-science collection at the Newark Museum, workers were toiling yesterday to complete its new Victoria Hall of Science, New Jersey's riposte to that other, better-known natural-history collection in Manhattan.

headline: Debt Crisis For Venture In Cellphones In Mexico
summary: Vodafone Group and Verizon Communications spent over $2 billion in Mexico to buy what was once a promising wireless telephone company in one of the world's fastest growing markets. Their gamble has not paid off.
