summary: Some of the world's biggest record companies, facing rampant online piracy, are quietly financing the development and testing of software programs that would sabotage the computers and Internet connections of people who download pirated music, according to industry executives. The record companies are exploring options on new countermeasures, which some experts say have varying degrees of legality, to deter online theft: from attacking personal Internet connections so as to slow or halt downloads of pirated music to overwhelming the distribution networks with potentially malicious programs that masquerade as music files.

headline: POP/JAZZ
summary: California ALL TOMORROW'S PARTIES -- Los Angeles, June 19-22. Begun in England four years ago, this occasional series has become one of the world's most innovative pop festivals by applying a simple principle: hand over the programming to a well-connected artist or musician and allow every nepotistic indulgence. What results is more variety than you'd expect. After having the New York brahmins of Sonic Youth program a Los Angeles festival a year ago, the organizers have made a more local but still stranger curatorial choice: Matt Groening, the creator of ''The Simpsons,'' who was a rock critic early in his career and seems to have been paying a good deal of attention to alternative music. His highlights include Wire, the Boredoms, Coldcut, Johnny Dowd, the Melvins, Mission of Burma, Kool Keith, Fantomas, Melt-Banana, Yo La Tengo, Le Tigre and the Fall. Mr. Groening has also arranged the reunion of Captain Beefheart's Magic Band after more than 20 years, minus the captain, Don Van Vliet, who remains immovable in his new life as a painter. (Another A.T.P. festival, with Stephen Malkmus as the boss, was planned for the New York area in September but has been postponed.) www.atpfestival.com

headline: Surcharge on Cellphones, but for What?
summary: IN February, Nassau County began collecting a 30-cent monthly surcharge on all cellphone bills to help upgrade the county's 911 system for cellular calls, but the charge is not levied on wireless bills in Suffolk County. State Assemblyman Robert K. Sweeney, who represents Lindenhurst in Suffolk County, supports the 911 system upgrade, and he doesn't object to the surcharge in principle. But last year he declined to sponsor legislation that would have allowed Suffolk to impose the charge, saying its vague language did not guarantee that the money would be spent as intended. In fact, he says, little of the money raised since 1991 by a New York State surcharge on wireless bills has actually gone to install a 911 system for cellphone users as originally intended.

headline: In the Region/Westchester; Fuji Photo Moves Its Base to Valhalla From Elmsford
summary: IN the largest commercial leasing deal in Westchester in two years, Fuji Photo Film U.S.A. moved its United States headquarters last week, along with 330 employees, from cramped quarters in Elmsford to 164,000 square feet in an office park here. The United States marketing unit of the Tokyo-based Fuji Photo Film Company has signed a 10-year lease and spent about $10 million to refurbish the space at the Summit at Valhalla, a 102-acre office park built by Cappelli Enterprises in 1990 and acquired by Reckson Associates in 1998. Other tenants at the corporate park include Verizon, PepsiCo and Nortel.

headline: In HBO, AOL Sees a Sibling And, Crucially, A Role Model
summary: For the last six months, Jonathan Miller, the chief executive of the America Online division of AOL Time Warner, has pointed to the company's own cable channel HBO as the blueprint for a revival of the shrinking AOL service. His plan is to sell subscriptions to the online equivalent of must-see programming like ''The Sopranos'' that consumers cannot find anywhere else. It is an analogy that evokes cringes back at HBO headquarters, where some complain that Mr. Miller is reversing its history, two senior executives said. HBO started by persuading cable operators around the country to offer the channel, and only after it was the largest premium channel could it then afford to produce its own shows.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
summary: ENTERGY CORP., New Orleans, owner of utilities in four states in the U.S. Southeast, agreed to buy a 725-megawatt, natural gas-fueled power plant in Perryville, La., from Cleco Corp., Pineville, La., a utility owner in Louisiana. Terms were not disclosed. VERIZON COMMUNICATIONS INC., New York, the nation's largest local phone company, said it would sell six directory businesses in Europe to two private equity firms, 3i Group, and Veronis Suhler Stevenson, New York. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Report Criticizes Verizon Service
summary: A new report criticizes Verizon, the state's largest phone company, for poor service. The report, issued yesterday by Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester Democrat, says that the quality of Verizon's service has slipped in the past year, particularly in Nassau County and upstate New York cities, including Syracuse, Utica, Rome and Watertown. In February and March, the Public Service Commission received 1,314 complaints about Verizon, which has seven million customers. Cliff Lee, a company spokesman, said that service was improving, and that the company planned to spend $1 billion in the coming year to install fiber optic cables and make other improvements. Winnie Hu (NYT)

headline: Comcast Says Loss Widened But Forecast Is Looking Up
summary: The Comcast Corporation reported a wider first-quarter loss yesterday but raised its forecast for subscriber growth this year. For the quarter, Comcast, the nation's largest cable company, posted a net loss of $297 million, or 13 cents a share, compared with a loss of $89 million, or 9 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue, swelled by the acquisition of AT&T Broadband, more than doubled, to $5.52 billion from $2.67 billion. Excluding the effects of the acquisition, revenue would have increased 9.7 percent.

headline: Investing; Ferreting Out the Fittest in Cable
summary: SHARES of cable companies have generally performed well this year, but when Verizon Communications, the telecommunications company, announced this month that it was cutting the rates that consumers pay for high-speed Internet access, shares of a broad range of the companies fell. High-speed Internet access has been the fastest-growing sector for most cable companies. The Verizon announcement, on May 2, suggested a possible price war between cable and telecommunications companies, a prospect that troubles many investors. From that day until last Tuesday, most major cable stocks, including those of the Comcast Corporation, Cox Communications, Cablevision Systems and Mediacom Communications, dropped by about 5 percent or more; most have recovered partially since then.

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- New Jersey; Xanadu in the Meadowlands: Exotica Close to Home
summary: Three years ago Mack-Cali Realty, of Cranford, N.J., made a forceful move to expand its focus beyond the Northeast, announcing the intention to acquire another large real estate investment trust in Texas. But after Wall Street analysts criticized the plan and the stock price dropped, the company's chief executive, Mitchell E. Hersh, called off the nearly completed deal, pivoted back in the direction from whence he came and renewed concentration on Mack-Cali's core market, the Northeast. ''Ancient history'' is all Mr. Hersh wants to say now about the abandoned merger with Prentiss Properties of Dallas. These days Mr. Hersh, who has been affiliated with Mack-Cali through various company evolutions for 29 years, has fresh business to discuss.

headline: Verizon Sets Up Phone Booths For Internet Use Without Wires
summary: Verizon Communications yesterday introduced one of the oldest items in its inventory -- the humble phone booth -- as its newest weapon in the bitter competition to dominate the broadband communications market of the future. Verizon said that subscribers to its high-speed Internet access service would be able to go online wirelessly at no charge when they are near a Verizon phone booth in Manhattan.

headline: ARTS BRIEFING
summary: HIGHLIGHTS HANNIBAL LECTER: THE PREQUEL -- He's young. He's hungry. And they're going to make a movie about him. Movies about hungry young men are nothing new, but this one happens to be about Hannibal Lecter. Yes, the grisly gourmet is coming back, according to a Reuters report of an interview that the producer Dino De Laurentiis gave to the trade paper Screen International for its special issue at the Cannes International Film Festival. Mr. De Laurentiis said that four actors would be needed to play the cannibal at the ages of 12, 16, 20 and 25 (they're obviously skipping the baby food stage) in ''The Lecter Variation: The Story of Young Hannibal Lecter.'' Mr. De Laurentiis said the story being prepared by the author Thomas Harris, who created the character memorably portrayed by Anthony Hopkins in ''The Silence of the Lambs'' in 1991 and ''Hannibal'' in 2001, would trace Lecter from his childhood in Lithuania, where he was born into a wealthy family. Orphaned by World War II, he makes his way to Paris as a teenager and then to the United States.

headline: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
summary: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert. * AARKTICA, Galapagos, 70 North Sixth Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 782-5188. Aarktica's songs are extended reveries, built on loops of guitars and drums and occasional voices. The musical elements hover and circle, float by or bristle with distortion, as the songs drift through serenity and trouble. Tomorrow night at 7; admission is $8 (Jon Pareles).

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths PEGRAM, HATTIE
summary: PEGRAM-Hattie. Mrs. Hattie Pegram has passed on. The retired New York Telephone / Verizon 27 year veteran made a tremendous effort to overcome the side effects of a critical operation to remove an aneurysm this past January. She died peacefully in her sleep on May 10, 2003 at 5:45 AM. She is survived by her husband of 40 years Jerry Myer Pegram Sr., her son Jay Michael Pegram, her closest cousin Stephanie White. Her stepson Jerry Myer Pegram Jr. and his family, her best friend Patricia Lavelle, and scores of relatives, neighbors, friends, and co-workers also survive her. Donations in lieu of flowers: St. Raymond's Elementary School Re: Hattie Pegram Tuition Fund 2380 East Tremont Avenue, Bronx, New York 10462.

headline: Phone Companies See Their Future In Flat-Rate Plans Of Many Services
summary: Fifteen years ago, Arthur C. Clarke in the science-fiction novel ''2061: Odyssey Three'' predicted a future as follows: ''With the historic abolition of long-distance charges on 31 December 2000, every telephone call became a local one, and the human race greeted the new millennium by transforming itself into one huge, gossiping family.'' That future may be at hand, only a few years behind schedule, as a result of the telephone industry's declining economic fortunes, increasing competition and recent technological advances. Starting with MCI, which introduced its Neighborhood plan in April 2002, most leading phone companies -- AT&T, BellSouth, Qwest Communications, SBC Communications and Verizon -- have rolled out programs that allow customers in some states to make unlimited local and national calls for one flat monthly price.

headline: Deal Is Seen For NextWave Spectrum Sale
summary: NextWave Telecom is nearing an agreement to sell nearly a fifth of its radio spectrum licenses to one of the nation's largest wireless carriers, Cingular Wireless, in a deal that would allow NextWave to start paying off some of its billions of dollars of debt, executives involved in the transaction said yesterday. The deal, described as imminent by one of those executives, would transfer roughly 20 percent of NextWave's spectrum licenses to Cingular for $1.3 billion to $1.5 billion in cash.

headline: Revenue Up At Vodafone; Still, It Loses $16 Billion
summary: The Vodafone Group, the world's largest wireless operator, reported today that operating results for the year exceeded expectations, as revenue rose 14 percent. Vodafone, like other wireless operators, has been grappling with a worldwide slowdown in subscriber growth and with delays in the introduction of third-generation wireless services. But Vodafone, based in Newbury, England, has managed to wring strong gains out of its core European markets.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T To Sell Services From Former Division
summary: AT&T will start selling a package of services that includes mobile calling from AT&T Wireless Services, a company it spun off in 2001. Terms were not disclosed. The service package will be tested in some markets in the next few months and be offered nationwide by year's end, a spokesman, Gary Morgenstern, said. AT&T also sells Internet access and local calling to some of its 43 million residential customers. AT&T wants to sell partners' products to win and keep customers, after abandoning a plan to sell phone, wireless and cable service from under the same roof in 2000. Local carriers like Verizon Communications have added long distance to their offerings, and analysts say subscribers with multiple calling services on one bill are less likely to switch carriers. Shares of AT&T fell 34 cents, to $18.91.

headline: Where Adults Go to Play In the Mud
summary: LIKE most of the students at Hummer camp, Maria del Carmen Grimmelmann tends to gush. ''It moves me,'' Mrs. Grimmelmann, 51, said of the supercharged Hummer H2 she and her husband, Frank, bought earlier this year. ''You know when you go shopping and nothing moves you?'' she asked. ''Then there's the time you see something, and right away know it's perfect. It's like falling in love. When I'm driving it, I feel empowered. It's the car that opens the sea for me. Now I know how Moses felt.''

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Delinquent Telecom Debt
summary: One of Mexico's largest wireless telephone companies, Grupo Iusacell, missed a $25 million payment on its $350 million 2006 bond and promised to come up with a debt restructuring plan within the 30-day grace period. The operator, which is jointly owned by Verizon Comunications and the Vodafone Group, has about $815 million in total debt. The company has struggled for several years behind Mexico's dominant wireless carrier, América Móvil, and faces well-financed competition from Telefónica Móviles of Spain, which is moving aggressively into the Mexican market this year. Some market analysts speculate that if Iusacell can work out a favorable restructuring plan with creditors, then Verizon may be willing to put new capital into the company. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Martha Stewart Is Indicted And Vows to Fight Charges Martha Stewart was indicted on charges of conspiracy, obstruction of justice and securities fraud for a personal stock trade she made in 2001. She pleaded not guilty and vowed to fight the charges. Hours after her arraignment in federal court, the media and merchandising company she founded, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, announced that she was stepping down as chairwoman and chief executive. She will continue as a director and be the company's chief creative director. [Page A1.]

headline: Cellphones Made Easy
summary: Red phones, blue phones, Cellphones, new phones! Look at all the things they do: This one has a camera, too. One has built-in G.P.S., One plays Tetris, Clue and Chess. Some play films while making calls, Some find studs inside the walls, Some do e-mail, some play jazz, I'm not sure what stuff mine has. Soon they'll be so slick and small, Cellphones won't make calls at all! IT'S too bad Dr. Seuss, a noted lover of silliness, didn't live to see today's cellphones. Their features are so far-fetched and nonsensical, they make Horton and the Whos look like subjects for ''Biography.''

headline: Virgin Mobile begins a campaign to make itself the premier wireless company for young people.
summary: VIRGIN MOBILE USA hopes to jump-start its cellphone business among teenage and young adult customers with a campaign beginning tonight during the MTV Movie Awards. The spots, which carry the theme ''Live without a plan,'' will seek to demonstrate that the company truly understands young people, down to the kind of billing plans that they prefer.

headline: In Fight Over Online Music, Industry Now Offers a Carrot
summary: Like a lot of music fans roaming the Internet these days, David Bishop registers one basic sentiment when he thinks about the record industry. ''They're a bunch of greedheads,'' he says. ''They've been really fat on what I think of as huge profits and now they're trying to maintain the status quo.'' Mr. Bishop is not your typical college-dormitory Internet pirate. A 49-year-old illustrator in San Rafael, Calif., he has steered scrupulously clear of file-sharing software like Napster and KaZaA. But he recently discovered how to play the music provided by other online fans without copying it, and has no compunction about flouting recent efforts to stamp out the practice.

headline: The History of American Capitalism in a Single Industrial Complex
summary: To take the pulse of the American economy, you could do worse than go to Maynard, Mass., and toss questions at Jeff Taylor. As the chairman of the Internet job board known as Monster, Taylor has built a central hub for the world's job seekers and located it just down the hall from his large corner office. Actually, the hub is somewhat less grand than it sounds: a brightly lighted room, dense with the fug of electronic heat, lined with rows of Dell computer servers. These are the company's databanks. Monster currently has about 26.5 million résumés on file and lists about a million help-wanted ads from employers every month. ''Each of these servers can do 480 job searches a second,'' Taylor said as we paused in front of some blinking equipment on a recent afternoon. ''We get two million visitors per day and 30,000 new résumés. People come here quietly and stomp around looking for work. They're here right now.'' Taylor can quickly relate what the traffic through this room says about the state of health-care jobs (strong and growing), general desperation (we're still in a trough) and manufacturing (those 2.5 million lost jobs may not be coming back). He considers Monster an early indicator of trends in the broader market. So it is not encouraging to hear that at this moment, in midspring, a rebound is not visible -- postings by employers remain flat to down.

headline: Cable Is Confident of Internet Lead Over Phone Rivals
summary: The cable industry has grown up, and it has taken on a new swagger. The industry that started out with the transmission of television programs has matured into a broad-ranging provider of telecommunications, using digital technology to offer video-on-demand, phone service and, in particular, high-speed Internet connections.

headline: Olympic Hopefuls Gather in New York
summary: With the 2004 Athens Olympics rapidly approaching, the New York City Fencing World Cup is carrying added significance. The World Cup is a leading Olympic qualifying tournament, and the preliminaries at Columbia University yesterday trimmed the number of men's and women's sabre fencers to 128 from 300. The top 16 fencers in the world in each event received an automatic bid for the finals today, but the rest had to qualify yesterday. More than 100 women's foil fencers will compete for 64 spots in the final rounds starting today and running through tomorrow.

headline: Verizon and Vodafone Sell Wireless Stakes
summary: Verizon Communications and the Vodafone Group agreed to sell their stakes in the Mexican wireless company Grupo Iusacell, giving up on a venture that has cost the two global telecommunications giants more than $2 billion. Móvil Access, a telecommunications company owned by Ricardo B. Salinas Pliego, the owner of Mexico's No. 2 television broadcaster, is offering $10 million for 100 percent of Iusacell and plans to assume about $815 million in debt.

headline: MEMO PAD
summary: Airlines Installing In-Flight E-Mail Answering demand among business travelers, Continental Airlines and United Airlines are rushing to add two-way e-mail to existing in-flight technology supplied by Verizon's Airfone JetConnect. A spokeswoman for United, a unit of UAL, said the carrier would offer the e-mail service on selected flights starting today and on its entire domestic fleet by the end of the year. A Continental spokeswoman said its first installations of the full e-mail service would start on its fleet of Boeing 757's by the end of this month.

headline: United to Offer E-Mail and Data Access on Domestic Flights
summary: United Airlines said today that it would use a system developed by Tenzing Communications, a small technology company in Seattle, for an e-mail service it is planning to install in its North American fleet. The service will be available on more than 500 United planes by the end of the year. Continental Airlines is also starting to install the service and said that by the fall it would offer e-mail access on its entire narrow-body fleet.

headline: Public Service Panel Orders an Audit of Verizon
summary: Citing what it said was Verizon New York Inc.'s difficulty in responding quickly to consumer complaints, the state's Public Service Commission voted yesterday to order an independent audit of the telephone company. The audit, which will be conducted by the commission's staff and paid for by Verizon, will examine the company's ability to find and fix faulty equipment quickly. The audit will also study the company's worker productivity, which, according to the commission staff, is worse in New York than in other states Verizon serves.

headline: FOOTLIGHTS
summary: On Broadway in Scarsdale It's not far from Scarsdale to Broadway, but Stuart Malina, who graduated from Scarsdale High School in 1980, travels by way of Harrisburg, Pa., where he serves as music director and conductor of the Harrisburg Symphony Orchestra. Mr. Malina, who worked with Twyla Tharp and Billy Joel on ''Movin' Out,'' shared a Tony award for orchestration earlier this month with Mr. Joel. Back in Scarsdale the cheers were loud, not only because Mr. Malina's parents, Michael and Anita, still live there but also because the Scarsdale Summer Music Theater, of which Mr. Malina is an alumnus, can take a bit of credit. The 35-year-old program, which aims to give eighth graders through college seniors a five-week near-Broadway experience, was ''as professional as a nonprofessional activity could be,'' said Mr. Malina, who acted in one production and was music director for four others in high school and college.

headline: Commercial Property/New Jersey; An Industry-Government Team Lures Backup Sites
summary: NEW rules that say financial companies doing business crucial to the national economy must be able to resume operations within 24 hours of a major emergency have led to formation of a New Jersey group that seeks to work with companies that might put backup offices in the state. The new consortium includes two large real estate companies, the Gale Company and Cushman & Wakefield; Verizon; the Public Service Electric and Gas Company; and state authorities, including the Commission on Commerce, the Economic Development Authority, the Commission on Science and Technology and the Urban Enterprise Zone Authority.

headline: Verizon and Union Talks Begin With a Clash on Health Care
summary: Verizon Communications and its largest labor union began negotiations yesterday and immediately clashed over the company's push to have workers pay more for health coverage and the union's push to make it easier to organize workers at Verizon Wireless. Morton Bahr, president of the Communications Workers of America, warned there could be a walkout on Aug. 2, when Verizon's contract expires, unless the company eases the way to unionize 20,000 workers at Verizon Wireless.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Apple to Use I.B.M. Chip For Its Newest Computers Steven Jobs, left, the chief executive of Apple Computer, introduced an alliance with I.B.M. that will install a powerful 64-bit microprocessor chip on Apple computers. The new G5 chip, Mr. Jobs said, is also the foundation for the company's future software developments that will be based on an updated version of its OS X operating system -- called Panther -- that Apple will begin selling before the end of the year. [Page C6.]

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Fujitsu Wins Verizon Order
summary: A unit of Fujitsu Ltd., Fujitsu Network Communications, said it won a major order to supply equipment and software for the new fiber optic network of Verizon Communications. The deal is worth ''hundreds of millions of dollars over several years,'' a Fujitsu spokesman said. The equipment will help Verizon build a synchronous optical network that can handle voice calls and data. Fujitsu has lost money the last two years, partly because of a downturn in spending on telecommunications equipment. Ken Belson (NYT)

headline: In a Reversal, Verizon Backs Rule to Keep Cell Numbers
summary: Verizon Wireless said yesterday that it would drop its opposition to a government plan to allow callers to keep their wireless phone numbers when they switch carriers. The about-face by Verizon Wireless, the nation's largest mobile phone company, probably means that some other mobile phone operators will have little choice but to yield to the arrangement. Verizon, which has led a protracted, industrywide effort to prevent the Federal Communications Commission from requiring that cellphone numbers be portable from provider to provider, said it now supported F.C.C. rules scheduled to take effect on Nov. 24 and would end its legal and legislative campaign against them.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 6 British Soldiers Killed By Iraqi Gunmen in South Iraqi gunmen killed six British soldiers in southern Iraq as violence and unrest spread to areas of the country that had been largely quiet since the war ended almost two months ago. A1 The United States military has cordoned off part of an Iraqi village near the Syrian border that was hit in a deadly aerial assault last week and evicted five families whose houses were bombed in the attack. A1

headline: Toward One-Party Rule
summary: In principle, Mexico's 1917 Constitution established a democratic political system. In practice, until very recently Mexico was a one-party state. While the ruling party employed intimidation and electoral fraud when necessary, mainly it kept control through patronage, cronyism and corruption. All powerful interest groups, including the media, were effectively part of the party's political machine. Such systems aren't unknown here -- think of Richard J. Daley's Chicago. But can it happen to the United States as a whole? A forthcoming article in The Washington Monthly shows that the foundations for one-party rule are being laid right now.

headline: Page Two: June 22-28; Making Pirates Walk the Plank
summary: THE recording industry launched a new broadside in its campaign against copyright infringement. The industry's leading trade group said it would track down and prosecute music fans who trade files online. ''Any individual computer user who continues to offer music illegally to millions of others will run the very real risk of facing legal action,'' including criminal prosecution, warned Cary Sherman, president of the Recording Industry Association of America.

headline: Global Partnership Puts RealNetworks's Media Player on Vodafone Handsets
summary: RealNetworks Inc. plans to announce a partnership on Monday with the Vodafone Group, the world's largest cellphone operator, that would place RealNetworks's Real Media Player in handsets using the Vodafone service. The agreement would enable many of Vodafone's subsidiaries and partners in 36 countries to use the Real Media Player as well as RealNetworks's Helix Universal Mobile Server software to deliver audio and video to some of the company's 119.7 million cellular subscribers.

headline: Union and Verizon at Odds on Focus of Talks
summary: Threatened with a strike in a month, Verizon Communications has a simple message for its unionized workers: Let's form a partnership so Verizon, one of the few unionized telecommunications companies, can compete in a fiercely competitive industry. But the president of Verizon's largest union said it was well-nigh impossible to take talk of a partnership seriously when management was battling unionization efforts at Verizon's wireless operations.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Germany to Accelerate A Sweeping Cut in Taxes Desperate to pump some life into Germany's economy, Chancellor Gerhard Schröder announced that his government had approved plans to accelerate a sweeping tax cut. The decision, reached at an unusual cabinet meeting, would bring forward by a year tax cuts that had been scheduled for 2005. The government estimates that the cuts, which will now take effect in 2004 along with other tax cuts, are worth 18 billion euros, or more than $20 billion. [Page C2.]

headline: Employers Seek To Shift Costs Of Drugs to U.S.
summary: The bills to provide drug benefits through Medicare that were passed by the House and the Senate last week offer some of the country's largest employers a long-sought prize: shifting at least some of their burden of soaring drug costs to the federal government. With billions of dollars at stake, those companies are lobbying hard to make sure that those gains survive in the final version of the law.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Companies Lobby to Shift Part of Drug Costs to U.S. The bills to provide drug benefits through Medicare that were passed by the House and the Senate last week offer some of the country's largest employers a long-sought prize: shifting at least some of their burden of soaring drug costs to the federal government. With billions of dollars at stake, those companies are lobbying hard to make sure that those gains survive in the final version of the law. [Page A1.]

headline: WorldCom Agrees to Pay $750 Million In S.E.C. Suit
summary: A federal judge approved an agreement yesterday for WorldCom to pay $750 million to settle an accounting fraud lawsuit by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The ruling by Judge Jed S. Rakoff in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York ended the monetary phase of the complex suit, which is unfolding in tandem with WorldCom's bankruptcy proceedings in another federal court in New York.

headline: Unions Finding That Employers Want More Concessions
summary: For the 470 workers on strike at the Tyson Foods sausage and pepperoni plant here, the big question is why the company is so eager to cut starting salaries, freeze pensions and adopt a health plan with less coverage when the plant is so profitable. In the first strike in the plant's 128-year history, the workers have been picketing since Feb. 28, carrying signs accusing Tyson of greed and hoping to persuade it to withdraw its demands for a string of concessions.

headline: STOCK IN SONUS NETWORKS RISES ON VERIZON DEAL
summary: Shares of Sonus Networks Inc. surged 24 percent yesterday after the company announced a deal with Verizon Communications. An unexpectedly strong earnings report, released after the market's close on Thursday, also supported the price. Sonus, which is based in Westford, Mass., makes hardware and software for voice and data networks. Verizon is using Sonus's voice equipment in its central offices. Financial terms were not disclosed. On Thursday, Sonus reported a net loss of $3.2 million, or 1 cent a share, on revenue of $21.4 million for the quarter. The company reported a net loss of $17.8 million, or 9 cents a share in the quarter last year. Sonus's stock rose $1.38, to $7.10 a share.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A2-4 C.I.A. Chief Takes Blame For Error in Bush's Speech George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, took responsibility for letting President Bush say incorrectly in his State of the Union speech that Iraq had been trying to acquire uranium from Africa. Earlier, during his visit in Africa, the president said the C.I.A. had reviewed the speech and approved it. A1 American intelligence agencies are warning of a possible wave of attacks against American forces in Iraq over the next week to coincide with anniversaries tied to Saddam Hussein and the Baath Party. A1

headline: Verizon Is Told It Must Reinstate 2,300 Workers Let Go Last Year
summary: An arbitrator has ruled that Verizon Communications improperly laid off 2,300 workers in December and must reinstate them, a decision that union officials hailed but that company executives said underlined Verizon's need to gain more flexibility in contract talks to cut costs. In a 59-page ruling that the parties received yesterday, the arbitrator, Shyam Das, concluded that Verizon violated a job-security provision that said the company could not lay off union workers unless an external event directly reduced the need for employees.

headline: Study Calls for Better-Kept Subway Phones
summary: It is the sort of news that never exactly comes as news to any regular subway rider: the state of pay phones on the platforms leaves a lot to be desired. Some appear to have been dismembered. Others have been befouled. Many others simply seem as if they have been unplugged. But a report to be released today by the city's public advocate found that there are more broken and smelly phones in some places than in others. A study of 206 phones in 41 stations across the city found that 23.3 percent either had no dial tone, would not allow calls to be completed, did not return change or would not accept change. But of the phones tested in subway stations in low-income neighborhoods, 43.5 percent had those problems, the study says.

headline: The Invisible Hand Opens the Checkbook
summary: IT has long been possible to pay bills online, but now you can use your personal computer to receive bills, too. These days it is common for banks, other financial institutions, personal finance software programs and Web sites to handle bill paying. These services allow you to pay individual bills or schedule automatic payments for recurring bills like mortgage or car payments. The services typically cost several dollars a month (although some are free) and virtually eliminate having to write checks. They can also help you manage your money better by allowing you to schedule payments at your leisure, knowing that a check will be sent out or funds electronically transferred on the date you specify.

headline: Combos For Mutt And Jeff
summary: YOU know the TV ad for Apple's latest laptops? Two passengers sit side by side on a plane: Verne Troyer, the 2-foot-8 actor who plays Mini-Me in the Austin Powers movies, and Yao Ming, the 7-foot-5 center for the Houston Rockets. Each pulls out a laptop to watch a DVD on the flight. The joke, of course, is that Mr. Yao pulls out Apple's diminutive 12-inch model, and Mr. Troyer pulls out the 17-inch model, which seems roughly the size of Utah. If those two characters were shopping for communicators -- that is, combination cellphone-palmtops -- then Samsung would be ready for them. Its new i500, which runs on the Palm operating system, is so small that it rattles around in a shirt pocket. The other new model, the i700, runs on Microsoft's Pocket PC software; it's so big, you feel like you're talking into a romance novel.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Profit Drops 30% at G.M. As Sales Fall Amid Price War General Motors reported a 30 percent decline in second-quarter net profit, in large part because of falling vehicle sales in North America coupled with a price war that continues to escalate. But the company was upbeat about the outlook for the second half of the year, in contrast to a gloomier picture offered by the Ford Motor Company. [Page C2.]

headline: Union Votes Would Allow Verizon Strike
summary: The two main unions of Verizon Communications announced today that more than 75,000 workers had voted overwhelmingly to authorize a strike if no contract is reached by Aug. 2. Verizon's largest union, the Communications Workers of America, said 92 percent of its 60,000 members working for Verizon in the Northeast had voted for a strike. The union, based in Washington, said the next step required for a walkout would be for the 20-member executive board to authorize the union's president to set a strike date.

headline: Sending E-Mail While Aloft
summary: Travelers on some United and Continental flights can now send and receive e-mail. Both carriers have offered Verizon Airfone's JetConnect service on some planes since late last year, enabling customers with laptops to plug a phone cord into an Airfone and send text and access news and entertainment services for $5.99 a flight.

headline: Some Bet the Future of Broadband Belongs to Regional Bells, Not Cable
summary: To Jim Hjartarson, the future of Internet access lies in telephone lines, not television cables. That is not a popular view these days. From the moment Mr. Hjartarson joined four fellow Canadians in 1998 to develop high-speed Internet equipment, their venture, Catena Networks, hitched its wagon to the regional Bell companies.

headline: MEXICAN WIRELESS COMPANY OBTAINS AN ARGENTINE OPTION
summary: Latin America's largest wireless company, América Móvil, said yesterday that it had acquired an option to buy a controlling interest in an Argentine wireless company, CTI. CTI, in which Verizon Communications holds a 47.8 percent stake, is in talks to restructure its $1.1 billion debt. América Móvil said that after the debt restructuring, CTI's enterprise value would fall to less than $200 million. If exercised, the option would give América Móvil a 60 percent voting interest and a 49 percent economic interest in CTI, which has 1.2 million subscribers and licenses covering all of Argentina. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

headline: Verizon and a big union joust with help from slick hired guns.
summary: LABOR battles are often fought on the picket lines, but Verizon and its largest union are dueling to get the upper hand in an unusual battle of newspaper ads and spot broadcast messages. Facing an Aug. 2 contract-negotiation deadline, Verizon and the union, the Communications Workers of America, have poured more than $1 million into advertising in a dozen Northeastern cities, straining to win public sympathy and throw each other on the defensive.

headline: Regina Sampogna, Paul Saake
summary: Regina Sampogna, the daughter of Madelyn and Dominick Sampogna of Eastchester, N.Y., is to be married today to Paul Thomas Saake, the son of Barbara and Paul H. Saake of Colts Neck, N.J. The Rev. Robert J. Romano, a cousin of the bride, will perform the ceremony at Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. The bride and bridegroom, both 24, graduated from Loyola College in Baltimore, where they met.

headline: MCI FACES INQUIRY FOR FRAUD ON FEES FOR LONG DISTANCE
summary: Federal prosecutors have opened an investigation in the United States and Canada into accusations that MCI, the nation's second-largest long-distance carrier, defrauded other telephone companies of at least hundreds of millions of dollars over nearly a decade, people involved in the inquiry said. The central element of MCI's scheme, people involved in the inquiry said, consisted of disguising long-distance calls as local calls to avoid paying special access tariffs to local carriers across the country. Those tariffs are the largest single source of MCI's costs for carrying calls and data transmissions.

headline: MCI's Competitors Are Quick to Make Use of Federal Inquiry
summary: MCI came under attack today from rival phone companies, which seized on the news that it is the focus of a criminal investigation. One competitor criticized MCI in bankruptcy court, another challenged its government business and a third made public letters suggesting that MCI's new management team had been aware for some time of the problems at the center of the inquiry. MCI, whose lawyers met today with federal investigators, said it intended to conduct an internal inquiry into accusations that it improperly diverted phone traffic to avoid paying access fees on long-distance calls to other companies.

headline: The Line Between Cost Management and Deceit
summary: No one in the phone industry is surprised that MCI wanted to cut the access payments that it makes to local phone companies like SBC Communications, Verizon and BellSouth to complete its customers' calls. The question is whether MCI engaged in tactics that crossed the line between deft cost management and fraud. MCI faces accusations that it used at least two schemes to reduce its access charges.

headline: INSIDE
summary: Terror: Don't Bet on It A Pentagon plan that would have rewarded investors able to predict terror attacks and other global unrest is being aborted. PAGE A10 Progress in the Ozone Scientists say they have found the first sign that phasing out chemicals that harm the ozone layer is having a restorative effect. PAGE A11

headline: Accusations Against MCI Could Drive Clients Away
summary: Whether true or not, accusations that MCI used fraudulent methods to reduce the access charges it pays to other phone companies could make it harder for the company to keep some of its current customers and to sign up new ones, according to industry consultants. The accusations are raising new questions about the reliability of the financial data and projections that MCI is giving to creditors and to the federal bankruptcy court in Manhattan overseeing its reorganization.

headline: Talk of Partners, Rumblings of Battle at Verizon
summary: Even though Verizon faces the threat of a strike this Sunday, the company is insisting in its high-wire labor talks that it wants to create an ambitious new partnership with its unions to survive and thrive in today's fiercely competitive telecommunications industry. In urging its unions to agree to hold down costs and give management the flexibility to cut jobs, Verizon, the nation's largest telecommunications company, is sounding like Detroit's Big Three automakers two decades ago when they sought -- and established -- a trailblazing partnership with the United Automobile Workers.

headline: Company Tries to Catch Up On Repairs on Long Island
summary: With Verizon workers poised to go on strike this weekend, about 2,400 orders for phone-line installations on Long Island have gone unfilled as workers scramble to respond to a glut of repair orders, according to union leaders. Last Friday, Verizon declared a state of emergency on Long Island, which allows the company to demand extra overtime from its workers. Since then, workers have been responding only to repair calls and emergency phone-line installations, said Bob Morrow, vice president for Communications Workers of America Local 1108 in Suffolk County.

headline: Past Looms Large as Verizon Prepares for a Strike
summary: If unions representing 78,000 Verizon workers in the Northeast go on strike this weekend, the company insists customer service will not suffer. But past experience is not on management's side.

headline: TELLABS TO CLOSE PLANT AND LAY OFF 325 WORKERS
summary: Tellabs Inc. said yesterday that it would close a plant in Bolingbrook, Ill., and send the manufacturing work to the Sanmina-SCI Corporation, eliminating 325 jobs. The shift will cost Tellabs $90 million to $110 million in the third quarter. Tellabs, a maker of fiber optic network equipment, has been struggling as customers including Verizon Communications Inc. have cut spending on networks. Sanmina-SCI, based in San Jose, Calif., makes electronic products like printers and computers. Tellabs has been a Sanmina-SCI customer for more than 10 years. Financial terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

headline: Credibility of Witness Is Challenged in MCI Inquiry
summary: A Minnesota telephone company at the center of the most recent criminal inquiry into MCI today attacked the credibility of a whistle-blower who may be the most important witness in the case. The company, Onvoy Inc. of St. Louis Park, Minn., is under investigation by federal authorities after accusations that it took part in a conspiracy with MCI to improperly avoid paying access fees owed to other phone companies.

headline: Verizon Talks Bog Down as Deadline Nears
summary: With a strike deadline set for tomorrow morning, Verizon and its two main unions again reported no progress yesterday in negotiations that were assisted by the top federal mediator. Spokesmen for the company and the two unions said the talks remained deadlocked over job security, with the company demanding contractual language that would make it easier to shed workers, while the unions continued to insist on strong language for job security.

headline: Dolen Perkins, David Valdez
summary: Dr. Dolen Marie Perkins, the daughter of Barbara J. Perkins and James A. Perkins of Memphis, Tenn., was married on Wednesday to David Solomon Valdez, the son of the late Elena Socorro Valdez, who lived in San Salvador, El Salvador, and the late Jimmy Wilson, who lived in Long Beach, Calif. The Rev. Dr. P. J. Lawrence, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Grand Old House, a restaurant in Grand Cayman, Cayman Islands. The bride, 30, will be known as Dr. Perkins-Valdez. She is a president's postdoctoral fellow at the Center for African American Studies at the University of California at Los Angeles. In the fall, she will be an assistant professor of English at Mary Washington College in Fredericksburg, Va. The bride, a graduate of Harvard, received a master's degree in creative writing from the University of Memphis and a doctorate in English from George Washington University.

headline: Verizon and Unions Agree To Talk Past Strike Deadline
summary: Encouraged by progress in contract talks, the two main unions at Verizon Communications announced last night that their members should report to work today even though an agreement was not reached with the company before the midnight strike deadline. Officials with the Communications Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers announced an hour before the strike deadline that 78,000 workers at Verizon should not walk out this morning.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL 3-8 Sons of Hussein Buried By Family Near Tikrit Uday and Qusay Hussein were buried in their hometown by members of Saddam Hussein's family. The funeral touched off an outpouring of nostalgia for their fugitive father and angry calls to rid the country of American occupiers. 1

headline: NextWave: Airwave Rich But Cash Poor
summary: For the last seven years, some of the most valuable assets in technology -- billions of dollars of communication airwaves -- have been sitting untapped, tangled up in bankruptcy and other federal courts. If commercial airwaves were New York City real estate, it would be as if Midtown Manhattan were a big empty lot. Now NextWave Telecom, proclaimed by a Supreme Court decision in January to be the rightful owner of licenses to use that airwave spectrum, has declared plans to build out a wireless network for data transmission. The news has been greeted with skepticism by an industry that would prefer to have NextWave sell its licenses to carriers that need more radio spectrum to improve their cellphone services.

headline: Verizon and Unions Report Significant Progress as Contract Talks Go On Past Deadline
summary: Verizon Communications and two unions representing 78,000 workers continued their intense contract talks yesterday after the unions waived a strike deadline set for yesterday morning. Last night, the parties said for the first time that substantial progress was being made in the talks. Candice Johnson, a spokeswoman for the Communications Workers of America, said at 10:15 p.m., ''We are making significant progress in bargaining although a few outstanding issues remain to be resolved.''

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A2-7 With Iraqi Courts Gone, Young Clerics Judge A group of clerics wanting to establish an Islamic system of government in Iraq have set up courts in Najaf and Baghdad, but the decisions and sanctions being promulgated are not recognized by either the American occupation forces or Iraq's other Muslim religious authorities. A1 Hunger Rises in Liberia As the food supply in government-held parts of Monrovia, the Liberian capital, dwindles to dire levels, childhood malnutrition is rising and hospitals are scrambling to feed patients. The World Food Program has distributed no food since mid-July. Its supplies are stuck at the port, and may have been looted. A1

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 First Peacekeepers Arrive In Bleak Liberian Capital The first planeloads of West African peacekeepers arrived in Monrovia, bringing hope that months of fighting might soon end. With President Bush still undecided about deploying the American forces positioned offshore in three warships, the Nigerian troops did not venture beyond the airport. They are the first of an expected force of 3,250 West African soldiers. A1

headline: Verizon Talks Are Less Upbeat As Union Cites Unresolved Issues
summary: Verizon's largest union took a more negative tone yesterday about contract talks, saying that some difficult issues remained unresolved and that the company was intent on increasing employees' contributions for health coverage and obtaining the power to dismiss workers at will. In a sharp contrast to remarks on Sunday that significant progress had been made, Jeff Miller, chief spokesman for the Communications Workers of America, said last night: ''There are still some very tough issues that haven't been resolved. Those specifically include demands to be able to lay off people at will.''

headline: Shares Are Mostly Higher, Led by Telecommunications
summary: Stocks advanced yesterday, led by telecommunications shares. Qwest Communications International said that it was talking to several potential bidders for its mobile-telephone network, encouraging investors that phone shares would rally. Verizon Communications climbed as it resumed talks with unions representing 78,000 employees after making ''significant progress'' in contract negotiations.

headline: Coping With Cellphone Calls Overseas
summary: For executives used to having a cellphone practically grafted to one ear, a business trip overseas presents some communication challenges. Although some wireless users in the United States have phones that can be used abroad -- usually referred to as world phones or triband phones -- phones that work in some countries do not necessarily work in others, and international phones sometimes do not get the best coverage outside metropolitan areas at home.

headline: SBC to Offer Wi-Fi Access at 6,000 Spots
summary: SBC Communications is expected to announce today plans to provide wireless Internet access at 6,000 hotels, airports, convention centers, restaurants and other public locations. The initiative draws SBC into an intensifying competition with start-ups and other telecommunications giants looking to deploy wireless Internet ''hot spots.'' SBC, which is based in San Antonio, says it will deploy its network over the next three years at locations mostly in its 13-state territory, which includes Texas, California, and Connecticut. Some service will be available by the end of the year, the company said, but SBC has not disclosed how much it will charge users for network access.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A2-8 Car Bomb in Indonesia Kills at least 10 A sport utility vehicle packed with explosives blew up in Indonesia's capital, killing as many as 15 people and wounding nearly 150 in a Marriott hotel, a large restaurant and an office building. It was the most devastating attack on Indonesian soil since the twin blasts in Bali last October. There were no immediate claims of responsibility, but because all three buildings were frequented by Americans, Indonesia's vice president, Hamzah Haz, said the attack appeared to have been aimed at American interests. A1

headline: Two Sides Differ On State of Talks For Verizon Pact
summary: Verizon Communications indicated yesterday that it was nearing an agreement with its two main unions, but a spokesman for the company's largest union said little progress was being made. The conflicting statements sowed confusion for many of the 78,000 workers who were poised to walk out on Sunday morning until union leaders suspended their strike threat because they were encouraged by progress in the talks.

headline: Both Sides See Verizon Talks Inching Toward an Agreement
summary: Negotiations between Verizon Communications and its two main unions inched forward yesterday, with officials on both sides saying that they expected an agreement in the next few days. But several union officials warned that although the sides continued to negotiate specific contractual language, things could still fall apart and the 78,000 workers from the two unions could go on strike. A strike would affect 13 states and Washington.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Wireless Access At F.C.C.
summary: The Federal Communications Commission is providing free wireless Internet access to visitors at its Washington headquarters. ''When you come to the F.C.C., leave the cords at home,'' said Michael K. Powell, chairman of the commission. ''We're embracing the power of 'Wi-Fi' and the freedom and convenience of wireless Internet access it gives to consumers.'' Last year, Mr. Powell told his staff to take steps to make the F.C.C. one of the first federal agencies to provide public Internet access through the Wi-Fi radio signal technology. Visitors who bring their own hardware will be able to use the service at the agency's building and in its courtyard. In May, Verizon announced that it would provide Wi-Fi access from phone booths around Manhattan. Wireless access is also available in some hotels, airports, convention centers, restaurants and other locations.

headline: A Marriage, and Divorce, of Convenience at Verizon
summary: Negotiations between Verizon Communications and its two main unions appeared to grow more thorny yesterday, with a settlement now unlikely in the next few days. But while the company and its workers currently find themselves on opposite sides of the bargaining table, they have often found themselves fighting on the same side, lobbying politicians and petitioning regulators.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Verizon Unions See Delays Because of New Proposals The two main unions at Verizon Communications said there would be delays in reaching a settlement because of new proposals the company had made on job security. Union officials said those proposals would require several sets of regional talks. But Verizon, the nation's largest telecommunications company, immediately countered that the unions were unnecessarily stretching out the talks to win concessions. [Page C4.] The company and its unions have often found themselves on the same side when it comes to lobbying politicians and regulators in Washington and state capitals. News Analysis. [C4.]

headline: Unions See More Delay in Talks With Verizon
summary: The two main unions at Verizon Communications said yesterday that there would be delays in reaching a settlement because of new proposals that the company had made on job security. But Verizon, the nation's largest telecommunications company, immediately countered that the unions were unnecessarily stretching out the talks to win concessions.

headline: After a Break, Verizon Talks To Split in Two
summary: After more than a week of intense negotiations with the assistance of a top federal mediator, Verizon and its two main unions said yesterday that they would take a break from contract discussions until Tuesday. When the talks resume, the two sides plan to meet at two regional bargaining sites, and will not -- for the time being -- continue to negotiate in Washington with the direct assistance of the mediator, Peter Hurtgen, the director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

headline: INVESTING WITH -- Brian C. Rogers; T. Rowe Price Equity Income Fund
summary: CORPORATE dividends mattered to Brian C. Rogers even when they were out of style. ''Three years ago, dividends were considered passé, almost a sign of corporate weakness,'' said Mr. Rogers, the manager of the $11.5 billion T. Rowe Price Equity Income fund since its inception in 1985. ''Now, dividends are in vogue again.''

headline: Jostling for the Wi-Fi Lead in a Crowded Field
summary: Is there any advantage in having been ahead of the crowd now that just about every telecommunications company is rushing into the Wi-Fi wireless world? Wayport, a pioneer in installing high-speed Internet access in hotels and airports, is about to find out. Wayport, based in Austin, Tex., is a name known to thousands of laptop-toting business travelers. It started providing wireless Internet connections in 2000 with the popular Wi-Fi networking standard in airports including Dallas-Fort Worth, Seattle, and San Jose, Calif. Even earlier, Wayport had placed wired broadband connections in hotels around the country, which it now often complements with Wi-Fi in common areas.

headline: Internet Providers Question Subpoenas to Stop File Swapping
summary: Arguing that the record industry is trying to force its members to become the ''police of the Internet,'' a group representing over 100 Internet service providers plans to deliver a letter to the industry's trade association today. The letter asks a series of pointed questions about plans to sue people suspected of illegally trading music files online. The letter from NetCoalition is the latest objection from Internet service providers to a flood of subpoenas from the record industry seeking the identities of Internet subscribers suspected of swapping files.

headline: Unions May Ask Verizon Customers to Try AT&T
summary: Raising the stakes in the protracted contract negotiations between Verizon and its unions, labor officials planned to announce a campaign today to collect the names of people who would be willing to switch their service to AT&T, a competing provider of local, long-distance and wireless phone services. Union officials said that the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which is coordinating the effort to appeal to millions of Verizon customers, would not yet urge them to switch phone companies. But the threat is seen as an effort to increase the bargaining position of the unions representing 78,000 Verizon technicians and operators who have worked without a contract for 10 days and also a sign that there may be more rancor in the negotiations than had been indicated earlier.

headline: INSIDE
summary: Fed Holds Steady The Federal Reserve left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 1 percent, but it cheered financial markets by strongly suggesting that it will not increase rates until next year. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Libya to Admit to Bombing Libya is expected this week to end 14 years of resistance and accept responsibility for the downing of Pan Am Flight 103, while paying $2.7 billion into a fund for the victims' families. PAGE A7

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Wireless Walkie-Talkie Service
summary: Verizon Wireless is expected to introduce today a phone with walkie-talkie functions to compete with the popular Direct Connect service of Nextel Communications, according to a report yesterday in RCR Wireless News, a trade publication. Verizon Wireless will initially sell handsets made by Motorola for the service, but will introduce others made by Samsung shortly afterward, the article said. It listed the handset price at $150 to $330, depending on the length of the contract. Executives from Verizon Wireless, Motorola and Samsung were not immediately available for comment.

headline: From Brooklyn Bridge to Airwaves, Bloomberg Tries to Be a Figure of Calm Authority
summary: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was having coffee at a Brooklyn diner yesterday afternoon when the lights went out, but so much sunshine was streaming in the windows that he said it took him a moment to realize what had happened. It quickly became apparent that it was not just a local blackout. So the mayor and his aides hurried back to City Hall. There, over the next few hours, Mr. Bloomberg spoke to power officials, Gov. George E. Pataki and the White House; held news conferences; and briefly strode out to reassure the sweaty throngs walking over the Brooklyn Bridge.

headline: When Wireless Phones Failed Because of Heavy Use, Callers Turned to Land Lines
summary: The regular public telephone network generally kept working after the power went out in parts of six states yesterday afternoon, but the cellular systems in affected areas were often unable to cope. Wireless network operators said their networks were unable to handle the heavy traffic as large numbers of people simultaneously tried to reach friends, family and business associates. But the lack of electricity or the failure of backup power systems at cellular transmitter stations and traffic switching centers were also partly to blame. While the transmitter stations typically have battery backup power, the batteries may not last more than a few hours.

headline: While Businesses Suffered, a Few Made Out
summary: Almost all the fancy stores on Fifth Avenue were still shuttered yesterday afternoon, Day 2 of the big blackout. But in front of Fendi, a slightly furtive-looking fellow hissed ''Prada!'' as he stood over a grimy sheet piled with handbags. He had plenty of customers (as did the nearby Prada store, selling the genuine article, which opened at 2 p.m. and was mobbed, despite the lack of air conditioning). Many experts say it is far too early to calculate the overall economic effects of the blackout. But as always in New York, the blackout produced economic winners and losers, and as always, a little hustle did not hurt.

headline: This Time, Fewer Arrests As the City Stayed Dark
summary: New York City was a crime scene waiting to happen, the imposed darkness offering a nearly perfect opportunity for those inclined to help themselves to whatever their neighborhoods had to offer: computers, jewelry, groceries, cellular phones. No cash, just carry. But while about 250 people were arrested in what the police described as blackout-related incidents Thursday night and early yesterday, the city never came close to descending into the plunder and destruction that occurred when the lights went out in 1977. During that fiasco, thousands of looters raged through the city and there were so many arrests that some were processed at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Three Are Killed as Blazes Erupt Across the Northeast
summary: Fires started by candles and generators during the power blackout led to one of the busiest nights since the 1970's for the New York Fire Department, officials said yesterday. There were also sporadic failures of the department's emergency medical service dispatch system. Two people died in fires in Brooklyn and Manhattan, and one person in Connecticut.

headline: The Bits Are Willing, but the Batteries Are Weak
summary: For many Internet addicts, the blackout last week was a rude reminder of just how decisively the vaunted 21st-century digital lifestyle can be laid low by a disruption in 19th-century electrons. While hardly enjoyable, being severed from the usual sources of food, water and transportation has occurred in previous power failures. But losing access to the digitized information that permeates our lives -- from work-related records to Google searches to e-mail love letters -- punctured a cherished illusion of the cyberage: that cyberspace is a separate universe, immune from real-world physics.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 Attack on U.N. Compound In Baghdad Kills 17 A suicide bomber drove a cement mixer full of explosives into the side of the United Nations compound in Baghdad, killing 17 people and wounding at least 100 in an attack on one of the principal agencies in charge of rebuilding Iraq. Among the dead was Sergio Vieira de Mello, the United Nations secretary general's special representative in Iraq. A1

headline: As Talks Resume, Verizon Argues With a Union Over an Ad Phrase
summary: While negotiators for Verizon Communications and its workers resumed bargaining yesterday over crucial elements like health benefits and job security, the two sides also swapped accusations over the appropriate use of the phrase, ''Can you hear me now?'' At the bargaining table, the negotiators, who took a break over the weekend, discussed the central issues with a federal mediator in Washington yesterday, the 17th day without a contract. But in court, a sideshow emerged, touched off by the use, or possible misuse, of a Verizon Wireless advertising slogan.

headline: U.S. Details Ground Rules For Baby Bells and Rivals
summary: The Federal Communications Commission today detailed the rules the Baby Bells and their rivals must follow in using existing and future telecommunications networks. The rules elaborate on a contentious F.C.C. decision six months ago that local telephone companies generally must share older equipment for voice transmission at wholesale rates but not newer technology dedicated to high-speed data.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Experts Work at Isolating Rogue Computer Program Computer experts successfully tracked down and isolated computers around the world that had been infected with a malicious computer program having the potential, the experts feared, to cripple an untold number of computers connected to the Internet worldwide. The program had been remotely installed in the 20 computers by one or more hackers who also started the latest iteration of a familiar and fast-spreading computer virus, SoBig, that appeared earlier this week and wrought havoc with many corporate PC's and business systems on the Internet. [Page A1.]

headline: Verizon's Protest of Union Ad Is Overruled
summary: An arbitrator has ruled against an effort by Verizon Communications to block a union from placing advertisements accusing a unit of the company of unfair practices. The newspaper ads do not violate an agreement between the Communications Workers of America, a union representing about 60,000 Verizon employees whose contracts are being negotiated, and Verizon Wireless, the arbitrator, Edwin Benn, said in a ruling.

headline: Local Phone Companies Challenge F.C.C. Rules
summary: SBC Communications and other local telephone companies asked a court yesterday to overturn new federal rules that give states more authority to decide if the phone companies must lease network components to rivals at discounts. SBC, the BellSouth Corporation, Qwest Communications International and the United States Telecom Association, a trade group that represents local companies, filed their request with the United States Court of Appeals in Washington, a week after the Federal Communications Commission issued the final version of the rules.

headline: Verizon Talks Are Halted
summary: Verizon Communications Inc., the local telephone carrier, and unions representing 78,000 employees in the Northeast halted contract negotiations until Tuesday, a federal mediator, Peter Hurtgen, said yesterday in a statement. Verizon and the unions, the Communications Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, have been seeking to avert a strike that could hamper service in 13 states from Virginia to Maine. The contracts expired Aug. 3.

headline: Officers' Sept. 11 Accounts: Catastrophe in the Details
summary: ''The first thing that hit my senses was the quietness of it all,'' remembered Inspector Timothy I. Norris of the Port Authority Police Department. Seconds after the south tower of the World Trade Center collapsed on Sept. 11, 2001, he was in the basement, near the usually bustling PATH Square. ''It was surreal. Then as we panned our flashlights about, we observed the devastation that had taken place. ''There was also a large fire in the area from what seemed like a broken gas line. I was just about to turn around and leave the area when my flashlight illuminated a bloody arm waving from underneath a debris pile.'' Inspector Norris and others lifted a man out. ''The man was semiconscious and heavy, and it seemed like an eternity before we emerged in the light and fresh air of Vesey Street.''

headline: Business; Going Gold? Maybe, if Enough Cellphones Ring
summary: ONE of the most popular songs in the country last week, ''Crazy in Love'' by Beyoncé Knowles and featuring Jay-Z, was not released only on compact disc and to radio stations. It was also sent to cellphone users who wanted to download it as their ring tone. The music industry may be having trouble persuading people to buy its songs online rather than swap them without paying. But the cellphone market is another matter.

headline: Sharpening Up the Old 'En Garde'
summary: IN the rented school gym in Rye Brook, the late-summer session of the Westchester Fencers Club was in action recently, and the clash of steel on steel competed with the erratic beeps of the touch detector. ''Aagh!'' ''Beautiful!'' ''You're a good man.'' ''Leave your arm down.'' ''Double.'' ''You didn't even get a hit.''

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
summary: DELPHI CORP., Troy, Mich., the maker of auto parts, said it had won contracts valued at more than $335 million to supply parts to Renault, Boulogne-Billancourt, France, through 2006. NORTEL NETWORKS CORP., Brampton, Canada, said it had won a multiyear, $1 billion order to upgrade the network of Verizon Wireless, the cellphone company, which is a joint venture of Verizon Communications, New York, and Vodafone Group, Newbury, England.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 U.S. Would Aid North Korea If It Gives Up Nuclear Arms President Bush has authorized American negotiators to say that he is prepared to take a range of steps to aid North Korea -- from easing sanctions to a peace treaty -- if North Korea will begin to surrender its nuclear weapons and all the facilities to develop them. A1 Rumsfeld Seeks More Iraqi Help Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld arrived in Iraq and said his highest priority was to accelerate the recruitment, training and deployment of former Iraqi officers to combat disorder and violence. A1

headline: INSIDE
summary: Verizon in Deal With Unions Verizon and its unions reached agreement on a tentative contract that includes a wage freeze and job security protections. PAGE C1 S.E.C. Enters Fund Inquiry The main regulator of mutual funds, the S.E.C., is now investigating practices of big funds, catching up to a New York inquiry. PAGE C1

headline: Verizon and Unions Agree on Tentative 5-Year Contract
summary: Verizon Communications and its unions announced last night that they had reached agreement on a tentative contract that includes a one-year wage freeze and retains strong job security protections that the company had sought to weaken. Verizon's two main unions boasted that they had achieved major victories on job security and health insurance, having beaten back Verizon's efforts to make its unionized workers pay significantly more toward their health coverage.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A2-6 Palestinian Prime Minister Appears Ready to Resign Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian prime minister, plans to announce his resignation. Associates of Mr. Abbas say he has concluded that the move may force Yasir Arafat, under international pressure, to bring back Mr. Abbas, or another prime minister, with guaranteed authority. A1 Weapon Sites Unguarded in Iraq American officials said about 50 munitions sites in Iraq containing explosives similar to those used in recent bombings remained largely unguarded. One official acknowledged that the military does not have enough troops to watch every site. A1

headline: Verizon's Pact Seen as Critical To Its Industry
summary: Verizon's unions were quite happy with the settlement they reached Thursday night with the company, but some analysts contend that the deal could make it harder for the nation's large telephone service providers to face increasing threats to their business from the cable industry and a variety of upstarts. The settlement comes as companies in the traditional local telephone industry, like Verizon, SBC Communications and Bell South, are moving from the effective monopoly control over direct access to consumers and business they long enjoyed to a much more challenging situation contending with powerful cable companies like Cox and Comcast that are offering rival data and voice services through their own pipes into homes and offices.

headline: Older Workers Are Thriving Despite Recent Hard Times
summary: Without fanfare, older workers -- the ones seemingly left behind by the dot.com boom -- are turning out to be the only group thriving in the jobless recovery. Even as younger workers have lost ground, a higher percentage of those aged 55 to 64 hold jobs today than when the economy plunged into hard times in early 2001. Their success has shifted the composition of the work force: older people now make up 12 percent of the nation's workers, up from 10.2 percent in 2000. That was the year the dot-com boom, so favorable to the young, began to collapse.

headline: Criticism Arises Over the Way Calling Plans Advertise Rates
summary: A telemarketer talked to Jeff Kane in April about an alluring offer to reduce his monthly phone bill. The pitch was for an unlimited calling plan that would let him pay a flat rate for all local and long-distance calls. Mr. Kane, tired of watching his minutes on the phone, snatched up the offer. Now he is keeping close watch on something else: his phone bill. He said he was assured that he would pay $49.99 for the Neighborhood plan from MCI. But with taxes and surcharges included, the bills have been around $65.

headline: Day in Court For Bid to End WorldCom's Bankruptcy
summary: Has WorldCom devised an acceptable plan to emerge from the largest bankruptcy on record as a healthy competitor in the struggling telecommunications industry? To the dismay of competitors who want the company liquidated, most of its creditors have voted yes.

headline: WorldCom Hearing Starts, Then Stops for More Talks
summary: Soon after a hearing began yesterday on whether WorldCom has come up with a viable and fair plan to emerge from bankruptcy protection, lawyers for the company and a group of creditors that has been among the plan's most vocal critics asked for more time to negotiate. Judge Arthur J. Gonzalez of United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan said the negotiators could have last night to try to settle their differences. A settlement would pave the way to quicker approval of a plan, shaving time from a trial that some lawyers expect to last for more than six weeks and ultimately allowing WorldCom to emerge from bankruptcy protection sooner.

headline: Cellphone Companies Agree to Set of Consumer Guidelines
summary: The nation's largest cellular phone companies are set to announce today a voluntary seal-of-approval program in hopes of staving off more restrictive consumer legislation. The national wireless carriers -- Verizon Wireless, Cingular, Sprint PCS, Nextel and AT&T, along with numerous regional companies -- have agreed to adhere to a 10-part code of behavior that is intended to make it easier for consumers to compare prices and plans.

headline: Mexican Cellphone Provider Expanding in Latin America
summary: It dominates its home market in Mexico and now América Móvil, Latin America's largest provider of cellular phone service, is stretching its reach across the entire region, looking to extend its hegemony by snapping up assets from fleeing global companies. The Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim Helú, who controls the company as well as Mexico's fixed-line service, Teléfonos de Mexico, has a simple plan. Buy up companies at fire-sale prices from financially troubled companies like BellSouth and France Télécom, who are leaving a region plagued by economic instability. Then send in the cost-cutters to make them profitable.

headline: Snap a Photo And Ship It, Without Hanging Up
summary: The digital cameras on telephones are not just point-and-shoot numbers these days, and the VX6000 from LG is a case in point: it comes with zoom control and three different picture resolutions. Chatty shutterbugs can also add color and special effects to their photos and then e-mail them by way of a picture-messaging service recently started by Verizon Wireless. In addition to its 1x, 2x and 4x zoom and picture resolutions of 160 by 120 pixels, 320 by 240 pixels and 640 by 480 pixels, the LG VX6000 can take up to five photos in a row without interruption. Other features on the phone include a color screen, Web browsing and e-mail software, a built-in personal organizer and as much as three and a half hours of talk time on a battery charge. The VX6000 normally sells for $200, but Verizon Wireless is offering a $50 mail-in rebate until Oct. 13.

headline: Verizon and WB Join for Promotion
summary: Verizon Wireless is introducing its largest promotion with a television network to date, teaming with WB to encourage customers to use text messaging in a campaign that also includes commercials and product placements. The multimillion-dollar promotion, now under way, is centered on the third-season premiere of the WB series ''Smallville,'' which is scheduled for Oct. 1.

headline: Lara Bianchi, Lorin Wiener
summary: Lara Tomei Bianchi, the daughter of Arlene and Aldo Bianchi of Brooklyn, is to be married today to Lorin Russell Wiener, a son of Marilyn and Michael Wiener, also of Brooklyn. Judge Albert Tomei of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, who is an uncle of the bride, will officiate at the Picnic House in Prospect Park. Ms. Bianchi, 27, will keep her name. She graduated from Purchase College of the State University of New York and is a third-year law student at Brooklyn Law School. Her father is the director of public policy and external affairs at Verizon, the telecommunications company in Manhattan. Her mother retired as a history teacher at Kingsborough High School for the Sciences in Brooklyn.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Suit Is Dismissed
summary: Verizon Wireless was blocked yesterday in a bid to sue an official at the Communications Workers of America for using its advertising slogan during a conference call. Verizon Wireless had asserted that a union vice president violated an agreement by publicly using the phrase, ''Can you hear me now,'' a tagline used in Verizon advertising. Judge Mary Cooper of United States District Court in New Jersey threw out the case, the union said in a statement. Verizon Wireless is a joint venture of Verizon Communications and Vodafone Group.

headline: ARTS BRIEFING
