AT&T's decision to increase rates for most of its 4.7 million local phone customers comes less than two weeks after it decided not to seek new residential customers or to work to retain them.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths COUNES, EDNA PATRICIA KILCOYNE
summary: COUNES--Edna Patricia Kilcoyne. On July 9, Of Counes' Restaurant. Condolences to lesliersaul@verizon.net.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Microsoft And Verizon Wireless Plan Venture
summary: Microsoft, which is expanding its MSN Internet offerings to attract paying customers, will work with Verizon Wireless to sell an instant messaging and e-mail service on mobile phones. MSN Mobile will be available on three phones with Verizon's Get It Now technology for $2.49 a month for three months and $2.99 after that. Users can communicate with computers and cellphones using MSN's free Hotmail e-mail and MSN Messenger instant messaging programs, Microsoft said yesterday. Microsoft and Verizon, the nation's largest mobile phone operator, aim to increase sales by attracting customers who are buying Internet- and camera-enabled phones. The number of worldwide customers using mobile phones once a week for tasks other than phone calls will quadruple in the next year, according to the researcher, A.T. Kearney.

headline: Jennifer Linker, Adam Nadborny
summary: Jennifer Spanier Linker and Adam David Nadborny are to be married today. Rabbi Neil Zuckerman will officiate at the Woman's Club of White Plains. The bride and bridegroom received law degrees in May from the University of Virginia. Next month, they are to become associates at New York law firms, the bride at Simpson Thacher & Bartlett and the bridegroom at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.

headline: Logging On At 30,000 Feet
summary: IN late May, Ortwin Freyermuth readied himself for an 11-hour flight from Munich to his Los Angeles home -- a journey typically preceded by a flurry of last-minute e-mail messages, in anticipation of a day's worth of traveling incommunicado. This time, though, Mr. Freyermuth eased onto his Lufthansa flight less harried than on previous trips. When his plane reached cruising altitude, he opened up his iBook, logged onto the Internet and answered messages from 30,000 feet.

headline: SQUARE FEET/Downtown Brooklyn; At Site Dodgers Rejected, Target Store Is a Hit
summary: IN the last week of July, on a steamy evening, Sandra Bernhard was holding forth in downtown Brooklyn at the new Target, entertaining the hundreds of guests who had come to celebrate the store's opening. It was a significant moment for a number of reasons. The Target is part of the Atlantic Terminal, a new mall built by Forest City Ratner. It is expected to provide millions in new tax revenue and upgrade the quality of the other stores in the area.

headline: Lowe weighs bringing in another outsider to help it regain its financial and creative footing.
summary: THE makeover of Lowe & Partners Worldwide, the struggling division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, could accelerate as the agency considers hiring a well-known senior executive from Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group, for a new post. Lowe, under pressure to regain its footing after a spate of high-profile account losses, may soon bring in Tony Wright, the chief strategy and planning officer at Ogilvy in New York, to take a high-level post under Jerry Judge, the Lowe chairman and chief executive. The post being discussed would place Mr. Wright, 43, in line to succeed Mr. Judge at some point.

headline: Trump Must Ante Up $55 Million To Hold On to 25% of His Casino
summary: As Donald J. Trump's publicly traded casino company, Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts, goes into a bankruptcy reorganization, Mr. Trump has to invest $55 million of his money in the enterprise to maintain a large ownership stake. But does he have it?

headline: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Four Charged In Pay-Phone Theft Scheme
summary: Four Bronx men, including a coin box collector for Verizon, were charged yesterday in a scheme to steal more than $50,000 in nickels, dimes and quarters from the telephone company's pay phones. The Bronx district attorney, Robert T. Johnson, said the Verizon employee, Mario Colon, 35, repeatedly siphoned coins from the telephones he serviced into canvas bags, and transferred the bags to the other men before driving his company truck back to the Verizon garage. Edison Burgos, 32, Raphael Burgos, 31, and Louis Ortis, 30, were also charged with grand larceny. Mr. Johnson said that the charges covered thefts by the four men since April, and that they were ''suspected of having engaged in this criminal conduct for many years, costing Verizon hundreds of thousands of dollars.'' Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

headline: In No Mood for Chatting? Send a Video Instead
summary: Those digital cameras on wireless phones are not standing still anymore. The new LG VX7000 wireless phone is among the new breed of video-enabled handsets that can take 15-second movies as well as still photos and send them by e-mail, making it easy and quick to share your video of the new puppy or the baby doing something cute. The folding phone features color screens on the inside and outside of the handset and can send and receive multimedia messages containing text, photos and sound. It works with the Verizon Wireless service and includes a personal organizer, room for 500 contacts in the address book and four megabytes of space for games, ring tones and other programs. The VX7000 is compatible with Verizon's optional Mobile Web 2.0 service, which delivers software updates and other information directly to the phone.

headline: A Wi-Fi Thief Unmasked: Guess It's Time to Move On
summary: A FEW weeks ago, after a refreshing twilight swim in the community pool, I returned to my apartment in downtown Los Angeles, opened my Apple iBook, and fired up the browser, ready for some high-speed urban surfing. Instead of my usual home page, what appeared on the screen was an unfriendly looking digital blockade bearing the Verizon logo. It read, as snippily as text can sound, ''Please enter your 10-digit evening contact telephone number that you provided when ordering your Internet service, or your Login Code. (No spaces or hyphens.)'' Annoyed, I typed in my own Web address, and then another, and another. Each time, the browser refused to budge.

headline: Accounts
summary: Sprint, Overland Park, Kan., expanded its relationship with Publicis & Hal Riney, San Francisco, part of the Publicis Groupe, by consolidating at the agency all its general advertising, aimed at consumers and at businesses. The consolidation was made by awarding Riney the local consumer part of the account, which had been handled most recently by McCann Erickson Worldwide, New York, part of the McCann Erickson Worldgroup unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Billings were not disclosed for the assignment, which McCann resigned when it was recently awarded the Verizon Wireless account. ConAgra Foods, Omaha, expanded its relationship with Leo Burnett USA, Chicago, awarding the agency its Pam cooking spray account, with billings estimated at $10 million to $15 million. ConAgra placed the account in review after parting ways with Fogarty Klein Monroe, Dallas. Burnett, part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide division of the Publicis Groupe, also creates campaigns for ConAgra brands like Chef Boyardee and Healthy Choice.

headline: Man Dies in Fall From 5th Floor While Fleeing Police in Harlem
summary: A man fell to his death from a fifth-floor window in Harlem on Wednesday after leading police officers with a search warrant on a 30-minute chase across rooftops and through strangers' apartments, the police said yesterday. The man, 27 years old, whose name was not disclosed, was alone in a vacant apartment under renovation when he fell, the police said.

headline: URBAN STUDIES/Serving; Where Few Dare Stir Except to Mix In the Sugar
summary: JUST after the Penthouse Club has closed for the evening, and before the drivers of New York are awake enough to honk their horns, Asif Raja is well into his workday. Raja, as he likes to be called, owns the Quick Stop Cafe, the formal name for a street cart oasisof caffeine and carbohydrates on 11th Avenuenear 43rd Street in the farthest reaches of Hell's Kitchen.

headline: A Texas Race For the House Or the F.C.C.?
summary: Becky Armendariz Klein is widely expected to lose her bid for Congress in Texas. But that has not stopped executives and lawyers from the nation's largest telephone and energy companies from pouring money into her campaign. Indeed, some of her strongest supporters expect her to fail.

headline: Verizon and Qwest Ask Court to Overturn F.C.C.'s Price Freeze
summary: Verizon Communications Inc. and Qwest Communications International Inc. asked a federal court yesterday to overturn the government's decision to freeze prices paid by competitors for use of local-telephone networks. The Federal Communications Commission last week ordered companies including Verizon, Qwest, the BellSouth Corporation and SBC Communications Inc. to maintain for six months discounted rental rates charged to the AT&T Corporation, MCI Inc. and other telephone companies. The regulations requiring the discounts expired in June after a federal appeals court ruled them illegal.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Mondavi Family to Reduce Control of Wine Company The Robert Mondavi Corporation, which was founded by Robert Mondavi, left, in 1966, has proposed a recapitalization that would reduce the family's control of the wine business. The company also took the first step to separate its wine into luxury and everyday wines. Among its luxury wines is Opus One, which it produces in partnership with Baron Philippe Rothschild. Its Woodbridge line and midpriced wines under the Mondavi name fall into the everyday category. The announcement strengthens speculation that one or both parts of the company may be up for sale. [Page C3.]

headline: One Way to Get Online: Piggyback
summary: ABOUT to begin graduate school, Radha Patel needed a high-speed Internet connection at her Brooklyn apartment. She turned first to her cable company, only to encounter weeks of technical and bureaucratic hurdles. Then she turned to her neighbors.

headline: A Boom Along the Border
summary: Yoshiro Takemoto walks swiftly through the Panasonic factory, showing off the improvements being made to produce the latest generation of flat-panel digital televisions. New automated equipment for wiring electronic circuit boards hums away. Japanese-style work teams collaborate to assemble plasma screens. Mr. Takemoto, the president of Panasonic's North American television manufacturing operations, tracks all his components on intricate charts covering the walls of a conference room.

headline: AT&T Uses Its Long Past To Promote Its Near Future
summary: AT&T may be your grandma's phone company, but it is also trying to be the company of the future with its Internet phones. Even as it is getting out of the business of providing traditional phone service to consumers, AT&T is aggressively pushing its Internet phone plan, CallVantage, in hopes of making up for its faltering long-distance operation.

headline: From Wireless To Wire Maker
summary: As someone on the losing side when the telecommunications bubble burst, Stephen Carter no longer worries about trying to build the world's biggest wireless phone company. Instead, he is busily selling cables. ''It's different being out of the consumer side,'' said Mr. Carter, 51, former chairman and chief executive of Cingular Wireless. He moved from Cingular in 2002 and was named a vice president of SBC Communications, the wireless company's parent. But he quit and is now chief executive of Superior Essex Inc. in Atlanta, which makes wire and cable for telecom and other industries.

headline: For Now, Unwired Means Unlisted. That May Change.
summary: Sterling Wilson cannot find his old friends. Mr. Wilson, 25, who grew up in Southern California and now lives in the state capital of Sacramento, has been trying to make contact with childhood chums. He figures that the ones he has not tracked down must have cellphones, but he has no idea where to look up their numbers. It is not like the old days.

headline: At Last, Mobile Phone Plans That Connect (Almost) Anywhere on Earth to Any Place
summary: The model Naomi Campbell and the saxophonist Kenny G are his clients. So are pop bands like Earth, Wind & Fire and the soccer star David Beckham and his wife, Victoria. And if there is one thing that the publicist Mark Young has learned about the celebrities he represents, it is that they want to be able to talk to him at any time of the day or night no matter where they are, be it on the set between gigs, their private jets or the ski slopes of Aspen. That used to be a problem when he was traveling overseas. No more.

headline: In Internet Calling, Skype Is Living Up to the Hype
summary: HOW big a deal will Skype turn out to be? I have no idea whether the company itself, which was founded one year ago, will someday come to epitomize and dominate a particular booming business, the way Google, eBay and Amazon now do. But I feel confident that the service it provides will be attractive to most people who give it a serious look. Skype, a made-up term that rhymes with ''tripe,'' is the most popular and sexiest application of VoIP, which doesn't rhyme with anything. VoIP -- sometimes pronounced letter by letter, like C.I.A., and at other times as a word -- stands for voice over Internet protocol. Essentially, it is a way of allowing a computer with a broadband connection to serve as a telephone.

headline: Can You Hear Me Now?
summary: THREE years ago this week, when terrorists attacked, many New Yorkers found themselves unable to make a telephone call. Cellphone networks were clogged or went down, and many people lost even land-line service at home or in the office. Telephone communication was gridlocked except for pay phones, which became our lifelines. Now, even as we improve preparedness in sophisticated ways, we are overlooking a major security failure -- keeping the pay-phone network handy and reliable. Indeed, that true-blue backup phone system may be in worse shape than it was on 9/11.

headline: Trading In His Playbook for Operatic Scores
summary: MORRIS ROBINSON, a 330-pound ode to the quirky rewards of a bidisciplinary lifestyle, is luxuriating on his black leather sofa, his brown eyes fixated on a televised football highlights show while the operatic strains of Mozart's ''Magic Flute'' float into his ears via his trusty Bose headphones. The football show is his eye candy; his ears are doing their homework. He removes the headphones to indulge a visitor intent on finding out why this brawny, budding opera star is providing the soundtrack for tomorrow's ceremony at ground zero marking the third anniversary of 9/11, but the TV stays on. Given a choice between an opera and a football game, he confesses to opting for the latter. Good thing his employer, the Metropolitan Opera, sees no virtue in micromanaging his leisure hours. Once a jock, always a jock; this one just happens to sing like an angel with a bottomless voice.

headline: Sounds of a Silent Place; An Audio Walking Tour of the World Trade Center, With Stops for Eulogies
summary: The World Trade Center did not go up or come down quietly. And even when it was standing, it moaned and creaked. Shortly after the towers fell three years ago today, Davia Nelson and Nikki Silva, also known as the Kitchen Sisters, the creators of National Public Radio's Lost and Found Sound (a project to save the sound artifacts of various places and times, like Route 66 and the whole 20th century), set up an NPR phone line for people to call in with their audio memories of the World Trade Center. They also asked Verizon to save the phone calls made to and from the towers on Sept. 11.

headline: A Stodgy Style, But BellSouth Starts to Loosen Its Top Button
summary: The executives at the BellSouth Corporation, the nation's third-largest regional phone company, are not ones for hyperbole. Blue suits and button-down shirts are de rigueur at the company's unassuming headquarters. While rivals often make grandiose claims about their expansion plans, BellSouth's brass likes phrases like ''three yards and a pile of dust,'' a reference to football teams that methodically plow their way down the field.

headline: Barbarians At the Digital Gate
summary: KARSTEN M. SELF, who oversees a children's computer lab at a youth center in Napa, Calif., spends about a half-hour each morning electronically scanning 10 PC's. He is searching for files and traces of code that threaten to hijack the computers by silently monitoring the children's online activities or by plastering their screens with dizzying -- and nearly unstoppable -- onslaughts of pop-up advertisements. To safeguard the children's computers, Mr. Self has installed a battery of protective software products and new Web browsers. That has kept some -- but by no means all -- of the youth center's digital intruders at bay. ''You would expect that you could use these systems in a safe and sane way, but the fact of the matter is that you can't unless you have a fair amount of knowledge, time to fix the problems and paranoia,'' he said.

headline: Executives Say MCI Is Looking For Buyers
summary: MCI, the troubled telecommunications company, has quietly begun shopping itself to potential buyers, executives involved in the sale process said yesterday. MCI, which emerged from bankruptcy protection in April, has hired three investment banks, Lazard, Greenhill & Company and J.P. Morgan Chase, as well as the law firm Davis Polk & Wardwell, to help advise it and canvass for buyers, the executives said.

headline: They're Coming Through the Vents! Attack of the Subway Cellphones
summary: A middle-aged businessman in a gray suit clicked open his cellphone on a recent morning and started talking. ''Yes. Uh-huh. O.K. Tell Bill I'll call him as soon as I get to the office.'' He was completing a simple procedure that plays out countless times each day in New York. But with one noticeable difference: the man was riding the No. 9 train from Chambers Street to Franklin Street. In a city overrun with cellphones, where people are forever chattering on the street, in restaurants, in movie theaters or anywhere their little bars flash full reception, the subway has remained a kind of underground sanctum. What a joy it can be to know that at least for the duration of a subway ride there will be no ringing, no squawking, no unnecessary conversations that begin: ''I'm at Eighth Street and Broadway. Where are you?''

headline: Microsoft Asks Appeals Court In Europe to Delay Punishment
summary: Microsoft, seeking to stave off legal sanctions aimed at hindering its ability to dominate markets for desktop media players and server software, warned a European appeals court on Thursday that software developers and consumers would face dire consequences should it be penalized. Speaking at the start of a two-day hearing before the European Court of First Instance, Microsoft's general counsel, Brad Smith, asked the court to delay until the end of the appeals process moves aimed at forcing the company to change its practices drastically. That process is expected to last at least two years.

headline: Almost Here: Cellphones at 37,000 Feet
summary: ''Did you get it?'' I whispered to the guy on 43rd Street. ''Mrruzzichwatzlbzft,'' he replied.

headline: Justices Uphold 'Do Not Call' Registry
summary: The United States Supreme Court yesterday turned away an appeal by a telemarketing trade group and refused to question the national ''do not call'' registry, which bars unsolicited sales calls to more than 63 million phone numbers. The justices, in a one-line order, let stand a federal appeals court's conclusion that the registry does not violate the free-speech rights of companies seeking to market their products by telephone.

headline: The Journey From Renter to Landlord
summary: DINA CALHOUN will soon switch roles from renter to landlord -- a transformation she holds as sort of a mission. Ms. Calhoun, an administrative clerk for Verizon Communications, has run the rental gantlet -- six apartments in 24 years. Eventually, a generous landlady in Brooklyn helped make it possible for Ms. Calhoun, a single mother of three, to buy a two-family home in Jamaica, Queens, with the prospect of her rental income covering most of her mortgage costs.

headline: In Pitch to Older Customers, Static for Cellphone Industry
summary: Having equipped most adults and half of all teenagers with cellphones, the mobile phone industry is turning its attention to the last untapped demographic -- people over 65. But its dreams of collecting monthly subscription fees from grandparents talking to their grandchildren, retirees calling friends from their recreational vehicles or patients checking in with their doctors may exact a hefty and unexpected price. The mobile phone industry has roused the interest of AARP, the powerful lobby and advocacy group for older Americans.

headline: Phone Line Alchemy: Copper Into Fiber
summary: Rick Montey and his two-worker crew want to present a new image of the local phone company: prompt, friendly and hands-on helpful. At the home of T.J. Smith here in this Fort Worth suburb, Mr. Montey helped choose an inconspicuous spot to bore a small hole through the side of the house for the fiber optic line that would enable Mr. Smith's son to download big computer files quickly for his graphic-design work and let his granddaughter pull video clips off the Internet.

headline: F.C.C. Approves Internet Access On Power Lines
summary: Clearing the way for homes and businesses to receive high-speed Internet services through their electrical outlets, the Federal Communications Commission adopted rules on Thursday that would enable the utility companies to offer an alternative to the broadband communications services now provided by cable and phone companies. As a further spur to the rollout of broadband Internet services, the F.C.C. also ruled that the regional Bell companies do not have to give competitors access to fiber optic lines that reach into consumers' home -- a decision that prompted two of the Bells, SBC Communications and BellSouth, to announce that they would move quickly to build new fiber optic networks in residential neighborhoods. The ruling was criticized by rivals of the Bells and consumer groups, which called it anticompetitive and said it would lead to higher prices.

headline: Disney Rethinks a Staple: Family Films but Decidedly Not Rated G
summary: When the Walt Disney Company's ''National Treasure'' arrives in theaters on Nov. 19, it will tell the story of an adventurer, played by Nicolas Cage, on a hunt for riches, with clues hidden in pieces of Americana, like the back of the Declaration of Independence and the weird images on a dollar bill. Mr. Cage's mission is not unlike that of Disney, which hopes ''National Treasure'' will help crack the code for a new, edgier kind of family entertainment that is meant to become the hallmark of its cherished Walt Disney Pictures brand. Previous Walt Disney films typically relied on youths on screen, as in ''Heavyweights,'' ''Freaky Friday'' and ''The Princess Diaries.''

headline: Earnings Surge at Lucent; Year Is the Best Since 2000
summary: Lucent Technologies said yesterday that profit in its latest quarter more than tripled compared with the period a year earlier, helping the company post its first annual profit in four years. Lucent, the nation's largest telecommunications equipment maker, and its rivals have benefited from third-generation mobile phone networks that carriers are installing throughout the world. The company, based in Murray Hill, N.J., has also taken advantage of the increase in spending on optical fiber networks and the services to maintain them.

headline: Verizon to Extend Fiber Optics To Parts of Six Eastern States
summary: Verizon Communications, the nation's largest regional phone company, announced plans yesterday to start introducing fiber-optic connections for residential phone and data services in six Eastern states. The company, which has been installing its new high-speed lines in parts of Texas, California and Florida, will extend its construction to parts of Virginia, Delaware, Maryland, Massachusetts, New York and Pennsylvania.

headline: SQUARE FEET/One Washington Park, Newark; The Revival Talk Just Won't Die
summary: AN investment group led by Marc E. Berson recently closed on a major office building in the north end of Newark's business district, paying $26.5 million for the 17-story 400,000-square-foot structure. It was an unlikely investment, since the building has sat almost vacant since its principal tenant, Verizon, pulled out about a year ago, and the city's office vacancy rate hovers around 15 percent. But Mr. Berson thinks Newark is on the verge of a major revival -- one that has been talked about for a long time, but which has been very slow in happening. Now, however, several development and infrastructure projects are under way or in advanced planning that could capitalize on Newark's excellent transportation links to bring a new generation of people to live and work in the city.

headline: Phone companies are delivering the results of a successful turnaround. Investors, however, are not impressed.
summary: FOUR years after the collapse of the Internet bubble, phone companies and equipment makers are finally producing steady profits. But their turnaround has failed to impress investors, who have lingering doubts about the industry's outlook. The reasons for hesitancy are many, but they boil down to this: Growth in the next-generation services and wireless products now being offered by phone companies only partly makes up for the declines in their older, traditional phone businesses.

headline: Approval Expected Today for Big Cellphone Deal
summary: Federal regulators will formally approve Cingular Wireless's $41 billion purchase of AT&T Wireless today, company officials briefed on the matter said over the weekend. In approving the deal, analysts said that the Justice Department and the Federal Communications Commission would demand that Cingular give up some of its spectrum licenses, among other steps, to ease concerns that the new company would possess too much market dominance.

headline: With F.C.C. Consent, Cingular Buys AT&T Wireless
summary: Cingular Wireless completed its purchase of AT&T Wireless yesterday after the Federal Communications Commission signed off on the $41 billion deal that creates the country's largest mobile phone provider. The F.C.C. approval came a day after authorization from the Justice Department, which required that Cingular sell some of its spectrum licenses in Detroit and Dallas, as well as some AT&T Wireless spectrum licenses and operations in 16 markets.

headline: When wireless networks merge, so do their promotional campaigns.
summary: AFTER an intense marketing blitz beginning tonight, anyone left unaware that Cingular Wireless is acquiring and absorbing AT&T Wireless may have been too busy talking on the phone to pay attention. Now that its $41 billion takeover of AT&T Wireless has been approved by regulators and completed, Cingular, based in Atlanta, will spend hundreds of millions of dollars in coming weeks on its campaign.

headline: Fair or Stormy Weather Ahead? Phone Alerts Let You Know
summary: Your cellphone could be promoted to weather forecaster if you use the subscription-free weather alerts offered by the Weather Channel and the Mobile Media Company. After sending a text message to 4CAST (42278) containing a ZIP code or city name, a user will receive from the service a return message with a localized 36-hour weather report for 75 cents a message, plus whatever carrier fees apply.

headline: New Round of Cuts at SBC Will Eliminate 10,000 Jobs
summary: SBC Communications, the nation's second-largest telephone company, will eliminate 10,000 jobs by the end of next year, according to a filing made yesterday with securities regulators. The cuts will amount to 6.1 percent of SBC's work force of 165,000 employees and will come through attrition and layoffs, the company said. They come on top of 7,000 jobs SBC plans to cut this year as well.

headline: Dollar Skids, Despite Stock Rally and a Strong Jobs Report
summary: The dollar skidded to a record low against the euro yesterday, despite a surprisingly strong jobs report for October and another rally in the stock market, which has posted gains every day since the election. The surge in stocks after the jobs report signaled a shift from the post-election bounce and the beginning of the return of investor focus to economic fundamentals, said Bob Froehlich, chief investment strategist at Deutsche Asset Management.

headline: Verizon Wireless Will Pay $3 Billion for Additional Capacity
summary: Verizon Wireless said yesterday that it would pay $3 billion in cash for the spectrum licenses owned by NextWave Telecom, a move that should help it expand coverage for new subscribers. The extra licenses will give Verizon Wireless, the country's second-largest mobile phone provider, room to grow in 23 markets, including New York, Boston, Washington and Los Angeles. An aggregate of 73 million people live in these markets.

headline: Ignorance Is No Obstacle
summary: There was a time when students taking the SAT needed only two things: a sharpened No. 2 pencil and steady nerves. That day is long gone. Over the years, the SAT has generated a test-preparation industry that lives off the Educational Testing Service -- creators of the test for the College Board -- the way that tick birds live off the back of a rhino. A bewildering profusion of products and services promise desperate students that they can learn the secrets of the test and raise their scores. Help comes in the form of books -- some as thick as the telephone directory of a major city -- hand-held computers, compact discs, online tutoring services and face-to-face classes. The impending arrival of the new SAT has thrown the test-prep industry into a frenzy, inspiring a slew of revised test-prep products and a welter of snazzy new electronic games and devices. Eager to survey this amazing growth industry, I sat down and, for the first time in my life, studied for the SAT. Night after night, surrounded by dozens of helpers, print and electronic, I worked my way though sentence completions, vocabulary tests, word problems and algebraic equations that I had not a prayer of being able to solve. Integer. The word sounded vaguely familiar. It was like hearing the name of an old high-school classmate. Didn't he use to hang out with sine, cosine and tangent? Impossible to remember at this late date, which is tragic, since the new SAT has muscled up the math section with advanced algebra and geometry.

headline: Forgoing subtlety, Verizon Wireless makes a direct and personal appeal to its top rival's subscribers.
summary: THE purchase of AT&T Wireless by Cingular Wireless is just a few weeks old and already the company is under attack from its biggest rival, Verizon Wireless, which is trying to recapture the top spot in the cellphone industry. Verizon Wireless started an advertising campaign yesterday in the Northeast that takes aim at customers of AT&T Wireless. In a series of advertisements in regional newspapers, Verizon Wireless plays up the potential for discord at the newly merged Cingular, and invites dissatisfied customers of AT&T Wireless to jump ship.

headline: Even for Thrift Stores, Harder Times
summary: IN its new home in a former Fauchon pastry shop on the Upper East Side, the Arthritis Thrift Shop is posting the best sales in its 50-year history, and no one could be more relieved than its director, Joe Moore. The store brought in $91,500 in October selling cast-off furs, Chanel-style suits and enough gently used designer shoes to outfit the cast of ''Sex and the City'' for weeks. The shop, at 1383 Third Avenue, could approach $1 million in revenue in 2005 if business keeps up. The money benefits the New York chapter of the Arthritis Foundation.

headline: The Banks of the Gowanus Put the Gleam in a Builder's Eye
summary: There is a strange beauty to sunset on the Gowanus Canal, when the blue film on the surface of the notorious waterway catches the sunlight streaming past the elevated trains at just the right angle. For a second, an optimistic visitor can ignore the pungent aroma and the odd plastic bag floating by -- after all, the waterway is much cleaner than it was a few years ago -- and begin to imagine staying awhile. Such a visitor might enjoy living in Gowanus Village, a collection of loft buildings and townhouses on the east bank of the canal that, at the moment, exists only in a few developers' imaginations. But to the chagrin of opponents, and one of the developers, the proposal recently slipped into view.

headline: SBC to Start Project to Send TV Over Lines
summary: SBC Communications, as part of its effort to compete head-on with the cable industry for television subscribers, plans to announce today that it will pay $400 million to Microsoft for software used to deliver TV programming over high-speed data lines. It would be a crucial move into unproven territory for SBC, which like the other regional telephone giants wants to grow by expanding beyond phone and Internet services and into entertainment. To do that, SBC expects to spend more than $4 billion over the next three years on its fiber optic network to offer faster Internet connections able to carry digital video programming.

headline: Cingular defends itself against a Verizon ad campaign with some tough talk of its own.
summary: MOVE over, Coke and Pepsi, here come Cingular Wireless and Verizon Wireless. The cellphone rivals have been jostling for consumers' attention since Cingular bought AT&T Wireless last month to leapfrog over Verizon into the industry's top spot. Last week, Verizon advertisements invited unhappy AT&T Wireless subscribers to jump ship by suggesting that Cingular will be plagued by service problems as a result of the merger.

headline: Figuring The Cost Of Being Mobile
summary: FOR those who use cellphones only for talking, a five-year-old black brick will still work fine. Aside from sexier design, the appeal of a new phone is its unspoken abilities. Even most entry-level models allow notes to other phones using a technology called short message service. Much as e-mail can substitute for phone calls, SMS messages like ''u get it?'' are replacing cellphone conversations. An increasing number of phones also offer multimedia messaging service, or MMS, for adding photos or video clips to messages sent to other phones or to online photo storage sites.

headline: Forced to Work Off the Clock, Some Fight Back
summary: Soon after Trudy LeBlue began working at the new SmartStyle hair salon outside New Orleans, her salon manager began worrying that business was too slow and profits were too weak. To keep costs down, Ms. LeBlue said, the manager often ordered her and the two other stylists to engage in a practice, long hidden, that appears to have spread to many companies: working off the clock.

headline: The Week Ahead
summary: SMALL CHANGE -- Some consumers will receive a rare commodity in their phone bills: an honest to goodness rate rollback, albeit one measured in dimes. Beginning with its billing cycle next week, Verizon Wireless will eliminate a 40-cent monthly fee to cover the costs associated with a rule, enacted a year ago, allowing customers to keep their phone numbers when switching service providers. Responding in part to Sprint, which cut a similar fee to 25 cents from 40 cents, Verizon, the nation's second-largest mobile phone carrier, will forgo $15 million a month. Dimes add up when you have more than 40 million customers. GOING NUCLEAR -- The future, it appears, is going to be a tough place to get to. A consortium of countries, including members of the European Union, along with South Korea, Japan, China, the United States and Russia, has been working on a futuristic fusion reactor that will be three decades and about $10 billion in the making. But creating a clean and everlasting source of energy may be simple compared to figuring out where to build the reactor. Beginning Thursday, the European Union members will meet to discuss how to convince the other partners that France should be the host country, as Russia and China are reported to favor.

headline: Cable's Rivals Lure Customers With Packages
summary: For years, consumers who wanted to cut the cord with their cable company found that getting television and high-speed Internet service often meant the inconvenience of finding two new providers. That's now changing. Cable's two hungry rivals -- phone companies and satellite providers -- are stealing cable's disgruntled customers with cheaper all-in-one packages that bundle TV with Internet and phone services.

headline: When Curtain Rises on Property Disputes, It Helps to Have a Program
summary: LAND use battles -- development, design, planning, zoning and landmarks -- offer some of the best theater in New York City. The problem has been the lack of a playbill. Until last month, there was no comprehensive, timely guide to the workings of all of the arms of government involved in land use: the Board of Standards and Appeals, the Buildings Department, the City Council, the City Planning Commission and the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

headline: A Burglary Foiled by Calls That Didn't Reach 911
summary: The plan seemed simple enough. The building had been cased and the burglars knew exactly what they wanted -- advanced computer circuit panels that could be sold on the black market for hundreds of thousands of dollars. The night before Thanksgiving, about 8 p.m., they entered the Verizon building in White Plains undetected and set to work.

headline: Internet Access, Delivered From Above
summary: Jeff Thompson may be afraid of heights, but he appears to be at home on the 81st-floor terrace of the Empire State Building. Overlooking the 1,000-foot drop, Mr. Thompson said he saw the entire New York metropolitan area as the battleground where his company, TowerStream, will challenge phone companies for high-speed Internet business customers by delivering fast, cheap service without digging up streets to install cables.

headline: Should Your PC Be Your Telephone?
summary: WITH e-mail and instant messaging, the Internet has already changed the way people communicate, but the technology it threatens most directly is the telephone. Among the attractions of Internet telephone service, already in an estimated 600,000 households nationwide, are inexpensive, often unlimited local and long-distance calling plans and less red tape when compared to conventional phone service. In addition, many of the Internet phone providers have rolled out new features and options made possible by the decentralized nature of Internet technology.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Case On Cable as Internet Carrier
summary: The Supreme Court on Friday stepped into one of the most heated debates over the future of the Internet: how to classify high-speed Internet cable service for purposes of federal regulation and, ultimately, for the question of whether competing Internet service providers are entitled to use the cable companies' networks to reach their subscribers. The justices accepted appeals filed by the Bush administration and the cable industry from a federal appeals court decision that struck down large portions of a deregulatory order issued by the Federal Communications Commission in 2002. The order freed companies that provide cable modem service of the obligation that federal law places on providers of ''telecommunications services'' to open their networks to their competitors.

headline: LIVING IN/The Nyacks, N.Y.; A Trio of Villages Hugging the Hudson
summary: DRIVING down Main Street on the way to a family gathering two years ago, Matt Koke and Bobby Belfry were quickly won over by the Nyacks' charms: the Hudson River views, the wood-frame homes with welcoming front porches, and the profusion of restaurants and galleries in the downtown business district. They were so smitten with the villages of Nyack, Upper Nyack and South Nyack, in Rockland County, 25 miles north of New York City, that they decided to leave their apartment in Astoria, Queens, and become suburbanites.

headline: A Library and Cinema in Your Pocket
summary: One day before too long, when your mobile telephone sounds, it could be a novel calling to recount how the headstrong heroine dumped the handsome heartbreaker. Or it might be a guidebook surfacing at a critical moment in a crowded bar to provide you with pickup lines in Spanish, French or German. The increasing power of cellphones is fast shaping innovative forms of compact culture: micro-lit, phone soap operas and made-for-mobile dramas that can be absorbed in less time than it takes to flick through a book introduction.

headline: Nextel Said To Be in Talks With Sprint
summary: Nextel Communications is in advanced talks to merge with the Sprint Corporation, according to executives involved in the negotiations. The deal would form the third largest cellphone company in the nation, with 39 million wireless subscribers. A deal could be reached as early as next week if the talks continue apace. In the meantime, the talks may bring to the game a third player, Verizon Wireless, which held several internal conference calls yesterday to discuss the possibility of making a run at Sprint, executives close to Verizon Wireless said.

headline: Sprint Is Near $34 Billion Deal To Buy Nextel
summary: Sprint is near a deal to acquire Nextel Communications for more than $34 billion in a transaction that would further consolidate the rapidly changing telecommunications industry, according to executives involved in the negotiations. The deal comes as the mobile phone industry faces fierce new market pressures, with competitors seeking to keep and attract customers who can jump easily from one operator to another.

headline: In U.S. Market, Cellphone Users Are Often All Talk
summary: One of the most popular new cellphones this holiday season is the Razr, an ultrathin model that stresses style over services. That is good news for Motorola, which makes the Razr, but bad news for wireless carriers that are spending billions of dollars to build high-speed networks in the hopes that their customers will do more than just talk. Carriers like Cingular Wireless and Verizon Wireless are hoping that faster speeds will entice customers to use more data services -- trading photos, downloading songs and surfing the Internet on their handsets. Such services can add more than $10 a month to subscribers' bills and help defray the cost of the extra voice minutes that carriers are offering customers to keep them from jumping to competitors.

headline: A Flier Confesses: Jet Lag Made Me Do It
summary: Oh, I'm good. When this year ends, I will have traveled just over 200,000 miles by air, domestically and internationally. I always get to the airport two hours early, boarding pass and ID in hand. I never set off the magnetometer. I drink lots of water, seldom check bags, sleep on long flights and, on my return trip, transfer to an airport hotel to make sure I'm in good position to drop off my rental car, hop the shuttle and settle into the lounge to await boarding an early flight. I flew nonstop on a flight of 181/2 hours to Singapore on Singapore Airlines this year. And I almost never get jet lag.

headline: Latest Merger Would Recast Cellular's Face Once Again
summary: For most of its two decades on the American landscape, the cellphone industry has been known for its freewheeling upstarts and aggressive competition. Yet in just a few years, a wave of mergers has left the industry dominated by a handful of giant companies, with smaller contenders having to carve out niche markets to survive. The industry was further recast yesterday when Sprint and Nextel Communications -- two of the more distinctive and entrepreneurial mobile phone companies -- formally announced a merger that will create a formidable No.3 carrier. The new company, to be called Sprint Nextel, will join Cingular Wireless, which has 46 million subscribers, and Verizon Wireless, with 42 million, in an elite trio that will control three-quarters of the market.

headline: Big mergers in the mobile phone industry worry consumer groups, but industry specialists see no cause for concern.
summary: THE rapid consolidation in the mobile phone industry, as illustrated by last week's proposed merger of Nextel and Sprint and Cingular's recent acquisition of AT&T Wireless, raises a compelling question: With fewer carriers, has power in the industry shifted away from consumers? Conventional wisdom suggests that with fewer competitors, companies are under less pressure to cut prices and improve services, and that prices ultimately may rise. That's the line taken by many consumer advocacy groups.

headline: Sprint Will Offer A Radio Service That Plays Music Over Cellphones
summary: For those annoyed by people who seem to have a cellphone constantly held to their ears, count your blessings. It is about to get worse. Today, Sprint will offer a new reason, besides placing calls, for people to use their mobile phones. It will introduce a radio service that allows people to listen to music over their phones, whether through an earpiece or the phone itself.

headline: Want to Retire Early? Well, It May Take Some Work
summary: LYDIA POSNER was not considering retirement last year when Verizon offered her a buyout package. ''I always felt like I would work forever, so this was a very emotional decision for me,'' said Mrs. Posner, who was employed as a technical writer. ''I drove my husband and children crazy for six weeks talking about it, until my kids finally said, 'Mom, you worked for 31 years, you deserve this.''' Mrs. Posner was 56 when she retired in 2003. She is among the thousands of employees who have decided to call it quits in recent years after being offered buyout packages, which many companies have been turning to as an alternative to involuntary layoffs during cost cutting. Many other workers are quitting their jobs years before they qualify for Social Security payments, without the incentive of a buyout.

headline: Advertisers have a deep concern for the truth, especially when it comes to a rival's claims.
summary: MOST people do not think much about truth in advertising, especially when so many ads have so little to do with fact -- like the commercials for ''The Most Relaxing Classical Album in the World Ever!'' But Anheuser-Busch has shown an interest in ad accuracy lately, challenging commercials from not one but two other brewers as misleading.

headline: Coming in '05: Mobile Service From AT&T (Via Sprint)
summary: AT&T is expected to announce as soon as next week details about how it plans to offer mobile phone service using Sprint's cellular network, according to executives close to the companies. Sprint, which said earlier this year that it would work with AT&T to offer cellphone service to AT&T's business customers, is fast solidifying its position as the top reseller of telecommunications services. Because it is not affiliated with the regional Bell companies, it has been able to build a strong business as a wholesaler of network capacity to the Bells' rivals.

headline: Gaining Ground on the Wage Front
summary: Ever since the 2001 recession sent the economy into a prolonged period of weak hiring, hundreds of thousands of men and women have gone through some variation of Tom and Marie DeSisto's experience. Concerned that he might be laid off as Verizon cut staff, Mr. DeSisto, 54, accepted an early retirement package, giving up a manager's salary of more than $100,000 a year. Now he earns half that as a high school math teacher in Waltham, Mass., while Mrs. DeSisto, 50, brings home $63,000 as the supervisor of nurses in the same school district.

headline: Drugstores Fret as Insurers Demand Pills by Mail
summary: Employer health plans across the country are forcing millions of consumers to change their drug-buying habits. And one side effect could be the decline of the neighborhood drugstore. Instead of picking up their medicines at a local pharmacy, growing numbers of consumers will be required -- starting this month when new health plans take effect -- to buy dozens of widely used drugs, like insulin for diabetes or Lipitor to lower cholesterol, by mail order.

headline: Millrose Games Will Go On
summary: Speculation circulated this week that the Millrose Games, the showcase of American track and field, would not be held next month because the company that runs the meet could not find a title sponsor. Even people connected with the meet were unsure. But Paul Feller, the president and chief executive of Pro Sports and Entertainment, the Los Angeles company that runs the meet, said last night that the 98th annual Millrose Games would be held as scheduled, Feb. 4 at Madison Square Garden. Highlights will be shown Feb. 5 by NBC, he said.

headline: Young Cell Users Rack Up Debt, One Dime Message at a Time
summary: Chaz Albert, a freshman at Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., is a passionate ''texter,'' someone who loves to send and receive pithy text messages via cellphone. He does it at home, at school and at work. He often prefers texting over talking on his cellphone. Last month, though, Mr. Albert's habit caught up with him. Only $80 of his $400 cellphone charges were his father's, and most of his own, he said, were for text-messaging.

headline: On the Way; From the Show Floor: Bells, Whistles and Bluetooth
summary: FOR consumers who are not enthralled by the prospect of 3G services, the wireless industry has some other tricks up its sleeve. At the Consumer Electronics Show here, carriers and cellphone manufacturers showed off some of them. Samsung demonstrated the first two-megapixel camera phone available in the United States. The phone, the A800, takes still images and video clips and can handle 3D games. Available by March at a price to be determined, it works on CDMA networks operated by carriers like Sprint and Verizon Wireless.

headline: A New Crop of Handsets, Ready for What's Out There
summary: AS wireless carriers introduce new services like television and streaming music, cellphone manufacturers are coming out with the handsets needed to use them. The devices generally have larger, higher-quality color screens, cameras capable of taking higher-resolution still pictures and video clips, and better sound reproduction. Carriers are selling most of these handsets for a few hundred dollars after rebates, contingent on the user signing up for a one- or two-year service agreement.

headline: Verizon and Yahoo Team Up to Offer Broadband Service
summary: Verizon Communications, the nation's largest telecommunications company, said yesterday that it planned to work with Yahoo, the Internet search engine, to introduce a portal for its high-speed Internet service. The venture comes as competition for broadband customers between telephone and cable companies continues to heat up. Yahoo is also looking for ways to attract visitors to its Web sites and reduce its reliance on advertising revenue.

headline: Yahoo's Profit Soars in Quarter On Ad Spending and Investments
summary: After announcing a partnership with Verizon Communications to develop a portal for high-speed Internet services on Monday, Yahoo Inc. posted strong fourth-quarter profits yesterday, driven largely by strong advertising sales and a sizable windfall from sales of an investment. The company said it planned to extend its broadband presence in 2005 and to continue its international expansion through acquisitions of Web portal and search sites. The company drew 119 million unique visitors in December, more than any other site, according to comScore Networks, an Internet research firm.

headline: A Mystery Girl Who Comes From a Bad Family
summary: You know the forces of darkness are in full tilt when a mother tells her teenage daughter that she would look prettier with her hair in her face. The occult invades every high school dance and beach party on ''Point Pleasant,'' a new Fox series that is a steamy soap opera with a satanic subplot -- Motel 666.

headline: Shares Fall Amid Earnings That Analysts Call Mediocre
summary: Stocks fell yesterday as disappointing results from companies like Motorola and Lucent Technologies overshadowed economic data that showed declines in consumer prices. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 11.35 points, or 1 percent, to 1,184.63. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 88.82 points, or 0.8 percent, to 10,539.97. The Nasdaq composite index fell 32.45, or 1.5 percent, to 2,073.59.

headline: AT&T Profit 84% Higher In 4th Quarter
summary: AT&T, the nation's biggest long-distance carrier, said yesterday that its profit jumped a better-than-expected 84 percent in the fourth quarter as it cut costs. The company, based in Bedminster, N.J., earned $625 million, or 78 cents a diluted share, in the quarter, compared with $340 million, or 43 cents, in the quarter in 2003. Last year the company eliminated 11,200 jobs, or 23 percent of its work force, and it continues to automate large parts of its operations to reduce operating expenses.

headline: AT&T Looks Beyond 'Number, Please'
summary: For a century, AT&T was known as America's premier phone company. If Hossein Eslambolchi has his way, that label will go the way of the dodo bird. As chief technology and chief information officer, Mr. Eslambolchi is the technological strategist behind AT&T's ambitious turnaround plan to become a data transmission company selling an array of software products like network security systems -- with phone calls being just one of many digital services.

headline: Verizon, Seeking New Home Base, Is Said to Be Staying in New York
summary: Verizon Communications, which recently put its corporate headquarters up for sale and began shopping around the country for a potential new home, has decided to remain in New York after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg began an aggressive campaign to keep the company in the city, three people with knowledge of the agreement said. The company, which put its two-million-square-foot Midtown office tower on the block late last year, is continuing to look for a place -- almost certainly outside New York -- to consolidate the numerous parts of its operations peppered throughout the country.

headline: EarthLink in Phone Deal
summary: EarthLink, one of the country's largest Internet service providers, plans to announce today a $400 million joint venture with SK Telecom of South Korea to offer mobile phone service in the United States, said an executive close to the deal. EarthLink will sell phone service using the networks of Sprint and Verizon Wireless. SK Telecom, one of Korea's largest cellphone carriers, will be a technical partner in the venture. EarthLink and SK Telecom will each contribute $200 million to the deal, the executive said.

headline: SBC Said to Be in Talks to Buy AT&T
summary: SBC Communications, the second-largest regional phone company in the nation, is in talks to buy AT&T for more than $16 billion, according to executives close to the negotiations. A deal, if reached, would be the final chapter in the 120-year history of AT&T, the first technological giant of the modern age and the original model for telecommunications companies worldwide. A deal would be a reunion of sorts, putting back together some of the largest pieces of the Ma Bell telephone monopoly, which was broken up in 1984.

headline: Dial M for Merger
summary: If SBC Communications succeeds in buying its former parent, AT&T, the reunion of two players in the old Bell system could set off another round of mergers in the rapidly consolidating phone industry. In other industries, a dwindling number of players typically means fewer choices and higher prices for consumers. Yet in the telecommunications industry, technology is turning that logic on its head. Cellphones, high-speed Internet connections and video -- not plain old phone lines -- now determine the winners and losers in today's market. Cable providers and a host of new businesses that barely existed a few years ago can easily provide those services just as well as old-line phone companies.

headline: Verizon Seeks Coordination Of Downtown Street Work
summary: Verizon has warned public officials that telephone service downtown and the development timetable at the World Trade Center site may be in jeopardy unless government agencies better coordinate rebuilding efforts. ''There is a significant risk that the restoration projects planned for Lower Manhattan may be delayed and that telecommunications services, including emergency E-911 services to Lower Manhattan, may be again disrupted,'' said Stephen Lefkowitz of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, lawyers for Verizon, at a hearing on Wednesday before the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. (E-911 refers to the enhanced 911 system.)

headline: SBC Near Deal To Acquire AT&T For $16 Billion
summary: SBC Communications last night was close to concluding a $16 billion deal for its former parent, AT&T, that would lead to the virtual disappearance of one of America's best known corporate icons and set off what promises to be a new round of competition between the Baby Bells, executives close to the negotiations said. SBC's board approved the deal while AT&T executives met far into the night trying to reach an agreement.

headline: Not Just for Emergencies Anymore
summary: LONG after cellphones became an annoyance in movie theaters and restaurants, the incessant ringing turned up at an unexpected place: the Holiday Park Senior Center in Wheaton, Md., near Washington. It started about a year ago, when musical performances and lectures began to be interrupted regularly. The problem got so bad that the 600 people who come daily for various programs had to be reminded to turn off their phones.

headline: In Touch; When Friends Are Family
summary: Cellphone carriers market service packages that include several lines and a bundle of minutes for one price as family plans, but you don't have to be part of a family to take advantage of them. A group of unrelated people -- usually five at most -- can sign up for a family plan, as long as one person agrees to be responsible for the bill.

headline: Employers Unite in Effort to Curb Prescription Costs
summary: In a new strategy to rein in prescription drug costs, a group of 30 large employers has banded together to monitor the business practices of the middlemen drug buyers that most employers use to get discounts from pharmaceutical companies. The new group, called Rx Collaborative, to be announced today, is part of a stepped-up effort by employers across the country to cope with drug costs that have been rising 11 percent or more annually. National spending on drugs rose to an estimated total of $199 billion last year.

headline: For MCI, Qwest May Not Be Most Desirable
summary: Michael D. Capellas is at it again. As chief executive of Compaq, Mr. Capellas successfully engineered the sale of that troubled computer maker to Hewlett-Packard three years ago. Now, as chief executive of MCI, the big, challenged long-distance phone carrier, Mr. Capellas is in talks to sell the company to Qwest Communications, the smallest and weakest of the four Bell operating companies, for about $6 billion, according to industry executives.

headline: Shot-Put Event Is Shorter To Lift Millrose Appeal
summary: When Christian Cantwell and the rest of the shot-put competitors walk into Madison Square Garden tonight, they will be the rock stars of the Millrose Games. The rest of the events will pause. The spotlight will fall on a once-obscure event that has been retrofitted for a modern track meet. Four of the world's top throwers, who all happen to be American and who have all worked in their own ways to make their event a crowd-pleaser, will get four attempts each. In 16 minutes, a winner will be crowned to great fanfare.

headline: Sprint's Profits Rise With Wireless Demand
summary: The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit surged as growing demand for wireless calling lifted sales. Net income rose to $437 million, or 29 cents a share, from $110 million, or 8 cents, a year earlier, when profit was cut by costs for discarding a billing system. Sales rose 3.7 percent, to $6.93 billion, Sprint said.

headline: MCI and Qwest Still in Talks, But the Air Cools
summary: Merger talks between Qwest Communications and MCI cooled yesterday, though the two companies may still reach an agreement, according to people close to the negotiations. The companies could still reach a deal over the weekend, they said. But that prospect was less likely than earlier this week, when the companies appeared to be closing in on an agreement in a matter of days. It seems more likely that the companies will continue their discussions next week.

headline: Talks Between Qwest and MCI Seem at a Standstill
summary: As merger talks between Qwest and MCI remained stalled yesterday, telecommunications industry analysts began to wonder whether a deal might not be done. Such speculation was a factor in a decision by one analyst, Anthony F. Ferrugia of A.G. Edwards & Sons, to downgrade his rating on Qwest's stock to a sell from a hold.

headline: S.E.C. Rebuffs Investors on Board Votes
summary: Signaling a retreat, the Securities and Exchange Commission told three large companies on Monday that they could rebuff requests by institutional shareholders seeking the opportunity to nominate a small number of rivals for board seats. The decision by the staff of the commission, which officials said was not opposed by the S.E.C. chairman, William H. Donaldson, was seen as an unambiguous sign that an earlier proposal to open the proxies, or votes, to greater shareholder participation was dead.

headline: Insert Sound Effects (Arrr!) Into Phone Conversations (Waah!)
summary: First there were ring tones. Then came ringbacks. Now a San Francisco company, Phonebites, is betting that Razzes -- silly sound effects inserted into conversations -- will be the next cellphone craze. By allowing cellphone users to spike conversations with the sound of a baby crying or a Jerky Boys audio clip, Phonebites is hoping that its Razz software will open a new avenue in mobile entertainment.

headline: Whether They're Coming or Going, Deal Makers Are Well Paid
summary: The merger of Hewlett-Packard and Compaq Computer may not have fared so well, but the two executives who put it together have been handsomely rewarded anyway. Carleton S. Fiorina is walking away with a severance package of at least $21.1 million from Hewlett-Packard. The man who persuaded her to buy Compaq -- its former chief executive, Michael D. Capellas -- left with more than $15 million in cash and stock after a short stint as president of the merged company. And he could pocket another big paycheck if he succeeds in efforts to sell the company he is running now, the struggling telecommunications carrier MCI.

headline: Ebbers Avoided Verizon Deal, Trial Is Told
summary: Bernard J. Ebbers, the former chief executive of WorldCom, and his finance chief, Scott D. Sullivan, backed out of preliminary merger talks with Verizon Communications in 2001 to avoid having to open the company's books to outsiders, according to testimony yesterday from Mr. Sullivan. That summer, Mr. Sullivan said, he and Mr. Ebbers were in merger talks with their counterparts at Verizon Communications. But the two sides had not yet started a due diligence process that would have allowed Verizon to inspect WorldCom's confidential accounts. According to Mr. Sullivan, Verizon's chief executive, Ivan G. Seidenberg, had told Mr. Ebbers that he wanted to announce a deal before Labor Day.

headline: How to Stop Junk E-Mail: Charge for the Stamp
summary: COMPARE our e-mail system today with the British General Post Office in 1839, and ours wins. Compare it with the British postal system in 1840, however, and ours loses. In that year, the British introduced the Penny Black, the first postage stamp. It simplified postage -- yes, to a penny -- and shifted the cost from the recipient to the sender, who had to prepay. We look back with wonder that it could have ever been otherwise. Recipient pays? Why should the person who had not initiated the transaction be forced to pay for a message with unseen contents? What a perverse system.

headline: Is Labor Out in Front On Health Care?
summary: IT'S no secret that surging health costs have become a C.E.O.-level issue. When a company like General Motors looks more each year like a giant health plan that operates a nice little nonprofit car business on the side, who wouldn't sound the alarm? But to many business leaders, their union counterparts' view of soaring health costs remains a mystery. Given union readiness to strike in the face of even modest efforts to slim generous health plans, these costs almost certainly doom unionized workers to few if any real wage increases for years to come. Do union leaders get this trade-off? Are they hamstrung by political dynamics that make it hard to approve even sensible health plan changes that can be cast as ''givebacks''? And what is their answer?

headline: Phone Mergers May Curb Price Wars
summary: American corporations could see an end to the price war of recent years in telephone and Internet services as a result of the sudden consolidation in telecommunications that was punctuated by yesterday's announcement that Verizon Communications would acquire MCI for $6.7 billion. The deal pairs Verizon, which is based in New York and is the nation's largest regional telecommunications company, with the second-largest provider of telephone and Internet service to corporations across the country. The Verizon-MCI pact comes just two weeks after SBC Communications, the No. 2 regional phone company, based in San Antonio, agreed to pay $16 billion to acquire the long-distance leader, AT&T.

headline: An Overseer Is Chosen For All Work Downtown
summary: Charles J. Maikish, a former Port Authority official who was responsible for rebuilding the World Trade Center after the 1993 terrorist attack, was named yesterday to oversee rebuilding throughout downtown. He is to be the first executive director of the Lower Manhattan Construction Command Center, created three months ago by Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to bring some order to the building, demolition and roadwork in one of the city's densest and most constricted quarters.

headline: With Huge Proposed Mergers, the Regulatory Maze Ahead for a Recast F.C.C.
summary: The deals have been forged on Wall Street, but their final shape may depend on Washington. Most people expect the huge telecommunications mergers recently announced to be approved in the current political climate, but the deals could prompt a considerable fine-tuning of existing rules.

headline: Thanks to Cellphones, TV Screens Get Smaller
summary: New from the creators of ''24'': a spinoff series about a rogue Washington antiterrorism agent who is trying to infiltrate the Department of Defense. It's called ''24 Conspiracy,'' but unlike ''CSI: Miami'' or ''Law & Order: SVU,'' it is not broadcast on a different night, or on television at all. It is seen exclusively on Verizon's newest mobile phone. Each of the one-minute mobile episodes (referred to as mobisodes) is specially shot and edited for the small, small screen. ''Conspiracy,'' produced by Twentieth Century Fox Television, a division of the News Corporation, is one of three original series making their debut on Verizon's V Cast, a high-speed cellular phone network that delivers broadband Internet-quality video.

headline: From MCI, a Lesson in Corporate Complacency
summary: From audacious start-up to industry innovator to an insatiable acquirer that came to symbolize the corporate greed that brought down other highfliers, MCI's story had it all. It was William G. McGowan who in 1968 saw the potential to make history with the fledgling MCI, which had begun five years earlier as an 11-employee company seeking to build a row of microwave towers to connect truckers with dispatchers. He set the seemingly impossible goal of breaking the stranglehold that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company held on telephone lines in the United States. At the time, AT&T controlled 90 percent of the nation's local calls and nearly 100 percent of long-distance traffic.

headline: BOLDFACE NAMES
summary: They Just Didn't Want To Have Lunch With Him Who is the epitome of cool, we asked CEDRIC THE ENTERTAINER at the premiere of ''Be Cool'' in Hollywood on Monday night? ''Other than myself?'' he asked. ''ANDRÉ 3000 is cool. BILL CLINTON is cool. Travolta is cool, but I'm the coolest.'' In ''Be Cool,'' a sequel to ''Get Shorty,'' JOHN TRAVOLTA reprises his role as CHILI PALMER.

headline: Spruced Up, Qwest Looks At Its Options
summary: When Qwest's takeover offer was rejected by MCI last weekend, the setback was much more than a missed merger opportunity. By losing to Verizon despite being the high bidder, Qwest Communications International sent an unintended advertisement to investors about how financially shaky the company still is. And by trying so desperately to buy MCI, Qwest, the smallest of the four regional Bell companies, signaled that it would need a partner if it hoped to be competitive in the consolidating telecommunications industry.

headline: A Folksy Lawyer With a High-Powered Client
summary: The first four weeks of the trial of Bernard J. Ebbers, the former chief executive of WorldCom, have moved like mud. Witness after witness has testified about a blizzard of arcane accounting details and their various roles in the $11 billion fraud that sank the telecommunications company in 2002. Like the jury, Mr. Ebbers's lawyer, Reid H. Weingarten, has endured the hours of tedious testimony. With his weathered briefcase, slightly askew necktie and affable demeanor, Mr. Weingarten has listened intently at times and appeared lost in thought at others.

headline: Delay in Naming of Spy Chief Is Said to Hurt Terrorism Fight
summary: The top Democrat on the Senate Intelligence Committee complained Wednesday of White House ''foot-dragging'' in appointing an overseer for American spy agencies, saying the two-month delay was hurting efforts to fight terrorism and nuclear proliferation. At a hearing, the senator, John D. Rockefeller IV of West Virginia, called the failure to name a director of national intelligence ''unacceptable.'' The job was created by the intelligence overhaul bill President Bush signed on Dec. 17.

headline: Publisher Aims at Cellphones
summary: Stepping into the rapidly expanding business of providing information for wireless hand-held devices, Random House announced yesterday that it had acquired a minority stake in Vocel, a San Diego start-up company that offers educational content to subscribers over cellphones for a monthly fee. Random House said it had also agreed to license two product lines -- Living Language, a series of foreign-language self-study programs, and Prima Games, which publishes video-game strategy guides -- to Vocel for use with its cellphone technology.

headline: Key Witness On Worldcom Tells Jury He Broke Law
summary: Scott D. Sullivan, the government's star witness in its case against Bernard J. Ebbers, the former chief executive of WorldCom, ended seven days of testimony by admitting he broke the law so the company could meet financial targets. Under questioning, Mr. Sullivan, WorldCom's former chief financial officer, said that he had hid billions of dollars in expenses to mask the company's deteriorating performance.

headline: With $3.50 and a Dream, The 'Anti-Christo' Is Born
summary: You've seen Christo's ''Gates'' in Central Park. But what about Hargo's ''Gates'' in Somerville, Mass.? Sure, Hargo is unabashedly riding on the coattails of Christo and Jeanne-Claude. But it did take him some time to make his gates: 0.002 years, he estimates. That's a good chunk of a day. You may as well take a look: www.not-rocket-science.com/gates.htm. Just who is Hargo? Is he some kind of genius wrapper? His name is Geoff Hargadon, he is 50 and, in a telephone interview, he would only say, enigmatically, ''Art is not my profession.'' His last installation was a studio full of discarded ATM receipts. The show was called ''Balance.'' It was about ''people, privacy and money,'' he said, adding: ''You want to know how much people have? Here it is.''

headline: As telecommunications companies listen to the siren song of mergers, their equipment suppliers are likely to follow them.
summary: CALL it the trickle-down theory of mergers. A wave of telecommunications industry mergers has created behemoths in the traditional telephone and cellular industries in the last year. Now the consolidation wave is likely to hit the equipment makers that supply the big carriers. Investors are increasingly talking about potential deals between Motorola, Lucent Technologies, Nortel Networks and possibly European manufacturers like Alcatel. The rationale is simple: When carriers merge, they cut their capital spending budgets. To survive, their equipment suppliers have to merge to keep revenue growing and expand into new product areas.

headline: Qwest, Refusing to Go Away, Said to Be Weighing Bids for MCI
summary: Qwest Communications International spent the weekend weighing proposals to make an another $8 billion bid for MCI, executives close to the company said yesterday. Qwest, which lost an auction for MCI to Verizon Communications last week despite making a higher offer, is hoping to break up that deal and get a seat at the negotiating table.

headline: West Street Decision Won't Be Easy, but It's Needed Soon
summary: ON the stretch of West Street-Route 9A that runs along the World Trade Center site, the rubber is about to meet the road. Whether the road will be on the surface or in a tunnel, however, is a question only Gov. George E. Pataki can ultimately answer. What faces the governor is a choice. There is a cheaper, easier and politically palatable option: rebuilding Route 9A as an eight-lane surface road. And there is an unpopular, complex and far more expensive alternative -- tunneling four lanes of express traffic through an underground bypass -- that he has already endorsed in principle and that may, in the long run, be a better planning approach.

headline: Qwest Renews And Sweetens Its MCI Offer
summary: Qwest Communications made a sweetened $8 billion bid for MCI yesterday, potentially igniting a bidding war with rival Verizon Communications. The latest offer from Qwest came a week after the board of MCI voted to accept a $6.75 billion takeover proposal from Verizon, despite receiving a higher offer from Qwest that was worth about $8 billion in cash and stock.

headline: Higher Tax Payments Help Push MCI Loss to $32 Million
summary: MCI, the subject of a bidding war, released an earnings report yesterday that gave the outside world a glimpse of what its suitors, Qwest Communications and Verizon Communications, are fighting for. MCI said it lost $32 million, or 10 cents a share, in the fourth quarter last year, compared with a profit of $22.2 billion in the last quarter of 2003. The loss, which was mostly a result of higher tax payments, was far less than the $3.4 billion MCI lost in the third quarter of 2004.

headline: BellSouth, Indifferent to Mergers, Seems Certain of Its Path
summary: As the merger merry-go-round spins through the telecommunications industry, one critical player appears to be sitting out the ride. BellSouth, the third-largest regional Bell carrier, has not only been absent from talks that led to deals for AT&T and MCI but, according to its chief executive, F. Duane Ackerman, is very happy to go it alone, thank you.

headline: Verizon Gives MCI Time to Review Qwest Bid
summary: Verizon Communications, which had been set to buy MCI, said yesterday that it would grant MCI two weeks to further consider a rival offer from Qwest Communications International. Two weeks ago, the MCI board agreed to accept a $6.75 billion offer from Verizon, rejecting an $8 billion offer from Qwest after determining it was not comfortable with the financial stability of Qwest and the prospects for its stock price.

headline: Bank of America Settles Lawsuit Over WorldCom
summary: Bank of America agreed yesterday to pay $460.5 million in a settlement with investors who bought WorldCom's stock and bonds before the company filed for bankruptcy in 2002. The deal was struck between Bank of America and Alan G. Hevesi, the comptroller of New York State and trustee of the state's Common Retirement Fund. Mr. Hevesi is the lead plaintiff in the securities class action representing investors who lost billions when WorldCom collapsed.

headline: In Canada, Phone Books Are the Desire Of a Publisher
summary: The Yellow Pages Group, Canada's largest publisher of telephone directories, secured most of the Canadian market on Monday, saying it would purchase Advertising Directory Solutions Holdings from Bain Capital for 2.55 billion Canadian dollars ($2.07 billion). The Yellow Pages Group controls most of the directory business in eastern Canada, while A.D.S., which is being sold by Bain Capital, is the leading publisher in the western provinces of British Columbia and Alberta. Bain is based in Boston.

headline: 2 Front-Runners Seen for Nomination to Lead F.C.C.
summary: Michael D. Gallagher, a senior official in the Commerce Department, and Kevin J. Martin, a commissioner at the Federal Communications Commission, have emerged as the top contenders to become the next chairman of the F.C.C., administration officials said on Wednesday. President Bush is expected to announce his choice soon. Michael K. Powell, the current chairman, will preside over his final commission meeting on Thursday. He plans to leave the agency next week after seven and a half years, including four as chairman.

headline: The Week Ahead
summary: BATTING CLEAN-UP? -- Two American institutions, Major League Baseball and Congress, are scheduled to collide Thursday. Congress, as is its habit, will have both the home-field advantage and the rule of law on its side. After players and executives from baseball both politely declined an invitation to testify about the use of steroids in the sport, the House Government Reform Committee fired the ultimate brush-back pitch, issuing 11 subpoenas last Wednesday. Four executives and seven current and former players -- Sammy Sosa, Rafael Palmeiro, Jason Giambi, Mark McGwire, Frank Thomas, Curt Schilling and Jose Canseco -- were named. When the players and executives responded by saying they may fight the subpoenas, Representative Tom Davis, Republican of Virginia, compared them to the disgraced Enron executive, Kenneth L. Lay, and said he would hold them in contempt.

headline: WorldCom Teaches a Pricey Lesson
summary: ENGINEERING the earth's largest accounting fraud and filing the planet's biggest bankruptcy evidently wasn't enough for WorldCom.
